PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the House to move a motion censuring the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) for his gross and arrogant mishandling of the Australian economy while he served as Treasurer and his deliberate campaign of treachery and destabilisation within the Australian Labor Party over the last six months.

—Mr Speaker, the Government will facilitate any motion which the Opposition cares to move at 2 o'clock but as Opposition members well know the practice of the Government has been to accept this period as time for private members' business.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under those circumstances, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the member for Bennelong moving forthwith the following motion:

SPEECH.PARA: "That this House endorses the remarks of Senator McKiernan when the labour force statistics for November were released that `there are now 900,700 reasons why Paul Keating should not be Prime Minister of Australia' and censures the member for Blaxland for:

(1) his gross and arrogant mishandling of the Australian economy while he served as Treasurer, which continues to inflict immense misery on hundreds of thousands of Australians and their families; and

(2)his deliberate campaign of treachery and destabilisation within the Australian Labor Party over the past six months which not only helped to destroy the member for Werriwa as Treasurer, but has also paralysed the actions of the entire Hawke Government.
Mr Speaker, it is now known around this House that at 6.30 the final crunch will come inside the Government.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Beazley) put:
That the honourable member be not further heard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want the House and the Australian people to know that the man they are about to install as Prime Minister destroyed the Australian economy.
—Order! The member for Bennelong will resume his seat.

PARA.TAB: Question put.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—Mr Speaker, I second the motion. No wonder Whelan the Wrecker went broke.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Beazley) put:
That the honourable member be not further heard.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) put:
That the question be now put.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now just say a couple of words to the House and seek the House's guidance. Under standing order 193, a motion moved by anyone other than a Minister cannot be put to the House before 12.30 p.m. So we are in the technical position that the motion moved by the honourable member for Bennelong and seconded by the honourable member for Mayo to suspend Standing Orders technically cannot be put until 12.30 p.m. However, the House has voted to bring on the question. If there is no objection from either side, I would propose to put now the question that Standing Orders be suspended on the basis that to put off a motion after the House has decided that it wants to call it on would be a bit of a nonsense. We would just have to come back at 12.30 p.m. and vote on the motion. There would not be any intervening debate because the question that the question be now put has been passed. So if there is no objection, I will put the question—
—I object, Mr Speaker.
—Order!

—If this procedure goes ahead, on any occasion when general business is called on, the mere moving of a motion to suspend will, in fact, bring on a vote or else create a debate on whether the suspension should be carried. I do not wish to object, but I believe it is a precedent which should not be set by the House.
—Does the right honourable member for New England wish to make a point?

—Mr Speaker, on that point, I believe equally that the House, having produced its Standing Orders, should follow them, even though we conduct debate and come to conclusions. Because the Standing Orders prescribe a certain timetable, that timetable should be followed. For that reason, I object to our having a vote other than at 12.30 p.m., as the Standing Orders suggest.

—On this matter, I agree with the right honourable member for New England. The Standing Orders are pretty clear on this. I also agree with the sort of tactical sentiment, if you like, of the honourable member for Corio on this matter. So my view also is that this question ought to be put at 12.30 p.m.
—As the author of the motion, I have to agree with the Leader of the House.
—These strange unity tickets are worrying me.
—I'm the real third man.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the National Party might wish to say something.
—Not on this matter, Mr Speaker.

PARA.TAB: Mr Gear interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Canning is making up for not being here for a while, I imagine. The point I put to the House sought the House's guidance. I think the members have made their point that we should deal with these matters the way we have—we have not had to deal with a matter like this before—
—Yes, but there are a lot of things we have not dealt with before.
—Order! Having heard the points made by the three speakers, I advise that this motion will now stand deferred until 12.30 p.m. today.

PARA.TAB: Mr Tim Fischer—Mr Speaker—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Leader of the National Party seeking indulgence?

PARA.TAB: Mr Tim Fischer—Mr Speaker, in the absence of advice on ministerial arrangements which would normally take place at 2 o'clock, I seek to table a letter signed by the Prime Minister where he advises that he will tender his resignation as Leader of the Caucus—
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the National Party will resume his seat. The Leader of the National Party does not have my indulgence any further. He will resume his seat.

PARA.TAB: Mr Tim Fischer—I seek leave to table the letter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Resume your seat.

PARA.TAB: Mr Tim Fischer—He is resigning. Who is the Prime Minister? Who enjoys confidence?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House the tragic war in Croatia which has caused an immense loss of human life, widespread suffering of Croatia's civilian population and the systematic destruction of Croatian cultural monuments, civilian centres and economic infrastructure.
Your petitioners pray that the House as a matter of urgency:

PETITION.PARA: 1.Continues to publicly express its abhorrence at the war of aggression being perpetrated by the Serb-led Yugoslav Army on Croatian territory and against Croatian people;
2.Urges the Australia Government:

TAB.TAB: 2.1To use its influence with allies, including the United States of America, to stop this brutal aggression;
2.2To implement immediately the motion moved by Member for Corio, Hon. Gordon Scholes M.P., and unanimously carried by the House on 13th November, 1991;
2.3To recognise the independence of Croatia and Slovenia without delay.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Crosio (from eight citizens), Mr Ferguson (from 37 citizens) and Mr Grace (99,955 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House the tragic war in Croatia which has caused an immense loss of human life, widespread suffering of Croatia's civilian population and the systematic destruction of Croatian cultural monuments, civilian centres and economic infrastructure.
Your petitioners pray that the House as a matter of urgency:

(a)continues to publicly express its abhorrence at the war of aggression being perpetrated by the Serb-led Yugoslav Army on Croatian territory and against Croatian people, and will use its influence with allies including the United States to stop this brutal aggression;
(b)without delay recognises the independence of Croatia and Slovenia;
(c)immediately implements the motion proposed by Mr Scholes and unanimously adopted by the House of Representatives on 13 November, 1991.

PETITION.TITLE: Abortions: Government Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:

PARA.TAB: Every abortion kills an unborn human baby. More unborn Australians are killed every year (80,000) than the Australian death toll for the whole of World War II (30,000).
Australia's population is aging. Our live birth rate is below replacement level.
About 98 percent of abortions in Australia are performed for non-medical reasons (see SA Health Commission statistics).
Post abortion depression is a silent epidemic and is linked with the growing incidence of child abuse by mothers who have previously had abortions.
The Australian Government should not fund the killing of future Australian citizens.
Mothers with problem pregnancies need positive help to carry their babies to full term.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:

PARA.TAB: pass the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990, and
help pregnant women with problems to continue their pregnancies.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Downer (from 19 citizens), Mr Steele Hall (from 27 citizens) and Mr Langmore (from 12 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided medical benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley (from 199 citizens) and Mr Ronald Edwards (from 203 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby;
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights;
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life;
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect;
That in 1989/90 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 69,587 abortions totalling $7.8 million;
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
That God is the Creator of all Life Gen 1:31;
That He put human life under special protection by giving us the 6th commandment `Thou shalt not kill';
That He gave governments the mandate and authority to uphold this law;
That in 1989/90 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 69,587 abortions totalling $7.8 million;
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will carry out its duty to uphold the 6th commandment by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: A humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Attention is drawn to Australia's increasing role in the militarisation of the Pacific region and in particular to the current Government-led arms export drive.

The arms trade is not only detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from socially beneficial areas—for example, health, education and social welfare—but is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of the people of the Third World.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:

PARA.TAB: Cease all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people.
Direct all Federal and State Government Departments and instrumentalities to withdraw from participation in and support for AIDEX and similar arms fairs in Australia and overseas.
Close down AIDEX 1991.
Establish a register of all applications for arms transfers and offset agreements which would be subject to public scrutiny.
Redirect all monies currently being used to promote the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bilney (from 135 citizens) and Mr Fitzgibbon (from 42 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of New South Wales draws to the attention of the House the current campaign which is being waged by the Communist Government of Serbia and its agents against the aspiration for independence of the Republic of Croatia.

We particularly draw to your attention the fact that Croatia has satisfied the conditions of international law for independence, and that it has made every effort to enter into meaningful dialogue with its opponents in Serbia. These have been to no avail.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House as a matter of urgency offers immediate recognition to Croatia as a sovereign nation.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Grace (from 855 citizens) and Mr Melham (from seven citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is increasingly unable to fulfil its responsibilities to provide independence, integrity, quality entertainment and commercial-free services.
The Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be funded in such a way for these responsibilities and obligations to be maintained.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
(1)Increase the annual funding base of the ABC by a minimum of $32 million;
(2)Guarantee adequate and properly indexed funding to the ABC for the next three years on an agreed basis with the ABC;
(3)Maintain the legislative prohibition on corporate sponsorship and advertising on the ABC.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia and Slovenia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That 92% of Croatians who voted in a referendum on 25 April 1991, supervised by the Constitutional Court of the Republic of Croatia, declared their support for Croatia as a sovereign and independent State and their opposition to Croatia remaining in the Yugoslav Federation;
That 88% of Slovenians who voted in a referendum democratically expressed their support for Slovenia as an autonomous and independent State;
That both Slovenia and Croatia have declared themselves to be independent Republics and that each Republic is prepared to defend its territorial integrity.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should request the Australian Government to:

Establish diplomatic relations with the legitimate representatives of each Republic and of any currently subjugated country whose residents by a democratically expressed popular vote have declared their wish to be independent; and
Establish trade relations with the Croatian and Slovenian Republics, to take advantage of the very favourable attitude which exists between the people of these Republics and the Australian people.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom 0055 Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the CATHOLIC WOMEN'S LEAGUE (HERVEY BAY, QUEENSLAND, BRANCH) draws to the attention of the House the disgust of all members of the League with regard to the irresponsibility of your Government in allowing a Government institution, namely TELECOM, to offer such services which threaten moral decency on 0055 telephone numbers.
We therefore request that the house take such action as to enforce TELECOM to withdraw this service forthwith in order to save further degradation of our Nation.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS Television: Dutch Community, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that under the new broadcast schedule of the Special Broadcasting Service the members of the Dutch community in Victoria are deprived of a disproportionate amount of transmission time on radio station 3EA.

That the decision to so reduce the amount of broadcasting time in Dutch precludes an adequate functioning of the Special Broadcasting Service as required by the Broadcasting Act and leads to great concern and disappointment amongst those residents in Victoria who were born in The Netherlands, Flanders and the former Dutch East Indies.

Your petitioners therefore ask the House to advise the Governor-General to command the Chairman and Members of the board of directors of the Special Broadcasting Service to review the relevant decision and to give proper regard to the demographic realities in allocating broadcast time on radio transmitter 3EA.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
There is widespread concern about the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which wars such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your Petitioners request that the House in Parliament assembled shall urge the Australian Government to:
(a)lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.
(b)outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations, government and private.
(c)reverse its decision to host the arms bazaar, AIDEX 1991.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members in the House of Representatives assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesman-like leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:-

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: No. 2 Flight Air Training Corps
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia, draws to the attention of the House, the proposal to relocate the No 2 Flight Air Training Corps, from Wanneroo to Leederville.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:
(i) ensure that the No 2 Flight Air Training Corps remains in Wanneroo and is not relocated to Leederville,

(ii) seek funding from the Department of Administrative Services to enable the only Flight in Western Australia currently not funded, to access sufficient project monies to complete and maintain its facilities already under construction at Landsdale, and
(iii) prevent the loss of this valuable youth organisation to the northern corridor of Perth, the second fastest expanding residential region in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House their deep concern that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
(1)(a)makes inadequate provision for a subjective judgement by parents as to what is in the best interests of their children,

PETITION.PARA: (b)makes inadequate provision for parents to use their discretionary powers to act on such judgements.

PARA.TAB: (2)creates the potential for conflict between parent and child (rather than the atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding mentioned as valuable in the preamble).
(3)will produce closer monitoring by Government agencies of relationships between parents and children.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that:
(1)By Act, Parliament ensure that all international treaties (excluding national security) are debated by the Parliament.
(2)The Parliament take action to have the Convention amended in order to pay the highest regard to the importance of the family unit, and to the rights and responsibilities of parents.

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House:-
The European sponsored Genocide of the Croatian people and her precious heritage;
The wilful and intolerant destruction of Hospitals, Schools, Cathedrals, Villages, and Historical Monuments by the Serbian Army;
The continual Serbian misinformation campaign over its motives in the current war;
The deep sense of hurt and betrayal felt by the Croatian Community in Perth over the Government's continued indifference to the plight of our brothers and sisters.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore ask the House to:

PARA.TAB: Enforce a political, economic and social boycott of Serbia from all World bodies and organisations;
Necessitate Serbia to accept full responsibility and pay war reparations;
Immediately recognise Croatia as expressed by her sons and daughters in Australia.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Security Office, Cobar
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Cobar Shire draws to the attention of the House:
That more than 300 people in Cobar are registered as seeking work. That with the recent announcements concerning eligibility of rural families for Job Search Allowance this number is increasing.
That the nearest Department of Social Security Office is at Dubbo 300 kilometres distant.
That at a recent meeting of unemployed job seekers 85% of people had experienced difficulties in dealing with the Department of Social Security.
That many of these difficulties are associated with the fact that there is no Social Security presence in Cobar.
That main street office accommodation is available in Cobar at $70 per week.
Your petitioners therefore request the House take immediate steps to establish a Department of Social Security Office in Cobar.

PETITION.TITLE: Civil Aviation Authority: AMATS Program

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain Airline Pilots, draws to the attention of the House the direction that the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) is taking Australian Aviation. We therefore request that the CAA is not permitted to implement the UNPROVEN procedures associated with the Airspace Management and Air Traffic Services (AMATS) Programme.
The principal areas of concern include the following:

PETITION.PARA: The removal of the DIRECTED delivery of amended operational information such as amended forecasts, weather observations and NOTAMS;
Removal of information on Visual Flight Rules (VFR) aircraft from the DIRECTED traffic information service;
The requirement for pilots to monitor multiple radio frequencies simultaneously;
The large reliance on the "see and avoid" principle of separation for high performance passenger aircraft, a concept that is a flawed and unreliable method of collision avoidance; and
The removal of the proven AFIZ system and its replacement with the UNPROVEN MTAF system,
which we believe will lead to reduced and unacceptable safety levels.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned also wish to voice our deep concern about the CAA's failure to listen to the express concerns of industry members, and its seemingly deliberate campaign of misinformation about changes to procedures.

PETITION.PARA: Our petitioners therefore request the House to ensure that passenger and crew safety is safeguarded by preventing the implementation of the UNPROVEN procedures associated with the AMATS programme.

PETITION.TITLE: National Estate Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to attention of this House that we are concerned at the lack of protection of National Estates Forests. Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his Government to enact to
(1)Immediate and full protection of all National Estate Forests.
(2)Suspension of all forestry activity in those areas while under investigation.
(3)Immediate restructuring of total forest industry, to maximise employment opportunities whilst moving to ecologically sustainable, plantation based industry.
(4)Funding to be made available to Federal Government for Identification of Wilderness areas in Australia.
(5)Separate Legislation to Protect National Estates Forest.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights Violations: Myanmar
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable members in parliament assembled: We, the undersigned, respectfully draw your attention to the continuing human rights violations in Myanmar (Burma), and request that the House make its concern known as appropriate to the Government of Myanmar (Burma).

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: (a)The signatories to this petition ask that there be a comprehensive PUBLIC review of the AUSTUDY scheme. The aim of the review will be to establish a student income support scheme that is simple, promotes greater access and equity within Higher Education, and ensures a payment of an allowance at least equivalent to 100% of the poverty line, as estimated by the Australian Council of Social Services (ACOSS).
(b)As part of this review we seek the following changes to the AUSTUDY scheme:
(1)Abolition of the Personal Income Threshold for AUSTUDY recipients;
(2)Abolition of the Academic Progress Rules;
(3)An increase in the Spouse Income Test to $18,150;
(4)The re-introduction of the Incidentals Allowance;
(5)A reduction in the age at which a student is automatically granted independent status from 25 to 19 years of age.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom 0055 Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House—
The readily available range of sex and fantasy audio text services transmitted via Telecom through the use of the 0055 prefix.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to—

Take action to ensure this "adult" information and entertainment is not available to children and persons under the age of 18. Your petitioners are deeply concerned as to what affect these messages have on our youth and Australia's moral standing.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Deportation of Mr Aka Vana
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament House Canberra.

PARA.TAB: As electors of the Division of Indi, we hereby draw to the attention of the House the extraordinary plight of Mr & Mrs Aka Vana and family. Mr Vana, a soldier in the Australian Army has had his application for citizenship rejected and will be deported on 30th November 1991.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House may urgently undertake to review this case and grant a reasonable hearing to Mr. Vana, currently serving in the Australian Army.

PETITION.TITLE: Avalon Airfield
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned residents of the Little River/Avalon Airfield area, believe that the noise survey on which the proposal to lift the night curfew on aircraft movements at Avalon Airfield is founded is not comprehensively based, inasmuch as it claims that no houses will suffer a noise level greater than 45dBA, whereas Australian Standard 2021 gives sound levels at some houses of greater than 90dBA when aircraft take off to the north of the runway. An ASTA newsletter states that aircraft will take off to the north when weather conditions require it, but the survey does not seem to allow for this.
We therefore request that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.No lifting of the curfew be allowed until a new more comprehensive survey takes place;
2.That public meetings be held where residents can express their concerns, before preparation of the new report;
3.That proper consideration of aircraft movements to the north of the runway be made in preparation of the report;
4.That noise from other sources including ground running of engines at night, be included in the report;
5.That other sources of pollution including smoke and kerosene fumes from aircraft, be included;
6.That any other issues raised by residents at the above meetings be included;
7.That no final decision to lift the curfew be made unless the residents agree, after due consideration of the final reports.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned request that the House take note of and act on the above.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: $3.50 Co-payment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled:

PARA.TAB: This petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully points out—
(1)During the last election the Government campaigned to defend Medicare.
(2)The opposition parties had no such policy.
Your petitioners therefore require the House to reverse the 1991 Budget decision to impose the $3.50 Medicare co-payment.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which wars such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:
(i)call on the Federal Government to outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations, government and private.
(ii)call on the Federal Government to lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.
(iii)Cancel the AIDEX 91 arms bazaar.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Les Scott (from nine citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all innocent human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights.
That the first duty of the Parliament and of the Government is to protect this right to life.
That in 1989/90 alone Medicare provided medical benefits for almost 70,000 abortions at a cost to taxpayers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of unborn Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Dili Massacre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of 14 citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we wish to protest at the continuing Indonesian occupation of East Timor and to deplore the massacre of Timorese civilians in Dili on 12 November.
Your petitioners therefore urgently request the House of Representatives to urge the Australian Government to vigorously promote:

PETITION.PARA: 1A credible United Nations investigation of the Dili Massacre; and
2the placing of United Nations observers in East Timor to prevent further human rights abuses;
and further call upon the Australian Government to:
1join with European Parliament members in immediately ceasing military aid to, and imposing of economic sanctions on, Indonesia; and
2demand a United Nations referendum on East Timor's right to self-determination.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would allow the Treasurer to give the House his assessment of the current depressed state of the Australian economy which is evidenced by almost one million people unemployed, and to justify his proposal for a `pump priming' policy U turn which will inevitably lead to a further increase in Australia's already burgeoning foreign debt.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, I move that motion because this country faces—

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Robert Brown) put:
That the honourable member be not further heard.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In seconding the motion, I say that I want to hear from the Treasurer (Mr Willis). This economic—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Deputy Leader of the National Party will resume his seat.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Beazley) put:
That the honourable member be not further heard.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Beazley) put:
That the question be now put.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade I have pleasure in presenting the Committee's report, incorporating a dissenting report, entitled Australia's Relations with Papua New Guinea, together with the minutes of proceedings and the evidence received by the Committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to present to the House the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea. This is the second report in a series that the foreign affairs subcommittee is making on Australia's relations with countries in its immediate region. In 1989 the subcommittee reported on Australia's relations with the South Pacific, and next year it expects to complete an inquiry into Australia's relations with Indonesia.

PARA.TAB: This inquiry on Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea is by far the most comprehensive and wide ranging inquiry into Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea ever undertaken by an Australian parliamentary committee. The recommendations, if adopted, would have the effect of greatly transforming our nation's relations with Papua New Guinea, thus leading to a substantial broadening and strengthening of those relations. Inquiries such as this into the basis of the whole relationship are, of necessity, wide ranging and complex.

This inquiry into Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea has been a long one, having been interrupted by the election of May 1990. The terms of reference covered economic issues, including trade, investment and aid, and political, strategic, social and cultural issues. Experts and interested parties from all these areas spoke to the Committee in the course of over 18 public hearings conducted throughout Australia.

The report takes into consideration the often divergent views of the inquiry's many witnesses and tries to set them into an historical context. The Committee's report is based on the following overall historical assessment: Australia's relationship with Papua New Guinea is governed by the fact that we obtained it as a colony in a burst of strategic nervousness, just as we ourselves were seeking decolonisation. We were therefore diffident colonisers who governed with casual practicality and who departed with alacrity and too little care.

The strategic concern which motivated the acquisition of the colony in 1883 remains a constant factor in the relationship, coming as it does from our geographic proximity. A lingering sense of responsibility bred of our rapid departure governs our commitment to aid. Over the last 15 years we have developed many formal ties and relationships. Officially the relationship is given top priority and it has worked smoothly, albeit with questions arising about the processes involved in aid and defence cooperation.

Australia's major concerns are about the effectiveness of our aid in supporting Papua New Guinea's nation building, a process that has slowed, and about the instability of Papua New Guinea, which is evident in the secessionist movement on Bougainville or the political, social and economic disruptions of crime and corruption. Unofficially, at an institutional and personal level, the relationship has been weakened by time. Here there is scope for strengthening it and for re-humanising it.

Certain issues consumed much of the Committee's attention. These were Australia's position and role as a major aid supplier to Papua New Guinea, the defence cooperation program and the strategic considerations which prompt this program. Furthermore, the problems on Bougainville were of great concern to the Committee. The Committee believes that these are central issues to the relationship and that they are issues that need to be addressed.

In the case of Bougainville, there is a need for urgent resolution. Given the current delicate stage of Papua New Guinea's economic and social development, the Committee believes that it would be wrong to withdraw too hastily from our aid obligations in support of Papua New Guinea. These are obligations that extend from the days of colonial administration and particularly from the failure of successive Australian governments to prepare Papua New Guinea sufficiently for independence.

Low standards of education and health remain as a legacy of that neglect and these factors continue to retard Papua New Guinea's development. The Committee therefore believes that Papua New Guinea is in a crucial stage of its development and that the next 10 to 15 years will be vital in seeing the benefits of the rich resources of the country successfully applied to infrastructure and other developments.

For this reason the Committee believes that aid must be maintained at nominal levels for the next five years. Furthermore, there should be no automatic formula for the reduction of aid by the year 2005, and only significantly higher than expected returns from resources should alter such an arrangement. Furthermore, no such changes should occur without adequate consultation with Papua New Guinea or without sufficient planning time.

The Committee received a large number of recommendations urging changes to the development cooperation program. The Government has already initiated some changes, but the Committee believes that the current proposals should be modified. The key recommendations on aid are as follows: the Committee recommends that Budget support should be replaced by program aid, supported where necessary by project aid. The move from Budget support to program and project aid should be undertaken as a matter of urgency, commencing in 1993 or as soon as possible thereafter. During the transition there should be a mix of Budget support and program and project aid, with the former being phased out by the end of 1998.

Given that negotiating projects and programs involve greater administrative complexity and absorb large amounts of scarce high level managerial capacity, the Committee recognises that there may be delays in the implementation of this recommendation. If that occurs the total level of aid should be maintained through continuing Budget support.

The choice of program areas and designated programs should be based on sound, long term economic and social policies and be determined after close consultation between Australia and Papua New Guinea. It is important to explain what we mean by this system of program aid. If aid is to be maintained, it should also be targeted more efficiently to areas of need. Present negotiations seem set to convert the existing Budget support into project aid. The Committee does not believe that it is realistic to maintain nominal aid levels and, at the same time, convert this successfully into projects. Projects have a long lead time, are administratively complex and require high level managerial capacity. Therefore, the Committee supports a system of program aid.

Program aid is defined as the funding of a sector, such as the education sector, with a view to meeting predetermined objectives in a given period. It is a form of aid that would have definite goals, would be monitored each year, would involve non-government organisations, might encompass projects within the target area and would involve long term funding commitment additional to, and not a substitute for, normal Papua New Guinea funding of the sector in question.

The Committee believes that this last factor is most important if there are to be improvements in Papua New Guinea's infrastructure. The process of consultation between Papua New Guinea and Australian governments will also be a vital factor in the success of this system, particularly in ensuring that the targets are met and that the process remains within the power of the Papua New Guinea Government.

Much media attention has been given to security issues in Papua New Guinea. The evidence put before the inquiry certainly confirmed that the problem is serious. It is a twofold issue. There is lawlessness and violence in the towns and villages, which create fear and inhibits development, and there is the movement on Bougainville for secession, perhaps the most destabilising and intractable problem Papua New Guinea faces. Both these problems have focused attention on the weaknesses within the defence and police forces, the need for better training and more discipline, and an understanding of the need to protect human rights in dealing with civil disorder or disputes.

These questions have prompted a review of expenditure on defence generally. The Committee understands the decision of the Papua New Guinea Government to rationalise its expenditure on security through joint training, joint logistics and more cooperative arrangements for the use of personnel. There is the difficulty that a small nation has in finding adequate funding for the training and equipment of two separate forces. However, there are dangers in the merging of the two functions of domestic policing and external defence, and the Committee believes that these dangers need to be addressed by the defence cooperation program. There is scope within the training offered by Australia for some stress on humanitarian law and civic duties.

Bougainville in particular has revealed the problems that Papua New Guinea faces in the future, problems of maintaining national integrity, problems of the recognition and satisfaction of the nationalist aspirations of groups within the country, problems of investment and resource development, problems of land ownership and compensation. The isolation of Bougainville has gone on for too long. Too little is known about the real cost in terms of human suffering and loss of life over the last two years. Too little effort seems to have been made to find a solution to get talks started and to stop the blockade.

The Committee believes that the Australian Government could and must do more, despite the reservations expressed by various witnesses who saw the Australian involvement precluded by defence arrangements and commercial interests.The report also argues strongly that the time has come to pay close attention to the cultural and social aspects of the relationship which have become sadly neglected. There is more material about that issue in the report.

In fact, let me say in conclusion that this report recognises the many strengths that exist in the relationship between Australia and Papua New Guinea, a formal relationship government to government that rests on regular consultation and review. However, there is scope for an extension of the informal connections, the educational, the cultural and the social exchanges. We are urging a wholesale transformation of the aid relationship and many other things. In all there are 56 recommendations.I am extremely gratified by the fact that, with the exception of one minor dissent, this report has been adopted unanimously by the foreign affairs committee and the full committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was indeed a most comprehensive inquiry and report into Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea. As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), who is chairman of the subcommittee said, it is the most wide ranging investigation ever undertaken by an Australian parliamentary committee into our relations with Papua New Guinea.

PARA.TAB: If our recommendations are adopted, they will no doubt greatly change Australia's relationship in the future with that country, with which we have had a very special relationship for many years. The report covers four major areas. It looks at political and social developments within Papua New Guinea; its economic issues; security issues; and Papua New Guinea's relationships with the region.

There are two major issues in this report which I would like to address. One is Australia's attitude to aid for Papua New Guinea and the other is the Government's handling of the Bougainville situation.

Papua New Guinea is the largest of the Pacific island countries to our north, with a land area of 462,000 square kilometres and a population of about 4 million people. It is the second largest nation in the South Pacific in terms of population and it has demonstrated in recent years a leading role in the South Pacific Forum. Papua New Guinea is also richly endowed with natural resources and its significance in the South Pacific region, plus its strategic importance to Australia, makes it a most significant nation.

It is therefore a great mystery why Australians, especially since PNG independence, have little real interest in this nation to our north and regrettably the media also has not given PNG the significance it deserves. Consequently, a number of our recommendations cover not just the need to improve the relationship between the governments of Papua New Guinea and Australia but also the need to improve media and journalistic contacts, the establishment of links between professional bodies and organisations, the establishment of an Australia-Papua New Guinea council and various other major initiatives which at the human level are so significant in creating the infrastructure necessary for a worthwhile relationship between our two countries.

Australia is, of course, Papua New Guinea's largest importer, although Japan is in fact its largest source of exports. However, our relationship is and always has been primarily concerned with assistance. This will reduce over the 1990s in the context of the economic development of Papua New Guinea and in particular the development of new mineral and oil projects.

Papua New Guinea is a former colony of Australia. When it achieved its independence in 1975 it had little economic or financial substance on which to base its new-found political independence. Putting it quite simply: Australia gave independence to Papua New Guinea too early and our economic and social infrastructure support took place too late. It was only in the last decade before independence that any worthwhile activities in that direction were taken.

Nevertheless, the lack of economic and financial development on which it based its new-found political independence has not in many respects held back the development of that nation, although it has brought with it major social strains which were earlier referred to. As I said, with the benefit of hindsight I believe that Australia did leave too soon and that is why we still have to have an aid program which is effective in maintaining the degree of social and economic cohesion which that nation clearly needs.

We have given direct grants to Papua New Guinea of some $3.7 billion out of a total of $4 billion since 1975. However, the Australian Auditor-General has found that these funds have not been spent effectively and that:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite $4 billion in aid assistance by Australia . . . real living standards for most of the population are lower than those for comparable developing countries.

Putting it quite simply: the record is not satisfactory. That Budget support has not been effective led the Committee to recommend that a new approach to development assistance be considered. The Government is currently looking at replacing Budget support with a substantial project aid program.

PARA.TAB: According to the National Centre for Development Studies, project aid has problems in that it is hard to absorb, the recipient country loses control and, more directly, Papua New Guinea's absorptive capacity for foreign financed investment is limited. Consequently, the Committee recommended that Australia provide program aid to PNG for certain programs with objectives to be set in advance and to be met and adequately monitored each year for the results. We also recommended that the amount of aid given to PNG be continued for the foreseeable future.

But the question of aid is not the only issue in Australia's relationship with Papua New Guinea. The most recent controversial issue which comes to mind is the situation in Bougainville and the part the Australian Government has played, or perhaps more accurately has not played, in that crisis. Not only did the PNG Government use Australian helicopters to put down the revolt but also the copper mine was developed by an Australian company and had Australian staff. We should not lose sight of the fact that it was the opening of that copper mine which was the essential reason why the revolt developed in that important province of Papua New Guinea.

Many people have referred to that revolt as the most serious threat to PNG's internal stability. That is a fair comment because if it was successful in the longer term there is every prospect that there would be other attempts by diffuse groups within the Papua New Guinea nation to seek their independence also. Consequently, in our opinion, Australia's reaction to the crisis was unsatisfactory. The Government did not act to help find a solution to the conflict between Bougainville and the central Government. This was especially stark in the light of the successful efforts of the Australian Government to date in helping to find a solution to the war in Cambodia.

Papua New Guinea is our closest neighbour and the Government did not act to help. The Government gave the PNG forces helicopters so they could be used to assist with the operations on Bougainville. The armed forces of Papua New Guinea were equipped and, to some degree, trained by the Australian Government. Therefore, in the minds of the Bougainvilean population there was a clear nexus or link between the PNG Government and Australia's role in the overall situation.

The Committee has found that the helicopters were used in a way which contravened the conditions under which they were donated. They were used to fire at people and to dump bodies into the sea. We recommended that on providing military equipment to PNG the Australian and PNG governments should develop clear and agreed guidelines about how the equipment will be used. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in its evidence stated that the Bougainville Republican Army was, `very suspicious of Australia and its role'. That is understandably so. The Australian Government supplied PNG's forces with weapons and transport, so they see us as having a direct responsibility both in creating the crisis and perhaps in trying to solve it. This will have long term implications for our relations with both Bougainville and the PNG Government.

The Australian Government should at least urge the PNG authorities to lift their restrictions on humanitarian aid to Bougainville as soon as possible. This raises the question of human rights abuses. The Committee was presented with some evidence of these abuses having taken place on both sides in Bougainville. In addition, Amnesty International has already detailed some 50 cases. Legal redress for such abuses in Bougainville is currently non-existent.

We recommended that the Australian Government do more to encourage PNG inquiry into these abuses and in consultation with the PNG Government to explore ways in which Australian aid might be used to enhance safeguards for human rights protection. The main conclusion which has come out of this report is that the relationship between Australia and Papua New Guinea has weakened over time and the understanding that neighbours should have of each other has also weakened.

As PNG's stature grows in the region we should be maintaining a close relationship built on continuing dialogue and negotiation. It is a strong, wealthy and independent nation and as it becomes more independent and stronger we should be there to help to work to ensure that the human, individual and cultural contacts are not lost.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to add my voice to the comments that have been made on the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. As has been said, this is one of the most comprehensive and wide-ranging reports into Australia's relationship with Papua New Guinea. I also believe that the recommendations, if adopted, would lead to a substantial broadening and strengthening of the relationship between the two countries.

PARA.TAB: Of course, we have to appreciate that Papua New Guinea is a sovereign independent state. Some people giving evidence to the inquiry seemed to think that Australia could act as if it were the colonial master. We cannot do that. What problems Papua New Guinea has must be solved by Papua New Guinea but this is not to say that Australia cannot or should not help.
Of course, anyone who has been to PNG or who follows developments in the country cannot help being concerned about the internal law and order issue.

It is a concern shared by the Government of PNG and one that it is attempting to address. Until the matter of law and order is fully addressed it is doubtful whether PNG will reach its full potential for investment or tourism, both of which could be significant contributors to the economy.

I fully support the recommendations made in regard to aid, in that Budget support should be replaced by program aid, supported where necessary by project aid. The choice of program areas rests on sound, long term economic and social policies and should be determined after close consultation between Australia and Papua New Guinea. I stress that matter of close consultation.

Papua New Guinea has one of the fastest increasing population rates in the world. That country will never achieve its full potential unless the population question is tackled. The birth rate is now over 3 per cent a year. The Committee recommended that Australia offer a specific project to the Family Planning Association of Papua New Guinea in order that it might develop and promote comprehensive services on birth control. This aid could be delivered either through an expansion of current non-government organisation services or through an AIDAB health project. We should also encourage the United Nations Family Planning Association to be involved. There is little doubt that many of the problems of PNG can be traced back to the high birth rate. As a member of the executive of the Asia Forum on Population and Development, I am sure this organisation would also be prepared to assist.

It is important that the mining operations that have an impact on the Torres Strait be carefully monitored and the Committee has made recommendations in this regard. Having visited the Ok Tedi mine with the Committee and seen the waste that goes into the Fly River, I have serious concerns about the possible impact on the Torres Strait. Both countries should be concerned that the waste and the overburden that is going down the Fly River could have an impact on the fish and the fishermen of the Torres Strait.

I agree with other members of the Committee that we have to work to maintain the good relationships that we have had with Papua New Guinea. I believe that more members of parliament should visit that country so that they can be aware of the problems and the challenges that it is facing.

I would like to congratulate the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, which worked over a long period and took evidence in many places. I would also like to congratulate the staff of the secretariat.

TALK.START.PARA: —As other members have said, this important report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade deals with Australia's relationships with Papua New Guinea in a way and in a depth which have not been approached before. As other speakers have mentioned, PNG is a vital nation in the South Pacific. After Australia, it is the second largest nation in the region. Its contribution to the development of political and social thought in the South Pacific and the immediate region is of untold future importance.

PARA.TAB: This report seeks to deal in detail with the issues confronting the relationship. Hopefully, it has done so with a degree of impartiality and a lack of political bias. I believe that this has done much to recommend the work of the Committee not only in this inquiry but in other inquiries as well.

I believe that the main essence of the report is its outline of how the relationship between Australia and Papua New Guinea has changed. There is no doubt that the special relationship, remembered by people in the older age bracket, that was developed between Papua New Guineans—the fuzzy wuzzy angels—and Australians during and shortly after the Second World War is breaking down both in Australia and PNG as time passes. Something needs to be done about this.

A very interesting section in chapter 5 of the report deals with people to people links. Two paragraphs in this chapter headed `The Media—Perspective from Papua New Guinea' and `The Media—Perspective from Australia' are very important in the sense that they outline the real need for both individuals and organisations to develop closer relationships. The recommendations for the exchange of personnel are most important.

The birthrate in Papua New Guinea has been mentioned as one of the major problems confronting the nation in the future. I would certainly agree with that. Children have to be educated and given meaningful employment. It seems to me that that is the main task confronting future governments of Papua New Guinea. Australia should be playing a significant role in assisting successive governments of PNG to deal with this extraordinarily difficult problem.

Speakers in this debate have mentioned the very apparent problem of law and order and this has been dealt with in some detail in chapter 4 of the report under the heading `Social Developments in Papua New Guinea'. Without going into the detail, the ramifications of the breakdown of law and order touch just about every aspect of PNG society and affect very markedly the future successful prospects of PNG development.

It is very evident when one travels to PNG that attention needs to be paid to increasing communication activity and developing transport between parts of that country. PNG is an enormously difficult country to get around. But if it is to successfully achieve its potential, obviously more attention is going to have to be paid to the communications difficulties of all sorts. Again, Australia can play a most significant role in helping in this area.

It is impossible to deal with a report of this length and complexity in five minutes. Suffice it to say, I believe that the report requires close study and I hope that the recommendations will be adopted by the Government. In conclusion, I would like to thank very sincerely all the staff of the Committee who, over the years, have been associated with the development and compilation of the report. Their work has been magnificent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to commend to the House the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I would like to begin my remarks by thanking the staff of the Committee by name because they have done a particularly fine job. They are: Judy Middlebrook, Margaret Swieringa, Celeste Conlan, Denise Picker, Margaret Gibson and Margaret Brown, and the two consultants, Rowan Callick and Matthew Nuhaus. One can see from the length of the report just how substantial their work has been. Also, one can see from reading the report the high quality of that work. On behalf of every member of the Committee, I thank them very warmly.

PARA.TAB: I want to make just three points in the remaining four minutes that I have to speak to the report. The first is that the essential theme of the report that human contact between Australia and Papua New Guinea must be upgraded is absolutely right. During the last 15 years there have been a fracturing and a deterioration of those human contacts. These contacts were very strong during the Second World War and the colonial period. Once independence had been achieved, Australians tended to withdraw—and quite properly, in many senses. But I think Papua New Guineans would welcome greater contact between the two countries. Also, Australia would benefit from this greater contact. It is that human contact which will ensure that relations are good in the future.

The report makes many specific recommendations about the ways in which that can be achieved—through secondment of people in business; through more travel by journalists, including staff of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation; through greater publicity by government departments linked with programs in Papua New Guinea; and by the establishment of an Australia Papua New Guinea council. I think the establishment of this council is one of the very important recommendations. Such a council could become a focus for business and cultural organisations with all kinds of links. The Committee recommends increased cultural exchanges and parliamentary visits.

The second point I want to make relates to maintaining aid. The Committee runs against the conventional wisdom in saying that nominal levels of aid should be maintained for the time being. I believe that is absolutely correct. There are enormous problems in Papua New Guinea and that country needs the funds at present. Without those funds from Australia, Papua New Guinea will not be able to upgrade its police force, upgrade its education system, increase its attention to agricultural extension and build improvements to the infrastructure which are the requirements of continuing development.

Until Papua New Guinea gets increased revenue from mineral exports, Australian nominal aid must be maintained. If that additional revenue builds up, there may be scope for cutting aid and that is something that both countries would welcome. No-one likes the kind of dependent relationship which aid creates. But until that happens we must make our contribution.

I do, however, sound a note of caution about the enthusiasm with which some people are greeting the idea of program and project aid. I think there are points in favour of moving in the direction of using more of the aid in program or project form. But I think it is easy to underestimate the administrative complexity and cost of negotiating projects and programs. It may well be that by the end of the century some of the aid will still be in the form of budget support. If that happens, I do not think it is something to be concerned about. It may be that negotiating all the projects and all the programs that are required to spend the aid are beyond the capacity of the scarce personnel resources available in Papua New Guinea. They might be beyond even AIDAB's capacity unless the staff of that organisation is built up substantially.

The third point I want to make is the central importance of building up the education system and creating more small business opportunities. It is tragic to see that there are still only four senior high schools. That number must be doubled very quickly. More attention must be given to technical education, vocational education and tertiary education. Small business, the trades sector and the informal sector must be encouraged. Those are the areas which will allow development to occur in the mass of the population—not from the top down, which is the way the Australians encouraged during the colonial period. We need more mass development of employment opportunities so that the great bulk of the people can experience the benefits of economic development.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join in commending the staff of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for the work they have done and the part they have played in the preparation and presentation of this report. I recommend the contents of this report not just to those in this Parliament but to a wider audience. It is a excellent report and I would like to compliment the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the Committee for the work they have done.

PARA.TAB: In my view, there is no more fundamental relationship for Australia than that between Australia and Papua New Guinea. It is a unique and strange relationship. At a time when in Europe countries are coming closer together, perhaps it is time for us to recognise the countries in our region to a greater degree than we have. For that reason, I am delighted that our foreign affairs subcommittee has now taken on board a study of our relations with Indonesia.

Whatever Prime Minister or party in government, for an indefinite period to come Australia's relations with PNG are something that we need to consider and pursue carefully, with an understanding of the particular difficulties of our heritage, and to a far greater degree than in the last few years.

Some aspects of our relationship concern me greatly. Paddy Fagon, a Papua New Guinean from Goroka, was in my office in the last sitting period. He is an aspirant for political office and wants to stand for the Eastern Province at the next PNG elections. I was interested to hear from him and others I spoke to in PNG of the extent to which our relationship is still seen as critical.

All of us have been amazed at the degree to which Papua New Guinea has preserved the semblance of the Westminster democratic system. Papua New Guinea is a very diverse country. There are four million people there, but they are not one people; they are four million people from many individual tribes and families. There are many languages, and communications are hopeless.

Unfortunately, in the years since independence, many Australians who played such an important role in the colonial days have largely withdrawn. Yet the PNG people look to us to continue. The honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) commented about a matter I put very high on my list of concerns. That was the point about human contact. We cannot just give money, provide aid and think that is all we need to do. I go along totally with the comments of the honourable member for Fraser in that we cannot just look at maintaining aid in quantity terms, despite the change in its form, and think that will be sufficient; we need to maintain the volume of aid, but we also need to maintain personal involvement.

For that reason, I think project aid might be a way by which we can take unto ourselves particular projects over a period of time. One of those projects in which I would like to see greater private sector involvement is in the education field. I felt very sad to see in some of the schools we visited the extent to which people are being trained according to our lights and under an educational system which I do not think really relates to the fundamental problems of PNG, rather than being trained to become better villagers or better participants in the PNG economy.

I think we need to help people to acquire the skills necessary to make a success in their own villages. We need to ensure that in technical training there is an opportunity for people to be able to go back to the villages and then contribute from those villages to the national economy. When we are looking at the law and order problem, the difficulty is to provide jobs, to provide education for jobs and to look at the roots of the problem and not just at the training of police, prison officers and so on. In our aid program, we need to place greater emphasis on education. I think some schools in Australia, particularly in the private sector and in the religious sector, could do well to look at opportunities by which they might be able to cooperate in education with some of the schools in Papua New Guinea.

Finally, I want to say a little bit about defence. I am greatly concerned about the direction the PNG Defence Force is taking. I think that integration with the police force is the wrong direction. I understand the shortage of resources, but there needs to be within the Defence Force an understanding that the criteria used for those who are trained for defence purposes are different from those required for maintaining civil order. I trust that in the development of contacts in the aid program and elsewhere by the Australian Government we keep in mind the essential difference between police responsibilities and domestic law and order and the responsibilities of a Defence Force, which, of course, relate primarily to external defence and, to some degree, to other sorts of terrorist activities within the nation. Nothing should deter that. (Time expired).
Motion (by Dr Theophanous) proposed:
That the House take note of the report.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—In accordance with sessional order 102B, the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Beddall)—by leave—agreed to:

That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the time for presentation of committee and delegation reports and statements on those reports being extended until 11.45 a.m. this day.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I present the Committee's report entitled Skills Training for the 21st Century—A Report on Skills Training: Apprenticeships and Traineeships, together with the minutes of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is the third report tabled by this Committee this year. It deals with the major avenues for reform of the current training system in Australia. These include post-compulsory education and training, integrated entry level training, employer subsidies, competency based training, participation targets and the expansion of the training market. The Committee's findings and recommendations, if adopted by the Government, will steer this country towards a greatly improved training system for skills development in Australia as we approach the twenty-first century.

PARA.TAB: There has been a vast amount of interest in the area of skills training since the Committee's inquiry commenced in June 1990. A number of reports have been produced reiterating the need for haste in reforming skills training in this country. Skills training is a crucial element of Australia's economic future. Widespread reform of Australia's education and training system is required if Australia is to be internally prosperous and internationally competitive. Industry needs to improve its productivity and quality and therefore there is a greater need for more skilled workers in industry.

The impact of technological change in industry has also brought about the need to develop better work and management practices. This also means training must be appropriate, flexible, accessible and of high quality. Industry is still reliant on a training system that was developed last century. The Committee is disturbed that the process of reform is so slow. It is essential that vested interests which are impeding progress be put aside in the interests of achieving outcomes required to see Australia survive into the twenty-first century. The report seeks to accelerate improvements to the training system in Australia so that worker skills are competitive and advanced.

The starting point for the inquiry was the apprenticeship and traineeship system. There have been many criticisms of Australia's current trade training system. The first one is the apprenticeship system. This is based on a master-slave relationship which is much more cognisant of the needs of a very different era as society moves towards the industrial revolution, not of a society moving towards the technological twenty-first century. It is the reliance on this system that is hampering Australia's development. We also found that such an apprenticeship and traineeship system does not adequately meet the needs of the majority of young Australians. In terms of a gender breakdown of the apprenticeship system, only 10 per cent of apprentices in this country are females and they represent 52 per cent of the population. So on any basis whatsoever apprenticeships are seen as denying young Australians the kind of training that is necessary for them to proceed to the twenty-first century.

Proposals for an integrated entry level training system combining apprenticeships and traineeships will go some way towards solving the inadequacies. This must be combined with an extension of training provision across a broader range of occupations and industries which employ young people. Historically, Australia's post-compulsory education system saw the majority of young people leaving school following the completion of year 10 and a smaller proportion of people continuing to years 11 and 12. This pattern has changed in recent years with the increase in retention rates, which have risen from 34.5 per cent in 1980 to 60 per cent in the last decade. In the Australian Capital Territory school retention rates are close to 95 per cent.

The needs and aspirations of our young people must be met and it is up to the school system to respond to the changing needs of our students and to offer courses which do not assume that all students will continue to university. It is blatantly silly when we see that universities provide for 25 to 30 per cent of our young people, yet schools offer courses as if 100 per cent of our students are moving into the tertiary sector. That is a nonsense. The traditional forms of senior secondary schools have to change. We would argue that many changes are needed in the post-compulsory sector. During our inquiry we saw a number of excellent secondary colleges which provide a range of courses and have links with TAFE colleges, universities and the local industry. They provide for a whole range of people—not just for young people but for other people hoping to return to school.

One of the great shames of Australia is its involvement in vocational training, which can be described only as dismal. In terms of the percentage of compulsory students in vocational programs, Australia rates second last compared with other OECD countries.
