Only Greece has a smaller number of students involved in vocational training. The Committee believes that the lack of commitment in this area should be of concern to all Australians. If we are to do anything about skills training in Australia this situation must be tackled head on and addressed.

For Australia to achieve the skill levels required, the belief in the community that vocational training is somehow inferior to universities and other educational institutions must change. The Committee has no doubt that the prejudices relating to the different status of the various occupations continue to be reinforced in schools. The effectiveness of any entry level training system depends on young people being aware of, and fully understanding, the various options available. It is essential that proper careers education be available in schools to assist students to make informed decisions about their education, training and employment.

The Committee has gone further and has recommended as part of the reform process that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) ensure that teacher release to industry is an integral part of in-service programs. Many people in our schools have known nothing else. They have gone to school and to teachers training colleges and have then gone back to school, offering no world experience wider than their own within the school system. They have very limited experience of industry. That particular point was raised by a whole range of people we met during our inquiry and also at a workshop which we held.

The Committee also supports the move towards competency based training rather than time based training. However, this has meant that there needs to be a national framework for the recognition of training and credit transfer. The Committee found that it is particularly important for Australia to acknowledge a national system so that where there are national industry requirements the skills of a person trained in Melbourne can be used by the industry in Mount Isa, Dampier or Carrawatha. It is obviously ridiculous that the State boundaries which currently exist are there only for State and education administrations; they are not perceived by industry or other people as being important.

Another great tragedy which the inquiry exposed was the issue of our technical and further education colleges. In the last decade while there has been a growth in the number of students staying on at school and a growth from 15 to 30 per cent of our young people moving into universities, the TAFE system has stayed where it is. One must ask why. It is this failure by this major sector of the training industry that has to be addressed and has to continue to be developed. TAFE is central to vocational training. We have noted that State governments have not been prepared to increase funding to their own TAFE institutions. We would go further and say that we have seen a growth in the university sector as a result of direct Commonwealth funding. If the TAFE system is to expand, we recognise that there is a need for Commonwealth Government funding. There is a need for a whole series of reforms.

The Committee looked at the whole question of a nationally consistent basis; the need for national targets for young people; and, of course, the development of a single integrated entry level training system which will provide enhanced career opportunities not only for our young people but also for the community at large. The Committee also made a whole range of other recommendations.

On behalf of the Committee, I thank all those who contributed to our inquiry through either submissions or the Committee's extensive program of public hearings, visits and discussions and the Committee's workshop. I personally thank the efforts of our secretarial staff, Linda Holub, John Cummins, Kerry and Susan—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to rise to support the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), in bringing down the Committee's report entitled Skills Training for the 21st Century: A Report on Skills Training: Apprenticeships and Traineeships.

PARA.TAB: The Committee has been at this task for some 16 months. It has travelled the whole of Australia from top to bottom and from side to side. We have spoken to industry, we have visited training centres and we have spoken to the training people. We have tried to cover every base imaginable to come to grips with the major problem that we face in education and training. Australia has an appalling record in vocational training, which is absolutely intolerable.

Over the past decade we have doubled retention rates in secondary schools and high schools. We have increased dramatically the number of young people at our universities and what were once called colleges of advanced education and institutes of technology, but we have stayed static in terms of vocational training. While the Committee does not come to any view about placing blame, nonetheless it makes a number of very significant major recommendations for change in order to rectify the difficult situation in which we find ourselves. Perhaps this starts with an attitude that was generated in the public's mind at least in both Victoria and New South Wales. Honourable members will recall that both these States at one time had vocational high schools and there was a two-stream education approach at the school level.

One of those streams sent students on an academic train designed for university, and the other stream was designed to put young people into apprenticeships with structured training at TAFE. We decided that that system was inappropriate, that it offered second-class education to those who went to technical high schools, so in New South Wales in the late 1970s we quit technical high schools. In Victoria in the early 1980s we quit technical high schools. We have replaced them, unfortunately, with nothing.

The United States a long time ago adopted an attitude that was expressed by industry. Industry wished the schooling system to produce students who were well balanced and had good basic skills in communications, reading and writing, and in maths. The Germans, however, developed a dual-stream approach where a portion of the students went on to the academic stream designed for entry to university, and the majority of German students went to vocational schools, underwent structured vocational training and entered industry as trainees who were paid a training wage. The American system has worked well for Americans and the German system has worked well for the Germans, but we in Australia need something to take the place of the vocational high schools we once had and of the apprenticeship system which, as the honourable member for Ford has told the House today, is no longer appropriate in the world of work in the 1990s.

So we need a new approach to the structured entry level training into industry. The Committee was not able to come to a unified view on this topic. Unfortunately it is a complex issue, and because the community is so much involved in deciding whether the system works we feel more study is needed in that area. However, in almost every other area we did bring down major recommendations and we are willing to back them. We talk about apprenticeships and we ask what is wrong with them, and I think the overview of the report covers that reasonably well. The Committee stated in its report:

SPEECH.PARA: The apprenticeship system has worked well but for a very small proportion of students, and those who are headed towards crafts. They are supported by demarcations in industry set up through our industrial relations system. But the apprenticeship system today excludes very large sections of the potential work force. It serves rigid demarcations within the work force and impedes the need to develop multi-skilled workers. It impedes the necessary retraining of workers and fails to provide the skills that industry needs when it needs them.

The Australian traineeship system introduced during the lifetime of this Government has not been a massive success because it has not been seen by the public to have had a high value either. So the history of education and training in Australia suggests that it is only in recent times that we have accepted the need for education for almost all of our young people and that we require higher and higher qualifications if we are going to be able to compete with the rest of the world in industry and in commerce and if we are going to survive as a nation economically. Honourable members will recall that once upon a time we built a tariff wall to protect ourselves. We hid behind that wall. For that reason, and because we built structured demarcations into our system, we did not need massive amounts of education. But those times have changed. Australia is changing rapidly.

PARA.TAB: In our report about the only issue we made no major attempt to address was industrial relations reform, but we did make one statement which I think is significant in indicating the bipartisan nature of this report. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee supports the process of reform. It is concerned however that the reform process based on industrial rewards linked with competency standards could lead to a whole new set of rigidities in the labour market. It is essential that the new system is flexible enough to respond to industry and individual enterprise needs and be adaptable enough to respond quickly to changing requirements in the economy.

That is significant. I point out that that is a 100 per cent bipartisan report; there were no dissenting views. Over 16 months, all of us came a long way from where we started. We finished up together, and we are as one. This report subsumes an early report of this Committee entitled The Restless Years, which deals with, in major respects, senior secondary colleges and the role that they might play in vocational training. It subsumes the Deveson report on the training costs of award restructuring, which deals with estimates and the need to change the operations of TAFE and charging TAFE fees, and also additional funding to improve the TAFE sector enabling more young people an opportunity to undertake vocational training which they will value. It further subsumes the recent Finn report into post-compulsory education. In that respect, it deals with the need to finance TAFE and to finance training.

PARA.TAB: The issues that we dealt with included, significantly, entry level formal training, but unfortunately we have not been able to come to a unified view on how to go about implementing this system and we will continue to work towards that end. The Committee is of the view that we must establish a training wage. The report details mechanisms that we believe will be appropriate. The training wage is basically a training allowance so that those who are in training are paid according to their level of competence, not according to their age or the length of time they have been in a training capacity. That wage would be substantially less than the wage of a full time employee in that sort of a job. We said that there has been information about the training wage out in the marketplace for two years. Everyone sits on it and no-one does anything about it. The Committee would urge the Government and the education institutions to get on with it, and urge the unions to join them.

We discuss the links between schools, TAFE, universities and industry, and those links are becoming daily more critical. We discuss credit transfer between all four. We make recommendations about funding of vocational education. That is significant in that we recommend that the Commonwealth take over from the States the responsibility for funding TAFE because the States have made a poor fist of it. We see no indication that the States have any desire to change their ways. We make major recommendations regarding registration of private providers. We would encourage private provision of vocational training in conjunction with industry and industry training bodies.

I would be remiss if I did not thank our secretariat, John Cummins, Linda Holub, Kerry Warner and Susan Cardell, for doing a fantastic job over a long 16 months, interwoven with other reports. We owe them a great debt of gratitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the state of the House.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—I would advise the honourable member for Wakefield that the spirit of private members Thursday is normally that we would not call quorums. However, I only use the word `spirit'. The Standing Orders do not prevent him from doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for statements on this report has expired.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Ms Crawford) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with sessional order 102B, the debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.
—On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report 312, Finance Minutes, and report 313, Control of Visitor Entry, both dated December 1991.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the presentation of a bipartisan report from the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training and these reports from the Joint Public Accounts Committee, I think it was entirely uncalled for and beyond precedent that the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) should call a quorum when reports were being tabled in this House today. I think it would be judged by both sides of the House to be poor form.

PARA.TAB: The Committee's 313th report, the report on the control of visitor entry, is the second and final report on the Committee's inquiry into the business migration program and control of visitor entry. The need for two reports arose after the inquiry commenced in June 1990. In the initial response to the inquiry so much concern was expressed about the operation of the business migration program that the Committee decided it would examine that program before looking at matters relating to the control of visitor entry.

The Committee presented its report on the business migration program to Parliament in June of this year and then began its examination of this matter. This inquiry arose from criticisms made by the Auditor-General of visa issue and entry operations administered in the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The Auditor-General found control weaknesses, procedural breakdowns and systems deficiencies which created a serious inherent risk that entry could be granted to people contrary to the national interest.

For this inquiry, the Committee received 57 submissions and held three public hearings. It also conducted inspections at the entry control point, the international terminal at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, and at the entry operations centre in Canberra. The Committee was aware that the administration of the entry of visitors to Australia is fraught with difficulties. The importance of tourism to the economy and the legitimate expectation of all Australians that family and friends from overseas should be able to enter the country easily as visitors are important considerations. They must be balanced against the need to prevent the entry of undesirable persons such as terrorists and criminals and of those who seek to jump the queue to enter and remain in Australia, albeit illegally.

The number of visitors to Australia has been steadily increasing. Since 1984-85 there has been an average increase of 20 per cent in the number of visitors and temporary entry visas issued each year. In 1990-91 alone, more than 1.48 million visas were issued. DILGEA has developed a range of databases which allow it not only to control entry but also to have accurate knowledge of who is in the country and whether that person is a legal or an illegal entrant. In 1990-91 over 9,000 illegal entrants were located. Of these, over 4,000 had their departures enforced and over 700 were deported. In April 1991 it was estimated that there were 78,000 illegal entrants in Australia.

Although the number of overstayers is small against the overall number of visas issued, it is a matter of concern to the Committee that some of these people, both students and people from other groups, are involved in serious crime in Australia. The Committee believes that appropriate means have been and are being taken to reduce the number of people who are overstaying their visa period. It notes that additional resources have been provided in the 1991-92 Budget and has recommended that these resource levels be maintained in real terms to reduce even further the number of overstayers in this country.

The Committee is aware that there are legitimate reasons why a person who holds an Australian passport may wish to travel on another passport. However, the Committee believes that Australian citizens should always use their Australian passports when entering or leaving Australia. Therefore, the Committee has recommended an amendment to the Migration Act 1958. The Committee believes it should be an offence under the Act for Australian citizens not to use their Australian passports when entering or leaving the country.

Evidence given to the Committee highlighted problems which arise when, after the forfeiture of an Australian passport, holders of dual passports can still leave the country. The capacity exists within DILGEA's databases for information to be stored and retrieved on holders of more than one passport. The Committee considers this information could be used more efficiently than it is at present. The Committee has recommended that the databases maintained by DILGEA and the Australian Customs Service be searched for dual passport holdings and that an emergency alert be placed on these databases to prevent the departure from Australia of the holder of a surrendered Australian passport leaving on any other passport.

When Australian citizens apply for Australian passports, they must provide details of citizenship of any other country. The Committee suggests that, before passports are issued, databases maintained by DILGEA and the Australian Customs Service be searched for information on whether applicants hold additional passports. While the number of persons entering Australia temporarily and committing serious crimes is small against total numbers of visas issued, the Committee noted that it was not possible to establish actual numbers or the categories by which such persons gained entry. Accordingly, we have recommended the establishment of a working party to establish procedures to measure the extent of this criminal activity. This working party should examine policing problems, the type of criminal activities undertaken, any geographical concentrations and multi-agency action which should be taken to deal with these activities.

The immigration records and information system, or IRIS, is a database which creates a record of the application for a visa, checks the application against alert lists and prints a visa. IRIS has been established in two phases, and the first version has now been installed in 48 posts overseas, which issue 95 per cent of visitors visas. It is expected to be introduced in all posts by the end of next year.

To provide an effective immigration screen, the Public Accounts Committee believes the remaining high and low volume posts should be equipped with IRIS as a matter of priority. The Committee has recommended that IRIS be installed in all overseas posts as soon as possible. We believe that the efficiency of the migrant alert list would be improved by the establishment of a two-way communication link with overseas posts and have recommended that such a link be established as soon as possible. Passenger cards are completed by persons entering or leaving Australia and the information provided is used by a number of authorities. After considering this issue, we believe these cards serve a useful purpose and have recommended that they be retained.

Pre-visa assessment is a means of screening applicants for student visas from countries which pose a high risk of visa overstay. The introduction of this assessment has had a major impact in controlling student entry because it acts as a bona fide test and includes an assessment of financial viability. The Committee believes that pre-visa assessment of applicants for student entry should continue and that a test of financial viability should be one of the criteria for that assessment. We believe it is particularly important that such assessments of students enrolling in a non-formal course be rigorously maintained.

The Committee notes that the pre-visa assessment is currently under review by a working party made up of DILGEA, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. We have recommended that this working party review pre-visa assessment for short, non-formal studies, including the retention of prepayment of fees and the introduction of bonds or bank guarantees as a financial viability test in that assessment.

Our final recommendation deals with the possible use of asylum provisions in the Migration Act by persons holding student visas. Statistics on asylum seekers are compiled against the applicant's country of origin, but there is no record of the category of entry by which an applicant entered Australia. The Committee has recommended that statistics on asylum seekers include an analysis of the categories under which they gained entry to Australia. The Committee acknowledges that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has been working towards an effective system to control visitor entry. We believe our recommendations will make that system work more efficiently.

In commending the report to the House, I take the opportunity to thank all members of the Public Accounts Committee for their efforts, particularly those on the sectional committee for this report, and the staff who have worked so diligently on this issue. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the report Control of Visitor Entry by the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts, I would at the outset welcome the adoption on 17 December by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) of the whole of the Committee's earlier, complementary report on business migration.

PARA.TAB: As the member who pushed most vigorously for this inquiry, I am pleased to see that the Minister, having already put into effect the Committee's recommendation to abolish the discredited former business migration program, has established, again as recommended, specific criteria for the new independent business skills category. These criteria properly include a points test which will assess potential business migrants according to the size of the turnover of their business, facility in the English language and possession of capital for transfer to Australia. Similarly, our report Control of Visitor Entry should lead to improvements in the management of immigration policy and establish a more secure situation at our borders.

Several important recommendations are made in the report and I would particularly draw the attention of the House to the recommendation that the Migration Act 1958 be amended to require persons who hold Australian passports to use them when entering or leaving Australia. Apart from the obvious law enforcement advantages of this recommendation, it should be a matter of national pride for Australian citizens to use their passport when entering or leaving their own country.

Likewise, the Committee recommends that a working party of DILGEA and Federal and State police representatives be established to measure the extent of criminal activity of persons entering Australia on visitor and temporary entry visas, and that is vital. Although the proportion of visitors entering Australia engaging in criminal activity is low, the actual activity engaged in is a serious problem, as the Chairman, the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch), correctly alluded to a few moments ago.

The Committee looks forward to the Minister acting expeditiously on these and our other recommendations, just as he has done with our report on business migration. It has again been a pleasure to work with the Committee and the Chairman. I would particularly commend Ms Jane Vincent, Mr Richard Cavanagh and other staff in the PAC secretariat for their diligent and inspired work on this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)nominate 2 April 1992 as National Wool Day;
(2)calls upon Members and parliamentary leaders to present appropriate speeches to the Parlia- ment during private Members' business and after Question Time;
(3)agrees to form a committee of 4 Members, including the Members for O'Connor and Stirling, to publicise this day and arrange a display in the Great Hall and a social function in the Members Hall;

(4)calls upon the wool industry, manufacturers, retailers, inventors, researchers, State governments, especially State education departments, and local government to give this day appropriate recognition; and
(5)calls on the Government to consider the issue of an appropriate postage stamp if time permits.

At the outset, I recognise the interest and support of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) in my efforts to have this matter considered. I also express my thanks to Mr Speaker and the President, who have indicated that they will assist us in this particular project.

PARA.TAB: One might ask: why a national wool day? We should start by considering the many `days' we have already. I am reminded of people walking around the streets wearing little red noses. I am reminded of their putting such items on the front of their motor cars, trucks and buses. Australians have a lot of `days', most of them being for very good reason and many being in support of charities and other things.

I am also reminded, however, of my time at primary school where we had a history book which, as I recollect, was published by a Professor Porteus. I have never forgotten a drawing in that book which showed the map of Australia and immediately under the Great Australian Bight a sheep that apparently was grazing. Of course, the caption was `Australia lives on the sheep's back'. In my youth, that was something I believe all Australians considered to be the case.

There have been many changes in Australia since I went to school. But after consulting the relevant statistics, I found that in the last 25 years—quite recent history—wool has been our major export commodity in eight of those 25 years; our second major export commodity, after coal, in seven of those 25 years; our third major export commodity, after coal and wheat and other agricultural products, on seven occasions, and after coal and iron ore, on one occasion; and our fourth major export commodity, after coal, wheat and iron ore, on two occasions. In other words, in the last 25 years, wool as an export commodity has never been further back than fourth and, in fact, that was on only two occasions.

Wool has been a major source of income for Australia. In 1988-89, it produced income of $5.5 billion; in 1989-90, it produced $4.1 billion. Of course, the great concern we have today is that, for 1991, that figure is predicted to fall to $2.8 billion. But that is still a substantial amount of money coming into Australia at a time when we desperately need it. Average sheep numbers around Australia run at about 150 million. It varies substantially, sometimes up in the 170 millions and sometimes down in the 130 millions; nevertheless we have a major sheep population. That sheep population creates substantial employment. The harvesting of wool is quite labour intensive and, of course, the shearing industry has been a great traditional base for the Australian Labor Party. It is part of Australian history that the shearing industry really set the trade union movement in place, and I do not think that a lot has changed in that regard.

It is a very interesting aspect of trade unionism that shearers are probably still as fiercely independent as ever, notwithstanding their ability to organise, and of course the shearer himself is still a pieceworker. Nevertheless, shearers do represent a substantial part of the history of the Labor movement in Australia. That just brings to our attention another reason why this proposal should be a bipartisan one.

I would reiterate that I am very grateful to the honourable member for Stirling for coming to me after I had made some earlier remarks. I am sure his initiatives at this stage equal my own, and I am extremely grateful for that.

We have some tremendous reasons for promoting a national day for a product—at the moment under great pressure in economic terms—that has delivered to Australia a huge amount of prosperity. As I have already pointed out, it has been our major export commodity for eight of the last 25 years. With this motion I hope that we can put a focus on wool at the commencement of the winter retail season, so that Australians go back to their local product and use it wherever possible.

On previous occasions I have stood in this chamber and drawn the Parliament's attention to some of the products manufactured from wool that are now available but which most Australians do not know exist. A CSIRO invention has given us a wool doona—or a wool quilt, as the CSIRO calls it. It is a magnificent product that I have used this year. Australia should be promoting this product around the world, remembering that some eight to 10 million doonas are sold to Japan alone each year.

An aspect of this motion is to have a function in the Members' Hall aimed at inviting people from the embassies and others, particularly their trade commissioners. I am sure we will take time to take them out to the Great Hall and show them some of these new and innovative products and do as much marketing as we, as members of parliament, can competently do. I hope that all honourable members are in the Members' Hall and in the Great Hall on that day giving support to and pushing wool.

I am hopeful that our call will be understood in many areas of Australia. I would like to think that particularly country local government would have excellent entertainment on that occasion to recognise wool. I am not suggesting that we go to massive expense; I am suggesting that this Parliament, by giving one day's recognition to wool, focus public attention on the product at a time when retailers and others are bringing out their winter fashions. I am hopeful that retailers will consequently also recognise this call. Of course, our committee will be corresponding with them suggesting that on that day there be major launches throughout Australia of wool products in the retail sector and that manufacturers be put on notice.

I say to the media and others that there is a great opportunity for financial reward. All the people involved in various manufacturing industries that benefit by supplying products to wool growers and those that manufacture wool into end-user products would be willing to advertise on that day. Maybe our national print media will go to supplements for a national wool day. Hopefully our television people will take the opportunity to have some entertainment and push wool, and do it at a profit. We all recognise that they should have that opportunity.

It could be a big day. I am sure, with the bipartisan support that we have, that will happen. Just the other day I read that a person can now insulate his or her house with wool batts. They do not burn and do not have the problems that many others do. They are not carcinogenic or anything of that nature. All the opportunities are there. This could be the day when the Australian Parliament says, `Come and have a look at wool. We support wool. We support the wool industry'. I am sure we will all get together. There will not be one word of disagreement in the Parliament in promoting wool on that day. I thank the honourable member for Stirling for his cooperation. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

—I second the motion. I congratulate the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) on his initiative because it is very important. One of the complaints that the Australian people have of this Parliament is that a lot of the time we seem to be at one another's throats, yet out there people face real problems. We in this Parliament ought to take the opportunity, whenever we can, to show the Australian people that we are of a single mind on a matter of national significance.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for O'Connor, very astutely, has identified a matter of national significance, and that is the wool industry and its importance to Australia. In his remarks the honourable member for O'Connor identified all the levels of production. He spoke about the labour component—the shearers and their historical significance—and the importance of the wool industry for export.

I thank him for his remarks in relation to my seconding the motion. When I heard him talk about a national wool day it was my view that we ought to have this day and provide a focus for the Australian people. In many respects, the Australian people focus on this Parliament. We ought not let pass a major opportunity to talk about a major industry such as wool.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only constructive thing we'll do all day.

—It is an opportunity for us to do something very constructive on this day. We are saying to honourable members: here is a chance for us to get behind an initiative of our colleagues. To promote this product, as the honourable member for O'Connor has said, and to say that we, as members of parliament, believe we have a role to play in helping a major industry such as wool, will greatly benefit the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for O'Connor is quite right: there will not be opposition; I would be surprised if there were. Our colleagues will recognise that this is a great opportunity. It is true that the reaction from the contacts we have had is that it is a good idea. I am pleased to support this motion. I thank the Speaker and the President for their support of this day. They gave approval that this day on 2 April could go ahead. It gives us in this Parliament an opportunity to go ahead with the organisation of this big day.

The honourable member for O'Connor has identified some of the people who can assist in helping promote the wool industry on this day. We can look at a range of those. The retailers and the Australian Wool Corporation will be important. So, of course, will people connected with shearing. I would be pleased if shearers were to be present and take this opportunity to play a role. Wool classers and a number of others could be involved.

The honourable member for O'Connor was quite right. We looked at a paper at the ABARE Agricultural Outlook Conference this year given by a gentleman from Coles-Myer. He spoke about the opportunities for new products. He talked about products such as those that the honourable member for O'Connor has referred to. The use of wool doonas is one. Insulation is another.

When I was a child, if someone's woollen jumper somehow got mixed up in the wash and went into the washing machine, it went from a size 16 to a size 12. That is now history; that does not happen to wool. Because of the work of the CSIRO and others in the industry, wool is much more universally used and much more valuable in our community. I use the word `valuable' deliberately. We need to see more value-adding in our wool production. People should use this day as a chance to ask what else they can do to value-add to this very important product. As the honourable member for O'Connor has said, when one looks at the fact that 70 per cent of the world's apparel wool comes from Australia, one realises what a significant role Australia plays.

If the industry were to reflect on the matter, it would realise that in some senses it priced itself out of the market. There is no doubt that wool, as a fine quality product, is unique; there is no other product that can substitute as well. It was when one moved down the price range that wool began to lose its leverage in the market. Certainly, men can have a wardrobe of two or three suits and that will do. But for women, who often want a wider range of garments, it was often a very expensive commitment to buy woollen garments.

On this day we want to get the retailers in here and get them to display to us good value woollen products—because they are available. But the Australian people have lost sight of the fact that there are available many good value products made from Australian wool. We want to see more of those made and manufactured in Australia; not exported and re-imported as a final product. We want to see value-adding in production.

What we are saying to the Parliament is that here is an opportunity for us as a community in the Parliament to get behind a national wool day. The honourable member for O'Connor has referred to people coming in here, for example, from the trade commissioner area, and having a display in the Great Hall. Honourable members will understand that the intention would be for all of us to wear a woollen garment on that day. I am sure that, if we speak to our colleagues in the Parliament, they will all ensure that on that day in the Parliament they wear a woollen garment made from Australian wool. I think that it is very important that we demonstrate—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are Paul Keating's suits made out of Australian wool?

—This debate is a bipartisan one, and I am sure the honourable member for Mayo knows that. We feel that the proposed national wool day will be a good opportunity for Australians to wear Australian made wool products.
—Are you saying that Australian made products are bad?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleagues are enthusiastic about Christmas coming up, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—They should control their enthusiasm.

—I thank the Chair. In the paper presented to the Outlook Conference, the gentleman from Myer, Mr Mike Howell, did say some very significant things. I thank him for what was a very good paper in which he talked of examples of how we can reinforce the role of wool. He talked about Superwash in the United States. He mentioned how retail customers through the Marks and Spencer store came to realise that, with Superwash, wool could be treated like any other fabric and that, therefore, it was universally useable. I refer also to the wool mark, which has become a standard. We must congratulate the industry on achieving that standard. It has now been very clearly fixed in people's minds that wool is a quality product.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howell also went on to point out that fabric blends and clever marketing could realign wool to the middle market and improve consumption dramatically. I think that that is one of the areas on which we have to focus. We want to see people going in and buying at this middle range. That is the area in which we need to have wool used more and more. In fact, I heard the honourable member in a radio interview in Canberra talking about the increase in the consumption of wool that would occur if we all wore woollen socks, et cetera. It is interesting to see the significant amount of wool that would be taken off the market if we insisted—or, I should say, encouraged, people to wear Australian made wool products.

TALK.START.PARA: —Make it mandatory.

—We do not want to make it mandatory. We should be stating the significant advantages of wool as a fabric. Here we are in an Australian summer, and I am wearing an Australian made wool suit—a medium to light weight wool suit.
—Are you sure?

—Yes, it meets all the tests. It would meet the test of being a cool wool. By that I mean that it is a product that is not too heavy to wear in an Australian summer. It is important that we be able to say to the community that wool is one of those products that can be used across a wide range of applications.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, in summing up, I am very pleased to second the motion moved by the honourable member for O'Connor. I think it is a great initiative. I thank him for taking that initiative. I want to support him straight out. We need to say that our proposed national wool day on 2 April next year will be a very significant day. We would like to think that members of parliament would get involved. We would like the wool industry, in all its phases—woollen mills, retailers, workers—to be involved. Certainly, we would like the fashion industry to display its new fashions on that day, because we will be between seasons and it would perhaps be appropriate to display winter fashions on that day. I would like to think that we could use this great parliament of ours for such a purpose. I am very pleased to endorse the motion. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a future date.
Leave granted.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—The Clerk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave of the House to move a motion.
—Order! I have already called the Clerk. The debate is adjourned.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave of the House—
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will resume his seat.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am seeking leave of the House—
—Order! I am putting the motion. I ask the honourable member for Mayo to resume his seat. The motion is that the debate be adjourned.

PARA.TAB: Debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Clerk.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave—
—Order! I ask the honourable member for Mayo to resume his seat. I have called the Clerk, who is calling on the next item of business.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. If I may say so, I really do think that this is bringing, with the greatest of respect, the procedures of the House into disrepute.
—What is the honourable member's point of order?
—I clearly stood up on two occasions, which you know only too well, Mr Deputy Speaker. On two occasions, I stood up to seek leave of the House. You were deliberately endeavouring to cut me off.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER—The honourable member for Mayo should be aware of the procedures of the House. I had—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am. One of the procedures is that I am allowed to seek leave of the House.

—If the honourable member for Mayo will let me finish what I was saying, he should know what the procedures of the House are. I had already called the Clerk to call on the next item of business, which has been agreed to.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, it is perfectly clear, if I may say so with the greatest of respect, that you had not. It is perfectly clear that you had not called the Clerk when I stood up to seek leave of the House to move a motion.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order.
—The honourable member for the Northern Territory on a point of order.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your indulgence as to whether this person is in order in addressing you—
—Order! The honourable member should refer to him as the honourable member for Mayo.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, if the honourable member for Mayo was such an honourable person, he would treat you with the respect which your position deserves. He would allow you to run this House in an appropriate manner.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order.
—The honourable member for Hume on a point of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on that point of order: you knew that the honourable member for Mayo was seeking the call. If I may say so, you deliberately avoided calling the honourable member for Mayo. In the circumstances, I ask you to reconsider your ruling in the interests of the good conduct of this House, and call the honourable member for Mayo.

—I have a great deal of respect for what the honourable member has said. However, he would be aware, even better than I, of the procedures of this House. If the honourable member for Mayo will recall, I was finishing the procedure on motion No. 1. He sought—
—The honourable member for Mayo is talking about the procedures of the House, but he keeps interrupting me when I am explaining. The honourable member for Mayo actually started to stand there—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order.

—I ask the honourable member for the Northern Territory to wait until I have finished. After that I then called the Clerk. Once I had called the Clerk, he was then bringing on the business for the day. So, I am not going to reconsider my ruling. I call the honourable member for the Northern Territory.
—The two members opposite me reflected on you, Mr Deputy Speaker, in the course of your address. I ask them to withdraw their adverse reflections on you as Deputy Speaker.
—I do not think that we will get into that. I think that we should proceed with the motion.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order.
—The honourable member for Stirling.
—Mr Deputy Speaker—
—Order! I have already called the honourable member for Stirling.

—The selection committee had set down the program for business today. It is my understanding that the Chair was following that order of business set down by the selection committee. That is my understanding.
—That was my understanding.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I move dissent—
—Order! I take it that the honourable member for Mayo is seeking the call?
—Yes. I am entitled to it.
—All right. It is the normal custom of this House to wait until an honourable member is called.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I tried to get the call before, but you would not give it to me. Mr Deputy Speaker, do I have the call?
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Deputy Speaker's ruling be dissented from.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I am moving this motion—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the honourable member for Mayo is moving a motion of dissent, the motion has to be handed in in writing.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, it is being handed in in writing. I am moving the dissent motion because the ruling that you have handed down—

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Snowdon) put:
That the honourable member be not further heard.

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called and the bells being rung—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Standing Order 193, as amended by Sessional Order, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Provided that, on sitting Thursdays, any division called for in the House before 12.30 p.m. on a question, other than a motion moved by a Minister, shall stand deferred until 12.30 p.m.
The question before the House relates to a motion moved by a Parliamentary Secretary. The division shall, therefore, be proceeded with forthwith.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the honourable member be not further heard.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Snowdon) put:
That the honourable member be not further heard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, this is outrageous.
—Order!

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called and the bells being rung—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: under Standing Order 193, only a Minister is able to move a motion before 12.30 p.m. I put it to you, Mr Speaker, that the honourable member who moved that motion is not a Minister and therefore the motion is out of order.

—Order! The right honourable member for New England might recall that he raised a matter on the particular motion that the House passed about Parliamentary Secretaries having the right to move motions, and the House has adopted that provision. The Parliamentary Secretary is in order.

—Mr Speaker, I refer you specifically to that Standing Order. It does not say a person acting instead of a Minister; it says a Minister specifically. For that reason I put to you that the motion is out of order, in spite of your ruling.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the honourable member be not further heard.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the Deputy Speaker's ruling be dissented from.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Snowdon) put:
That the question be now put.
Mr Downer—Mr Speaker, in order to avoid any further confusion—

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the honourable member for Mayo have a point of order?
—Yes, I do, Mr Speaker.
—It had better be a proper point of order.

—It is, Mr Speaker. It is in order to assist both you and the House. You would appreciate that my points of order always are proper points of order. My point of order is that in order to avoid any further confusion of this unseemly kind, I should like to notify you that at the end of this division I will be proceeding to try to move a motion.
—There is no point of order.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with standing order 193, the motion to dissent from the Deputy Speaker's ruling stands deferred until 12.30 today.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 November, on motion by Mr Johns:
That this House:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1)notes that:

PARA.TAB: (a)water is one of Australia's most valuable resources;
(b)its use, treatment and availability vary enormously throughout the nation;
(c)there is debate as to whether this resource is managed sufficiently well so that the water available to the next generation will be at least as good as that currently available; and
(d)together, water and sewerage activities involve total employment of 35 000 workers and $2 billion worth of investment annually; and

PROCTEXT.PARA: (2)calls on the Government, in conjunction with the States and other authorities, to:

PARA.TAB: (a)consider how Australia can achieve more efficient and environmentally sound use of its water resources; and
(b)develop a national strategy for sustainable water quality management.
Mr Downer—Mr Speaker—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mayo will resume his seat.

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer—Mr Speaker, on a point of order—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mayo will resume his seat.

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer—Mr Speaker, I did take the courtesy of informing you that I was proposing to seek the call at the end of the division.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order.

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer—Mr Speaker, you were aware of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mayo will resume his seat.

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer—You were aware of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mayo will resume his seat.

PARA.TAB: Mr Fife—Mr Speaker—

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the honourable member for Hume have a point of order?

PARA.TAB: Mr Fife—Yes, Mr Speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Hume on a point of order.

PARA.TAB: Mr Fife—Mr Speaker, I actually seek your indulgence.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable member has a point of order, he might make the point of order.

PARA.TAB: Mr Fife—Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence—

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable member for Hume has a point of order, I will hear him.

PARA.TAB: Mr Fife—I ask you: what do we on the Opposition side of the House have to do today to attract your attention? The honourable member for Mayo gave you—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Hume no longer has the indulgence of the Chair. He will resume his seat.

—I am delighted to have the opportunity to speak on this subject. Coming from the driest State in the driest country of the world, I know that water, particularly River Murray water, is of paramount importance to us. Of course, a lot of work is being done on the River Murray.

PARA.TAB: A number of years ago I had a lot of input in respect of the dreaded disease, amoebic meningitis, which was located in Murray water that was pumped to my area in the northern part of South Australia. Unfortunately, a couple of deaths occurred.

South Australians in general are highly conscious that their State is the driest State in the nation as measured by total run-off and ground water resources. Given that the Murray is the State's only major river—South Australia lacks a Hawkesbury, a Clarence, a Goulburn or a Shoalhaven river—South Australians have been most alarmed by the algae disaster in the Darling system.

While the Darling and its tributaries do not offer the same water flows as the Murray, South Australia has depended on the Darling in the past at least to partly dilute the Murray's salinity. The Darling also has the effect of increasing turbidity of water flowing to South Australia, which discourages algae. In the past, development of new irrigation along the Darling has been severely questioned in South Australia. Those concerns now appear to have been fully justified.

While the outbreak of toxic algae has been frightening enough to people living along the affected stretches of river, expert commentators are saying that the algae are still only a symptom of poor water management which may lead to further disasters. In the past, outbreaks of algae have been reasonably common in farm dams, warm still lakes, et cetera, but huge blooms stretching over hundreds of kilometres of a large Australian river have to be regarded as a major warning. The algae are brought on by human actions, namely, sewage and fertiliser run-off in estimated equal quantities plus the impounding of surplus river flows by cotton and other irrigators in the Darling Basin.

The expert view is that sewage inflows from major inland towns in the Darling Basin—towns such as Tamworth, Orange, Dubbo and Toowoomba—are critical to the nutrient levels and thus to algae growth. Wide-ranging catchment management changes are also essential. Clearly, provision of funds and advice here is of national, not just local, significance.

While nutrients in the Murray-Darling are presently being highlighted because of the outbreak of algae, the main pollutant is still salt. Salinity is estimated to cost Australia about $60m a year in lost production, $43m of this being incurred in the Murray and Murrumbidgee valleys alone. More than 1.3 millions tonnes of salt flush into the Murray each year and this may double in 20 years in the absence of major remedial action. Meanwhile, the economic loss would amount to approximately $95m a year.

South Australia has been highly conscious of the salinity problem for some time and has frequently urged more concern from New South Wales, Victoria and the Commonwealth. Adelaide depends on the Murray for between 40 and 90 per cent of its water. Murray water is widely distributed to country areas of South Australia, including my areas of Whyalla, Port Augusta and Port Pirie.

On the positive side, the relatively young Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council, together with the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, is making great strides towards better basin management. Once dismissed into the too hard basket, interstate cooperation on the basin is blossoming with the realisation that the Murray-Darling Basin's problems could be terminal. Already, much has been achieved.

A crucial move by the Council has been to initiate the drawing up of a natural resources management strategy and a salinity and drainage strategy for the basin. The four involved governments are likely to spend hundreds of millions of dollars over 30 years in salinity abatement programs alone.

On the subject of water resources generally, one can list some consequences of living in a dry continent, few of which are fully appreciated in the eastern States. Droughts are part of the Australian climate and must be integrated into water policies. Political and public interest in water needs to be more constant. There is a danger that public concern will flush away with the algae!

There are many uses for water. Its cost should reflect not only the capital needed to store and distribute it but also its scarcity and the opportunity cost. The Murray-Darling water is needed for drinking water, irrigation, fishing and other recreation, forest and wildlife preservation, flushing of sewage and other nutrients, and so on. Major users, such as cotton and rice growers, cannot be allowed to take unsustainable allotments from what is a very small river system in terms of run-off.

One would expect a dry country to invest heavily in water research. For example, the water requirements of economic and ornamental plants are of vital concern. The 1991-92 Federal Budget increased funding to the Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation by more than $2m, to $10.8m. CSIRO has a strong interest in water research.

One would expect water to be charged on a user-pays basis—that is, fee per volume—rather than as a paid service tacked on to a rate bill. Full changeover to this method of payment is unlikely to be popular at first but there is no better way to put over the conservation message.

Given the unreliable rain and high evaporation rates so typical of Australia, there should be a high incidence of rainwater tanks in cities. Their relative scarcity is a reflection of generous but short-sighted water allowances.

Our rivers having limited flushing capacity and given the extent of ancient ocean beds in Australia, problems with salinity are inevitable. A total of $6.4m is set aside from the 1991-92 Federal water resources assistance program for salinity control and drainage in the Murray-Darling Basin.

There is a need for cooperation among States. The Murray-Darling Basin incorporates fully 15 per cent of Queensland, yet that State is not a participant in the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council.

There is a need to appreciate the natural functions of river flushes or `surplus' water. There is at present little control over private diversion of surplus flows in some rivers. Also, there should be maximum encouragement of flexibility in the use of water rights—for example, trading. Pollution levels have to be considered in the determination of `credits'.

Lastly, the consequences of poor water management in a dry continent are severe. Already, more than half of the irrigation area of the Murray-Darling Basin is under threat from salinity, so lost production is an early casualty. Secondly, without good management and cooperation, there is inequity and discord.

Sound water use is everybody's business. The 1983 report Water 2000 estimated that Australian irrigators were not as efficient in their use of water as their counterparts overseas. Much of the urban water supply was considered to be wasted as a result of gardening.

Thirdly, without correction, Australia's drinking water supplies will continue to deteriorate. Sydney and Melbourne water no longer has a reputation for purity, while country supplies are often grossly contaminated.

Lastly, poor management threatens our way of life culturally and imperils our environmental stage. The Murray-Darling and other grand Australian rivers are not to be regarded merely as water canals upstream and effluent ditches downstream of wherever a person, a farm or a town happens to be or stand. They must be allowed to serve a rich number of functions in harmony. Above all, we must learn that water is precious.

As I say, coming from South Australia, which is the driest State in the driest continent, I know that water has a very significant role to play in South Australia's expansion and economic way of life. I urge all honourable members to do more to project water, particularly water from the River Murray, as a major component of this country and this economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 104A. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order for the next sitting Thursday.
—Earlier today, the House had three motions before it which were deferred in accordance with standing order 104 as amended for this session. I shall now proceed to the first matter.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

TALK.START.PARA: —The question has been put on the motion moved by the honourable member for Bennelong that standing and sessional orders be suspended, and a division has been called for.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

TALK.START.PARA: —I will now restate the question on the suspension of Standing Orders moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. The question is that the motion be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question put.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will now restate the motion moved by the honourable member for Mayo that the Deputy Speaker's ruling be dissented from.

PARA.TAB: Question put.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I grieve today for this great nation which has suffered so badly at the hands of this inept Government. This recession, which is clearly the worst in 60 years, has inflicted much pain and suffering on Australia and Australians.

PARA.TAB: Even this week the ranks of the unemployed swelled to their largest since the Great Depression. The Australian Bureau of Statistics recorded more than 900,000 Australians as unemployed, an unemployment rate of 10.5 per cent. The number of Australians in jobs in November dropped by another 36,200. The number in full time employment in this country plunged disastrously by 90,400. Significantly, teenage unemployment has now reached a record 31 per cent.

The reaction of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) to these latest figures was that they were `not unexpected'. When he was interviewed and confronted with the disastrous news about the 10.5 per cent unemployment rate, he said that they were `in line with Budget forecasts'.

We have since heard the Treasurer (Mr Willis)—and I imagine he is a very temporary Treasurer indeed—concede that the Budget forecast that unemployment would peak at 10.75 per cent is now looking optimistic. In fact, the Treasurer admitted that what we have been saying for some time is becoming a possibility, that is, that before Australia comes out of this recession, unemployment will in fact go higher than 11 per cent. It seems to me extremely ironic that the Treasury boffins who are desperately seeking to find minor holes in the Opposition's Fightback package are now faced with the reality that their Budget estimates of just four months ago are, in fact, deeply flawed.

The news on unemployment, of course, becomes increasingly gloomy. An estimated 20,000 jobs will be lost in the Australian banking industry in the next year. The ANZ Banking Group Ltd announced only yesterday that it intended to reduce its staff in Australia by some 2,500 during 1992. Last week, the AMP Society announced its plans to shed 550 jobs. Almost every day manufacturers close down or go bankrupt.

It will, indeed, be a very depressing Christmas for those Australians who are unemployed and for the families of those who have been affected. The great irony is that until today the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) put his job ahead of the nearly one million Australians who are out of work. Today he has apparently decided to do the right thing and resign; and so he should. He is to blame for the miserable Christmas that is faced now by many Australian families. It is his Government's policies and those of the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), who is to be a candidate for the prime ministership tonight, that have inflicted this pain and suffering on Australians.
What hope will there be even under a Prime Minister Keating? As Alan Wood wrote in the Australian the other day, `Forget about the jockey; what about the horse?' He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Recovery is hardly being helped by all the activity in the jockeys' changing room.
What frenetic activity there is in the changing room today.

PARA.TAB: When the honourable member for Blaxland becomes Prime Minister, perhaps he will adopt the policy prescriptions of the Opposition in its Fightback package. I wonder whether he will be able to resist the temptation to panic and take the easy options. I wonder what deals are being done in the rooms and hallways of this place today to secure his election. No doubt his friend Bernie Fraser can be relied upon to chop a couple of percentage points off interest rates, but that is not the answer. There are no easy solutions to Australia's problems. I believe that Mr Keating knows this.

The Government's legacy to the children of Australia is, of course, a massive debt. Our net debt in 1979-80 was only $6.9 billion; today it is close to $140 billion. Interest payments on this debt increased to more than $14 billion in 1991; in fact, 23 per cent of the value of exports of goods and services is required just to meet that enormous interest debt. The net result of that debt, which was created by the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister to be, is that we have to keep borrowing just to keep pace; otherwise we will have to sell off the farm. Of course, the Government has been rushing headlong into doing that as much as it can as well.

This Government has mortgaged the future of the children of this country. Today that future is very much at risk as we see the spectre of our credit rating being further downgraded. Our living standards, which have fallen consistently and disastrously under this Government, will continue to fall. I say with great regret that we are a nation in debt and a nation out of work. Yet the Government's attention is focused—and we see so much evidence of this in this place today, with the Parliament a complete fiasco and out of control—on its own problems rather than on the country's problems.

The Government and, in particular, the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland, caused the recession. Now they are paralysed and cannot find a way out of it. They are unable to deliver the reforms that Australia needs. It has fallen to the Opposition to produce a blueprint for reform. We have taken the initiative; we have the vision; we have the policies. Rather than respond in kind, the Government has resorted to pathetic scaremongering. Its attempts to discredit our Fightback package have failed dismally. It has been unable to find fault with the arithmetic; it has been unable to find fault with the economics. The Government is hopelessly inadequate and cannot provide alternatives.
I was interested to read today the following statement of P. P. McGuinness about the Government:

SPEECH.PARA: All that remains to be seen is how much damage it does in its death throes.
This Government is to be condemned on every front. Not only has it created the worst level of unemployment since the Great Depression; it has also, as I said, saddled Australia with a great debt.

PARA.TAB: We have the enormous number of almost one million Australians out of work. The great shame is that many of these unemployed are young Australians. The youth unemployment rate across the country is running in excess of 30 per cent. It is a great pity for these young people. Their ranks are soon to be swelled by those leaving school shortly. Early in 1992 we will see an even higher rate of youth unemployment. The great pity is, of course, that kids are unable not only to get jobs, but also to access a tertiary education. We see that the Government has failed miserably in the provision of places at universities for them and we see it has failed dismally in providing places at TAFE colleges for them.

Today I grieve for this great nation, a nation that had so much potential and, indeed, still has potential, but a nation that has been failed by this Government, its Prime Minister and the person who pretends to be Prime Minister. At 7 o'clock tonight we may well have him as the leader of this nation. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) talks about his package being a visionary program for the future of Australia, he is correct. But it is a vision that is founded on New Right ideology. The package appeals to every bigoted, racist and sexist attitude that pervades our community, building upon a mammoth redistribution of income from low and middle income earners to the rich and powerful. It punishes the victims and the powerless and sacrifices those in our community with the least capacity to fight back.
—Oh!
—Have you read it? Can you read?
—Order! The member for Lowe and the member for McPherson will cease interjecting.

—The Liberals keep challenging us to look at the package as a whole agenda for change. We should certainly do so. It is an agenda to divide, to punish and to weaken our fundamental principles of social justice and fair play. It appeals to what the Liberals believe is the lowest common denominator in our community—greed. The basic message to the Australian community is, `We will give you more money by taking it away from someone else who, we believe, does not deserve it'. But it is like a shell game. Just when we think we know where that extra bit of money is, we lift the shell to find it empty.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition promises average families big tax cuts and then takes all of that income away from the extra costs of food and essential services through the GST. Ultimately, all of the tax cuts disappear with bracket creep, but the GST stays and continues to eat into people's incomes and living standards. This is clearly demonstrated in the New Zealand experience. Selwyn Parker in the Bulletin of 10 December wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: After five years of the goods and services tax, the New Zealand experience has overwhelmingly proved one thing: Consumption taxes are good for governments. So far, what can be said definitively about the GST is that:

* It has dramatically increased the indirect tax take without slowing much the government's haul from direct taxes. In its first year of operation, in 1986-87, the GST pulled in $NZ1.22 billion (about $A870 million). In 1990-91, as more and more taxpayers were drawn into Inland Revenue's net, the take soared to $NZ6 billion after reimbursements. Driven by the GST, the total indirect tax take nearly tripled.

PARA.TAB: Although the quid pro quo of lower income taxes was supposed to compensate for the introduction of the GST, the tax you can't duck, the government's indirect tax take has continued to increase. Income taxes amounted to $NZ9.1 billion in 1986; in 1990, they were around $14 billion. Put another way, every New Zealander was paying $4800 in total taxes in 1986. By 1991, they were paying more than $8,000.

SPEECH.PARA: Another of Dr Hewson's promises is cheaper fuel, claiming a 19c a litre, or $12 a tank, fall in prices. But he has not explained how he is going to pay for road funding. The most obvious way is by increasing registration fees by $300 to $400 a year per person to pay for roads. Dr Hewson promises full compensation for inflation but fails to compute a whole range of factors into the inflation measurement, understating the inflationary impact by at least 3 per cent a year.

PARA.TAB: Dr Hewson promises great productivity growth, but when one actually looks at his calculations, one sees that over the next decade his projected growth in economic performance is less than what the Hawke Government has achieved over the last eight years. Hewson targets the unemployed, sole parents, Aborigines, migrants, older women, environmental groups and students, blaming them for all of the problems in our economy, and making them pay for the benefits which will flow to the wealthy.

The Opposition's package is one which rejects fairness and equity and looks set to abandon all that this Government has achieved in terms of social justice and the social wage which the Labor Government has delivered to the Australian public over the last nine years. This Government has done a great deal to lower the overall tax burden on the average PAYE taxpayer and reduce the size of the public sector. This appears to have been overlooked by the Liberal Party of Australia in the preparation of its package.

The Liberal Party's Fightback package is fundamentally flawed in that it distributes wealth away from the poor back to the rich. The package will see massive tax cuts for those on high incomes, while lower and middle income earners receive much smaller income tax cuts but will also be slugged 15 per cent on all the necessities of life. A person earning $25,000 a year will gain only $22.70 a week in tax cuts, but a person earning $75,000 will get an extra $135.30 a week in tax cuts. For the person who earns $25,000, all this $22.70 extra will be taken in higher prices because of the GST.

As the President of the Australian Council of Social Service, Merle Mitchell said, the sick, the disabled, sole parents and the unemployed would bear the brunt of the Liberals' Fightback package. Ms Mitchell said that changes proposed by the Liberal Party would force the wives of disabled pensioners to work part time and still provide care, while sole parents with teenage children would be locked out of part time work opportunities. Ms Mitchell states:

SPEECH.PARA: Increasing waiting periods for benefits would force even more families and individuals to rely on charity and handouts to survive.

The Opposition's Fightback package proposes that the social security Budget be cut by $2.5 billion. This, combined with the increase in inflation expected under the Opposition's proposals, would see the poor and disadvantaged even worse off. The cuts in personal income tax rates will be brought about not by the introduction of the GST but by slashing government spending, particularly in the area of social security. Professor Geoffrey Brennan of the Catholic Weekly stated:

If there is anything in the Hewson package for taxpayers as a group, it comes about not through the general sales tax or any over side change but through expenditure cuts. And here we need to remind ourselves that when government cuts $100 million from its expenditure, that $100 million in money that someone got from government yesterday that they won't not get tomorrow.
Professor Brennan states further:

Ultimately, however, the effects of the Hewson package on the tax side are swamped by the effects on expenditure side. Everyone tends to be in favour of cuts in other people's favourite expenditure programmes. And we all like to focus on how much less tax we will pay, and whether the tax calculations show us doing better than most others. But when roads deteriorate, hospital services decline, and we start to pay more for things like water and electricity and postage and television, the cost of tax cuts start to become very evident.

The package that the Liberal Party is proposing is, of course, a divisive policy mix. The Opposition has clearly given with one hand, by giving personal income tax cuts, and taken back with two hands with the introduction of a goods and services tax and major cuts in income support and services. According to Ross Gittins, the economics editor of the Sydney Morning Herald:
Dr Hewson has taken a consumption tax nobody wanted and buried inside a bribe.

If it all sounds too good to be true, it is. The reason Dr Hewson's tables show that everyone wins and no-one loses, is that it takes no account of the things that make the package add up: gross cuts in government spending worth $10 billion.
Since it is not possible to identify whose pockets would be hit by that $10 billion slash, it is ignored in all of Dr Hewson's figuring of who wins and how much.

He has taken . . . tax reform and surrounded it with gimmicks he thinks will appeal to people whose grasp on the topic is shaky: the abolition of payroll tax, the tax free saving scheme and the first home owners' scheme.
Political pressures have obliged him to pretend that changing our tax system is the key to rebuilding our economy. He is not silly enough to believe that.
Gittins concludes with this comment:
But if you would prefer to vote for tax cuts and gimmicks, the new look Professor is happy to accommodate you.

The GST package will do little to help those on low and middle incomes. A week after the release of the Fightback package the President of the Taxpayers Association, Eric Risstrom, strongly criticised the package. Risstrom stated:
John Hewson said at the launch that the tax cuts were directed at the low and middle income earners. The figures don't seem to stack up that way.

Clearly, the Liberal's package is a hoax. It may allow for some items to be cheaper and some people to be better off, particularly the rich, but as Hewson admits, if not boasts, this package will lead to a much more divided Australia.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: John Curtin School of Medical Research: Funding

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek to draw the attention of this House to an act of wilful vandalism that is being perpetrated by the Government in its attempts to wrest control of the John Curtin School of Medical Research from the Australian National University. Despite the wishes of the Australian National University Council, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) has made it clear that he intends to press on with transferring the funding of the John Curtin School to the National Health and Medical Research Council and to support arrangements which would effectively remove from the university the capacity to undertake strategic planning involving the John Curtin School.

PARA.TAB: The Government bases its stand on the report of the Committee of Review headed by Sir Ninian Stephen. Despite the understandable opposition of the university to the recommendations of the Committee in relation to the John Curtin School, the Government has demonstrated a quite remarkable determination to proceed regardless of any action taken by the university and any response by the university to the issues raised by the Stephen Committee. There has been a conspicuous unwillingness on the part of the Government to enable proper consultations to take place, consultations that would have been entirely appropriate given the magnitude of the changes proposed.

The Government's move is of dubious legality. It is certainly a departure from the spirit of the legislation governing the Australian National University which unambiguously vests in the university control over the John Curtin School. Further, the Government has not come to the Parliament to seek amendment to this legislation; rather, it is attempting to achieve its aims by financial power because it knows that the Parliament will not give it legislative sanction. It has resorted to those tactics we have come to know so well in higher education—the bully-boy tactics of thuggery and coercion.

It is of little consequence that the Australian National University will retain what amounts to token representation on the board of management. Behind the soothing words of this arrangement lurks the harsh reality. The disbursement of funding will not be controlled by the Australian National University. If the National Health and Medical Research Council does not get its way, it can simply ask the Minister to cut funding to the school.
