This is a far more draconian arrangement than the modus vivendi reached over the other research schools of the Institute of Advanced Studies in which the Australian Research Council is to consult and seek agreement with the Australian National University on the composition of review panels and the performance criteria to be applied in evaluating each school at five-yearly intervals. The reports of these reviews will form the basis of the Australian Research Council's advice to the Government as to the notional level of funding to be provided to each school.

It was an arrangement with which the ANU felt finally that it could live, its autonomy and integrity remaining intact. But not so with the John Curtin School, which is effectively being wrenched away, by the Government, from the Australian National University's control.

At the heart of the present dispute is a proposed administrative arrangement for funding the school through the NHMRC. Section 20 of the Australian National University Act confers on the Board of the Institute of Advanced Studies responsibility under the Council for all academic matters relating to the Institute. While the academic matters are to be determined by the ANU, the proposal makes clear that this is to be a matter of mere formality and that academic matters will not effectively include research. Hence, the main function of the school, in fact its very raison d'etre, is not to be within the effective purview of the university.

This is the latest chapter in an insidious process that has seen the inexorable expansion of ministerial discretion intruding into higher education. The concerns aroused by the Government's actions here are not confined to the John Curtin School nor to the Australian National University. The entire academic community is looking on aghast at this unprecedented trampling of university autonomy. It wonders which institution will be next. The John Curtin School of Medical Research is unquestionably a world-class biomedical research institute. Its standing in the international research community has been objectively demonstrated by bibliometric analysis which quantifies the use made in scientific journals of the school's work.

The school's particular mission has been in nurturing and fostering long term research on a diverse range of problems. It has been accused of being unfashionable because of this. One of these presumed unfashionable areas has been its continuing research—much of it in a voluntary capacity—into the physical legacies of that `unfashionable' war in Vietnam and the `unfashionable' ailments suffered by those `unfashionable' ex-servicemen, the Vietnam veterans. No one could have been unmoved last week when a representative of the Vietnam Veterans Association delivered to an Australian National University protest meeting his heartfelt and unsolicited appreciation of the John Curtin School's tireless efforts in treating the victims of agent orange and various cancers, including brain tumours.

It is clear that the Government's course of action has unleashed considerable anger, but it is useful at this stage to take a detached look at the criticisms levelled at the John Curtin School. It is clear, though, that significant measures have been set in train to attend to problems identified in both the Stephen Committee report and the decennial review of 1988. Given this, one must question the haste with which the Government is moving on the issue when the problems are already being addressed.

One of the criticisms is that the school has become, in the words of one critic, a sheltered workshop of scientific inbreeding. In academic circles, this is usually taken to mean a general sameness in type and origin of degrees, and for favoured students to be appointed to vacancies when their mentors retire. Professor Max Neutze, Director of the Institute of Advanced Studies has convincingly and irrefutably nailed this one. The facts are that the 31 tenured staff at the school obtained their first degrees from 15 different universities, eight of them overseas. Significantly, not one of them earned their first degree at the Australian National University and only nine obtained their higher degree there. The degrees of the 44 non-tenured staff originated in 25 different universities—15 of them overseas institutions. Only five earned their first degrees at the Australian National University and 18 earned their higher degree there.

Another criticism has been the vexed issue of tenure. The John Curtin School, along with the other research schools, has been moving towards a smaller ratio of tenured to non-tenured staff to the extent that it is now much lower than in other universities. Professor Neutze makes the point—and it is a vital one given the school's long term mission—that a nucleus of tenured staff is essential if academic freedom is to be protected and the best of the researchers are to be free to undertake long and difficult projects.

There have been, it seems, envious and covetous eyes cast at the level of funding for the John Curtin School. It has been alleged that the school is featherbedded and that its staff do not compete for funds. The school has been sensitive to this criticism, notwithstanding that there have been ongoing independent reviews of the school.

The fact is that from 1992, next year, the allocation of resources is to be refereed externally by experts both in Australia and overseas, as well as by a Research Advisory Board which has a majority of seven external members.

If the John Curtin School is forcibly brought under the funding aegis of the NHMRC, there will be one sole source of funding for all Australian medical research. In such a centralised environment, the very real danger is that the John Curtin School's long term mission—its propensity for so-called `unfashionable' research—will be destroyed. It is a further example of this Government's distrust of higher education and scientific communities. They have to be somehow controlled and brought to heel, and the means chosen to achieve this is increasing centralisation.

The world scientific community is looking very hard at what the Government is doing in relation to the Australian National University at present. The world's most influential scientific journal, Nature, said in its editorial:

SPEECH.PARA: The future of the ANU will (or should) be a test case.
Professor Peter Karmel, one of Australia's most eminent and respected educationists, has said:
I do not think there is any doubt that the Government is attempting to destroy the Australian National University.
Doctor Coombs, a distinguished public servant, said:
. . . this is the beginning of a serious deterioration in the quality of education and research in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hulls Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak in this House today about leadership. It seems to be a relevant topic in the media and elsewhere at the moment. I must say that the media hype, hysteria and sense of fair play on this issue have been pathetic and appalling and, above all, unprofessional.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, the leadership I want to talk about is that which has not been grabbing national headlines. I am going talk about two great community leaders in north-west Queensland: the late Philip Yanner, who died earlier this month aged only 44 and who will be missed by everyone throughout the Gulf; and Tony McGrady, the State member for Mount Isa and, as of this week, the Minister for Resource Industries in the Goss Labor Government in Queensland.

When Philip Yanner died of a heart attack in Burketown on Saturday, 30 November, he was chairperson of the ATSIC Gulf Regional Council and a member of the Burketown Shire Council and of the Carpentaria Land Council. He was the key negotiator for the Aboriginal communities in the Gulf region in discussions with the mining giant CRA about the Century Mine development near Doomadgee. Most importantly, he was a supportive husband to his wife, Irene, and eight children. Whenever someone was needed on a committee to lobby for Aboriginal interests, Philip would be there. He was the most travelled man in the Gulf. The Century Mine project kept him especially busy playing a coordinating role between the Doomadgee and Mornington Island communities, the State Government and the company.

Philip's massive contribution to the Gulf communities was recognised at his funeral service attended by over 1,000 people in Burketown on 7 December. People came from Doomadgee, Mornington Island, Cairns, Mount Isa and Townsville. I was privileged to be a pallbearer at the funeral. Everyone spoke of Philip's tireless commitment to his people and to the difficulty of finding a leader of similar stature to step into his shoes. I have no doubt that the void left by Philip will be filled. As his son Jason said at the service, it is important that Philip's work continues.

I believe it is especially important that someone continues the vital job of looking after the interests of the Gulf communities in relation to the Century Mine development. I arranged for the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) to visit the Century Mine site as a guest of CRA in September and I am fully supportive of the Minister's intention to fast track the project. CRA has already spent millions of dollars on exploration feasibility studies and I am confident that the mine will be a great boost to the local economy in north-west Queensland and, more importantly, of course, to the Australian economy generally.

Nonetheless, fast tracking does not have to be at the expense of appropriate environmental and Aboriginal concerns. Aboriginal interests are not necessarily in conflict with the interest of mining companies, despite the new right banter of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), who, in his continuing campaign to polarise the Australian community, announced this week that he would reverse the Coronation Hill decision if he got into power. He has also announced a possible review of the World Heritage boundaries of the wet tropics area of North Queensland. Economic rationalism rules the day for Dr Hewson. He will not be listening to greenies or Aboriginal groups: stuff the environment, the next generation can worry about that, trample over Aboriginal beliefs and interests and make a mockery of our international human rights obligations, of our basic humanity.

Dr Hewson can operate only in cliches; in black and white. It is all or nothing; in fact, it is extremes. Our world, however, is complex; it is shades of grey; it is a multitude of competing interests. It does not respond on cue to mathematical formula. For example, as I understand it, the Gulf Aboriginal communities are very supportive of the Century Mine development, although they do have concerns about a proposed slurry pipeline to the Gulf of Carpentaria. The Aboriginal communities' concern is echoed by environmental groups and by the fishing industry in the Gulf, who fear the consequences of a spill from the pipeline. I am very keen to the see the mine go ahead. However, I also share the community concern about the pipeline plan. I have made my concerns known to CRA, as has the Queensland Government.

It is pleasing to see that CRA has made an undertaking to the Queensland Government that it will fully examine the option of moving concentrate from the mine site to port by rail through either Mount Isa or Cloncurry, despite the company's current preferred option being the pipeline to the Gulf. I plan to work very closely with the Queensland State Government to ensure that the railway option gets the thumbs up. Recommendations in the report of the Industry Commission on rail transport released in August this year, if implemented by the Queensland Government, could increase the viability of the rail option for CRA.

One of the major factors influencing CRA's preference for a pipeline to the Gulf over a rail link with, say, Townsville is the initial infrastructure cost coupled with ongoing freight costs. In Queensland mineral royalties are recovered through the Queensland Rail system. At page 276 of its report, the Industry Commission, in relation to Queensland Rail coal pricing policy, concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, the collection of `royalties' by means of excess rail charges: has advantaged Queensland relative to other States in the distribution of Commonwealth general revenue grants; hides the true facts about both royalties and freight rates; provides little opportunity for negotiating more efficient ways of running services; enables unprofitable QR services to be cross-subsidised; and undermines the possible economic gains from more efficient ways of collecting coal royalties.
The Industry Commission further recommended:

. . . super-normal profits, whether described as `royalties' or otherwise, should not be obtained via rail freight rates. In the case of Queensland, this could initially be achieved by identifying, and separating, the royalty component from the freight charge, and requiring that the royalty be paid directly to the Queensland Treasury.

For very obvious reasons, it is hard to imagine the Queensland Treasury being too enthusiastic about this idea. However, if we are serious about micro-economic reform in the transport industry, then we must ensure that freight is costed on a rational basis. Also for very obvious reasons, the Queensland Mining Council has strongly endorsed the Industry Commission's assessment of the State's rail freight policy.

PARA.TAB: I believe there is also a role for the Federal Government in terms of speeding up investment and infrastructure. Dr Hewson's free market extremism ignores the critical role that public infrastructure can play in development in this country. The views of a group of nine major managing directors in Australia, including CRA, BHP and CSR, are not half as gung-ho as Dr Hewson about a free for all, sink or swim economy.

Caroline Currie, lecturer in banking and finance at the University of Technology in Sydney, makes the point that the group of nine have called for policies that draw from both sides of the political spectrum. What she is saying is that simple New Right economic rationalism on its own is totally inappropriate.

I believe government must work with industry to develop infrastructure to facilitate investment. We should be extending the national rail network, developing ports and building third runways. We should also be working closely with CSIRO to ensure that we develop a manufacturing base to service our mining industry. I intend to work very closely with Queensland's new Minister for Resource Industries, Tony McGrady, to ensure that both the State and Federal governments do everything they can to facilitate the railway option for the Century project.

As I mentioned at the start of this speech, Tony McGrady is one of the great community leaders in the north-west. Tony was sworn in as a Minister in the Goss Labor Government in Queensland only this week. It is as a personal friend and as a parliamentary colleague that I congratulate Tony. Tony has been a leader in the Mount Isa community for many years. He was Mayor of Mount Isa from 1985 until his election to the State seat of Mount Isa in 1990.

He is an obvious choice for Minister for Resource Industries, having started out working in the smelters of Mount Isa Mines when he was 20 years of age. When Tony resigned from Mount Isa Mines to become Mayor, he was the head of the Public Relations Department at MIM.

Tony McGrady is a very strong advocate for the interests of country Queenslanders. He is a very persuasive and effective advocate for his seat of Mount Isa. He understands the mining industry. Tony, as Minister for Resource Industries, will now have a pivotal role to play in the CRA Century Mine development. I look forward to a long and fruitful working relationship with Tony, leading hopefully to a railway link from the Century Mine to the Mount Isa-Townsville railway line.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today Australia is locked into a crisis of confidence and has been for almost 18 months. The Government has lost confidence, the people of Australia have lost confidence in that Government and the Government itself is racked with crises. We have a double-barrelled effect of economic and political problems which the Government has forced upon the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: I want to touch on one major issue that that lack of confidence has caused in the Australian economy—unemployment and the effect it is having on our younger and older people who cannot get work. We have reached a national unemployment figure of 10.5 per cent, which is the worst level ever recorded in surveys by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. That figure does not include the hidden unemployed: spouses who are not eligible for benefits; students staying at school longer; people on training programs; and those who have simply given up and have stopped looking for employment because they know that employers have no confidence in this Government. The Government has no confidence in itself. Support for the two leadership aspirants is evenly poised and the Government is racked with divisions.

Almost one million people stand in the dole queues while the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) spends all of his time trying to save his job—as he has been for the past 18 months—rather than trying to find policies that will put people back into employment. Those people have been put out of work by the Government's policies. The leadership fight has been going on for at least 18 months, probably longer. Somebody suggested to me that it has been going on since 1988. People within the Government ranks would know better than I would. But the leadership fight has been going on since the so-called Kirribilli deal and the Prime Minister welshed on that deal for the transition process.

There is a lack of confidence in the Australian economy and the major contributor to this is the high level of unemployment. That lack of confidence, of course, has been forced upon us. We have been led into this recession by a Prime Minister who has lost contact with the Australian people, who has lost the true direction of where we should be heading, and the economy has been pushed into recession by the man who said it was the recession we had to have.

Country Victoria is suffering in the extreme from the Government's failed policies. In Bendigo, for example, the unemployment rate almost doubled between June 1990 and June 1991, jumping from 6.6 per cent to 12.8 per cent—those figures are from the Department of Employment, Education and Training. In nearby Eaglehawk, it climbed from 7.7 per cent in 1990 to 15.2 per cent in just 12 months. Bet Bet shire, which is a little further out in a rural area, recorded a jobless rate of 25.9 per cent for the 1991 June quarter—the highest figure in Victoria. Nationally, unemployment has now reached 10.5 per cent.

At 6.30 tonight Government members face a difficult choice. They can either stick with the Prime Minister who has led us into this recession or they can move over to the man who has pushed us into the recession we had to have.

It is anticipated that in Victoria the jobless rate will exceed 11 per cent. There have been predictions by sources close to the Government that it will, in fact, exceed 11.5 per cent by June next year. I want to know how much higher that figure will go before the Government turns its attention to the leadership squabble and sorts it out. We have the answer now; the time of reckoning is at 6.30 tonight.

I do not think it is going to make any difference at all whom the Government chooses to lead it, because we have had two people who have been working in concert for eight years; the man who led and the man who pushed Australia into that recession. There would be a number of honourable members in this House who—like the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe)—must be very unsure of their political futures, with unemployment leaping in his electorate from 4.2 per cent in June 1990 to 10.8 per cent in June 1991.

What we on the coalition side have done is prepare an economic package which will lead Australia out of the mess that it is in. What the Government has chosen to do is talk about destroying the Fightback package. The only comment that we have really heard from the Government is that it is going to destroy the Fightback package. It says nothing about rebuilding this country and creating jobs for the million people who are out of work. It has been talking only in terms of destruction. It says, `We are going to destroy something'.

It has already destroyed the Australian economy. It has got a million people out of work. Is it going to destroy the economy further? Are Government members not going to pick up any of the initiatives which we on the coalition side have spelt out? We have spelt out a total package. The Fightback package is one of the most comprehensive documents ever seen in the Australian community. It is so embracing that it touches on virtually every aspect of Australian life. It holds out hope for people's futures. It provides some reward for effort. Let people get out and work. Provide them with some incentive to get out and work and reward them. Do not penalise them with the terrible taxation system that we have now whereby the harder they work, the higher the tax bracket they move into, and the less take-home pay they receive.

The Fightback package is one which will inspire confidence in this nation. Already the support for my leader, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), has rocketed ahead. People want some guidance and they want some leadership. They want to move into the 1990s with confidence. They have no confidence in this Government at the moment, none at all. A change of leadership will make absolutely no difference, because all it will do is move the leadership from the leader to the one who pushed. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) acted in concert for 18 months, drove this country into recession, forced it deeper into the mire, and took away the confidence of the small businessman from business and the private sector. We are not going to see any encouragement at all.

Imagine if the honourable member for Blaxland gets the leadership of the Labor Party. The farming community has already been given a terrible deal by this Government. Farmers have been forced into a situation where the Government has given them virtually no support for at least 18 months—and certainly for a long period before then. The rural members of the community would have no confidence in a government led by the honourable member for Blaxland. They have little confidence in the present Prime Minister. They would have even less confidence in the honourable member for Blaxland, because the people from the rural sector know that his ideology would not be in their best interests.

A number of manufacturers have closed down in my electorate. There has been a lot of discussion about tariff reductions. I can tell the House that those manufacturing industries did not close down because of tariff reductions. They closed down because of a lack of sales. The retail trading figures in Australia have been down for some 18 months. Month by month retail sales have been dropping. The lack of orders and the lack of sales have been why many of these manufacturers have gone out of business, closed down and retrenched their staff.

There will be no confidence in Australia until an election is held and the Leader of the Opposition takes over as the Prime Minister of this country. Australia wants the Leader of the Opposition to lead it out of this mire. He has presented the Fightback package, which spells out the reforms which need to be carried out in this country. Reward for effort will be our number one objective. People will work hard and be rewarded, not penalised for their efforts in Australia. This is the sort of leadership that Australia is demanding. The Fightback package is being so well received because it gives people hope for the future. There is absolutely no hope under the present Administration, nor will there be, irrespective of who leads the Labor Party. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham Mr D.

TALK.START.PARA: —At midnight on Tuesday, 10 December the New South Wales Government passed legislation overturning the High Court's decision in Latoudis v. Casey (1990) 65 ALJR 151. The High Court decision gave people appearing before the Local Court on charges of criminal offences the same right to obtain costs as citizens in civil proceedings if the charges were dismissed.

PARA.TAB: Until recently in New South Wales and other States the Crown rarely had costs awarded against it when prosecutions failed. Citizens were left not only with the personal trauma of having had to face the courts, but also with the expense of legal representation. Until the High Court intervened, individual citizens had to bear the costs of prosecutorial errors. Mr Justice McHugh described this very aptly. At page 164 of the judgment, he said, `The result is unequal justice'. Now, unequal justice has been reintroduced in New South Wales in midnight legislation by a government that nine hours later lost its majority on the policy.

The Justices (Costs) Amendment Bill 1991 was passed at midnight on Tuesday, 10 December by the New South Wales Legislative Assembly. The vote in the chamber was 47-all, with one independent, Mr Macdonald Manly, voting with the Government, and the other three, Mr Hatton, Dr Metherell and Ms Moore, voting with the Opposition. The Bill passed because the Speaker cast his vote with the ayes. Nine-and-a-half hours later, the Liberal-National Party coalition lost that majority when Mr Acting Justice Slattery declared The Entrance election result invalid. The Bill was then rushed through the upper House the next day without the usual five days delay.

The New South Wales Government has taken away the citizen's ordinary expectation that, if a prosecution against him in the Local Court fails, the prosecution side should pay his costs. The ancient legal rule that the Crown is immune from paying costs was overturned in the 1970s. The High Court judgments argue powerfully that, on the balance of public interests, the police should pay the costs. At pages 153-54, the Chief Justice, Sir Anthony Mason, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The argument that police and other public officers charged with the enforcement of the criminal laws will be discouraged by the apprehension of adverse orders for costs from prosecuting cases which should be brought is without substance and is no longer accepted by the courts: see Ex parte Hivis: Hamdorf v Riddle; Puddy v Borg; Barton v Berman. The courts have rightly recognised that the Executive's practice of indemnifying police officers against payment of costs ordered against them undermines the argument which found favour long ago in Ex parte Jones (1906).
On page 153, the Chief Justice argued powerfully:

In ordinary circumstances it would not be just or reasonable to deprive a defendant who has secured the dismissal of a criminal charge brought against him or her of an order for costs. To burden a successful defendant with the entire payment of costs of defending the proceedings is in effect to expose the defendant to a financial burden which may be substantial, perhaps crippling, by reason of the bringing of a criminal charge which, in the event, should not have been brought. It is inequitable that the defendant should be expected to bear the financial burden of exculpating himself or herself, though the circumstances of a particular case may be such as to make it just and reasonable to refuse an order for costs or to make a qualified order for costs. As the Report of Committee on Costs in Criminal Cases (NZ, 1966) par.30, stated:
"Because we cannot wholly prevent placing innocent persons in jeopardy that does not mean that we should not as far as practicable mitigate the consequences".

The High Court left to the discretion of the courts the decision whether or not to make an order for costs where, for example, the defendant brought the prosecution upon himself by his conduct or unreasonably prolonged the hearing.

PARA.TAB: The New South Wales Government, however, has not permitted the courts to make a decision on the merits. Acquitted persons have to prove exceptional circumstances. They have to somehow have the resources of an Ombudsman or the National Crime Authority and prove that the police investigation was unreasonable or improper, that proceedings were initiated in bad faith or that the prosecution unreasonably failed to investigate matters.

The individual citizen has no way of doing this, particularly at a time when the Ombudsman's office cannot help as it is under-resourced and overworked. The only way such evidence could be obtained would be to turn each local court case into a royal commission into the police investigation, leading to even greater legal costs and even greater court delays.

The Justices (Costs) Amendment Act 1991 is legislation for unequal justice; a police incompetence tax on all unfortunate citizens wrongly brought before the local courts on criminal charges; and legislation passed at midnight by a government with a false majority. The New South Wales Legal Aid Commission, which is partly federally funded, will now have to bear the costs of successfully defended cases. What an absolute disgrace that is.

On page 22 of the Sun-Herald of 15 December 1991, Mr Chris Murphy, a Sydney criminal lawyer, exposed the disgraceful exhibition of the Greiner Government. In an article headed `New law on costs just a folly', he quite rightly says:
While you were sleeping, a despicable piece of legislation discriminating against poor people slid through State Parliament at midnight on Tuesday.

SPEECH.PARA: Further down the page, he says:

PARA.TAB: The Justices (Costs) Amendment Bill 1991 is a stinker and a shameful cost-cutting measure repugnant to fair-minded people. It means the innocent get to suffer twice. . . Nick Greiner was aware that Entrance MLA Bob Graham was in danger of losing his seat on Wednesday. . . With his vote also crucial to the legislation it was rushed through the night before. . . So much for the myth that law and politics are about justice and fairness.

SPEECH.PARA: The Greiner Government in New South Wales should be ashamed of itself. The people of New South Wales will exact retribution early next year when the people at The Entrance get an opportunity to rightfully place another Labor member in the State Parliament of New South Wales. What happened on that night was a despicable and shameful act by the Greiner Government, resulting in an Act which each of those who voted for it should be ashamed of.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Merry Christmas, everybody. First of all, I would like to congratulate Ray Groom on becoming the Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania. Ray is an old mate of mine. He will do a very good job. I am sorry to see Robin Gray go out; he was a tenacious fighter against the Greens. I repeat at the end of the year: I hate the Greens in Tasmania for what they have done to the economy of Tasmania. I will hate them next year, too. But by the end of next year the Labor Green accord will not be in government. I heard my friend the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) talking about Mr Greiner and saying that we will have another Labor member in. My heavens, what the Labor Party has done to Tasmania is nobody's business.

PARA.TAB: Many people are unemployed: jobs are going left, right and centre every day. And to think that honourable members opposite can come into this House and praise the Labor Party and think that they are going to be the end of all the woes in Tasmania! I repeat: the Labor-Green accord in Tasmania has done nothing but damage. The quicker the media down there gets the message not to continually praise people like Christine Milne and Bob Brown and make gods of them when in fact they are ruining the economy of Tasmania, the better.

On a nicer note, I hope Ray Groom does a good job for Tasmania. I am sure that he will. He has six lovely children—I do not know whether that means much in politics—four nice boys and two lovely girls. He has a lovely wife. I am sure that they will do a good job for Tasmania. That is what it is all about. Happy Christmas, everybody. To all my friends in Tasmania and to all the people in this gallery, happy Christmas.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Misrepresentation by the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Ford) occurred on 28 November in respect of Mr Mark Leibler's response to three speeches by me on the Australian Taxation Office, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot vouch for the authenticity of what is contained in Mr Leibler's letters—
Yet paradoxically he then added:
. . . the unprovoked attacks on him by the honourable member for Deakin are unfounded.

All of my three speeches of 7 March, 5 September and 8 October were highly detailed and heavily backed by tabled documents. Furthermore, reference was made to an out of context quote from a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) to Mr Leibler on 2 October which, I must point out, also stated:

It is, of course, an absolute right of members to speak freely in the Parliament and this is certainly so in the traditions of the Liberal Party. The concerns you raise have been discussed with Mr Aldred who stands by what he said in the Parliament.

Later, on 28 November, the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) claimed that he had written to me on this matter on 6 November seeking withdrawal of my comments about Mr Leibler and had never received a reply. I had, in fact, replied by internal parliamentary mail on 20 November. In view of this claim, I subsequently sent another copy of the same reply to the honourable member's electorate office through Australia Post on 13 December.

PARA.TAB: My comments are not withdrawn and much of my speech on 8 October actually dealt with Mr Leibler's response. As my call for an inquiry into the ATO is now before the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts, I add nothing further except to note who have been flushed out as the aggrieved protectors of Mr Leibler's most interesting record.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to extend to my colleagues in the Opposition the best wishes for Christmas and to remind them once again of the difficulties they are going to have in selling their goods and services tax to the Australian people. Why will they have trouble explaining to people like those in the galleries that a 15 per cent consumption tax is a good idea? The reason they will have trouble is that it is so unfair. Those in the Opposition are trying to tell people in the galleries that they should pay 15 per cent more for bread, milk, train fares, food and clothing. What is going to be cheaper? Mercedes Benzes, BMWs and Ferraris. If those opposite think that is fair, there is something wrong with their logic.

PARA.TAB: What about the income tax cuts? The Opposition says, `Don't worry. It might be unfair but we will cut your income tax. If you are on $20,000 a year, you will be 5 per cent better off, but if you are on $75,000 a year you are 15 per cent better off'. So even the cuts in income tax are just as unfair as the increases in prices for basic commodities. The people on this side of the House are very determined to ensure that, when the people have a say on this tax, they will understand the basic inequality and unfairness of this proposal.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the House to move a motion censuring the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) for his disastrous handling of education, particularly in relation to government.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—The Chair will not entertain another motion. Ninety-second statements have been called on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today in absolute disgust at this excuse for a Labor Party government. A telephone call was received in my electorate office 25 minutes ago from Mrs Wilson of Boronia. Mrs Wilson was very quick and succinct. She said, `I would just like to lodge my utter disgust with the Labor Party and what the Labor Party is doing to this country, and what Hawke and Keating are doing. I am never going to vote for them again'. It is disgusting.

PARA.TAB: I note that in the electorate of the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), the electorate of Holt in the city of Dandenong, the Red Cross has just opened its first soup kitchen since the Great Depression of the 1930s. Local charity and aid groups have expressed support for the kitchen, but the unemployment is so devastating—and it is not finished yet, Mr Secretary to the Prime Minister of another few minutes. It is not finished yet. Unemployment is still rising. The newspapers daily cite thousands and tens of thousands of jobs yet to be shed over the rest of this year and next year. Where are the people going to find work? Where are the kids going to get training? How are they going to get places in school when the places are not available? The Labor Party sits there and destroys itself and destroys the country while we witness a fight between two men for one job.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be accused of being a candidate for another office, but I wish to respond to the comments of the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) in his attacks on the Labor Party for increases in unemployment. I think it is fair to say that it is easy to be wise in hindsight. This Government increased interest rates a number of years ago because it thought that the economy was overheating. In hindsight, perhaps we should have eased those interest rates more quickly than we did.

PARA.TAB: But what was the Opposition's policy throughout that period? What was the Opposition saying when perhaps the Government should have eased interest rates a little more quickly, so that we did not have unemployment as high as we have today? The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) said that we were easing interest rates too quickly. The people who are saying that unemployment is too high now wanted higher interest rates and therefore higher unemployment than we have today.

I think it is a bit rich that the Opposition says that unemployment is too high, when it was putting forward an alternative economic policy that would have resulted in higher interest rates and higher unemployment. Yet the Opposition has the hide to come out with this Fightback package which claims that it will be creating two million new jobs by the year 2000. When the Government asks the Opposition what is the basis of its scenario C in the computer model, we find that the basis assumes that there is no GST. The Opposition comes forward with a proposal that says it is going to create two million jobs because of GST, on condition that there is no GST. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —On many occasions in the Parliament we have heard those opposite speak of the corrupt non-Labor politicians in Queensland. In particular, we have heard ad nauseam from the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) and the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) about non-Labor politicians in Queensland having their snouts in the financial trough. I wonder how they now react to the events of the last couple of weeks in Brisbane, which show unquestionably that such a trough is a communal one from which a number of Queensland Labor politicians also have dined, and dined very well indeed.

PARA.TAB: As a result, Premier Goss has been forced into accepting the resignations of two of his Ministers and the Deputy Speaker of the Queensland Parliament. One of these ex-Ministers has departed the scene with little grace and continues his vehemence against the police and the judiciary. Clearly, a lot of the Goss gloss is wearing off and the Premier is experiencing pressures similar to those that are proliferating by the minute in the Labor corridors of this Parliament House. Like our very temporary Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)—and 6.30 tonight, of course, is H-hour—Premier Goss is under increasing political pressures, inside and outside the environs of George Street.

Premier Goss's honeymoon is now over and I welcome the Liberal-National Party alliance announced last weekend. I wish Joan Sheldon and Bob Borbidge every success in the lead-up to next year's State election. I congratulate Paul Everingham and Don McDonald on their organisational initiative which has demonstrated to the Queensland people that there is a viable alternative to Goss and the Labor machine. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, Mr Speaker, I wish you, our parliamentary colleagues and the staff of the Parliament the best wishes for this season. I trust that the Australian people have a peaceful 1992.

PARA.TAB: I wish to speak about the question of dumping in Australia. I note a report in yesterday's press which referred to the dumping of canned tomatoes in Australia and which reflects the grave concern that I have that our anti-dumping mechanisms are completely bureaucratic and slow. I might add that recently a report on cement in Australia was released by the Anti-Dumping Authority. Three-and-a-half years ago, members of the Labor Caucus took up the issue of cement being dumped in Australia. It has taken 3 1/2 years to get to the stage where it has issued a report saying that there was a case for dumping.

Whether one is talking about tomatoes, citrus, pasta, chocolates, biscuits or the situation with cement, the reality is that dumping has occurred in Australia and the current anti-dumping mechanism is overly bureaucratic and excessively slow. I put the point that, where the landed price in Australia is below the price in the country of origin of that import, then there is a prima facie case of dumping. It should therefore be on the importer to demonstrate that that good has not been dumped in Australia. We need to reform our dumping system because I believe the current system is ineffective. It certainly does not protect manufacturers who, in fact, very often suffer damage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express the bipartisan concern that is felt in this House about the toxic bloom that has occurred in the River Darling. I express this concern as a South Australian because the water on which I depend as an irrigator and on which Adelaide people depend for all other tasks is, of course, fed from the Darling River through the Murray-Darling Basin Commission.
—It is a national tragedy.

—It is a national tragedy, as the honourable member for Stirling points out. Taking this brief opportunity, I want to point out that it has been wrong simply to blame agriculturalists for this algae bloom. In fact, much of the algae bloom exists because, even in 1991, the disposal of effluent from towns along the Murray-Darling system, including towns in South Australia, tends to occur on the river flats, so effluent makes its way into the water system.

PARA.TAB: It is an indictment of the Government that after nine years so little has been done in the way of infrastructure reform that it has been possible for this sort of ad hoc and antiquated effluent disposal to continue on the river flats. I call on the Government to make greater resources available to river towns, on both the Darling and the Murray, so that effluent disposal currently undertaken on the river flats can be undertaken on higher ground. If this happens, the chemicals which invariably flow into the water as a result of effluent disposal will no longer find their way into the water, but will flow into an area which does not harbour toxic growth. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon to support the call by Mr Grant McBride, the Labor candidate in the upcoming by-election for The Entrance in New South Wales, for an initiative for the Sydney Olympics 2000 bid. I hope it would have the support of honourable members opposite. My good friend Grant McBride argued last weekend that if Sydney is successful in winning the year 2000 Olympics then perhaps there is time to consider the introduction of surf-lifesaving as a demonstration sport. Mr McBride has suggested that some of Australia's best beaches on the central coast of New South Wales would perhaps be a suitable venue for holding surf-lifesaving as a demonstration Olympic sport.

PARA.TAB: I hope that honourable members opposite will be more than keen, in the spirit of Christmas, to support the Labor candidate's call for this to be introduced as a demonstration sport.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I will not support it. We want it in Tasmania.

—We can certainly assure the honourable member for Franklin that we have not only the best and the cleanest beaches, but also the best surf. We can ensure that the events would be suitable competition for countries competing and we would certainly ensure that, like tennis at the Seoul Olympics, surf-lifesaving could be something that all Australians could be proud of at the Sydney Olympics 2000.

—Mr Speaker, I pass on my festive greetings to you and best wishes also to the Australian people. That is certainly not what will be delivered by this Government. We have heard the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) and the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards). They seem to be forgetting that they are actually in government. So let us not talk about anti-dumping legislation; let us not talk about the approach to it. Let us talk about the honourable members opposite who have been sitting there for the last 10 years doing absolutely nothing about it. When they are out of government, we will do something about the dumping laws. We will do something about making this nation competitive again and we will start putting our own industries in a competitive position.

PARA.TAB: The `Which Way Ballarat?' campaign started about three months ago. Efforts have been made to see senior government officials for the last three months, yet there has been hardly a reply from them, let alone a positive response. In the region of Ballarat, the unemployment rate is 24 per cent. That means that a lot of people will have a miserable Christmas. I do not care whether it is this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or the one we might get at 6.30 p.m.; they both should go. If Government members have any intestinal fortitude, they will put in someone who is going to make a real impact on this country; they will not put in the two who have destroyed it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—I heard the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) talking about Queensland politics. All I can say is that if Borbidge and Sheldon are the answer in Queensland, it must have been a pretty silly question.
—Order! The House will come to order. It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—I inform the House that the Governor-General has appointed the Hon. Ralph Willis as Treasurer, the Hon. Kim Beazley as Minister for Finance and the Hon. John Kerin as Minister for Transport and Communications. Mr Kerin will represent the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support in this House. Mr Willis will continue to represent the Minister for Industrial Relations.

PARA.TAB: I also inform the House that this morning the Governor-General appointed the Hon. Robert Tickner as Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, the new title more accurately reflecting his responsibilities.

The Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe, will be absent from the House today. The Hon. Peter Staples is Acting Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Mr Beazley will be representing the Minister for Social Security.

The Minister for Local Government, the Hon. Wendy Fatin, will be absent from Question Time today. In her absence, questions should be directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Hon. Gerry Hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. What sort of Christmas is it going to be for the one million unemployed to have Mr Recession back as Prime Minister?
—I am not commenting in this House on the internal affairs of my Party.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

— The question of who will be leading this Party and who will be Prime Minister of Australia will be decided by my Party in a ballot at 6.30 this afternoon. Let me say this, and I say this with absolute certainty: I cannot speak with certainty about the outcome of that ballot.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—For how long?

TALK.START.PARA: —But I can say this with certainty: whoever is leading this Government after this evening will ensure for now and into the future that the people of this country will have not only an infinitely better Christmas but every day an infinitely better day than if they had to suffer under the alternative government.

—I direct my question to the Treasurer. I refer him to the claims being made by Liberals and Nationals that all Australians would be made better off if a goods and services tax were introduced. If this is so, would the Treasurer please advise the House why the Government has repeatedly refused to introduce such a tax?
—You argued for it in 1984 and 1985.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.

—I have seen such reports. Of course, the Opposition's so-called Fightback package is based on the introduction of a goods and services tax. As the honourable member for Capricornia says, it is claimed by the Opposition that it would make all categories of Australian households better off. There is an inherent implausibility about a proposition which says that if we were to cut income tax and some other taxes and introduce a goods and services tax, and then cut expenditure and government outlays by several billion dollars, suddenly every household in Australia would be better off.

PARA.TAB: On the face of it, this would seem to be a rather implausible proposition and, on analysis, it has proved to be exactly that—a proposition which has no substance in truth. Analysis by the Federal Treasury shows that the great majority of full time wage and salary earner households and self-employed and farm households would be worse off as a result of the Opposition's package.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for McPherson!

—There are two major reasons for that difference. The first relates to the expenditure cuts of several billion dollars. The Opposition said that there would be $10 billion of expenditure cuts; the Department of Finance said that it was more like $7 1/2 billion. Seven-and-a-half billion dollars is still a lot of expenditure cuts. When Opposition members did the distribution of the impact of their package to households, do you know what they forgot to do? They forgot to include the expenditure cuts. The $7 1/2 billion of expenditure cuts, much of which goes to households, is not in the distribution.
—That is stupid, so stupid.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—Mr Speaker, for a start you see the absolute fraudulent nature of the proposition from Opposition members when they simply leave out a very important element of the package in terms of distribution to households and then try to con the Australian people into believing that this is something that is going to benefit every one of them. What a load of rubbish. The Opposition also says in relation to the tax bracket creep—`creep' perhaps is appropriate in terms of the Leader of the Opposition—that it will be returned to the taxpayers and in doing this—
—You are another Brian Howe. Kerin was better than this. Bring back Kerin.
—Order! The House will come to order. If the honourable member for Mayo interjects again I will name him.

—Those opposite say it will be returned to the taxpayers, but they use it as part of the means of compensating for the goods and services tax. Tax bracket creep is an increase in tax which comes about because of the impact of inflation. As people's income goes up with inflation, their average tax rate goes up because more of their income is taxed at higher marginal tax rates. That means that return of tax bracket creep is needed to compensate for the increase in tax itself. So when tax bracket creep is returned it is not done as compensation for some other tax; it is done in compensation for the fact that there has been an increase in tax, which is the tax bracket creep itself. But the Opposition gives back the tax bracket creep to many taxpayers—in fact, the bulk of them—as part of the compensation for the goods and services tax, another tax entirely. So they are using the one tax cut to pay both for the return of tax bracket creep—
—Order! The honourable member for Goldstein!

—That is, the increase in tax that comes from that area—and the other tax, the goods and services tax. So it is a complete rort, an absolute and complete con of the Australian people. Our analysis shows that all taxpayers earning under $40,000 per annum would receive less—
—Kerin was better.
—Order! The honourable member for Mackellar will cease interjecting.

—They would receive less by way of the Opposition tax cuts than would be needed to cover both the return of tax bracket creep and compensation for the goods and services tax. That is all of those earning under $40,000, which of course is the vast bulk of taxpayers. So the Opposition package is a complete con. Rather than providing net benefits to all households, the reality is that, after taking account of those expenditure cuts that can be included in the analysis—and many of them could not be included in our analysis because it was not statistically possible to do it—and the tax bracket creep con, we find that over 70 per cent of full time wage and salary earner households are worse off when all the things that can be taken into account in statistical analysis are taken into account, as are over 60 per cent of self-employed and farm households. All of that is without taking into account the road user charge which members of the Opposition implacably committed themselves to in the Fightback! document.
—The honourable member for McPherson will cease interjecting.

—They have since said, `No, we won't have one that is fuel based', but they have not walked away from one—well, not that I have noticed—which is not fuel based. If they are going to remain committed to this micro-economic reform which they talk so much about, then presumably they will go ahead with such a charge.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mackellar.

—In that case we would have over 80 per cent of full time wage and salary earner households worse off and 70 per cent of self-employed and farmers worse off. So in response to the honourable member for Capricornia may I say that there is no way, for the reasons that I have given, that we will be introducing a goods and services tax. We will be exposing to the Australian people what a complete pack of cons and crooks the people opposite are in trying to put a proposition to them which is a total fraud.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Why would Senator McKiernan say that there are over 900,000 reasons why the honourable member for Blaxland should not be Prime Minister?

—The unfortunate fact of political life is that we have the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in this House as a member. If he wants to ask in the appropriate place for the answer to that question, he should be in the Senate and address it to Senator McKiernan.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. It relates to the proposed mid-year—
—If the honourable member for Gilmore interjects again I will name him.

—My question relates to the proposed mid-year economic review. Is it intended that the review include consideration of industry policy, and will the Prime Minister undertake to examine the proposal to `securitise' the wool stockpile?

—If I may, I will take the second part of the question first. Yes, I am aware of such a proposal. All of us on both sides of the House are deeply concerned about the terrible conditions currently prevailing in our rural industries and, therefore, the importance of the Government's doing all that it responsibly can to assist rural industries.

PARA.TAB: Against that background, I am perfectly happy to say to the honourable member for Kennedy that we will undertake to have the proposal for `securitisation' of the wool stockpile, possibly through zero coupon bonds, to which the honourable member refers, examined and, if that examination shows the proposal to have merit, then to have the proposal acted upon.

I come to the wider issues raised by the honourable member's question. Our common starting point is a concern about the apparent slowness with which the recovery is proceeding, a concern given prominence and given substance by the preliminary results of the current review of the Budget forecasts. In responding to that concern, the review of the stance of policy to which the Treasurer—with my full concurrence—referred should, I believe, encompass all relevant policy arms and areas. It is my clear view that that should include a sectoral approach to industry policy, given the obvious successes it has had in areas such as the steel industry.

I believe that Australians have a great capacity for innovation, a great capacity to develop new ideas, new processes and new products. This belief has been strongly reinforced by recent discussions I have held with my science council and through the establishment of the now 35 cooperative research centres. Accordingly, I say in conclusion to the honourable gentleman that the review of policy I have scheduled for the early part of next year will be looking closely at ways of extending and building on our existing programs to ensure that we make maximum use of this valuable skill.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this extraordinary day my question is also directed to the Prime Minister. In December of last year, the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland said, `No one person and no one factor determines the overall state of the economy. The important point is that I'—meaning Mr Keating—`accept the responsibility for managing it'. Does the Prime Minister accept this analysis, and how critical was the role of the honourable member for Blaxland, as Treasurer, in creating the current recession, which is crippling our great nation?

—I simply make these points briefly in answer to the honourable gentleman's question: the honourable member for Blaxland, in his capacity as Treasurer of the Hawke Government for such a long period, played a critically important role in all the major economic decisions that we undertook. In that respect he is entitled to a very significant measure of credit for the—
—Ha! For one million unemployed!

—He is entitled to a considerable measure of credit for the great successes that were achieved in this country for the period from 1983 until the time of the recession. I remind the honourable gentleman again, without wearying him again with the facts, which I know he does not like to accommodate or understand, that during that period, under my Government and with the honourable member for Blaxland as Treasurer, we achieved in terms of employment, which those opposite keep talking about, a rate of employment growth four times faster than those opposite achieved and a rate of employment growth twice as fast as the rest of the world achieved. All of us are entitled to share with the Treasurer the credit for that period.

PARA.TAB: Equally, I have to say that the Treasurer of the time has to accept—as he has publicly done—a considerable degree of responsibility for what has happened since then, as we all do. This is the situation that prevails as a result of policies that were undertaken and also as a result, obviously, of conditions over which the Government has no control.
There is very little that either the honourable member for Blaxland or I can do about the drought.
Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—There is very little that anyone can do in this country about the level of prices that we have received for our major export commodities, other than what this Government has done par excellence to take a leading role in the Uruguay Round of negotiations to ensure that out of those negotiations we get a more sane international trading system within which the world's biggest competitive agricultural producers, the Australian farmers, have a better chance of getting a decent price for what they produce.
—You are beginning to sound like Malcolm Fraser. Do you realise that?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Higgins.

—I simply conclude my answer by saying: yes, the former Treasurer has to accept responsibility for many things, the pluses and the minuses, but they are responsibilities that all of us have to take some share in.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. Can he inform the House of the outcome of the analysis by the Department of Finance of the outlays measures proposed in the Opposition's Fightback package? What are the Government's intentions in this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can inform the honourable member of my Department's analysis of the Opposition's Fightback package and its impact, if ever implemented, on outlays. The Leader of the Opposition always describes the Government's figures as fraudulent or mistaken or whatever, and again it has been repeated by him. I must say that, were this country ever in the unhappy position of finding him assuming the prime ministership and were he to present this package as the policy he intended to implement, the advice that would come to him would be the advice that was tendered to the public on that package a week or so ago by my colleague the then Minister for Finance, Mr Willis.

PARA.TAB: The analysis is not a document cobbled together by Access Economics or a document cobbled together by individual Ministers of the Government. It is a document with the reliability of the departments behind it, those departments that would advise the Opposition were it in government.

There is no sense in the Leader of the Opposition's wandering around the country, as he does, and standing in front of shopping baskets while trying to explain that the Government's figures on the goods and services tax—a tax that imposes the most punitive rates ever of a goods and services tax on the necessities of life—and its impact on the average citizen are somehow or other mistaken. My friend, I will stack the Department of Finance up against Access Economics any day. If the honourable member ever gets into office as Prime Minister and intends to operate without the departments of Finance and Treasury, and uses Access Economics, he had better let the public know that now, because it is something they are obviously going to need to know in a big hurry.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one believes you. They believe him.
—Order! The honourable member for Kooyong will cease interjecting.

—That analysis points out that the Opposition package as presented is not implementable. Those opposite will simply be obliged to make choices. If they attempt to implement it, either they will have to reduce the compensation package or they will have to review some of the outlays that they intend to put in place. Remember it is not just a $10 billion cutback they are claiming; they have also got $6 billion outlays put forward. They are actually operating in a very narrow area of $4 billion, almost all of which, on the revenue and on the outlays side, they have lost. Effectively, they have lost three quarters of it. If they fail to do that, they have another alternative, which is to not proceed with some of the income tax cuts or, alternatively, to increase the size of the goods and services tax, which they have ruled out.

PARA.TAB: Whatever particular choice they make—and if they ever got into office, they would probably choose a combination of all of them—it will have a major impact on the distributional effects and it will mean, unimpeachably, that the ordinary Australian will be worse off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you tell the truth?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—Tell the truth! That comes from an honourable member whose sole contribution so far to public life in this country has been the organisation of the penguin parade in Port Phillip Bay. When he wanders around the country and actually asks about this, he does not debate the issue. What he does is stand up and say, `Weigh it'. In the final analysis, the defence of the Opposition's Fightback package is defence by weight. The Opposition says that because the package has 600 pages—it does not matter if half of them are plagiarised—it is a package to be believed. That is the Opposition's point of view. Those opposite come around and say, `Don't question our package. Just look at the size of it. There are 600 pages'. What we can do is get 600 pages from some other report and stick them in, or stick in the whole of the New Zealand goods and services tax package, which would add another 20 or 30 pages to it. It is defence by weight.

PARA.TAB: That was the position taken by the Department of Finance on the criteria put down by the Opposition. If we had dealt with this as a political exercise—not simply relied upon the Department to put forward its propositions in relation to the Opposition's assumptions and had put our own views on the achievability of the package—we would have had other things to say as well. For example, the Department of Finance gave the Opposition $200m in the defence package. The Department said, `We agree with the Opposition; it is possible for them to get $200m in defence'. The Opposition said, `Finance does not consider the extent of savings proposed to allow redirection of resources which, as indicated in the Opposition policy, can be achieved from administrative and support areas and rigorous application of commercialisation reforms on top of measures already factored into defence planning'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Table it! Table it! It has taken you a month to dream this up.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mitchell.

—The Department of Finance has said, `Yes, you can make those savings, but you must reduce defence capability'. The balderdash those opposite run around the country with, about finding $500m or $300m and devoting it to the pointy end of defence, is a load of rubbish. If the Opposition chooses to take that $200m, it will make a decision as to whether or not this country is defended. If the Opposition takes off the $200m, it will decide it is not to be defended. If the Opposition leaves it in because it decides to get responsible for a minute, that is another $200m out the back door from its package.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition talks about cutting funding for Austrade. Finance gave the Opposition $70m for that. The Department of Finance says of the Opposition's package:

ANSWER.PARA: The implications are that Australia will be less well represented by Commonwealth Government representatives in this area than it would otherwise be. This has implications for Australia's ability to promote its exports as well as its reputation in the international community. Possibly the gap could be filled by the other players identified but this is by no means guaranteed as Austrade was set up in 1986 because of the failure of these other bodies to do the work effectively.

We can go through just about every one of those cuts that Finance gives the Opposition and point out the public policy reasons as to why they cannot be achieved. This is supposed to be a document about the recovery of this nation. It is not. It is a document about a tenth order priority, mucking around with the taxation system. The real priorities in this country concern what happens in the labour market, which occupied 1 1/2 pages in the 600-page Fightback package, and what happens in micro-economic reform, which gets a couple of guest mentions in the Fightback package.

PARA.TAB: This package is a cobbled together excuse to get people to believe a 1980s obsession: the effort by the then adviser to the Treasurer of the day to get in place a goods and services tax because it was a really terrific idea. That was an effort made in the early 1980s; as a result of that the Opposition has produced a 1980s package. If those opposite do not think that will be exposed over the next 15 months, they have another think coming. It will be, and is being, thoroughly exposed. That is the situation, and as time goes by it will get worse and worse for the Opposition.

No goods and services tax or its equivalent operating anywhere has as draconian an impact on the essentials of life as the one proposed in the Opposition's package. The vast number of goods and services tax packages exclude necessities of life. Many of the goods and services tax-type operations have differential rates, so that luxuries are taxed at higher rates than more ordinarily used products. The public will learn over the next 15 months that this is a gigantic steal from the pockets of ordinary Australians to benefit massively the very wealthy in this country, and they will not take to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the Prime Minister not agree that the hundreds of thousands of Australians who have lost their jobs because of the economic mismanagement of his Government might see it as poetic justice that he should also lose his job, yet would regard it as a travesty of justice if that job were to go to the honourable member for Blaxland, who carries an even greater share of the blame for the cheerless and jobless Christmas that they and their families will undoubtedly face?

—I have indicated in answer to a previous question that I am not going to comment in this House on the internal affairs of the Australian Labor Party. The difficulties that we have will be addressed within the Party. I will not canvass them on the floor of this House.

PARA.TAB: In regard to the rest of the honourable gentleman's question, as far as I am concerned the future of this country will be determined by the people of Australia when we go to the polls in 1993 on the basis of their intelligent perception of where their interests lie, whether they be with the Australian Labor Party, which will put clearly to them policies which are based upon the fundamental premise that it is the responsibility of government to govern for all Australians and to ensure that the capacities of government are most directed to help those most in need, or whether, by way of alternative to that principled approach by a Labor Government, they be with choosing instead policies which are manifestly based on the tory premise, as my colleague the Minister for Finance has said, that the function of government is to attack the most needy in the community and redistribute from those most in need to those least in need. That will be the test Australians will have to apply. I am confident that in 1993, when Australians are confronted with that choice of fundamental political principle, they will show the intelligence to vote for the Australian Labor Party Government of the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Treasurer seen reports relating to baskets of commonly purchased supermarket goods and likely price movements under different indirect tax regimes? Has the Government analysed any of these baskets in order to determine the accuracy of possible price movements? What are the results of these analyses?

—I have seen various news reports of the Leader of the Opposition posing in supermarkets and pretending that the introduction of a goods and services tax would not cost the people of Australia very much. In that context, he has endorsed a survey conducted by a Queensland-based supermarket group which estimated the impact of a goods and services tax on a shopping basket of groceries at 4.8 per cent. On the face of it, this would appear to be a somewhat surprising figure, given that many items in a supermarket are food items which currently carry no wholesale sales tax themselves. Obviously there are other elements of tax which come into it, but when one takes account of all of those items—
—Have you?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—the Treasury estimates that food prices would increase by between 9 and 9 1/2 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Members on my left will cease interjecting.
—Ralph knows it is a joke.
—Order! I warn the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

—I will frown if the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would prefer. Why does this basket that the Leader of the Opposition thinks is so typical only cost 4.8 per cent more? The basket seems to be very heavy in some areas. It is extremely heavy in pet food—it contains seven kilos of pet food. The dog and the cat are going to be all right. This is also a household that is very clean. It has masses of cleaning products: disinfectant, dishwashing liquid, stain remover, starch, laundry detergent, household cleaning spray, toilet cleaner and bleach. The householders are strong not only on keeping the house clean, but on keeping themselves clean.
—Order! The member for McPherson will cease interjecting.

—This basket contains tissues, toilet rolls, toilet soap, toothpaste, shampoo, conditioner and baby powder. But all of these cleaning items and the pet food carry wholesale sales tax. So the Opposition has chosen a very heavy loading of items that carry a wholesale sales tax. Of course, the difference between the goods and services tax and the items carrying the wholesale sales tax is going to be much less than if there is no such wholesale sales tax applying to an item. There is a very substantial representation of items carrying wholesale sales tax.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, there are the basics or bare necessities of life such as bread. The basket contains one loaf of bread and a packet of bread rolls. Although there is a container of baby powder, there is no milk and there is no baby food either. If this baby is being fed by a lactating mother, that mother will have to go awfully light on the meat. There is one chicken and a small packet of bacon; that is the only meat. This is supposed to be a typical basket of goods costing $140. What an absurd proposition. This is a loaded basket to try to make it appear that the cost of going to the supermarket is not going to be very much more. It is deliberately loaded with the items which include the current wholesale sales tax. The message of all this is: if you want to survive under the goods and services tax, you will have to learn how to eat Pal and drink Harpic.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Honourable Member for Blaxland: Rural Industry

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. How is it that on the eve of Christmas, with the highest level of unemployment since the Great Depression, his Government can be so hopelessly bereft of policy solutions to Australia's economic problems—particularly those of rural Australia—that a desperate, illogical and panic stricken Labor Caucus could consider, even for a second, rewarding the person most responsible for all the pain of the recession with the country's top job?

—I suppose I can most easily and most briefly answer the question from the honourable gentleman by saying that, yesterday, I had the pleasure and the privilege of meeting, together with my Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, with representatives of the National Farmers Federation. I would assume that I am more likely to get some objective observations about the merit attached to the Government's policies from the representatives of the National Farmers Federation than I am from the jaundiced collection of individuals opposite. I am very pleased and proud indeed to say that that very congenial and constructive meeting concluded with the President of the National Farmers Federation unqualifiedly expressing his gratitude to me and my Minister for the policies of this Government in the areas affected by them.
—That is a laugh; that is a real laugh.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.

—I will take the assessment of the President of the National Farmers Federation in this matter and say that his assessment is correct—that this Government is fundamentally concerned with adopting policies to deal with the problems confronting the people of this country. In the area of fundamental concern to National Party members, there is no doubt that the truth is that, increasingly, the farmers of this country are coming to understand that the National Party has sold them out—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—What the National Party has done is to succumb to the blandishments of the Liberal Party. It is saying to people in the farming and rural communities of this country—many of whom, because of the situation in regard to farm prices, are paying no income tax—`We will give you a massive increase in your tax bill by embracing the concept of a goods and services tax, and we say to you that you will be compensated by a reduction in your income tax'. Bad luck when you are not paying any income tax. What a deal! Those of my members who represent rural and provincial seats are looking forward to the next election with a great deal of confidence, because not only will they hold their seats; they will hold them with an increased majority and we will take further seats from those opposite.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. In view of the importance to the national economy of the coal industry, is the Minister able to inform the House of any recent initiatives which the Government has taken to strengthen the competitiveness and stability of this important industry?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I know that he has taken a very strong interest in the future of the coal industry and the change which has been undergone in that industry. The coal industry today represents our largest export earner—some $6 billion.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—The reality is that it has got there only because it has undergone fundamental restructuring through the cooperation of management and the work force and through micro-economic reforms initiated by this Government. In the period this Government has been in office, coal production has increased by 57 per cent and coal loading productivity has increased 3 1/2 times. The coal loader at Newcastle, which I had the opportunity to visit on a recent occasion, is now the most efficient coal loading facility in the world.
