Yet people on the other side still rabbit on about nothing happening on the waterfront, which was always said by those opposite and some of those in the gallery to be the litmus test of this Government's performance in the area of micro-economic reform. Not only in coal do we have the most productive loading facility in the world, but in wheat as well.
—If the honourable member for Gilmore interjects again, I will name him.

—We do not have too many questions from the honourable member for Gilmore these days on these areas of micro-economic reform. If we look at a press release from the Wheat Board recently, we see that it is now saying that Australia's wheat loading facilities are also amongst the most efficient in the world. Have a look at the figures and understand the extent to which micro-economic reform has been effected. It has been effected because we have had a strategy to drive it and because we have actively worked to get management and labour together.

PARA.TAB: I remember that when I was in the ACTU the coal industry was almost a basket case because the unions were not prepared to embrace change. The reason for that productivity increase—and I know the honourable member for Bennelong will be interested in this—is the restructuring process and workplace reform that we have overseen the implementation of. On the back of that, I think it is important to recognise the important initiative that this Government announced at the beginning of this month to enhance further the capacity and the future growth of the coal industry. The coal industry package—

TALK.START.PARA: —Our policy.
—Your policy! Come in, spinner! I will tell members opposite about their policy. They had a policy in 1976, and I am happy to table it. I know that they have a policy now.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. I warn the honourable member for McPherson.

—Those opposite argue that we stole their policy on the coal export duty. They had a policy; we have acted. That is the big difference. The month after I came to this portfolio, industry sought talks with me concerning the abolition of the coal export duty. I commenced those discussions in September and the outcome of the coal industry package announced on 2 December reflected those discussions.

PARA.TAB: But what did we get in return? It is important to understand this because it is the fundamental difference between our approach to industry policy and the approach of those opposite. Those opposite seem to think that they are going to get industry going by simply changing the tax mix, rather than by using the leverage of their ability to actually engineer investment. What we did in being prepared to give up the $47m in the coal export duty was to get from BHP-Utah—those opposite should listen to this because they might learn something—a commitment to invest $122m in mining activity which will produce 120 jobs, a commitment over five years to an additional $65m for research and development and a commitment to $50m for rehabilitation works. In other words, for the $47m forgone, there will be a national outcome worth in the order of $240m. That is sensible industry policy. It is about government facilitating. It is about government removing the impediments.

I should just conclude on this point because we know that the Opposition has a policy to abolish the coal export duty. However, it had such a policy in 1976 as well. On 17 August 1976 it announced its intention to remove the coal export duty. Come 15 August 1978, it announced in the Budget a decision to delay that action. Again, on 24 May 1979, the Treasurer came into the Parliament and announced that he was unable to proceed with the planned lifting of the duty. Does the former Treasurer remember that decision? On 18 August 1981 there was not a commitment to abolish the damned thing; we were told it was to be extended.

All I am saying to those people who want to look at this so-called great package which says that people are copping 15 per cent on everything they spend—a new tax; a consumption tax on everything; a regressive tax; a tax that cannot be compensated for in terms of income support—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is Brereton? Is he out counting? Where is squeaky?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Gippsland.

—In return for that, the Opposition says that it will abolish seven other taxes. The record of those opposite is abysmal. I do not believe that the Australian public will believe honourable members opposite, and nor do honourable members opposite deserve to be believed.

—I ask the Prime Minister whether it is a fact that no Labor Prime Minister has ever been rejected by his own Party in a caucus ballot? What has happened to the Labor Party when this Prime Minister has already been subjected to the indignity of one caucus challenge, and now faces execution tonight?
—All I can say is that I hope that history will repeat itself.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development. Can the Minister advise honourable members of the latest state of play in the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations?

—I thank the honourable member for his question, which does address an issue of real importance to this country. We would have to say that we have reached the point of make or break in the Uruguay Round. Tomorrow the Director-General of GATT will bring down a package right across the Round on a take it or leave it basis for the international community. I believe that success is within our grasp if the international political will exists to accept that package. There can be no doubt that the international economy desperately needs the kind of boost it would receive from a successful Uruguay Round package.

PARA.TAB: We have pursued Australia's interests in the Round vigorously through the Cairns Group and bilaterally. Last week we had a very useful Cairns Group meeting in Geneva. The Group revealed both its unity and its determination to achieve a truly liberalising outcome to the Round. That commitment remains undiminished. I quote from the communique, which stated that the Cairns Group `renewed their resolve that the Round could not and would not conclude, in whole or in part, without a substantial outcome on agriculture'.

The Group indicated the essential elements required for a successful outcome to the agricultural side of the Round. I will go through the major points. It was stated that we must have a full reinstrumentation and reduction of border protection and assured increases in the current market access that agricultural trading countries have. It was stated that we reject any notion that these cuts in border protection should be balanced by increased protection in other agricultural areas—the so-called notion of `rebalancing'. It was further stated that we are urging substantial reductions in export subsidies. We believe that at least part of that reduction must be done in volume terms to be truly effective and that there must be an immediate commitment that export subsidies will not be used on new products or in new markets. Finally, of course, we want to see effective disciplines on all internal payments linked to production.

I relayed that message from the Cairns Group to the Director-General. The Cairns Group also asked me to stay involved in the negotiations in Europe during the week, so I had subsequent meetings with key British officials and with Dutch Prime Minister Lubbers and Trade Minister Van Rooy, who are critical because at the moment they occupy the presidency of the European Community. In all, I had a series of three major meetings with the Director-General of the GATT. He indicated quite clearly that he intends to bring down a package of measures across all aspects of the Uruguay Round on Friday, Geneva time. I believe that that package, with all the compromises that it involves, will still respond very clearly to the needs outlined by the Cairns Group.

In my meetings with Arthur Dunkel last week he made it quite clear that he was resolved to craft this compromise because the majors have as yet not managed to reach the compromises themselves. There are high level contacts continuing in Europe between the United States and the European Community. The Cairns Group has signalled in relation to those bilateral meetings that anything that emerges from those bilateral meetings must be multilateralised and must be acceptable to all of the 108 parties meeting in the Round. I believe that the action that Arthur Dunkel will take tomorrow will ensure a package which tries to address the interests of all the major players in the Round.

After that package has been tabled, I intend to inform all honourable members and the general community of its contents. However, I have to say that the package will be a comprehensive one encompassing all parts of the Round. It is one that will require careful analysis. It will not be possible to respond immediately so the Government will not be delivering any immediate judgment on the package. The response will follow careful consideration by the Cabinet here, but also careful consideration in consultation with our Cairns Group colleagues because we wish to continue the work we have done with them over the last five years.

Finally, I hope that the major players in the international community will take the same careful and considered response as this country has taken to the package. I plead with them not to allow narrow self-interest or particular issues in some sensitive areas to blind them to the wider benefits to the whole international community of a successful outcome to the Round.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House censures the Prime Minister for allowing his government to be destabilised and rendered impotent over the issue of leadership at a time when:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) a million Australians are unemployed with little chance of getting a job;
(2) the Australian economy has been in recession for five consecutive quarters;
(3) business investment has ground to a halt and bankruptcies are running at record levels;
(4) Australia's foreign debt of $166 billion is a crushing burden on every Australian worker; and
(5) the Labor government has manifestly failed its responsibilities to the people of Australia.

The censure of a Prime Minister is a very important matter, in particular the censure of a Prime Minister in the circumstances in which we find this nation today; namely, the worst economic circumstances for 60 years. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) over the period since the last election, now nearly 20 months, has allowed a continuing process of destabilisation to undermine his leadership and his Government, to the point of total paralysis. In fact, the situation has been left to drift and our economy has now slipped into the worst recession, as I say, in 60 years. Most recently we have seen some of the manifestations of that economic slide. Most important and alarming is the significant increase in unemployment in the course of the last couple of years as the economy has slid into that very deep recession.

PARA.TAB: Last week we saw the unemployment rate reach 10 1/2 per cent, the highest level since the 1930s. There are over 900,000 Australians recorded officially as unemployed. Of course, we know that that official statistic dramatically understates the full magnitude of the unemployment crisis in Australia, where there are some 500,000 or 600,000 other Australians who cannot get the work they want. Approaching 17 or 18 per cent of our work force today is directly or indirectly touched by unemployment. That means that not one family in Australia today can really stand up and say it is not directly or indirectly touched by unemployment.

Last week we also saw the release of the balance of payments number, $1.7 billion, a number that is staggering in its size, given the depth of the recession. I put it to the Prime Minister that a few years ago there would not have been an economist who would have been prepared to concede that our balance of payments monthly number could be as high as $1.7 billion in the midst of the worst recession in 60 years.

That is the outcome of the paralysis of policy and leadership that has characterised this Government since the last election. It is very hard to point to any significant attempt, let alone decision, to deal with those problems in that time. Undoubtedly the Prime Minister would point to the Budget as an occasion when he attempted to deal with those problems, but already it is conceded by the new Treasurer (Mr Willis) that that Budget is dead in the water, that its growth assumptions were unbelievably optimistic.

In particular the Government completely misread the state of the international economy, and we have implicit recognition now that perhaps 1992 will be worse than 1991. We have already had five consecutive measured quarters of negative growth in the Australian economy. It is a staggering admission on the part of the Government, in the one major attempt it has made to deal with the problem, that the Budget itself was dead in the water within a very short space of time.

I hope that when the Prime Minister and the new acting Treasurer or temporary Treasurer rise to deal with this motion, they will spell out their current assessment of the Australian economic circumstances and where our economy is headed in 1992. It is fundamental now to every Australian that an open and objective assessment be provided by the Government as to where we find ourselves in the midst of the worst recession in 60 years. That has arisen because this Prime Minister has been so weak that he has allowed the continual destabilisation of his leadership and his Government by members of his own Party. It is not just back bench members of his Party, not just outer-Ministry members of his Party; it is also some of his key Cabinet colleagues who have repeatedly destabilised this man and his Government in the last 20 months.

A couple of examples come to mind. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) is a classic case. He has had a longstanding public role in undermining the credibility and direction of the Hawke Government. We can go back before the last election, to about October 1988 when, it will be recalled, that Minister—who should more appropriately be called the `Minister for unemployment'—went in and told the Prime Minister it was time to go. Even right back then before the last election, or immediately after the last election, this man—the Prime Minister—did nothing about the undermining actions of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training.

Since the election there have been dozens and dozens of occasions on which we have seen evidence in the media that that Minister has continued to undermine this Prime Minister. For example, immediately after the last election campaign the `Minister for unemployment' predicted that the economy would get worse.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—The Leader of the Opposition should refer to Ministers by their appropriate title.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the appropriate title.
—I do not need the advice of the honourable member for Bruce.

—The Minister for Employment, who is a principal cause of the level of unemployment, predicted immediately after the last election campaign that the economy would get much worse than the Government had forecast, not because he had any commitment to the truth but because he had an irrational hatred of this Prime Minister. One can go through the following 18-month period and see the magnitude of the debilitation, the extent to which that Minister has undermined this Prime Minister. For example, that Minister spoke to the press gallery and publicly called on the Government to develop a `pick the winners' industry policy, speaking deliberately and consciously outside his portfolio and knowing that it would undermine the Prime Minister—not because he had any genuine belief in industry policy, but because he wanted to continue to undermine the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Again, on Australia Day this year the Minister for Employment, Education and Training called on the Government to adopt the policies of Gough Whitlam. It shows how frustrated he was getting, when he resorted to a call for the policies of Gough Whitlam. Again this was not because he had any particular interest in those policies, but because he wanted to undermine the Prime Minister.

Subsequently the Minister went on and blamed the Government's float of the Australian dollar as being the major cause of some of our economic problems. That was the one decision that the Prime Minister had publicly identified himself with as being a great success in his early years in government, and the Minister for Employment deliberately sought to undermine the Prime Minister by drawing attention to the fact that he believed that that float decision was a mistake. Again this Prime Minister sat by and showed a complete lack of leadership in failing to deal with a blatant act of disloyalty by one of his principal Cabinet Ministers.

At the ALP conference this year that same Minister tried to launch a debate on immigration, not because he had any particular interest in the issue of immigration, and not because he even tried to relate it to the labour market and the emerging unemployment crisis in this country, but because he knew that the issue of immigration went to the very heart of one of the areas always cherished by this Prime Minister as a particular area of his own interest and success. Again, that Minister sought to undermine the Prime Minister.

Immediately after that conference there was another good example of that Minister's going public. He said that there had been a distinct failure of leadership at the conference. That was more or less a veiled attempt to again undermine the Prime Minister. And so it has gone on. There have been dozens of occasions when the Minister for Employment has deliberately and knowingly set out to undermine the Prime Minister. On every occasion this Prime Minister has just stood there, or sat there, and done nothing about it.

There are many other examples, within the front bench and within the innermost sanctums of the Caucus, of senior Ministers undermining this Prime Minister. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) is another classic example. On behalf of the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), she torpedoed the Prime Minister's new federalism policy. Indeed, she wanted to make sure, after the challenge of the honourable member for Blaxland failed back in June, that his chances were kept alive and well. She took onto her staff the ex-press secretary of the honourable member for Blaxland so that the honourable member could continue to have the press resources of a Minister at his disposal and so that he could continue to wage the leadership campaign against this Prime Minister.

The Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett) is another classic example, and we saw him at Question Time today. He and the others are all Judases on the front bench of the ALP, deliberately and knowingly undermining this Prime Minister. Of course, the original Judas had a basic sense of decency; he at least had the sense to go out and hang himself after the betrayal. But not this lot. This lot stayed and continued to betray. This lot continued to put out their hands for the 30 pieces of silver.

The ultimate betrayer, the ultimate underminer, the ultimate wrecker, was the honourable member for Blaxland, who was relegated to the back bench. If he gets up tonight, he will bring with him two monuments which will be recognised in the history of this country. The first, of course, will be the nearly one million Australians who are unemployed as a result of the recession that he said we had to have. Nobody else believes we ever had to have it. He will have the distinction of being the first Labor Prime Minister to destroy his own Party. The honourable member for Blaxland is a classic in the tradition of Jack Lang. Today I came across a quote worth putting on the record:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a copious ability to hate and envy anyone whom he thought was financially, socially or intellectually superior, especially if that individual appeared to be a rival . . .

That is a description of Jack Lang. But does it not fit Jack Lang's student, the honourable member for Blaxland, the ultimate underminer, the man who set out on a clear cut course to wreck this Prime Minister and this Government? He has brought this Government to its knees in the midst of the worst recession in 60 years, when this Prime Minister and his Government have been unable to deal with the emerging economic crisis.

PARA.TAB: That is the principal reason why this Prime Minister ought to be censured. But a second very important reason is that this Prime Minister has no sense of direction, no sense of vision, no real understanding of the needs of the people of Australia and has spent the great bulk of the last 18 months not only being obsessed with the protection of his job, irrespective of the costs of other jobs around Australia, but he has also been obsessed with trying to destroy us.

Never have we seen that obsession more pronounced and extreme than in the last four weeks since we released the Fightback package, where he completely misread the direction in which we would go in relation to rebuilding the Australian economy and found himself absolutely flat-footed and unable to deal with a very clear-cut sense of direction and vision for this country. The big difference that we highlight in the Fightback program that this Prime Minister has just not been able to come to grips with is that we, in that document, do not put our faith in government, bureaucracy, mates, union leaders, business mates, lobbyists or some of those who have managed to extract unbelievable deals out of this Government; we put our faith in the average Australian, in the people of Australia. This country will be rebuilt by the average Australian as an individual, as a member of a family, as a person running his business or trying to expand his business. It is that group of people who will rebuild this country.

The Fightback package has struck a chord with average Australians because it has tapped their mood, their hope, their vision for this country and their embarrassment about the extent to which this Government has undermined our standing as a nation in the world as a whole, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region.

The Prime Minister is to be censured for two principal reasons: firstly, the total lack of leadership that he has shown over the course of the last 18 to 20 months as he has allowed a succession of his innermost Cabinet to undermine him publicly and privately and reduce his Government to a point where it is totally paralysed and unable to deal with the worst economic circumstances in 60 years; and, secondly, he has been unable to respond positively, he has only been able to respond negatively, to a clear-cut alternative which gives a sense of direction, vision and hope for the people of Australia.

The extreme nature of this man's obsession about destroying the Fightback package is the clearest commentary on just how far out of touch he now is with the people of Australia. The people of Australia are not the slightest bit interested in whether the Prime Minister can destroy our package. They are not the slightest bit interested in how many hours are put in by the Treasury staff, the Finance staff and the Employment Department staff in an attempt to find numerical holes in our package. They are not the slightest bit interested in any of that; they are interested to see whether the Prime Minister has any clear-cut sense of direction and commitment to the future of this country, whether he can understand the hardship that they now feel, and whether he can give them some hope and some sense of direction out of the mire.

The amazing thing is that as the Prime Minister has gone around Australia—I have followed him to some of the towns that he has gone to—he has not listened to what the people have been saying to him, whether they have been saying it to him on talk back radio or at lunch time meetings. I notice that, on most occasions, he does not take questions so he does not give them a chance to get to him directly, but he certainly has not listened to what they have said to him. They do not want bickering, fighting and political game playing and they do not want outlandish claims and blatant lies about our figuring.They want the Prime Minister to develop an alternative sense of direction for this country.

They have seen what the Prime Minister's style of Government has done in the last eight years. They wish that he could rise above the mire and that he could take a clear-cut view of the direction in which this country has to go. The Prime Minister could make a genuine political fight out of the period between now and the next election by presenting an alternative and arguing that alternative so that the people of Australia are given a real choice at the next election as to which way this country can and should go as a result of a change of government at that time.

The other disturbing feature of what is now emerging in this leadership battle—I guess it is true; it does not matter who wins tonight—is that we will see the worst features of a tired and visionless Government. I think that either one will ditch any sense of economic respectability and responsibility; there will be a dramatic policy U-turn; and we will see a resort to the old pump priming, infrastructure, government expenditure style projects to try to get us out of our difficulties. That is the last thing that this country could possibly contemplate in the midst of the worst recession in 60 years.

One of the things we have done in recent days is to take the Government's Murphy model and look at what might happen if in that model the Government were to proceed down the path of a February mini-Budget with, let us say, a 2 per cent cut in interest rates across the board and an increase in government expenditure of about $1 billion a year. It is a fairly modest package, I fear, compared with what the Government would do whoever is to win tonight, but the consequences for the Australian economy are horrific.

One of the real risks, and a principal risk, is that of an exchange rate crisis. Not only has the domestic confidence of both consumers and business leaders been shot in recent days by this debilitating leadership contest but also international confidence in Australia could easily be shot. If that were to happen, as shown in this analysis, the exchange rate could fall quite significantly. So we would suddenly see a return to the higher inflation days; a jump in inflation of somewhere between 3.5 per cent and 6.7 per cent as a result of that further drift in policy.

Sure, it might be possible to create 50,000 or 60,000 jobs under that sort of scenario. It may be possible that they will not be real jobs, they will not be sustainable jobs and they will be created only by a significant increase in our international debts yet again at the cost, roughly, of $100,000 in debt per job. That is the prospect that the Australian economy has under either alternative.

It does not matter whether Hawke or Keating gets up tonight. There will be a major policy U-turn in this country which will blow this country out of the water and inflict much greater pain and hardship on average Australians than they have yet endured, and they have already endured the worst recession in 60 years. It is a sad commentary on just how far out of touch both the honourable member for Blaxland and the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) are that their insane personal ambitions have thrown this economy into the worst circumstances in 60 years, and their solutions will inflict further pain and hardship on average Australians. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion, and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset let me just make a couple of observations about some of the personality issues that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) introduced in his speech this afternoon. He referred to the fact that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) came to see me in 1988 and that I did nothing about it. I listened to what Mr Dawkins had to say and then I went on with the business of government and won the 1990 election. That is what I did.

PARA.TAB: There are different ways in which an individual can handle representations or attacks upon himself: he can get into a lather, he can start wielding big sticks and throwing his weight around, or he can listen and then make the decision that he will quietly get on with the job of governing. I chose to do that in 1988. All I can say is that I plead guilty to the result of having beaten the mob opposite pointless in the 1990 election.

I really want to go on, however, with the issues of substance that are involved in the attack which the Leader of the Opposition has made upon me. The Leader of the Opposition has gone to serious issues and we heard him in silence. I hope that I will receive the same respect.

I welcome the opportunity afforded by the motion of the Leader of the Opposition to address the real issues confronting this nation and, may I say, to expose once again the hypocrisy of those opposite. As I have had cause to say before, and as I said earlier today, in 1993 there will be a clear choice for the people of Australia. That choice will be a stark one. It will be a choice which will highlight the fundamental differences of philosophy, policies and approach between the two sides of politics in this country.

The Leader of the Opposition has gone to his package. Let me say that nowhere—absolutely nowhere—are those stark differences between Labor and the tories more evident, nor are they better illustrated anywhere else, than in the Opposition's consumption tax package. It is for that reason that this motion is in its essentials about that package.

The clear choice in 1993 will be this: it will be between a coalition committed on its own admissions to an immediate rise in unemployment, to higher interest rates, to a sharp rise in inflation, to a 15 per cent tax on all goods and services—the essential necessities of life—to an increase in the foreign debt, to a massive redistribution of the national wealth in favour of the top 15 per cent of the nation's income earners, to the destruction of Medicare, to the destruction of the social wage, to a reduction in real wages and to an era of industrial confrontation and disruption without parallel in postwar Australia. That is their promise, that is their boast and that is their vision.

On the other hand, the people of Australia will have the choice of a government which will have restored growth, which will be creating jobs and which has beaten inflation; a government which will continue to deliver tax reform and to do that in the context of a strong and restructured economy. It will be a government delivering on jobs. It will be a government delivering on inflation, delivering on micro-economic reform, delivering on fair, modern and efficient welfare, health and education systems. And it will be a government delivering to this generation and future generations of Australians an internationally competitive economy built on the foundation of fairness, justice, equal opportunity and cooperation. That is our commitment, that is our achievement and that is our vision.

Let me in some more detail go to these points. I want to emphasise to the Opposition and, through this House, to the people of Australia that I have indeed welcomed the publication of the Opposition's document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—In the first place, it has totally confirmed my warnings of the past year given specifically on relevant occasion after relevant occasion that this is the most ideologically driven and most socially divisive Opposition in the post-war era of this country.

PARA.TAB: In each of its substantial parts—the consumption tax itself, the regressive tax system, welfare, health, education, industrial relations and immigration—it is simply a recipe for social division and disruption. Secondly, the people of Australia have 18 months to understand the full extent of the fraud which this Opposition seeks to impose upon them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Parkes.
—Because of its impact on the most vulnerable sections of the Australian community and its cynical exploitation of the anxieties and concerns of the people, it is not just a hoax—it is a cruel hoax.

PARA.TAB: On this side we can have only one conceivable ground for apprehensiveness about this as a political document. In the weeks and months ahead, as block by block we destroy this document, our only apprehension will be that this Opposition itself will abandon this document along with its authors. That is the only apprehension we have about this document. But as long as this document remains on the political agenda of this country, our task, our duty and our responsibility is to highlight the gulf between the great goals of the Labor Government and the failed nostrums of the Far Right.

The Labor principles are clear and they are unequivocal. They are the principles of fairness, equity, tolerance, equality, freedom and opportunity. Those are the values that have been cherished by the overwhelming majority of Australians. They have been fundamentally responsible for the development of this great country which I have the pleasure and pride to lead.

When we talk about the qualities of Australia, when we talk about the concept of the fair go, of the equality of opportunity, not only are we on this side of the House proud to share those Australian qualities but we have a special pride. There is no institution in this country which has been more involved in the development and the acceptance of those principles than the Australian Labor Party.

We say that any system which proposes that those seeking assistance from the community should first be regarded as guilty until proved innocent is an approach and a philosophy which is repugnant to us all. That is the foundational philosophy and approach of this document—those who need assistance are guilty until proved innocent. We repudiate that approach. We find it totally repugnant. But that is the total thrust of their welfare proposals.

We say that any approach which seeks deliberately to divide Australians, deliberately to return to confrontation, to re-entrench privilege, is simply a direct assault on the democratic tradition built up by the work and the sacrifice not only of the labour movement but by the hard won consensus of the nation itself over a century of its national experience. Yet that concept, that approach of confrontation and divisiveness is the purport of all of their industrial proposals which, in their own words, are the heart of their package. They are their words. They say that their proposals in regard to industrial relations are the heart—the centrepiece—of their package. Yet, that centrepiece is based upon the concept of a hatred for the working men and women of this country. They do not trust them.
Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Members on my left will cease interjecting.
—They do not trust them. They reject and repudiate the organisation in the trade union movement—
—No wonder they are getting rid of you, you old fool.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo.

—Instead of the concept of saying that they will sit down and work with the representatives of the working men and women of this country, what they are saying is that they will take them on. They say that, if necessary, they will send the troops onto the waterfront. As I have had cause to say before, 100 years ago their political predecessors—
—You said—
—Order! The honourable member for Moncrieff will cease interjecting.
—Mr Speaker, it was 100 years ago that their political forebears—
—You are demeaning yourself.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Higgins.
—They sent out the troops with Gatling guns and turned them on the working men and women. This is what they did.
—You put the troops in. You knew that.
—Order! The House will come to order. Members on my left will cease interjecting. I warn the honourable member for Moncrieff.

—Mr Speaker, I understand the embarrassment when they are reminded of their ancestry. But there is nothing they can do to disinherit themselves from their political ancestry, particularly when after 100 years they repeat exactly the same prescription. It was 100 years ago that the troops were out with Gatling guns against the working men and women in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—And now, 100 years later, their promise about micro-economic reform is to send the troops onto the waterfront. They were wrong 100 years ago and they have learnt nothing in a century.

PARA.TAB: We say that the responsibility of government is not to stand to one side, but to lead. There is a responsibility to intervene where there is a need. There is a responsibility on government to intervene on behalf of the disadvantaged and the underprivileged, to intervene on behalf of the national good.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are talking about your own failures.
—I warn the honourable member for Bradfield.

—It is the responsibility of government to set standards of fairness, equity and efficiency. Put simply, this package of those opposite does not stack up in three ways. Let me put it to them—and I hope that they will listen and understand this—that their package does not stand up on the basis of fairness, efficiency, and economic activity and employment.

PARA.TAB: Let me turn first to the standard and the test of fairness. This package is inherently unfair. It is manifestly unfair because low income earners will pay the same tax on the basic necessities of life as the richest people in the community. That is essentially unfair. Those on the lowest income will pay the same amount of tax and the same price increase as the richest person in the community—and they will pay it on the necessities of life. Having said that it is fair that I and the Leader of the Opposition should pay the same amount as the lowest income people in the country, those opposite also say that it is fair to reduce the tax on luxury goods, on luxury cars and so on. Where does fairness begin to emerge in that situation? It is the absolute antithesis of what is fair, what is decent and what is equitable.

TALK.START.PARA: —And where are the jobs?
—I warn the honourable member for Gilmore.

—But what does the Leader of the Opposition then do? He argues that he is going to give income tax cuts and he argues that those income tax cuts are going to be targeted. Well, my God, they are targeted and let me explain how they are targeted. Let me explain how the Leader of the Opposition's concept of targeting works. It works in this way: workers on $20,000 get a gain in after tax income of 4.8 per cent. Remember, on $20,000 one gets a gain in after tax income of 4.8 per cent. On $30,000, the level of average weekly earnings, it is 6.8 per cent. But if one earns $75,000, as only 2 per cent of wage and salary earners do, the gain in after tax income is not 4.8 per cent or 6.8 per cent; it is almost 15 per cent. There is the essence of unfairness in the tax that the Opposition will impose. (Extension of time granted)

PARA.TAB: Mr Prosser interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for Forrest. If he interjects again, I will name him.

—There is the unfairness. In the tax that the Opposition will impose, it will make the richest pay no more than the poorest: the poorest will pay the same as the richest. That is in the tax that it will impose. In the tax that it will take off, it will give virtually nothing at the bottom and it will give a massive hand-out to those at the top. By any decent, historical standard of a fair go, where is the fairness in it? It is not there.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.

—Despite the dishonest protestations of the Leader of the Opposition, the whole package is grossly unfair, as the Treasurer has and will continue to demonstrate. The Opposition Leader claims that everyone is better off and that the package is progressive. This is a bald-faced lie. This package is profoundly regressive. There has never been a more profoundly regressive proposal put before the Australian people than the centrepiece of this package. The big winners under this package are the high income earners of Australia. They are the winners; the losers, tragically, are the least able to look after themselves—the poorest, the low and middle income earners—
—Including the farmers.

—Including the farmers. If one is going to win under the Hewson package, one will already have to be amongst the most privileged in this country. But if, at this stage, one happens to be amongst the least privileged, if one happens to be amongst the low income earners, one will be amongst those who will suffer the most. The gross deception in the Opposition's document is that it omits in its calculations of impact many of the significant elements in the package, almost all of which have the greatest impact upon those in the community with the least capacity to look after themselves.

PARA.TAB: This is the magic pudding of the Leader of the Opposition. He claims that everyone is a winner, but how did he get to the conclusion that everyone is a winner? He got there simply by ignoring the impact of these regressive proposals that are included in it. The critical decisions which adversely affect households—the net $4 billion reduction in outlays—will not impact upon the rich; they will hurt the poor. So by ignoring, as my colleague the Treasurer said, the regressive impact of the reduction of these services, he comes out and says that this magic pudding has produced this situation where everyone in this country is better off. This is absolutely untrue, and the tragedy is that the Leader of the Opposition knows that it is untrue. That is the magnitude of the deceit of the Leader of the Opposition. As I have said all along, as I have said to my Party, as I have said to the people of this country, it is the same old tired, discredited, tawdry tory propaganda.

I turn now to the area of efficiency in micro-economic reform. Only 75,000 businesses pay the existing wholesale sales tax. Under the Hewson GST proposal, it will be one million. Not only would these one million small businesses around the country have to pay for it, but they would have to undertake all the administrative re-equipment to deal with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Think of the paperwork.

—Paperwork, new equipment. That is 75,000 now, one million under this proposal. As far as the incorporated small businesses are concerned, those opposite say, `Have we got a deal for you. We are going to increase your tax from 39c in the dollar to 42c in the dollar'. Then we will hear them saying—but not too loudly; it will be sotto voce—`We are handing out a gift to big business, because we are taking payroll tax off them; but, of course, you don't get the compensation for your increase in company tax from 39 to 42 per cent, because you do not now pay payroll tax. Have we got a deal for you'.

PARA.TAB: The 15 per cent consumption tax would create a whole new area of tax avoidance. This tax would clearly be an inefficient tax, particularly in the transition, when there would be massive costs for government, for business and indirectly for households.

What is perhaps just as interesting in terms of the Opposition Leader's commitment to micro-economic reform and efficiency is the area of road user charges. I will spend no more time on this than to remind this House and this nation of what the Leader of the Opposition said in his document. I read it again:

SPEECH.PARA: The overall level of road user charges and road expenditures will be the responsibility of the National Road Transport Commission. Charges and taxes on road users and the level of expenditure on roads will no longer be subject to the vagaries of the political or budget processes which have produced wild fluctuations in rates of charges and levels of expenditure in past years.

In other words, on the Leader of the Opposition's own statement, his micro-economic reform in this centrally important area depends upon the imposition of charges. But I snookered him the first day after he released the package. He said, `No, we will take off the excise on petrol; you will get the benefit there'. By definition, the only way he can deliver, if he is going to deliver, is by a massive increase in registration charges. But when, in the late night confrontation with the National Party, he was told, `Not on your nelly', he caved in. He will not get the revenue to do the micro-economic reform by charges on petrol or road user charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the honourable member for Aston interjects again, I will name him.
—The Leader of the Opposition wimped at the first hurdle when he had to come to the question of implementing micro-economic reform.

PARA.TAB: I turn next to the question of the economy and employment under the package. This package would devastate the Australian economy and employment. Those opposite admit as much in their own document. The consumption tax package would cause higher inflation, higher interest rates, a blow-out in foreign debt, lowering of real wages and an immediate increase in unemployment.

Mr Speaker, the members of my Government do not sit down and say, `Tonight we have to conjure up a new vision'; our vision has been the vision of creating an Australia in which there is an equality of opportunity. In the area of education we now have two out of every three kids in school instead of the one in three when we came into office. We will continue to deliver. We will deliver the policies which are necessary to get us out of this recession. That is starting. We will continue the restructuring of the Australian economy. But, most importantly, my Party, my Government, will continue to take a position where we regard those in the community who most need the help and assistance of this Government not as those who are already privileged but as those who are least advantaged. That is not only a policy of principle; it is a policy of justice. Ultimately, it is the only policy which will produce a decent, cooperative, efficient economy in this country. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On what clearly will be an historic day in the political history of Australia, we have just witnessed possibly the swan song of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The House has been subdued, because I think the gallery and honourable members on both sides realise that it is an extraordinary circumstance in which the Prime Minister has presented a letter saying he will resign as leader of his Party at 6.30 p.m. tonight.

PARA.TAB: I begin by addressing some of the points the Prime Minister brought forward in the debate and highlighting one factor he completely ignored in his examination of the coalition Fightback package. In that context, I can do no better than refer to the remarks of Dr John Bell, one of Senator Button's senior public servants, Deputy Secretary to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, who has no brief for the Opposition. He said recently that the current taxation regime, particularly with regard to sales tax, creates a 5 per cent disadvantage for all Australian export industries, on all Australian exporters.

That does not come from the Opposition; it comes from Dr John Bell, a senior public servant in John Button's Department. The Fightback package abolishes that sales tax disadvantage to our exporters and provides the framework for our export industries to get up off the floor and to generate jobs and economic active by removing the horrific 5 per cent disadvantage which should have been abolished by now.

I make a second point in respect of the Prime Minister's address. He wants to talk about the regressive nature of our package. He is wrong on two counts. Dr John Edwards, senior consultant economist to the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), said last week:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has made a plausible effort to arrange the tax cuts and the social security compensation so that the poor are not worse off as a result of the imposition of the goods and services tax.

Another aspect of the argument about the regressive nature of the goods and services tax is the question of superannuation. This Government has presided over some very regressive treatment of superannuation, where the rich have got bigger and better tax breaks —more than Mr and Mrs Average Worker.

PARA.TAB: In the coalition Fightback package we are addressing that in a way which is absolutely fair. If that is not enough, let me turn to a list of 14 organisations which have come out in support of the package: the National Farmers Federation; the Voluntary Health Insurance Association; the Motor Trades Association; the National Catholic Education Commission; the National Council of Independent Schools Associations; the Australian Supermarket Institute; the Australian Institute of Company Directors; the Australian Livestock Transporters Association; the BCA; the CAI; the Housing Industry Association; the Institute of Chartered Accountants; the Metal Trades Industry Association; the New South Wales Farmers Association; and the National Association of Forest Industries. Those organisations, to name but some, have all come out and strongly supported the integrity and vision of the alternative conferred by the coalition Fightback package successfully launched by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) several months ago.

I put it to the House that in his final attack when at the dispatch box, in his attack on the coalition package, the Prime Minister is wrong. I put it to the House that the strong endorsement by the community, reflected by opinion polls and by the comments of organisations, show very clearly that people are satisfied with the alternative vision, with the vision which will create jobs and give people a chance to have a go and get off the dole list, which will boost industry, which will boost exports in a responsible way. People are attracted very much to the coalition package. I read the press releases of the Forest Industries Association with particular interest, as does the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) and other frontbenchers. We noted yesterday its very strong criticisms of the resources security legislation.

The truth of the matter is that the Caucus's problem is that it faces Hobson's choice: a paralysed Hawke versus a pathetic Keating. The honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls) occasionally gets around his electorate beyond Mount Isa. He has done his soundings. Last week he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Keating is unacceptable.
He is unacceptable in the bush. Senator Margaret Reynolds, based in Townsville in far north Queensland, which is well known to me and many others who visit there regularly, said:
You cannot give Keating away.

Last week, in a famous press release which may go down in history as the one most used—especially in the electorate of Swan—between now and the next election, whenever it might occur, Senator Jim McKiernan said:
There are 900,700 reasons why Keating should not be Prime Minister.

The truth of the matter is that the Caucus, the Parliament and the country have run out of confidence in the Prime Minister and in the honourable member for Blaxland, as demonstrated by the polls and as would be demonstrated if the Parliament had a secret vote on the matter.

PARA.TAB: I want to mention one other key issue. What right has the New South Wales right wing of the Labor Party to bludgeon Caucus into accepting its choice as Prime Minister? What right does the New South Wales Right have to impose a Prime Minister on this nation against the will of the Parliament, against the will of the people? That is what we will face at 6.30 tonight. I put to honourable members the chilling terms of the letter by the Prime Minister which I sought to table earlier today. The letter, dated 19 December, which is addressed to the Caucus Chairperson, says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is evident to me that there is now an intention to challenge my leadership before the Parliament rises.
I believe in these circumstances that it is in the interests of the Party and the Government that this issue be resolved at the earliest reasonable opportunity and in the least disruptive manner.

For this purpose and to avoid, therefore, any requirement for any show of hands or signing of a petition, I request you to convene a special meeting of the caucus at 6.30 pm today. At that meeting I will tender my resignation as Leader and offer myself for re-election and go to a secret ballot if anyone wishes to challenge me for this position.

Honourable members should listen to the last paragraph of this extraordinary letter. Here is the nub. This is the last paragraph of a letter from a Prime Minister who has led the Labor Party to four election wins, for reasons various. This is the last plea he had to insert into this letter:
Should there be such a challenge I would ask that all members be released from any suggestion of having to show their ballot paper to any other member.

What a shameful comment from the Prime Minister. The bludgeoning, the bulldozing New South Wales Right is so out of hand that the Prime Minister of this country has to ask for a fair dinkum secret ballot in his own Caucus, not the show and tell method so well practised in the New South Wales State Parliament by the honourable member for Robertson, (Mr Walker), the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton), and other members who have graduated from that university of hard knocks—the bear pit of the New South Wales Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has given the lie to how democratic this ballot will be in the Caucus tonight. The Prime Minister has had to plead on bended knee for a truly secret ballot to decide who will be Prime Minister beyond this day for the few remaining twilight months of this particular administration. That is simply not good enough. I say to the House that the New South Wales Right has no right to decide who will be Prime Minister of this nation. I say further to the House that the sooner we have a fair dinkum Federal election so that the people can decide who gets the keys to the Lodge the better for the sake of all Australians.

Another key issue has involved the total tearing up of the Westminster convention on Cabinet solidarity in recent months. Minister after Minister has directly and indirectly attacked this Prime Minister. Then we had the famous activities of last week when the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) led the six-pack into the office of the Prime Minister. There was the Minister for Finance, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand), the Minister for Defence (Senator Ray), the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) and the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus). This famous six-pack wheeled into the office; this famous six-pack blinked; this famous six-pack departed the office. But every Westminster convention was torn up because the six-pack did not offer to resign in accordance with Westminster convention; the six-pack decided to hang on. I must add that in those circumstances they have certainly tainted themselves in their conduct and their modus operandi as Ministers and frontbenchers of this Government.

I want to highlight what has happened since this Parliament last met. Not only have we had a Cabinet and a Government in absolute chaos, a Government in policy paralysis; we have had a Government that can do no better than attack a fair dinkum alternative which honestly seeks to address the problems facing Australia. This Government just did not wake up to the fact that every time it did that it enhanced the credibility and the standing of Dr Hewson and the coalition Fightback package. This Government, as a result of its actions over the last month, has demonstrated its incompetence, its lack of integrity and its selfish cynicism. It has now reached a stage where it will be a rich irony that the Prime Minister, whose popularity is now 17 percentage points lower than the popularity of Bill Hayden when Hawke took over as the leader of the ALP, will have to go out to Government House to hand in his resignation to the same Bill Hayden, now Governor-General of Australia.

But the Prime Minister must resign. He cannot shy away from his responsibility for the recession. The Prime Minister cannot shy away from the fact that he has continuously and dishonestly raised community expectations about this recession, when he must have had figures from his office telling the story as it is. During the last election campaign the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no need to fear a recession in any sense.
That was before we had the one million unemployed and before we had the five consecutive quarters of negative growth spelt out in this motion. In May of this year the Prime Minister said:
The signs of the recovery will be apparent in the second half of the year.

That is the second half of this calendar year. There is no recovery, Prime Minister. There is no recovery, members of the Cabinet and Caucus. The trouble is that so many of them are embedded in the cocoon of Canberra, so many are embedded in the rhetoric of the Treasury and the mandarins of economic advisers to this Government that they have no idea of the extent of economic misery existing across Australia today. I take the point that it is wrong to blame the people of Canberra as they ride their bicycles around on their hot mix bitumen freeway bicycle paths for the recession we did not have to have. But it is in order to blame the elements of this Government and the elements of Treasury and Finance who delivered to the rest of Australia this recession we did not have to have. They delivered it ahead of the real impact of the drought; they delivered it ahead of the world recession; and they delivered an economic downturn deeper than that in the rest of the world. I sheet home the blame to Canberra, to this Prime Minister and to the former Treasurer.

PARA.TAB: It is for these reasons that the Prime Minister must resign. He has given misleading quotes which have given people false hopes which have been dashed in this Christmas time. I remind honourable members that in October the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: It's (recovery)—
that is, of the economy—
already started to come out. . .
He then went on to say:
It's not a massive recovery but we are coming off the bottom. . .
I think the economy will be really moving by the end of this financial year.

He had another six months on that particular projection. The truth of the matter is that all those projections are false hopes, because the fundamentals are wrong. The fundamental economic policies are so wrong and the economic situation so serious that this new Treasurer, in the course of seven days, has completely changed his attitude and is now looking for an economic U-turn. I say to the House that there is only one U-turn which will stack up: when John Hewson is Prime Minister of Australia; when we have the coalition Fightback policy on the legislative books of this nation; and when we have fair dinkum alternative policies in place which abolish seven taxes, greatly reduce three other taxes, including massive reductions in income tax, and create jobs for millions of Australians who have been forced onto the jobless queues.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian people are indeed fortunate that members of the Opposition are not in government at present, because if they were to implement the program laid down in its so-called Fightback! document, then the Australian nation would be plunged into much more severe economic circumstances than currently exist or are likely to exist. The fact is that in moving this motion today the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) found it difficult to work up any particular amount of fire and brimstone. He made only two points which are worthy of comment. The first was that there was a supposed paralysis of policy on the Government side, with no significant attempt to deal with problems; and, secondly, that there was an implicit acknowledgment by us that 1992 will be worse than 1991. I will refer to those two points before coming to some other matters which I think it is very important for the Australian people to understand.

PARA.TAB: There is no paralysis of policy. There has been a constant and substantial amount of work done by this Government to address the issues faced by this economy in their fundamentals in the short term and the medium and longer term. In the medium and longer term this Government, as distinct from all prior governments in this century, has embarked on an enormous amount of fundamental micro-economic reform to try to undo the enormous damage that was done by the conservative governments of this country in the postwar years, when they dominated the government of this country for the previous 33 years. They built this economy and industrialised it in completely the wrong way, which they implicitly acknowledge by the fact that they now argue for completely opposite policies.

We are the ones in government who have undertaken the brunt of the task of making this fundamental structural change to the Australian nation, because we recognised before those opposite that the course that had been pursued for the previous 33 years was immensely damaging and could not be sustained by the Australian nation. We had to change the structure of our economy because the structure which depended overwhelmingly on exports of commodities and essentially value added products was not going to enable this country to continue to grow and expand, to maintain anything like full employment and improved living standards for the rest of this century, let alone the next century. This Government has embarked on the enormous amount of structural change necessary to put us on a path where the Australian nation can have some real hope of becoming a leading economic nation in the future.

So there has been no paralysis in that sense and there has been no paralysis either in the sense of dealing with the short term nature of the economy. Of course there are economic difficulties. There are economic difficulties in almost every country in the Western world; recessions are all over the place. In particular, most countries which have a GST still have not been able to avoid an economic slowdown, and many of them are in recession. So proposing the GST as some solution for recession is simplistic nonsense of the worst kind. The fact that this Government has continually addressed policy to try to get the economy back onto a growth path is shown by the Budget, which involved a significant turnaround from the $8 billion surplus of a couple of years ago to a $5 billion deficit this year, a very substantial turnaround allowing the full play of the automatic stabilisers and some slight discretionary easing. The 10 reductions in official interest rates have meant that monetary policy has been considerably loosened since the beginning of 1990.

So there has been this continuous process of adjustment. But quite clearly there are concerns, which I have acknowledged outside this House earlier this week, that maybe there is need for further adjustments of policy to be made. This nation, like virtually every other nation in the Western world—certainly all the English speaking ones—is suffering the acute difficulty of economic management at a time when, through the 1980s, there has been a corporate debt binge with financial deregulation and an asset price boom, the management of which by the economic authorities has been extremely difficult.

This corporate debt binge has changed the nature of economic reactions by corporations which are now very much concerned about redressing their balance sheets rather than investing. Also, the asset price boom and the collapse of prices subsequent to that have added greatly to that difficulty. We are in somewhat unique economic circumstances and they do make the processes of economic management at this time a difficulty for many countries which have experienced much the same kind of circumstance. That is not an excuse; it is simply stating the real facts. The facts are that we recognise that the policies have to be put in place which will get Australia back on a sustainable growth path, sustainable in terms of maintaining low inflation and in terms of not going back to the kinds of balance of payments difficulties which marked the economy two or three years ago. We can do that. We are in a position now to lock in the low rate of inflation which we now have.

In the December quarter we will almost certainly see inflation drop below 2 per cent, and probably well below. The underlying rate will be a bit above that, but we are looking at exceedingly low levels of inflation. We are also able to have a real opportunity to lock that in because we have an accord in which the trade union movement has agreed, in relation to wages policy, to seek wages outcomes which will enable the inflation rate of this country to be comparable to those of our major trading partners. So there is in that sense a real opportunity to lock in the low inflation rate and for Australia uniquely to make that most important structural adjustment and to go into the rest of the 1990s as a low inflation country with inflation rates less than those of our major trading partners. It is a position that we very rarely enjoy. We have enjoyed it only momentarily at spots in time; it is not some continuing feature of our economy which has given our industries a real chance to export and to become internationally competitive.

These are the kinds of developments which are available to us now. The task is to get back onto that growth path as quickly as possible, so long as we do not do it in some way which blows the opportunities we now have in terms of low inflation and achieving long term growth, including substantial levels of economic and employment growth, without bringing about the problems of rising foreign debt. There is no policy paralysis. I indicated earlier this week that there is a mid-term review of economic policy taking place at the present time of our Budget forecast. If that review, which we will publish when it is available in late January, shows that we will significantly undershoot our economic forecasts, then we will certainly be prepared to adjust policy to try to get to the kinds of levels of growth for 1992 and beyond that we forecast in the Budget. The Budget was somewhat bullish about employment in 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was wrong.

—That kind of growth in employment is what we should be aiming for, something in the order of 150,000 to 200,000 jobs a year. We will need several years of that to get back to the unemployment levels that anyone in this country would regard as acceptable. So it is very important to get back onto that growth path, and we will pursue policies to achieve that.
—Pump priming.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Order! The honourable member for Flinders!

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be no pump priming and there is no policy paralysis. Let me say with regard to this stupid statement by the Leader of the Opposition about implicit acknowledgment by us that 1992 will be worse than 1991 that there was no acknowledgment by us to that effect. There was nothing remotely like that. I said that we may perhaps significantly undershoot the Budget forecast. But that does not mean in any way that 1992 will be worse than 1991. I say now, quite dogmatically, that 1992 will be much better than 1991—
—Because there will be no recession.
—The honourable member for Flinders!

—The last thing this nation needs to have imposed upon it is the kind of solution that would come from the Opposition. This Opposition has put forward in this so-called Fightback! document a program which would certainly not only knock the economy to the floor but also nail it to the floor for most of the rest of the decade.
—That is your fault.
—I warn the honourable member for Flinders.

—It would do it because the goods and services tax and the rest of the program that comes with it would be the last thing that we need. Let us have a look at what it involves. In the first year it involves a significant tightening of fiscal policy. If we were to swap sides with those opposite, they would be arguing straightaway to tighten fiscal policy and to have a real big array of expenditure cuts so that government expenditure can be cut down much further. Do they reckon that would do much to improve the economy? Do they think that would get us going again? Do they think that would engender a great entrepreneurial spirit and employers would rush out and hire a lot more people? Of course they do not; neither does the Leader of the Opposition. He admitted that, in the early stages of his program, there would be an increase in unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition admits that this is the first year effect of what he proposes. But what about the second year effect, which is that those opposite are going to whack a great inflationary impost on the economy? If that is not going to become permanently built in, then they will have to do something to tighten macro policy. But what are they going to do on fiscal policy? They are not going to tighten it; they are going to loosen it by $5 billion. That is a $5,000m turnaround in the Budget outcome in that year when they have imposed a 5 per cent or whatever the inflation impact is on the economy. In those circumstances, what do those opposite think the Reserve Bank is going to do—the independent Reserve Bank which they have told has to have an inflation rate of no more than 2 per cent? Those opposite are going to put 5 per cent in there and loosen fiscal policy by $5 billion. Where do they think interest rates will go? We will not be able to find them because they will go through the roof. They will be telling the Reserve Bank, effectively, to go for broke on interest rates because otherwise—

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't understand.

—If those opposite do not do that and override the Reserve Bank, it is no longer independent. What they will do is let inflation be built in, so all the structural change about the low inflation which we have now achieved will be out the window. It will be totally gone. They will build in inflation at much higher levels, double digit inflation, for the rest of this century. Those opposite have no wages policy, and they are proud of that. They say, `Let's let everybody go out there; let employers screw the workers. Let them hire them at wages less than the award rate. It does not matter. We are not concerned about minimum standards. We don't mind. Let all the conditions of employment be taken away. In areas where unions are strong, they can work up big wage deals—which means we will get a wages blow-out. Well, so what? That is the market at work'. That seems to be the wages policy of those opposite.

PARA.TAB: If there is this circumstance what do they think is going to happen to their wages policy, particularly when we give the workers chapter and verse on this and the great majority of them see that they are going to be much worse off under the Opposition's policies? Workers will see the tax cuts which start at 4.8 per cent for someone on $10,000 or less, and go to 14.6 per cent at $75,000. That is an indication of where the redistribution is going. But even when we take into account all the other elements, we will still find that the vast bulk of wage and salary earners are much worse off.

Who will be better off? Who will be creaming it in from this policy? It will be the top 10 per cent. That is the kind of policy that has been produced by the Opposition, and it will have a big inflationary impact on the economy. If the Opposition is going to stop interest rates going through the roof, what does it think will happen to wage claims? They will certainly go up. There will be a big increase in wage claims to seek that compensation. That will mean that low inflation will be gone.

The last thing the Australian people need is the kind of approach that the Opposition is proposing: immediate imposition of a tighter fiscal policy to increase unemployment and stop any recovery occurring and then, in the second year, a big inflation impact and a massive increase in interest rates to overcome the inflation impact—particularly given that the Opposition would be loosening fiscal policy. What a crazy policy. What a lunatic policy it really is.

It is a policy which no responsible alternative government should ever even think of proposing. This alternative government is led by a so-called economist, and one would wonder how a professor of economics could possibly put forward such a lunatic position. He puts it forward because at heart he is basically a right wing ideologue and not really a clear-thinking economist at all. He is a right wing ideologue with a thug as his 2IC. This is what we are getting from the Opposition: this hardline, right wing, totally free market approach from a group of people who think they can put up some rubbish like this and that the Australian people will accept it. We are here to tell the Opposition that Australians will not accept it. There is no way they will buy this package. The proposals that will come from us will put this economy back on its feet, not only in the short term but also in the long term as this Government continues to rule this country. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—During the latter part of the Treasurer's remarks, he referred to the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). I ask that he withdraw the terms he used.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for bringing the Treasurer (Mr Willis) into line. The most interesting thing about the Treasurer's speech on the Opposition's censure of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was that the Treasurer did not utter one word in defence of the Prime Minister. It reminds me of those words of the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) when a few years ago he said words to this effect: `The first leader I replace will be the one I tear down'.

PARA.TAB: Today the Treasurer, when asked to speak in defence of the Prime Minister, attacks the Opposition but fails to utter one word of support for the Prime Minister. Presumably, the Treasurer is more concerned about his job, following the reshuffle, than he is about the Prime Minister's job and defending him. If the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland, is right and the first leader he replaces is the one he tears down, and if he tears down the Prime Minister in the Caucus meeting at 6.30 tonight, today will be an historic day in Australian politics at two levels: the level of the personality of the Prime Minister and, secondly, the more important level, the direction which this country will take in the months ahead.

At the personality level, the Prime Minister will be the first Labor leader post war to be executed by his own Caucus. It will be the end of the longest serving period for a Labor Prime Minister, and it will be the end of the prime ministership of the most successful—electorally—Labor Prime Minister in Australia's history, who is to be replaced by the ex-Treasurer whose policies have brought about the highest unemployment since the Great Depression in the 1930s.

If there is a symbol of what has been going on within the Government in the last few weeks that captures the totality of Government members' thinking, it was last week when the unemployment figures were released. It was a classic. It showed how these people think. On the day that the unemployment figure came out showing the highest number of unemployed since the 1930s—10.5 per cent, or 900,700 Australians unemployed —Government members, instead of going into crisis mode and being concerned about the level of unemployment, were having secret conspiratorial meetings, one lot trying to keep the Prime Minister in the top job and the other lot trying to dislodge him from the top job and install `Mr Recession', the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland. There was absolutely no concern for those 900,000 Australians unemployed and no concern whatsoever—not a second thought—for the business people and the small investors who have seen their dreams shattered as a result of this Government's economic incompetence.

Government members did not stop to consider for a moment that nearly one in three young Australians is unemployed as a result of the Government's policies. These young people will be scarred for life as a result of this Government's failure. Government members are more concerned about their own jobs than anybody else's job. That says a lot about this Government and its priorities. That is what the day the unemployment figures were released showed: when it comes to jobs, the only jobs these people are interested in are their own jobs and nobody else's—the Prime Minister trying to keep his job and the ex-Treasurer trying to get it. It does not really matter who wins, they will both go on jointly putting themselves ahead of the community that they were elected to serve.

It is not only the two combatants, the two protagonists at the top; it is all their soldiers too. On the one hand, there are the Hawkites, the new Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley)—and I do not suppose he will be Minister for Finance for long—and the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), whichever side he is on; on the other, there are all the Keatingites, spending all their time, running up all their phone bills, and using all their stationery, officers and staff in actively pushing their own ambitions. This Government—not just the Prime Minister, but this Government and all the various factions which it comprises—has put itself ahead of the people and has failed the people.

I thought the Prime Minister's defence today in response to the censure motion also highlighted the second and substrata issue that I think today's events bring forward. When we placed a censure motion against the Prime Minister and sought his response to the charge of economic mismanagement, he spent virtually the whole of his speech attacking the Opposition. We have not been in office for eight or nine years. Today's problems are the problems of this Government.
