One of the reasons why this Prime Minister finds himself about to be executed in the Caucus tonight, if that is what happens, is that when we released the Fightback program, a comprehensive set of sweeping reforms to fix Australia's long term economic problems, this Government, which for 12 or 18 months had been saying, `Just release it. We can't wait for the day when you guys release it. We can't wait for the chance to get our hands on it and to demolish it from day one', had no response and no vision whatsoever. This Government has been in office for eight years, and it does not have the vaguest idea of what to do next in terms of solving Australia's economic problems that the Government itself is largely responsible for. The realisation that this Government has no response to the alternative vision that we have presented has dawned not only on this Government and the coalition but also on the whole Australian community.
Today we had the Prime Minister in his swan song. He stood in this place reading out word for word from a speech which had been drafted, typed and given to him by the bureaucracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense. You make it up as you go along.

—It is not nonsense. The speech was there on the dispatch box. If the honourable member for Capricornia had been just a bit closer to the front bench, he would have seen it. One would have thought that the Prime Minister in his swan song might have put up some defence or given some statement, some idea of his achievements, if he could find them, in his time as Prime Minister. There was nothing. There is an absolute vacuum when we look back over the wasted years of this Government. It is disappointing that he then went off on a whole pack of lies about the coalition's policy. He advocated a luxury tax on cars with the GST. That is just amazing. The Labor Party has just abolished the luxury car tax.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister then attacked us for our tax cuts. He said, `The rich are going to do much better than the poor'. That is his basic argument; it is the same old argument. Back in 1987—that is not so long ago—the Government introduced so-called tax reforms. The after tax increase for a person on $5,000 a year was 2.1 per cent; the after-tax increase for a person on $200,000 was not 2.1 per cent, it was 21.7 per cent. What incredible hypocrisy. It is just amazing that the Prime Minister could come in here and attack our package on the basis of so-called regressivity. Look at the Government's record, for heaven's sake—and that is not even half the picture. Government members have to look at the entirety of our package. What has absolutely gazumped the Government is the fact that our package is actually progressive; the people at the low end get proportionately more than people at the high end. If the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley), who is at the table, is going to speak next, we ask him to stand up and defend his superannuation. I see the smirk on his face. There it is—got him in one.

Those opposite defend the fact that high income earners receive a tax benefit of 33c in the dollar compared with the 6c in the dollar received by those on low incomes. That is a simple challenge to the Minister. He is going to be hot to trot and will deliver all the nonsense he can muster. I ask him to give us a simple explanation of how he justifies the regressivity of the benefits of superannuation under his policy. We ask him to do that and we will test him to see whether he starts with that in his response.

If Government members look at the totality of the package, they will see that we do not just provide benefits in superannuation for low income earners; in fact, the package is littered with benefits for those the Government claims to be concerned about. We have doubled the family allowance for those with incomes up to $30,000. The biggest benefit goes to those in greatest need.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't support the family.

—They do not support the family. Let us see whether the Minister opposes that proposition. We advocate a 50 per cent increase for those with incomes between $30,000 and $40,000 and a 6 per cent increase for those with incomes above $40,000. That is a clearly progressive measure within our package. The $300 increase in the annual dependent spouse rebate for families with children has been capped for the first time. What is the Minister's response to that? Silence, is my guess.

PARA.TAB: For those who take out private health insurance we have targeted tax concessions to those on low incomes. We have targeted the first home owners scheme to those in greatest need—the young people and those with incomes of less than $40,000 a year. A large portion of the increase in funding for education will go to low income, non-government schools and TAFE colleges. Again, the money will go to those in greatest need.

We zero rate health and education; in other words, we take tax off and we do not put it back on again. We financially advantage the provision of health and education services. Who does that particularly benefit? It benefits those on low incomes and the great swag of middle income earners. We maintain bulkbilling for pensioners, health care cardholders, the disabled, veterans and war widows for visits to doctors, all up covering about $4m. On the top end, we require the high income earners—this is something the Government has never had the guts to do—to stand on their own feet and take out private health insurance and, if they do not, we levy them.

The Minister is going to be full of hot air. What is his personal view? What is his honest reaction to the progressivity of our particular health fund insurance proposals? The $50m by way of increased funding for charitable and welfare organisations will help those greatest in need. They are very capable of achieving results for the low income earners. Why does the Minister not match that? Is it just too difficult for him to recognise that something in our package may be beneficial for those whom he claims to represent? The offsetting increase in pensions is 8 per cent. That is much more than the price impact of the package.

The level of prices will not go up 15 per cent, it will go up 4.4 per cent. The reason for that is that we are abolishing so many of the hidden consumption taxes which the Government relies upon, some of which are very regressive. The payroll tax is very regressive—nobody disputes that. Under this Government, the wholesale sales tax has become much more regressive. The Government has been hitting its own and has the cheek to attack us for a regressive tax system. Good God, how far will Government members sink? How desperate are they? We have had a repeat performance from the Prime Minister today in what may well be his swan song.

As the top job—the Prime Minister's job—has been fought over, this country's economic circumstances have continued to deteriorate. As people come to the Parliament today and listen to this debate, they want to know who has a set of policies that will provide this country with a glimmer of hope for the future. The answer to that is obvious to us all: only the coalition's Fightback package promises and provides people with some hope and some sense of vision for the future of this country. Those opposite stand condemned and deserve censure as they have, in an introverted way, been more concerned with their own jobs than the jobs of all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —This extraordinary fellow, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), has been wandering around the country for the last couple of weeks gradually getting himself into more and more trouble with virtually every group that he addresses on the subject of the consumption tax. He is having trouble with the building industry, the tourism industry and, increasingly, with small business. When he gets to each of these places and they actually ask him some sort of detailed question on what impact this whole scenario is going to have on them, how the Opposition is going to administer it and what its price effects are going to be on them, he simply repeats the sort of nonsense that we have heard here today—the gormless, meandering argument by assertion.

PARA.TAB: Whenever the honourable member for Flinders is presented with serious criticism of the impact of this package on the way in which the macro-economy is managed in this country, he comes out on to the steps of the Parliament for his one-liners, to his cobbled together press conferences, and says, `The package was properly assessed by the people who advised us. We would argue for our position against theirs any time'. It is fine to hear that argument. At some point he has to argue his position against ours if he is going to have any credibility at all.

It has to be acknowledged that, right at this moment, the Opposition is having a dream run because of the circumstances in which we find ourselves. There is no doubt about that. We are in a position that is somewhat analogous to the famous occasion of that confrontation between Winston Churchill and Lady Astor. When Lady Astor alleged erroneously, as his reply indicates, that Winston Churchill was drunk, he took a look at Lady Astor and he said, `Yes, and you are ugly, and the difference between us tomorrow is that I'll be sober'.

The fact of the matter is that tomorrow we will be in a position to focus on the sorts of issues that members opposite are raising in contemporary Australian politics. When that happens they will find that they are 18 months away from an election and that their package is now subject to increasing analysis.

At the moment, people in the gallery and very few people in the public have had an opportunity to witness what the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) is saying. He turns up in zoos to look at the impact of the GST on animals and he goes to supermarkets and suggests that the average family buys seven kilos of dog food a week and about seven litres of Harpic—but no bread, no meat and no vegetables—and lives on various household poisons.

As the Opposition Leader wanders around the country with those picture opportunities, with the State-based media as opposed to the media here, he will find himself increasingly required to give some answers. He actually knows this; he knows that all the serious economic commentators in this country have picked him. He knows that they have gone through the effects of his package in terms of both its achievability and, if the attempt is made to achieve it, its actual effect on the economy. They have demonstrated comprehensively what nonsense it is. When he actually appears before business forums he says, `Ross this, Ross that. I have had this discussion with Ross. Ross will find this or that'. I wonder who this Ross is who keeps appearing whenever the Leader of the Opposition manages to find himself at any forum in which there is any likelihood of a serious intellectual analysis of the proposition he has put forward. He is extremely defensive, because that Ross happens to be Ross Gittins, who day after day in the Sydney Morning Herald has done an exercise on this package which has rendered it utterly, totally, intellectually impotent. That is the position in which the Leader of the Opposition finds himself.

That is not a good position to be in, intellectually, 18 months out from an election; there is no question about that. If there is one thing that has to be understood about this package, it is this: this is the end of the Liberal Party's agenda as far as public presentation is concerned. It locks members of the Liberal Party in. This is what they will do. They will have nothing else to offer. Their position stands or falls on the viability of this package. What a thing to introduce into our society when what our society needs is major micro-economic reform, which it is getting from this Government, and major labour market reform, which it is getting from this Government and which ensures that the inflation rate that we now have gets locked in so that we are an internationally competitive nation. When those are the crying needs of this country, some bunch of loons marches down the main street with a lit bomb, like some nineteenth century anarchist looking for the grand duke so that they can lob the darn thing in his carriage, in order to start in the Australian economy the equivalent of World War I. That is what the Opposition mostly represents, if we are looking for historical analogies, as far as its package is concerned.

In that package the material that has so concerned the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) gets 1 1/2 pages. The serried ranks of people who are supposed to be responsible for micro-economic reform in this country—these are central issues—get a couple of pages. But what else do we get? We get, again in that sort of military parlance that Winston Churchill was so fond of, the principle that in war time it is necessary for a central truth to be surrounded by legions of lies in order for it to be got through. What is the central truth of this package at the end of the day? Economic policy is to be subordinated to the introduction of the harshest goods and services tax around.

We are talking about the productivity of this darn country. What if I came into this chamber cold and said as Minister for Finance, `Have I got a top idea for Australian business. If you take an item and add value to it, I am going to tax it at 15 per cent when you on-sell it, and when you add a bit more value to that, we will tax it again at 15 per cent, and when you add a bit more value, we will again tax it at 15 per cent. There will be a rebate system down the line, so that at the end of the day it will be paid for by the person who ultimately picks it up.'? If I said that that was my idea for increasing the productivity of this country, would anybody in this country think that I had come up with a good one? Would anybody in this country think that I had come up with what is going to be the thing that will lift Australians out of a malaise and will make them work harder and work better? Would anyone seriously think that that would be a proposition? Yet this is what the Opposition invites us to think.

Let me tell honourable members one or two other things about goods and services taxes elsewhere. People who introduce such taxes, as they are in existence mainly in Europe, generally do so with at least a partial eye to what their impact is likely to be on the average household and a partial eye to the possibility that maybe one needs to introduce elements of equity into the package itself. Therefore, in many of the European countries in which a goods and services tax operates, it is levied at differential rates so that luxury items are taxed more heavily than items which are more in everyday use and, above all, items that are essential in everyday use are not taxed at all. Therefore, a far higher rate of exemption and a far higher level of equity are introduced into such packages.

There is another piece of nonsense from the Opposition. Opposition members stand and say in this place, `Listen, it is so unfair. You have a wholesale sales tax now. What does the Government say about the fairness of that?'. I have listened to the Opposition on that subject. I have listened to that argument. If what honourable members opposite are seriously proposing is, say, a goods and services tax levied at 5 per cent, there is no doubt at all that at the various wholesale sales tax arrangements up to the 20 per cent mark, goods that were subject to a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax and then subsequently became subject to a 5 per cent GST would be cheaper. But the fact of the matter is that no goods under the wholesale sales tax, in so far as the taxation regime has an impact on its pricing—apart from those goods taxed at the 30 per cent level—are going to be cheaper.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—Of course it is true.
—It is not true.

—Of course it is true, you clown. When wholesale sales tax on an item goes through to the fellow who retails it, and there is a 30 per cent mark-up—which is not an unusual mark-up from the wholesaler to the retailer—and the Government charges in at 20 per cent at the wholesale tax level or ultimately at 15 per cent at the GST level, the results will work out at roughly the same. The only outputs that will materially be reduced are those at the 30 per cent level. The goods that are up there at the 30 per cent level— and these good will be reduced—are cars costing over $45,000, furs, jewellery, cameras, et cetera. Therefore, the only goods which will, by virtue of a change in the taxation arrangements, be materially cheaper will be those at that end which can by no means be described as—
—Oh, come on. This is rubbish.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Order! I warn the honourable member for Flinders.

TALK.START.PARA: —a set of goods which constitutes anything like personal essentials. Honourable members opposite are saying that, in order to bring those goods down in terms of taxation treatment, they will keep in place taxation arrangements which already exist on a number of goods and bring into the taxation system a vast array of goods and services that ordinary people need. Of course, it is an act of great inequity as far as the community is concerned.

PARA.TAB: What amazes me is that the public has now begun to understand this. When we tried to get the old Australia Card through, we started off with about 80 per cent public approval. The goods and services tax has started off at about 50 per cent approval. Somehow through the flak in the media in the last couple of weeks, between the sort of extraordinary pic-fax of the Opposition Leader parading himself around the country, it has actually got through to the average Australians that there is a man waiting around the corner with a great big club with a 15 per cent marker on it, ready to whack them over the back of the head as they come through.

Small business understands, too. I happen to know that from personal anecdotal evidence. Into my office a week ago came a man who has been a longstanding Liberal Party branch president in my electorate. He gave me what was effectively his resignation letter from the Liberal Party in Western Australia because he was a small businessman who had done his sums. He had made a calculation. He does not pay payroll tax, I might say, as one would expect, and 60 per cent of Australian small business does not. He had done his sums on what he would have to do in his accountancy arrangements to operate his business with a goods and services tax in place. He understood that he would be going to the wall. He did not think that this was a terribly good idea. So this fellow who, at least at the State level, had been a Liberal Party candidate from time to time in my electorate is a Liberal Party member and candidate no longer. That, of course, was a piece of intelligent analysis on his part. This will be more and more the feature. The Liberal Party has had the best run it is going to get on the goods and services tax. It has had the best of it. From this point on it will be hard slog uphill for honourable members opposite as each group in the community begins to understand the true ramifications of it.

In the final analysis we do not need to worry too much about that sort of area. The Opposition will be found out. The population will understand that the Opposition will damage it; what the population may not understand, but will come to understand, is just how much the Opposition will damage the country. The policy settings that the Treasurer referred to will mean that in one year there will be a massive clawback, which will massively increase unemployment in this country, and in the next year there will be a huge fiscal surge into the economy, ultimately sending interest rates rocketing through the roof.

The Opposition will introduce the situation where practically every conceivable impact on inflation that there is will be massively affected by the way in which the goods and services tax is introduced. But what is the coalition's answer to it? `Well, we will have the Prices Surveillance Authority run its eye over it'. Two or three years ago the coalition tried to abolish the Prices Surveillance Authority. The Opposition went into an election campaign with that approach.I quite like the Prices Surveillance Authority. We on this side have an ongoing favourable disposition towards it, but we do not expect it to monitor something like a million businesses and a million taxation outlets for a goods and services tax in this country. Fair dinkum; we are not in the business of considering that that Authority will have that sort of capability.

So what we have here, presented as a Liberal Party position as far as the future of this country is concerned, is a most terrible fraud. But fortunately it is an exposable one, and over the next 18 months we will have a great deal of joy, as a political exercise, going through it and pointing out what the employment and inflation impacts will be, how devastating it will be, and what a pathetic vision it is for the future of this country. We will start by shutting off this debate now to give us an opportunity to get out there to do that. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Question put:
That the motion (Dr Hewson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present a schedule showing Government responses to House of Representatives and joint committee reports for the period 6 June 1991 to 18 December 1991, and outstanding responses to reports presented from 1982. Copies of the schedule are being made available to honourable

INTERJECT.PARA: members and it will be incorporated in Hansard.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSES FOR THE PERIOD 6 JUNE 1991 TO 18 DECEMBER 1991
AND OUTSTANDING RESPONSES TO REPORTS PRESENTED FROM 1982

PARA.TAB: This document continues the practice of presenting to the House of Representatives at approximately six-monthly intervals a schedule listing government responses to House and joint committee reports as well as responses to reports which remain outstanding.

The practice of presenting this schedule to the House follows the undertaking of successive governments to respond to parliamentary committee reports in a timely fashion. In 1978 the Prime Minister announced that the Government would formally respond to committee reports within six months of the tabling of a report. With a change in Government in 1983, there was also a change to the method of response to parliamentary committee reports. On 24 August 1983 the Leader of the Government in the Senate stated that irrespective of any undertaking by the previous Government, the Government had decided that responses to parliamentary committee reports would be made by way of a ministerial statement in Parliament. Furthermore, the period in which responses were to be made would be reduced from six months to three months. More recently, the Government has advised that responses to committee reports will be made by means of a letter to a committee chairman, with the letter being tabled in the House at the earliest opportunity. However, the date of the presentation of the Government's response to the Parliament will be considered the date of the Government's response, not the date of any correspondence with the committee.

The schedule does not include reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, the Joint Committee on Public Works nor the reports of the House of Representatives Members' Interests, Privileges, Publications and Selection Committees. Responses to reports of the Public Accounts Committee are usually made in the form of Finance Minutes, which are tabled by the Committee.
Government responses to Public Works Committee reports are normally reflected in motions for the approval of works after the relevant report has been presented and considered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do, Mr Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. In the Sydney Morning Herald last Thursday there was a feature article relating to the Labor leadership issue. In that article my name and photograph appeared in a line-up of so-called defectors from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating). That description of me was clearly wrong and the Sydney Morning Herald has since carried an article correcting this.

PARA.TAB: After contacting the Deputy Editor, Mr Hicks, I was informed that the error came about because claims were being made to journalists that I had shifted camps and this was accepted without being checked with me. I received an apology from the supervising journalist, which I accept in good faith.

Mr Speaker, whilst a correction has been carried, there is an obligation on the part of the Press Gallery to check out claims involving personal credibility because failure to do this can be very damaging to MPs—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member is now debating the issue.
—who are constantly being judged by their peers in this place.
—The honourable member will resume his seat.
—Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a statement to the House.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do Mr Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—Yesterday in the Senate by way of a question, Senator Tambling made serious allegations against me and allegations against members of the Gagudju Association, an Aboriginal organisation, and misled the Senate as to the position of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation.

PARA.TAB: The substance of his allegation in respect of me was that I was an unauthorised consultant on a taxpayer backed management investment deal, whatever that meant. He also alleged that I had interfered in the internal affairs of the Gagudju Association, an Aboriginal organisation of traditional owners who own hotel properties at Jabiru and Cooinda.

The facts are, of course, that for some years I and my family have `had skin' with two Aboriginal organisations, Gagudju being one of them. `Having skin' simply means that one has been asked to become part of a clan. One becomes part of what is a broad Aboriginal community and family group. This carries considerable obligations. It is an honour which I was asked to take when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I was proud and pleased to accept that honour. It is not a token relationship.

In September of last year I was approached by Miss Jessie Alderson, the chairperson of the Gagudju Association who was concerned and worried about the financial and legal problems that were arising in respect of the future of both Cooinda and Crocodile hotels and she sought my assistance. That was not an offer that I could personally refuse, nor did I want to. I accepted her offer to assist on the basis of taking up an honorary consultation.

Having regard to the importance of both of those hotels to the tourism industry in the Northern Territory and having failed to contact Mr Vale, the Minister for Tourism in the Territory, I contacted the Chief Minister and told him of my involvement, of the objectives of the Gagudju Association and what I hoped to achieve. I also indicated to the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) and Senator Collins what was happening.

At various meetings the Gagudju Association has strongly indicated its desire to obtain greater involvement in the decisions concerning its own hotel properties with a view to ultimately managing them itself. My task has been simply to assist the realisation of those objectives against a number of competing agendas by various tourist groups.
Management agreements are made frequently all over Australia. A fresh one was made only this week in the Northern Territory. What I find of concern here—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable member is now starting to debate the issue rather than saying where he has been misrepresented.

—No. I will finish in a minute, sir. What I find of concern is that on the first occasion an Aboriginal group in Australia says `We want to learn how to manage and control our own hotels', it is the subject of attack and spurious allegations are made about its objectives and actions by Senator Tambling. I am proud of my association with the Gagudju Association and with other Aboriginal groups in the Northern Territory. I leave it to Senator Tambling to explain, if he can, his public relationships with Aboriginal groups in the Territory.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The adverse consequences for Australia of the `pump-priming' economic policy U-turn being proposed both by the current Treasurer and the alternative Prime Minister, the Member for Blaxland.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker—

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Griffiths) put:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That orders of the day Nos 2 to 11, Government Business, be postponed until a later hour of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, I was wondering whether the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), in support of his motion, could give us some indication as to what the business of the House will be for the remainder of the day.
—Looking at the events here, it looks very much as though we will be going through until about 3 or 4 a.m. to deal with all the material that is before us, but it is very difficult to predict that.

—Speaker, again with your indulgence, is it the intention of the Leader of the House to move a motion that is on the Notice Paper that would effectively prevent any member of the Parliament, other than a Minister, from moving the suspension of Standing Orders?
—Yes.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That Standing Order 399 be suspended for the remainder of this year, except when a motion is moved pursuant to the Standing Order by a Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: This will help facilitate the business of the House for the rest of the day and ensure that what is an extremely tight program is gone through. This is the first time since we have been in office that we have moved this motion; as a precedent, we have the shining example of the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Fife), who I believe was the last Minister to move this motion, no doubt for similar reasons—to ensure that for the rest of a very busy day the proceedings of the House can move along with a reasonable degree of expedition and concentration on the legislative issues that are before the House. With such an admirable and ample precedent before me, I have moved accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will oppose the motion moved by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley). I expected that the Leader of the House would draw to the attention of honourable members the fact that I was the last Minister to move this resolution, but the circumstances were completely different. There were two basic differences. The first is that the Opposition at the time was disorderly and was frustrating the conveyance of legislation through the chamber. This is a very serious matter. The second difference is that between now and 8 p.m. this evening, when the House resumes after dinner, there is every indication that Australia could have a new Prime Minister.
—That is irrelevant.

—It is not irrelevant. The Prime Minister and the Executive have a very important role in this country. What the Leader of the House is proposing now is a means by which the Opposition, for the remainder of today and, if the House happens to sit tomorrow, for the remainder of the sittings for this year, will have no capacity to move any motion concerning the changes that might occur tonight. Therefore, the circumstances are quite different. The Government is not just frustrating the Opposition. After all, a democracy is a system whereby the majority view prevails and the minority view is heard. On this occasion, the Leader of the House, with the support of the numbers of the Government, will take action to ensure that, for the remainder of this day, there will be no capacity for the Opposition to move any motion at all in relation to the monumental changes that are likely to occur tonight. We oppose the motion and we will vote against it.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received advice from the Opposition Whip that he has nominated Mr K.J. Andrews to be a member of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in place of Mr Smith.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration in Committee of the Whole House forthwith.
Consideration of Senate's amendments.
Senate's amendments—

PROCTEXT.PARA: No. 1—Clause 2, page 1, lines 6 to 8, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "2.(1) Parts 1 and 3 commence on the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent.
"(2) Subject to subsection (3), Parts 2, 4 and 5 commence on a day to be fixed by Proclamation.
"(3) If Parts 2, 4 and 5 do not commence within the period of 6 months beginning on the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent, they commence on the first day after the end of that period.".

PROCTEXT.PARA: No. 2-After clause 2, page 1, insert the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "2A.(1) Subject to subsection (5):

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)the Australian Electoral Commission must review such provisions of this Act as are prescribed for the purposes of this paragraph, and report to the Minister accordingly; and
(b)such other persons or bodies as are prescribed must review such provisions of this Act as are prescribed for the purposes of this paragraph, and report to the Minister accordingly.

PARA.TAB: "(2) A report referred to in subsection (1) may include suggestions for amendments of this Act to solve problems identified in the report.

"(3) A review referred to in subsection (1) must commence within 6 months after the last declaration of a poll at the second general election of members of the House of Representatives held after the commencement of this section.
"(4) The Minister shall cause copies of a report referred to in subsection (1) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days after its receipt by the Minister.

"(5) Subsection (1) does not apply if, 3 months after the first sitting of the Parliament elected at the second general election of members of the House of Representatives after the commencement of this section, an inquiry into some or all of the provisions of this Act by a committee of the Parliament is in progress but has not concluded.
"(6) The Governor-General may make regulations prescribing matters for the purposes of this section.".

PROCTEXT.PARA: No. 3-Clause 4, page 4, paragraph (b), proposed definition of "policy launch", line 17, after "means a", insert "single".
No. 4-Clause 4, page 4, paragraph (b), proposed definition of "public health matter", lines 38 to 40, omit the definition.
No. 5-Clause 4, page 4, paragraph (b), at end of paragraph, add the following definition:
"`Senate election' has the same meaning as in the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918;".
No. 6-Clause 5, page 5, line 3, omit "paragraph" (second occurring), substitute "paragraphs".
No. 7-Clause 5, page 5, after proposed paragraph 16(1)(ca), add the following paragraph:

"(cb)by order, to determine guidelines, not inconsistent with the regulations, to be observed by a broadcaster in respect of the days and times when, and the manner in which, election broadcasts within the meaning of Division 3 of Part IIID are to be made;".
No. 8-Clause 6, page 5, after heading to proposed Part IIID, insert the following heading:

PARA.TAB: "`Division 1—Introductory".

PROCTEXT.PARA: No. 9-Clause 6, page 5, proposed subsection 95(2), line 15, omit "sections 95A, 95B, 95C, 95D and 95E", substitute "this Part".
No. 10-Clause 6, page 5, after proposed section 95, insert the following heading:

PARA.TAB: "`Division 2—Political advertisements, etc.".

PROCTEXT.PARA: No. 11-Clause 6, pages 5 and 6, proposed section 95A, line 17 (page 5) to line 13 (page 6), omit the section, substitute the following section:

PARA.TAB: "`95A.(1) Nothing in this Part prevents a broadcaster from broadcasting:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)an item of news or current affairs, or a comment on any such item; or
(b)a talkback radio program.

PARA.TAB: `(2) Nothing in this Part prevents the holder of a public radio licence who provides a service for visually handicapped persons from broadcasting any material that he or she is permitted to broadcast under section 119AB.
`(3) Nothing in this Part prevents a broadcaster from broadcasting an advertisement for, or on behalf of, a charitable organisation if:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)the advertisement is aimed at promoting the objects of the organisation; and
(b)the advertisement does not explicitly advocate voting for or against a candidate in an election or a political party.

PARA.TAB: `(4) Nothing in this Part prevents a broadcaster from broadcasting public health matter, whether by way of advertisement or otherwise.
`(5) In this section:

PROCTEXT.PARA: "charitable organisation" means a public organisation whose objects are to benefit the public through the relief of poverty, or the advancement of education, religion, public health or science;
"public health matter" means any matter relating to public health, other than matter that:
(a)directly or indirectly promotes or criticises a particular public health system; or
(b)explicitly advocates voting for or against a candidate in an election or a political party.".
No. 12-Clause 6, page 6, proposed subsection 95B(4), line 25, omit "section 95E", substitute "Divisions 3 and 4".
No. 13-Clause 6, page 7, proposed subsection 95B(6), definition of "prescribed material", paragraph (d), line 12, omit "or of a State or Territory".

PROCTEXT.PARA: No. 21-Clause 6, page 9, after proposed section 95D, insert the following section and Division:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Some matter not to be broadcast during certain other periods

PARA.TAB: "`95DA.(1) If, when a prescribed day in relation to the Parliament of the Commonwealth occurs, it does not do so during the election period in relation to an election to the Parliament, a broadcaster must not broadcast any matter (other than exempt matter) for or on behalf of the government, or a government authority, of the Commonwealth during the period that starts on that day and ends immediately before the next election period starts.

`(2) If, when a prescribed day in relation to the legislature of a Territory (other than the Australian Capital Territory) occurs, it does not do so during the election period in relation to an election to the legislature, a broadcaster must not broadcast any matter (other than exempt matter) for or on behalf of the government, or a government authority, of that Territory during the period that starts on that day and ends immediately before the next election period starts.
`(3) A broadcaster must not broadcast any matter (other than exempt matter) for or on behalf of the government, or a government authority, of the Australian Capital Territory during the period that:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)starts 3 calendar months before the day on which the Legislative Assembly for the Australian Capital Territory is next due to expire; and
(b)ends immediately before the start of the election period in relation to the next ordinary election to the Legislative Assembly.

PARA.TAB: `(4) In this section:

PROCTEXT.PARA: "election" does not include a by-election;
"prescribed day" means:
(a)in relation to the Parliament of the Commonwealth—the day that occurs 3 calendar months before the day on which the House of Representatives is next due to expire; and
(b)in relation to the legislature of a Territory—the day that occurs 3 calendar months before the day on which the legislature is next due to expire.

PARA.TAB: `Division 3—Free election broadcasting time

PARA.EMPHASIS: Application of Division to radio broadcasts

PARA.TAB: `95DB.(1) Nothing in this Division is to be treated as requiring or permitting the Service or a licensee to broadcast an election broadcast by radio.
`(2) Nothing in this Division is to be treated as requiring the Corporation to broadcast an election broadcast by radio other than on its metropolitan and regional AM networks.

`(3) Despite section 95DC, the Corporation may broadcast by radio a broadcast that complies with paragraphs 95DC(a) to (e), inclusive, but which lasts for longer than 1 minute, and any such broadcast is taken to be an election broadcast for the purposes of this Division.
`(4) Despite anything in this Division, the Corporation may determine the times when it broadcasts election broadcasts by radio.

`95DC. Subject to section 95DB, a broadcast made on behalf of a political party, a candidate or a group in relation to an election is, for the purposes of this Division, taken to be an election broadcast if, and only if:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)the broadcast is of an advertisement that consists of words spoken by a single speaker (without dramatic enactment or impersonation) accompanied, where the advertisement is televised, by a transmitted image that consists of the head and shoulders of the speaker; and
(b)the broadcast does not include any other image, or includes a single additional static background image only; and
(c)no other vocal sounds are included in the broadcast; and
(d)the speaker is a candidate in the election or a member of the Parliament of the Commonwealth or a State, or of a legislature of a Territory; and
(e)if section 117 applies—the required particulars within the meaning of that section are announced by the person who speaks the words of the advertisement; and
(f)the broadcast lasts for:

PARA.TAB: (i)in the case of a televised broadcast—2 minutes; and
(ii)in the case of a broadcast by radio—1 minute; and

PROCTEXT.PARA: (g)the broadcast is made using a unit of free time allocated to the broadcaster under section 95DK.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Automatic grant of free time to certain parties

PARA.TAB: `95DD.(1) The Tribunal must, within the prescribed period in relation to an election, grant a period of free time to each political party that:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)was represented by one or more members in the relevant Parliament or legislature immediately before the end of the last sittings of that Parliament or legislature held before the election; and
(b)is contesting the election with at least the prescribed number of candidates.

PARA.TAB: `(2) The total free time period to be granted to political parties under subsection (1) is the period equal to 90% of the total time in respect of the election, and the Tribunal must grant each of those parties such part of that total free time period as it determines in accordance with the regulations.

`(3) Regulations made for the purposes of subsection (2) must, so far as is practicable, give effect to the principle that the amount of free time granted to each party should bear the same proportion to the total free time period mentioned in that subsection as the number of formal first preference votes obtained by that party or its candidates at the last election to the relevant Parliament or legislature bears to the total number of such votes obtained by all of the parties mentioned in subsection (1) or their candidates at that last election.
`(4) In this section:

PROCTEXT.PARA: "election" means an election (other than a by-election) to:
(a)the Parliament of the Commonwealth; or
(b)the legislature of a Territory; or
(c)a State Parliament;
"total time", in relation to an election, means the total free time available in respect of the election, being a time worked out in accordance with the regulations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Regulations for the purposes of section 95DD

PARA.TAB: `95DE. This Part does not apply in relation to an election to the Parliament of the Commonwealth or of a State, or in relation to an election to the legislature of a Territory until regulations are made for the purposes of section 95DD that relate to that election.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Applications for grant of free time

PARA.TAB: `95DF.(1) The chief executive officer of a political party (other than a political party to which section 95DD applies), or any other person or group of persons, may apply to the Tribunal for a grant of free time in relation to an election (other than a by-election) to:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)the Parliament of the Commonwealth; or
(b)the legislature of a Territory; or
(c)a State Parliament.

PARA.TAB: `(2) An application must be in the approved form and made in accordance with the regulations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Grant of free time on applications in relation to Senate elections

PARA.TAB: `95DG.(1) If, on receipt of an application by a person for a grant of free time in relation to a Senate election, the Tribunal is satisfied that:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)the person is a candidate in the election; and
(b)the person was a member of the Senate immediately before the end of the last sittings of the Senate held before the election; and
(c)the person is not a member of a political party to whom a grant of free time has been made under section 95DD;
the Tribunal must grant the person a period of free time.

PARA.TAB: `(2) The period to be granted to a person under this section is a period determined by the Tribunal in accordance with the regulations, being a period equal to not less than 5% of the total time in respect of the election nor more than 10% of that total time.

`(3) If the Tribunal is required under this section to grant a period of free time to 2 or more persons, the Tribunal must divide the period determined under subsection (2) between them in accordance with the regulations.
`(4) In this section:

PROCTEXT.PARA: "total time" has the same meaning as in section 95DD.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Grant of free time on other applications

PARA.TAB: `95DH.(1) If, on receipt of an application for the grant to a political party of a period of free time in relation to an election, the Tribunal is satisfied that the party has endorsed one or more candidates to contest the election, the Tribunal may, subject to the regulations, grant the party a period of free time determined in accordance with the regulations.

`(2) If, on receipt of an application for the grant to a person or a group of persons (other than a person or persons to whom section 95DG applies) of a period of free time in relation to an election, the Tribunal is satisfied that the person, or each of the persons, is a candidate in the election, the Tribunal may grant the person or group a period of free time in accordance with the regulations.
`95DJ.(1) The Tribunal must, in accordance with the regulations, notify:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)the chief executive officer of each political party to which a period of free time has been granted; and
(b)every other person to whom such a period has been granted;
of the period so granted.

PARA.TAB: `(2) If the Tribunal refuses to grant an application under section 95DG or 95DH, the Tribunal must, in accordance with the regulations, notify the applicant accordingly and specify its reasons for refusing the application.
`(3) The Tribunal must cause a notice to be published in the Gazette specifying:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)the political parties and persons to whom a period of free time has been granted; and
(b)the period that has been granted to each of them.

PARA.TAB: `95DK.(1) The Tribunal must divide each period of free time granted under this Division into units of free time in accordance with the regulations.

`(2) If the division of a period of free time granted to a political party, person or group under this Division results in a number of whole units and part of a unit, the Tribunal must, in accordance with the regulations, distribute that part of a unit to or between any other political parties, persons or groups granted a period of free time under this Division.
`(3) The Tribunal must, in accordance with the regulations, allocate units of free time to broadcasters.

`95DL.(1) Subject to this section, where one or more units of free time are allocated to a broadcaster under section 95DK, the broadcaster must make the unit or units available for use in making one or more election broadcasts during the election period for the election on behalf of the political party, person or group to whom the time is granted.
`(2) Subject to this section, the broadcaster must use the units in accordance with the regulations and any guidelines determined by the Tribunal.
`(3) A broadcaster must not make an election broadcast in relation to an election before the close of nominations for the election.
`(4) Subject to this section, a broadcaster must make, during the election period in relation to an election, at least:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)in the case of an election to the Parliament of the Commonwealth—3 election broadcasts by television on each day on which the broadcaster is required to use units of free time allocated to it to make an election broadcast; and
(b)in the case of an election to the legislature of a Territory—the prescribed number of election broadcasts by television on each such day; and
(c)in the case of an election to a State Parliament—2 election broadcasts by television on each such day.

PARA.TAB: `(5) A broadcaster who is required to make an election broadcast must do so free of charge.
`(6) A broadcaster is not required to make a unit or units of free time available under subsection (1):

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)if the political party, person or group to whom the time is granted notifies the broadcaster that he, she or it does not intend to use the time; or
(b)in the prescribed circumstances.

PARA.TAB: `(7) A licensee who is required to make an election broadcast is entitled to such additional broadcasting time, for the purpose of broadcasting other material, as is determined in accordance with the regulations.

`95DM. If the Tribunal makes a decision refusing an application under section 95DG or 95DH for the grant of free time to a political party, person or group of persons, the party, person or persons may appeal to the Federal Court of Australia against the decision.".

PROCTEXT.PARA: No. 35-Clause 15, page 14, proposed subsection 314AA(2), lines 37 to 39, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsections:

No. 38-After clause 15, page 14, insert the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "15B. After section 311 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Annual returns of income and expenditure of Commonwealth Departments

together with such policy statements as are prescribed.

(b)on the election of any person as a member of the House of Representatives or as a Senator as a result of such an election.

PARA.TAB: `(7) No civil or criminal action or proceeding of any kind lies against the Commission or any other person (other than a candidate) or body in relation to the preparation, publication or delivery of any document under this section, or in relation to any matter contained in any such document.'.".

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to remind honourable members about this Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill and the shabby and appalling way the Government has behaved, and to bring back some interesting comments that we made when this Bill was first considered by the Government. It was one of its shabbiest efforts so far to try to swing the pendulum its way when it comes up for re-election. It is worth noting that when the Government first considered this Bill the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)—the current Prime Minister for at least another two hours—was supposed to have said to some of his members of Cabinet in relation to the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) that this bit of legislation would be very appropriate as it would `teach this kid a lesson'. I wonder who has learnt the lesson since this legislation has gone through its tortuous path. It has some 47 amendments, it has involved the Senate in a considerable amount of debate and now that it has reached this place there is considerable doubt about its legality from a constitutional point of view.

PARA.TAB: When the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) introduced the Bill he made some rather interesting introductory comments in his second reading speech about the duty of the representatives of the people in a democratic society. He said that this duty requires government which is free of corruption and undue influence. That is interesting to note, particularly coming from the Labor Party, a party that makes no bones about its close affiliation with the ACTU and the union movement, a party that has no problems with collecting the affiliation fees that come from the union movement. My colleague Senator Parer—and he has done quite a lot of work on this—believes that between $4m and $5m is provided to the Labor Party each year from the union movement. The Minister wants to talk about the duty that requires a government to be free of corruption and undue influence. I would have thought that $4m to $5m is quite a bit of influence. Apparently, when it comes to the trade union movement and its influence on the Labor Party, that is somehow different. As has been pointed out in another place, not only have the unions got this influence but also they have a very protected position when it comes to comparing the treatment of them and the treatment of other organisations before the Taxation Commissioner.

Because time is short I will just make a couple of comments about some of the changes that have been brought in. Of course, it is the taxpayer who is going to foot the bill. We now have a situation where the Government has agreed, in order to keep its protected position for the union movement, that private donations of up to $100 will now be tax deductible. Obviously, this could mean that the taxpayer is indirectly going to be slugged even more. Not only will the Government be putting forward a position whereby all paid political advertising on radio and television is to be banned—and not only will this ban apply to Federal elections; it is going to apply to State and local government elections, by-elections and referendums—but also the Government is going to demand free time on radio and television. Likewise it is estimated that it is going to cost something like $8m to inform every household about who is standing in each election. Many people could abuse this by nominating themselves. For $250 they can get saturation exposure within an electorate; their name could become a household word, and if they are running a business it could be rather attractive.

I want to raise another salient point, and that is whether such a Bill could be challenged on constitutional grounds. I draw the attention of honourable members to an opinion that has been given to the Opposition by Professor Zines, the Robert Garran Professor of Law at the Australian National University. Professor Zines raises some very interesting constitutional problems. First of all he looks at whether or not these provisions can validly operate in respect of State elections, whether there are substantial arguments against these provisions that concern Commonwealth elections and referendums, and whether the provision of free time is not inconsistent with the Constitution. The central provisions relating to State elections—if I can talk about State elections first—are contained in section 95D of the proposed Bill. Professor Zines says that, in his opinion:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the law comes within the provisions of section 51(v) of the Constitution. . .
He then goes on to say:
In my opinion, therefore, a federal law which purported to control the advertising of political matter in relation to a State election would be contrary to the implied constitutional prohibition.
That is very significant. So we already have some very strong constitutional questions over this legislation. In relation to State elections, he goes on to say:

The conclusion I have reached might also be derived from section 106 of the Constitution which provides, in part, that "the Constitution of each State of the Commonwealth shall, subject to this Constitution, continue as at the establishment of the Commonwealth. . .
On that first point, the validity of this legislation in relation to State elections is obviously under some doubt from a constitutional point of view.

PARA.TAB: On the second point, in relation to Commonwealth elections, Professor Zines points out that the provisions of the Bill relating to Commonwealth elections may be susceptible to constitutional attack by virtue of provisions of the Constitution relating to elections or under section 92 of the Constitution. Again, there is considerable doubt about the constitutional validity of this Bill as it relates to Commonwealth elections. On the third question that I was going to raise, Professor Zines says that there is some doubt, but he has not given a conclusive opinion.

Despite the fact that we have 47 amendments before us, despite the fact that the Government has ignored considerable advice from the coalition parties in relation to the Bill, and despite the fact that, in view of the influence of the trade union movement, the Government is running a fairly hypocritical line when it talks about elections and those in public office having a duty to be free from undue influence, this Bill has considerable doubt about it.

It is also worth noting in passing that the Australian Democrats, despite their supposed concern about many provisions of this Bill, have allowed the Government to get away with this and have supported this. It is interesting to look a little below the surface to find out why this legislation would be so attractive to the Democrats. What has been found is that, under this legislation, the Democrats will be able to more than double the amount of television advertising they have had in the past. Some carrot, I would suggest!

While the Democrats may have stated during the debate in another place that they preferred less television advertising—and they have massively increased their own electronic advertising—the fact is that at the same time they will be denying the right to free time to many other parties and groups. They will be denied the opportunity of gaining free time—

TALK.START.PARA: —Hypocrisy.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Goldstein rightly points out, it shows their hypocrisy. So others who want to advertise are going to be denied. Just to show honourable members how much it has been worth, at the last Federal election the Democrats were able to afford $380,000 in electronic advertising. As a result of this Bill, they will get the equivalent of some $1.8m.

PARA.TAB: In the short time remaining, let me say that the coalition parties have very strong reservations about the constitutional validity of some parts of this Bill. Obviously we have expressed our concern and our opposition on many occasions to the way the Government is approaching this and on the utter hypocrisy of the Government when it talks about trying to remove areas of undue influence while still quite happily accepting such huge sums from the trade union movement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief, as I understand the circumstances we are in. I want to make a few responses to the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). He is critical of the fact that there is provision for tax deductibility for a donation of $100. I find that a little bit difficult to understand.
—I wasn't critical. I drew attention to it.
—I am sorry; he was not critical, he drew our attention to it. I find it a bit

SPEECH.PARA: difficult to understand why he is drawing our attention to it since it was his Party's amendment which introduced this provision to allow a tax deduction for donations to political parties. Perhaps he could have drawn his own Party's attention to its own amendment.

PARA.TAB: The other point I would make to the honourable member is that it was the Liberal Party which proposed in the Senate that that deductibility should be unlimited; that if BHP wanted to make a $1m donation to the Liberal Party at the next election, then BHP should get a $500,000 tax deduction for that political donation. It was actually the Democrats who forced the Liberals and the Nationals to put a ceiling of $100 on that donation. I suggest that, if members of the public are concerned about a tax deduction for a donation to a political party, they should write to the Opposition because it was the Labor Party in the Senate that opposed that political donation. I would suggest that, if the honourable member is drawing our attention to those matters, perhaps he could draw the attention of honourable senators to it.

Why is this measure so important? It is important because unless something is done about the cost of political campaigns in this country all of the parties—Labor, Liberal, National and Democrats—will end up corrupt. Corruption will become entrenched.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speak for yourself.

—The honourable member knows it. We will end up with a system such as the one in the United States, where only the Rockefellers or the Heinzes can afford the tens of millions of dollars that are required to run for Congress. In effect, we are simply extending to commercial television the system of free time that now applies to the ABC. Those opposite say that this is a massive threat to democracy in this country, but it is a system that has worked in Maggie Thatcher and John Major's Britain for decades. It is a system that ensures that the political parties do not have to sell their souls to fund the cost of radio and television. This is a proposal that has not been rushed through. It is something we have been discussing since 1987. It has gone through two parliamentary inquiries, and the sooner it is adopted the better.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.
Bill returned from the Senate with amendment.
Ordered that the amendment be taken into consideration in Committee of the Whole House forthwith.
Consideration of Senate's amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clause 16, page 9, proposed section 118F (including the Notes), lines 7 to 19, omit the section, substitute the following section:

TAB.TAB: "`118F.(1) Subject to subsection (2), a person to whom section 118A applies is eligible for an advance pharmaceutical allowance.
`(2) A person is not eligible for an advance pharmaceutical allowance if:
(a)the person is receiving a service pension; and
(b)the only reason why section 118A applies to the person is that the person is receiving that pension; and
(c)the Commission is satisfied that the person's ordinary income exceeds $20.00 per fortnight.

PARA.TAB: Note:for `ordinary income' see subsection 5H(1).

`(3) If the person is a member of a couple, the amount of the person's ordinary income for the purposes of this section is worked out by adding the couple's ordinary incomes (on a fortnightly basis) and dividing by 2.
Note:for `member of a couple' see subsections 5E(1), (2), (3) and (4).".
Motion (by Mr Humphreys) agreed to:
That the amendment be agreed to.
Resolution reported.
Motion (by Mr Humphreys) proposed:
That the report be adopted.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) indicated, this amendment does correct drafting problems in relation to the pharmaceutical allowance, particularly an advance pharmaceutical allowance. This amendment substitutes a revised section 118F, which sets out the eligibility criteria for an advance pharmaceutical allowance.

PARA.TAB: I will not detain the House on this historic day because I know that members of the Caucus are very anxious to go and wield the guillotine. I simply point out once again the need for this amending legislation. It illustrates the shoddy nature of legislation from this tired Government which has run its term of office. The Government has to keep coming back to the Parliament with follow-up legislation to correct drafting mistakes, as is the case in this instance. I affirm that the Opposition is not opposed to this amending legislation.

I salute the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who is at the table—this may be his last time as Minister in that portfolio—for the great deal of work he has done. There is probably no-one more loyal to the Prime Minister of this hour than the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It was a privilege to go to Gallipoli with both the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the Prime Minister of this hour for the seventy-fifth anniversary. I could not fault the excellent arrangements for, and hosting of, that extremely important occasion. This amending legislation shows the price we in this Parliament pay for legislative gobbledegook by a Government which has not double-checked its legislation before it brings it before the House. However, the Opposition is not opposed to the measure.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Selection Committee relating to the program of business prior to 12.30 p.m. on Thursday, 27 February 1992. The report will be printed in today's Hansard and the items accorded priority for debate will be published in the Notice Paper for Tuesday, 25 February 1992.

1WATER RESOURCES: Resumption of debate (from 19 December 1991) on the motion of Mr Johns—That this House:
(1)notes that:

PARA.TAB: (a)water is one of Australia's most valuable resources;
(b)its use, treatment and availability vary enormously throughout the nation;
(c)there is debate as to whether this resource is managed sufficiently well so that the water available to the next generation will be at least as good as that currently available; and
(d)together, water and sewerage activities involve total employment of 35 000 workers and $2 billion worth of investment annually; and

SPEECH.PARA: (2)calls on the Government, in conjunction with the States and other authorities, to:

PARA.TAB: (a)consider how Australia can achieve more efficient and environmentally sound use of its water resources; and
(b)develop a national strategy for sustainable water quality management.

Each Member—10 minutes.

1MR PROSSER: To move—That this House:
(1)recognises the vital role of small business in our economy; and
(2)condemns the Government for its poor economic and wages policies which have crippled the small business sector. (Notice given 6 November 1991.)

PARA.TAB: Time allotted 60 minutes.
Speech time limits—
Each Member—10 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.
2MR RUDDOCK: To move—That the House:

(1)recalls that the Australian Government was represented at the World Summit for Children in 1990 and that, on behalf of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, several promises were made regarding the needs of the world's children, namely:

PARA.TAB: (a)to cut down on all preventable child deaths by the year 2000;
(b)to cut maternal death rates by half by the year 2000;
(c)to reduce severe and moderate malnutrition among children by one half of the 1990 level;
(d)that a goal be set for the provision of clear water and sanitation for all families;
(e)that basic education be available to all and that at least 80 percent of all children complete primary education;
(f)that education be provided for at least half of uneducated and illiterate adults, especially women; and
(g)that children be provided with protection in situations of armed conflict;

SPEECH.PARA: (2)notes that to give effect to the above promises the Australian Government promised an interdepartmental committee to develop a plan to effect these aims by the end of 1991; and
(3)regrets that with less than two months left in 1991 there has been no announcement from the Government regarding the honouring of this commitment. (Notice given 28 November 1991.)

Chairman

PROCTEXT.PARA: No.1Clause 39, pages 24 and 25, proposed subsection 82BB(1), line 35 (page 24) to line 36 (page 25), omit the subsection, substitute the following subsection:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Deduction of allowable environmental impact expenditure

PROCTEXT.PARA: "`82BB. (1) Subject to this Subdivision, if a taxpayer incurs allowable environmental impact expenditure during a year of income (in this section called the "current year of income") in connection with an income-producing project of the taxpayer, then:

PARA.TAB: (a)if a decision is made before the end of the current year of income to abandon the project—100% of the expenditure is an allowable deduction for the current year of income; or
(b)if paragraph (a) does not apply and the project ends before the end of the current year of income—the expenditure is an allowable deduction for the current year of income; or
(c)if it is not practicable to readily estimate, as at the end of the current year of income, the time when the project will end—33 1/3% of the expenditure is an allowable deduction for:

TAB.TAB: (i)the current year of income; and
(ii)each of the 2 subsequent years of income; or

PARA.TAB: (d)if:

TAB.TAB: (i)none of the above paragraphs apply; and

(ii)it is practicable to readily estimate, as at the end of the current year of income, the year of income (in this paragraph called the "final year of income") in which the end of the project will occur; and
(iii)the final year of income is one of the 3 years of income subsequent to the current year of income;

PROCTEXT.PARA: equal parts of the expenditure are respectively allowable deductions for:

TAB.TAB: (iv)the current year of income; and
(v)the final year of income; and
(vi)the second year of income (if any); or

PARA.TAB: (e)if:

TAB.TAB: (i)none of the above paragraphs apply; and

(ii)it is practicable to readily estimate, as at the end of the current year of income, the year of income (in this paragraph called the "final year of income") in which the end of the project will occur; and
(iii)the final year of income is later than the third year of income subsequent to the current year of income;

PROCTEXT.PARA: 33 1/3% of the expenditure is an allowable deduction for:

TAB.TAB: (iv)the current year of income; and
(v)each of the 2 subsequent years of income.".

PARA.TAB: Clause 112, page 68, after proposed section 14ZY, insert the following section:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Person may require Commissioner to make an objection decision

PARA.TAB: "`14ZYA.(1) This section applies if the taxation objection has been lodged with the Commissioner within the 60 days and the Commissioner has not made an objection decision by whichever is the later of the following times:
(a)the end of the period (in this section called the "original 60-day period") of 60 days after whichever is the later of the following days:
