SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the motion moved by the Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Free), the coalition sought agreement in the other place and achieved Democrat support for the motion it moved, which provided that environmental impact expenses be deductible in the following circumstances: firstly, where the project proceeds, the expenditure is to be written off over three years; and, secondly, where the project does not proceed, the expenditure is to be deductible outright.

PARA.TAB: I am disturbed to think the Government acted quite inappropriately in not accepting that series of amendments which were put forward by the coalition and agreed to by the Senate. This is a very important issue for industry and the environmental movement in this country. The motion that we moved and was successful in the Senate provides that environmental impact expenses would be deductible in the following circumstances: where the project did proceed, expenditure would be written off over three years; and where the project does not proceed, the expenditure is to be deductible outright. We believe that it is only just and equitable that where a project does not proceed, expenditure can be written off forthwith—particularly as in those circumstances no asset has in fact been created.

The Government has now stated it will not support that amendment, as allowing for the expenses of an environmental impact study to be written off over that three-year period or, where a project does not proceed, for the expenses to be written off outright is providing a subsidy to the industry.

The tax deductibility of the expenditure to be written off over three years is not a subsidy. I substantiate that statement by putting to the chamber the following reasons. Firstly, the Industry Commission recommendations regarding depreciation—and there is an article in today's Australian Financial Review, 19 December 1991—indicate that an easing of depreciation rates is necessary. That Industry Commission report was set up by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). It gained Cabinet approval for the inquiry, and the brief to the Industry Commission was to study other countries' measures to boost exports.

The Industry Commission has now come back and will recommend that the tax burden on industry be lowered and that tax depreciation measures be reviewed. That is precisely what our motion and amendment to the legislation in the Senate provided—that those depreciation measures be reviewed and certainly that environmental impact statements be looked at.

The environmental impact statements, of course, are something which every level of government—local, State and Federal—has forced upon it by law. All of those EI statements are legitimate business expenses which we believe should be able to be written off.

The Australian accountancy profession also has recommended the three-year write-off period. I have in my possession a statement by the Taxation Institute of Australia regarding the environmental impact statements. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: At present, the income tax system unintentionally discourages taxpayers from undertaking certain environmental expenditure.

I would not think anyone in the chamber, particularly the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney), would argue with the proposition that it is necessary to undertake certain environmental expenditure and it is necessary to take out environmental impact statements.

PARA.TAB: I think that the Taxation Institute of Australia has set out an extremely good case in this matter. No doubt the Government has received that paper and the Minister handling this legislation obviously would be aware of it. But I understand that other countries, such as the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom, have acted in various ways to remedy similar anomalies and, in some cases, have gone even further by deliberately encouraging expenditure in a variety of environmental programs through the income tax system.

The failure to remedy the technical deficiencies in Australia's tax laws has the effect of discouraging taxpayers from undertaking environmental expenditure. It also adds to the complexity and inefficiency of the income tax system, its cost to taxpayers, and it impedes Australian producers who are attempting to compete with overseas manufacturers and producers and could result in Australian producers relocating their operations offshore. That is exactly the issue the Industry Commission has identified in its latest report, which was reported today, Thursday, 19 December 1991, in the Australian Financial Review.

I believe that the Taxation Institute of Australia has quite clearly recognised the importance of this issue. It also points out and emphasises that its submission to ourselves and the Government does not seek subsidies or incentives for environmental expenditure, but rather the elimination of unintended consequences which discourage beneficial action by the recognition that expenditure on environmental matters is now, in response to community demands, an ordinary business expense. Of course it is, because at all levels of government, local, State and Federal, it is a requirement by law.

It is also well to remember that, whilst no deduction is available to Australian companies for the cost of undertaking environmental impact studies and land rectification, deductions for donations to environmental groups are specifically allowable. The Government will not allow a deduction to any Australian company that is trying to do the right thing by undertaking what can at times be an expensive environmental impact study; yet deductions for donations to environmental groups are specifically allowable.

The Institute has proposed that with feasibility studies where the project proceeds a write-off period over three years be allowed; and where the project does not proceed, an outright deduction be allowed. The Australian accountancy profession has recommended, though, the three-year write-off. There is a need for Australia to be internationally competitive, and the adoption of three-year write-offs would put us in the forefront of environmental impact statement write-offs. The environmental impact statement expenses are a necessarily incurred expense required, as I mentioned, by all levels of government, Federal, State and local. The precedent for this has already been acknowledged in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) where preliminary expenses for exploration can be written off in the year of occurrence. Therefore, the same situation, I believe, should occur with environmental impact statements.

In fact, if we are searching for resources, whether it be for gold—I mentioned this in my contribution during the second reading debate—or for some other resource, one's taxation liability, the preliminary expenses for exploration, can be written off in the year of occurrence. We believe that should also occur with environmental impact studies. The Opposition amendment, which was moved and accepted in the Senate, recognises asset creation in the three-year write-off period. It is for those reasons that we register the coalitions's opposition to the Government not accepting the amendments which were moved and considered at great length in the Senate. I register the coalition's opposition to that proposal by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to support the comments made on behalf of the Opposition by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid). The steady increase in the burdens which are imposed on industry in the interests of environmental management is a matter which, I suppose, has commanded the broad assent and support of both sides of this House. I think it is now generally accepted that in the carrying out of business in Australia we expect very high environmental standards. By law, it is frequently required that before business can be carried out there will be an environmental impact statement.

PARA.TAB: The expense which is involved here is of a slightly different nature to the other expenses which are involved in seeking to establish a business because those expenses are, in a much more direct way, related to the public interest rather than the direct commercial interest of the taxpayer. I think that what illustrates the different nature of these expenses is the serious discussion which takes place about having the cost of environmental impact statements met not by the private but by the public purse. There is a quite serious argument that it would be sensible to have environmental impact statements publicly funded on the basis that those people conducting studies would then have their direct duty to the public, because many people who are concerned about the environment believe that, where a private enterprise body retains a consultant for the purpose of producing an environmental impact statement, there is essentially a conflict of interest.

I do not put that forward here because it is a matter that we are considering legislating on or because it is Opposition policy, but because I think that argument acutely illustrates that in requiring environmental impact statements we are looking to the public rather than to the private interest. I think that there are very good arguments for saying that it should remain a private cost. We are saying that one of the problems of environment management is that so many costs are hidden. The environment is used as a free good. As a result, air, water and soil are degraded without regard to the long term economic cost to the country, to the community and, indeed, to the enterprise itself.

But it seems to me to be flying in the face of reason to be saying to people who face what we would all regard as necessary environmental costs that those costs should not be regarded as costs which are necessarily incurred in carrying out the business. I think it is artificial to regard them as capital costs in the normal sense. I think that they are essentially costs which are there to provide information which enables the public interest to be protected.

This Government is probably foremost in the world, not for its environmental record but for trumpeting its environmental record and then claiming that it demands the world's highest standards and so on—these are a much remarked upon feature of the approach of the Hawke Government—and, in those circumstances, there is some requirement of a bit of consistency. I say to the Minister handling this legislation that I think it sits oddly with the Government's rhetoric that it should knock back these amendments which were passed by the Senate and which I think are no more than a reasonable acknowledgment of the fact that it is the parliaments of Australia which have imposed these additional obligations on people. We have done that because we believe that by imposing those obligations we protect the public interest. In those circumstances it is clearly a cost which is necessarily incurred in carrying out business. It, in fact, has nothing to do with achieving a profit.

In Australia, where carrying on business is very difficult, where thousands of small businesses and, indeed, some larger businesses have found the going all too hard to keep up and where a lot of people have gone bankrupt, I think we should be very careful when imposing statutory obligations on people to expect that cost to be borne out of after-tax income. That is essentially the case here. For that reason I wish to express my very great disappointment at the stance that the Government has taken. I do not know whether any discretion is left in Ministers in this place, but if there is any I would ask the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free), who is at the table, to consider taking the legislation back and having it considered in light of the comments that have been made principally by the honourable member for Bendigo and also in light of my own comments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Mr Free) proposed:
That Senate's amendments Nos 2 and 3 be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have little or no interest in the amendments Nos 2 and 3. However, I say to the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) that I would have expected the courtesy of a reply.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 29 November, on motion by Mr Griffiths:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has transmitted to the House the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, which is an omnibus Bill to amend various Acts in the Attorney-General's portfolio. The Bill was debated in the other place on 26 November last and was passed on that day with amendments. In particular, the Senate rejected amendments which the Government had put forward with respect to section 64 of the Judiciary Act 1903. In addition, the Senate inserted into the Bill amendments to section 9 of the Law Officers Act of 1964. It will be up to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) to formally indicate the Government's position on those amendments. As I understand it, the Government is not going to, yet again, pursue the amendment to the Judiciary Act. As I understand it, it has indicated that it will not be accepting the Senate amendment to the Law Officers Act. I will go into the question of the Law Officers Act amendment a little later.

PARA.TAB: Before referring to that element, I mention briefly two other matters that are contained within the Bill, namely, the amendment to the Commonwealth Places (Application of Laws) Act 1970 and, secondly, the amendment to section 117C of the Family Law Act 1975. It is my intention to speak at some considerable length on this matter. It is a fairly historic moment and I rather doubt that in the whole sweep of human history many people will take much notice of amendments to the Law and Justice Act at 10 minutes past six when there is a decision to be taken at 6.30.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concentrating on it.
—I know that the Attorney is concentrating on it. He is ever vigilant.
—What is that the Minister has in front of him? Playboy?
—Environment.

—Very good. I am green with envy. Section 5 of the Commonwealth Places (Application of Laws) Act 1970 will be amended to provide that State police, when investigating offences committed on Commonwealth land, are not bound by the provisions of part 1(c) of the Commonwealth Crimes Act 1914. The provisions found in part 1(c) were recently introduced by the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Act 1991, which was debated in the House on 13 February this year.

PARA.TAB: When the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Act was debated in the House, the Opposition expressed a concern that the legislation would give rise to operational complexities on the part of the State police and that in this respect the State police would be required to follow different investigatory rules, depending on whether they were investigating Commonwealth or State offences and, in some cases, both. That matter has now been attended to and was conceded by the Attorney in the second reading speech on the Bill.

Section 117C of the Family Law Act provides that parties to maintenance and property proceedings in the Family Court may file and deliver offers of compromise. Offers of compromise are designed to encourage the early settlement of disputes and to dispose of proceedings without final adjudication due to the cost consequences that may flow from the rejection of a reasonable offer of compromise.

By subsection 117C(3), the existence of an offer of compromise should not be disclosed to the court except at the conclusion of the proceedings when the court comes to consider the question of costs. Subsection (3) gives statutory expression to the rule of natural justice that a court or tribunal be free of any bias. In the event that an offer of compromise is disclosed to a judge during the course of proceedings, the rules of natural justice require that the judge, if an objection is taken by one of the parties, disqualify himself or herself from continuing to hear the proceedings. The Bill will amend section 117C by inserting a new subsection (4) to the effect that if the fact of an offer of compromise is disclosed to a judge, that judge is not disqualified from continuing to hear the proceedings.

The extraordinary thing is that no explanation was given by the Government about this proposed amendment for the proposed departure from the rules of natural justice. During the second reading debate on the Bill in the other place, an explanation was given for this derogation from the requirements of natural justice.

The explanation was put forward by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), who said that the amendment was in response to the entreaty of the Family Court judges. The Minister has given an assurance to the Parliament that the amendment will apply only where a judge becomes aware of only the fact of an offer and not the terms and conditions of the relevant offer of compromise. If a judge becomes aware of the terms and conditions of an offer, he or she will need to stand aside unless, of course, the parties do not object to the judge continuing to hear the proceedings.

Although the coalition is prepared to accept the amendment on the basis of the assurance given by Senator Tate, I take this opportunity to place on the record our concern with the amendment. The rules of natural justice, having been developed by our courts over the centuries in order to protect the rights of the parties, are fundamental to the administration of justice. The Parliament should always be cautious about interfering with the rights of individuals conferred by the common law. Accordingly, I would ask that the Attorney undertake to monitor closely the operation of this provision.

I now wish to say something about the amendment that the Attorney is not happy with, an amendment put by my colleagues in another place. It was supported by the Australian Democrats. It called on the Attorney-General to provide a statement concerning the background to the leave that he has given and, in case it should operate in the future, to leave given with full pay to the Solicitor-General. I refer to the amendment moved in the other place to section 9 of the Law Officers Act.

As honourable members will be aware—I have raised this matter on a number of occasions in this House—the Attorney-General's decision to grant the Solicitor-General paid leave of absence and his giving consent for the Solicitor-General to engage in private practice while on that paid leave have been widely criticised in this place, in the legal profession and in the wider community.

It is simply extraordinary that taxpayers are being called upon to subsidise the second most senior law officer of the land in his venture to supplement his very substantial income by returning to the bar. The Solicitor-General is an officer, I might add, to whom the Attorney-General may delegate all of his powers, privileges and responsibilities. What is even more extraordinary is the Attorney's refusal to account for the reasons for his decision before the Parliament.

I really do not know what is going on with this issue. It seems clear to me that taxpayers are outraged that a person of such alleged eminence in the law will be given $160,000, will have access to his offices, to government cars, to the title `Solicitor-General' and will be told, `Take this money; go on leave and earn $500,000 or $600,000 in the next year if you wish'. It really is the most extraordinary decision.

Every time I seek a reason from the Attorney as to why he has done this I am traduced for wanting to invade the man's privacy. The man's privacy! It is not his private money; it is public money. It is the money of the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock); it is the Attorney's money; it is the people's money. The Solicitor-General is on the public payroll and we are entitled to an explanation as to how this fellow can just wander in, have a chat with the Attorney, and walk out with $160,000 for the next 12 months, his title, his offices, his cars and everything else, which will take it to well over a quarter of a million dollars, and then be wished well in his endeavour to make more than half a million dollars at the bar. It is almost obscene.

People seem to think that I have some personal animosity towards the Solicitor-General. I have not. I have none at all. Members opposite keep saying to me, `What is wrong with a fellow working while he is on holidays?'. Come off the grass! As I have said, I have a few slow horses that have been pretty bad investments, but I cannot go to the Attorney to get an extra quid and go out and earn money at the same time. I cannot get 12 months leave from this place. It really is the most extraordinary decision, one which was given within 12 months of the time when the Solicitor-General entered into a new contract.

As I am appalled at the decision, I continue to ask the Attorney: will he please give the House a reason for his decision without traducing me for raising it or telling me it is private and confidential? It is taxpayers' money. The Solicitor-General is the second most senior law officer in the Commonwealth. He leaves to go to the bar for 12 months; he retains his title and his offices; he takes his money and is wished well. Indeed, it has been said in this place that honourable members opposite wish him well and hope that he can earn half a million dollars. It is the most extraordinary decision and, as I say, it has been widely criticised here and elsewhere.

Taxpayers are being called upon to subsidise the Solicitor-General's venture to supplement his already substantial income. According to the Attorney, matters relating to the administration of a statutory office and the expenditure of public moneys are private matters which need not concern either the Parliament or the people. This, to put it mildly, is a quite outrageous derogation from an excellent Minister who normally comes into this House and gives full reasons for his decisions—but on this occasion, not at all.

The Solicitor-General holds statutory office through appointment by the Attorney-General and the accountability of that office to the public must be channelled through the Attorney. The Solicitor-General is in no position to come in here and explain what has gone on; only the Attorney can do that. The responsibility of explaining the reason rests with the Attorney-General.

The Attorney claims that he need not account to the Parliament over the matter because to do so would intrude upon the Solicitor-General's personal affairs. Incomprehensible! The committee of inquiry chaired by Sir Nigel Bowen noted at paragraph 3.51 of its report, Public Duty and Private Interest:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee does not think that the right to privacy forms a complete and automatic bar to the imposition of any disclosure requirements. . .

Furthermore, as the Full Federal Court noted in the 1984 decision in News Corporation Ltd v. National Companies and Securities Commission, which is reported in part 1 of the 1984 volume of the Federal Court Reports at page 64, the expression `personal affairs', in the context of section 41 of the Freedom of Information Act, `clearly indicates a dichotomy between business and non-business affairs'.

PARA.TAB: The information that the Parliament seeks from the Attorney relates to the expenditure of public moneys and the administration of the affairs of a statutory office within his portfolio. That is not information of a private nature. Subsequent to raising the matter in the House on a number of occasions, I wrote to the Attorney and I requested of the Attorney, pursuant to the provisions of section 13 of what is termed the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act of 1977, that he provide me with a statement of the reasons for and the facts behind his decision in regard to the Solicitor-General and all this money.

The Attorney has refused my request on the somewhat spurious ground that I do not have sufficient standing. In addition to this, I delivered three—not one, not two but three—separate requests under the Freedom of Information Act for documents in possession of the Attorney, his Department and the Solicitor-General. In response, I got a letter from a departmental officer claiming to have authority to act on behalf of the Attorney, the Solicitor-General and the Secretary to the Department.

So I write, under the terms that are granted to any citizen under the Freedom of Information Act, to the Attorney, the Solicitor-General and the Department, and a public servant replies on behalf of all of them. One of the most curious aspects of the letter I received was a determination by this officer that my request—listen to this one—did not relate to a matter of public interest. This just heaps unbelievable proposition on unbelievable proposition.

We are debating this matter because the Senate took a stance on this issue and moved an amendment to the Bill. A chamber of the Houses of the Parliament of Australia has expressed a view on this issue, clearly indicating at the very least that it is a matter of public interest, but a public servant, on the Attorney's behalf, writes to me—and it would not matter who it was; it could be any elected official—sweeps all that aside and says that he, as the judge of public interest, is telling me that this is not a matter of public interest. That is completely at odds with the view taken by a chamber of the Houses of this Parliament—the Senate.

If a public servant's interpretation of public interest is allowed to override that of an elected body, namely, the Senate, then my fears are confirmed—that bureaucrats and those they represent, albeit temporarily, are making a mockery of the Freedom of Information Act. If this is not a matter of public interest, I do not know what is. The Government shovels out money to a public officer, lets him go on leave to earn as much money as he likes, we ask a question about it and we are told the matter is private. We are not going to be told the reasons. We seek information under the Freedom of Information Act and we are told it is not even a matter of public interest.

Lo and behold, a chamber of the Parliament has passed a view on it. Wait until we get before the AAT on this, because we will not rest on it. I am not going to leave it here. There are various avenues open to those who have rights under the Freedom of Information Act to go beyond simply the writing and receipt of letters. But given that the information we seek cannot be obtained through the parliamentary process or by the use of maybe other means—although I will be seeking to use those other means—we have been moved to put forward an amendment to section 9 of the Law Officers Act which would require the Attorney to table in both Houses a statement of reasons and facts when giving consent for the Solicitor-General to undertake paid work.

If the Attorney is not prepared to fulfil his ministerial responsibilities and to account to Parliament, it falls on the Parliament to compel him to do so by way of legislation. The amendment to the Law Officers Act uses the same formula as that found in section 13 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act in that the Attorney is required to table written reasons, together with a statement as to his findings, on any material questions of fact.It is appropriate that this formula be adopted, given that a decision by the Attorney-General under section 9 of the Law Officers Act is a decision of an administrative character made under an enactment and, therefore, prima facie amenable to judicial review. We take this opportunity to call on the Attorney-General once more—

TALK.START.PARA: —Again.

—Yet again, to provide an explanation of the factual basis for the decision to allow the Solicitor-General to engage in private practice whilst on leave. If the Attorney-General wants to traduce me then he can; he knows I will cop that. But he should not give me the same answer that it is private and that it is personal. He should be fair dinkum.

PARA.TAB: This Attorney, more than any other Minister, with great respect to the former Treasurer, is straight and direct but on this occasion there is some aberration; I do not know what it is. I would ask him to provide an explanation on the factual basis for the decision. Given that no doubt this will not be forthcoming, judging by the responses he has been making, we have been compelled to extract an appropriate explanation by amending section 9 of the Law Officers Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. In view of the fact that we are dealing with legislation that has been introduced by a Prime Minister who has just resigned, I put to you that it would be appropriate for the Attorney to move now that the House do now adjourn.
—I do not know whether the right honourable member for New England is giving advice to the Attorney-General but I do not think the Attorney is accepting that advice.

—Mr Speaker, let me just put the point of order: any matters that we now deal with are not appropriate to a government that is now no longer in office. Until the new Prime Minister has been sworn in, it is totally inappropriate for this Government—the Hawke Government—to continue with legislation that has now no relevance under a new Prime Minister. I put to you that it is inappropriate for this Parliament to continue the farce of in some way presuming that this legislation is going to be introduced by the next Government.
—The House has business before it. The House can deal with the business before it. Unless the Attorney wants to respond, I will call the honourable member for Warringah.
—On the point of order, Mr Speaker: as I understand the situation, we do not have a Prime Minister at the present time.
—Order! Australia does have a Prime Minister at the present time—it is the Hon. R.J. Hawke.
—He is on his way to Government House.
—Order! That is not a matter that is known to this House. As far as the House is concerned, we have a Prime Minister.

—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: quite obviously you need no assistance on this matter. What you have said is absolutely correct—that we still have a Prime Minister. At some stage tomorrow morning there will be another Prime Minister. I propose to proceed with the business of the House.

—That means that if there is no Prime Minister from the time the Prime Minister has handed in his resignation, which we have been told is going to happen in the next half hour, we will be acting totally outside the responsibilities of Parliament.
—Order! There is no point of order. The right honourable member for New England will resume his seat.

—I will not take up a great deal of the House's time, given the circumstances that have occurred tonight. While I am on my feet, I think it would be totally inappropriate if I did not pay some tribute to the outgoing Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I have for a long time held the view that his policies were not the policies that this country needed. But having said that, I say that I respect anyone who has made a contribution to Australian public life to the extent that the former Prime Minister has. On behalf of the people that I have represented for only a short time, I thank him for his contribution to Australian life over such a lengthy period.

PARA.TAB: Returning to the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, I will not go over the ground covered by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). I believe that the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) should take very careful and close notice of the honourable member's comments in relation to the Solicitor-General. I think it would be a shame if this matter did end up in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal but, if that is the path he wants to choose, so be it.

I specifically want to address the amendments to the Family Law Act. Section 60H of the Act preserves the effect of State and Territory child welfare laws in circumstances where orders might be made in relation to a child under the Act. Section 60H(1) of the Act prohibits a court exercising jurisdiction under the Act from making an order in relation to a child who is in the custody of, or under the guardianship of, or under the care and control of, or under the supervision of, a person under a State or Territory child welfare law.

The Bill proposes to substitute a new section 60H(1) that will allow courts exercising jurisdiction under the Act to make orders in relation to a child who is under the guardianship, or in the custody or care and control, of a person under a State or Territory child welfare law where the order comes into effect when such a child stops being under such guardianship, or in such custody or care and control, or the relevant State or Territory child welfare officer consents to the institution or continuation of the proceedings.

A new section 66FA will be inserted into the Act. This provides that proceedings in relation to the maintenance of a child under the guardianship, or in the custody or care and control, of a person under a State of Territory child welfare law may only be brought by the child; a parent of the child who has daily care and control; a relative of the child who has daily care and control; or a State or Territory child welfare officer.

The honourable member for Kooyong referred to section 117C. I have some concerns about this section. As you would know, Mr Speaker, at the moment there can be no mention at all in the Family Court of an offer of compromise. As a result of this amendment—which I do not necessarily object to—I have some concerns, given that there is the opportunity for the court to be made aware of the offer of compromise, that there is possibly the opportunity for some of the terms and conditions to be introduced via the back door without necessarily specifically itemising those terms and conditions. Therefore, I believe that there is still the potential for considerable compromise in respect of the judge who might be handling the particular matter. I think the Attorney needs to address that question very seriously.

Mr Speaker, I can, off the top of my head, give an example. Let us say that an offer of compromise has been filed for some $65,000. Someone giving evidence about the amount of property that he or she considers to be appropriate might be asked, `What do you believe is an appropriate figure?'. That person may say to the court, `Well, $60,000 seems reasonable to me', which is not far off what has been offered. In my view, this would obviously potentially compromise the judge in charge of the case. Although there is no specific reference to the terms and conditions of the offer of compromise, in a de facto way evidence has been led that will indicate roughly the terms and conditions of the offer of compromise. I really believe that the Attorney needs to have a closer look at that. I note that his advisers are with him tonight. I would be quite happy to have an input into the problems that I see in regard to that.

But I support the thrust of that amendment. Quite frankly, I believe that it has the potential to limit significantly not only individual costs but, potentially, the costs of the Legal Aid Commission. Mr Speaker, as you would well know, the Commission needs every red cent it can get its hands on at the moment.

The provisions under section 60H(1) and the other matters in relation to custody, guardianship, et cetera, make a lot of sense. I support those provisions. I think it is fair to say that the Family Law Act, which was introduced in 1975, potentially cleared the way for a more rational application of family law in this country. I, for one, would hate to go back to the days when people jumped through windows to take photographs.

I still have concerns about the Act as it currently operates. I have very great concerns about the question of child maintenance. I believe the Child Support Agency, and the legislation under which it operates, is creating a very significant division throughout the community. From my experience, and as you, Mr Speaker, would be well aware, the crisis in any marriage is not so much the act of separation but the act of division of property. It is the act of working out the level of maintenance and, in the end, of ascertaining who will and who will not retain custody of the children.

This Act in some ways addresses those concerns, but it has become an extremely divisive parliamentary weapon, a legislative weapon. I can assure you, Mr Speaker—and I am sure it is the same for a lot of other members in this House—that a great proportion of the people who come through our doors are there to see us about the Child Support Act and about complaints with the Family Law Act.

I hope that the inquiry that is presently taking place will address some of those concerns, but I do not believe that the inquiry is far reaching enough. It should have been far more far reaching. We need to address those potential divisions coming in to the family.

The extraordinary part—but maybe it is not extraordinary—is that those of my colleagues still practising in the family law area tell me that over the past 18 months applications have dropped off significantly. That obviously results from a combination of factors, but the recession appears to have had a considerable effect on the willingness or otherwise of people to separate. Whether that is related to the price of property or to the ability of non-custodial parents to pay sufficient maintenance is anyone's guess.

But, although the number of people taking the option of separation may have stopped for a certain amount of time, an extremely difficult period for Australian families has also been created in the Australian community. They are under enormous pressure at the moment. They are under enormous financial pressures, and I believe that in the long run we may well again see an upsurge in the number of people choosing the option of separation, but it will be related to nothing but financial disability which has led to the breakdown of the family unit.

In half an hour or so, or by tomorrow morning, we will have a new Prime Minister. While I pay tribute to the outgoing Prime Minister, I can assure honourable members that I pay absolutely no tribute to the incoming Prime Minister, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) because of the ramifications of his policies on Australian families and on the people affected by the Family Law Act. Obviously, we are just seeing the start of the problems. The honourable member for Blaxland is carrying around his neck the noose of one million people unemployed and of quite considerable family breakdown and the enormously detrimental impact on family life in this country.

I can assure honourable members that people will never forgive the honourable member for Blaxland for his comment of `the recession we had to have' because he knows that it was only his policies in the first five years of the Hawke Government that put him in the situation of taking that course. The recession that we had to have resulted from the policies of the honourable member for Blaxland, the soon to be Prime Minister.

I find it quite extraordinary that 56 members of the Australian Labor Party have put him in the position of Prime Minister. Obviously, the members of the Party do not know the intense hatred out in the community for what has happened to this country in the last three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member might get back to the matter before the House.

—This does impact very much on the matter before the House tonight because we are seeing the transfer to the Commonwealth of powers—the Attorney may well be able to advise me of the discussions he has had with his State counterparts—subject to the agreement of the States. It is regarded very much as a matter that concerns this Commonwealth Parliament. I believe it is directly related because we will be dealing under the Family Law Act with far greater numbers of people who have felt the impact of this Government's policies.

PARA.TAB: I fully agree with the notion in this amending legislation that we need to start focusing everything to do with family law and associated matters into one arena. It has been a long time coming. As honourable members will be well aware, there have been some constitutional problems that have stopped it. There have been some State-Commonwealth problems that have through the years since 1975 impacted on the focus of this area being transferred to the Commonwealth.

I am pleased to see that, through some of these amendments and others, the Attorney is redirecting that focus. But that focus and that responsibility, which is being put on to the Federal Parliament, needs to be very seriously addressed by the Attorney and by the Government, however it may be composed by this time tomorrow. I do not know whether the Attorney will still be Attorney. I hope he is as I have a great deal of respect for him, but none of us know what the night will bring. If we are to stay here until 4 or 5 o'clock tomorrow morning, we may know. If the members of the Gallery have any sense they will not be here until 4 or 5 o'clock in the morning although, if they want to stay, they know that they are more than welcome to do so.

We may well have a new Cabinet tomorrow morning by 3 or 4 o'clock. I am sure that my colleague the honourable member for Kooyong also would like to see his combatant partner across the table stay as Attorney-General because, apart from the issue over the Solicitor-General, we have been pretty happy with the way he has conducted himself as Attorney. I am sure that, if the Attorney were to stay awake until 4 o'clock in the morning, he may well even reconsider his position in relation to the Solicitor-General. I am sure that the honourable member for Kooyong and I would go and have a cup of coffee with him if he made that decision.

I do not want to say anything more on this except to urge the Attorney to listen to the community that is asking him to address the problems under the Family Law Act. They are very considerable. As I have said before, they have the potential to be extremely divisive. They are now being divisive. Regrettably, there is continuing potential for even greater conflict within the community unless we address those very key and important questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I will deal with some of the matters raised by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), the shadow Attorney, and then those raised by the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson). The shadow Attorney indicated, correctly—the honourable member for Ballarat also touched on this—that we will not be pursuing the amendment in respect of the Judiciary Act, for the reasons stated. The matters of concern expressed in respect of the Commonwealth Places (Application of Laws) Act no longer exist. The other issue raised by the honourable member for Kooyong related to section 117C of the Family Law Act relating to the assurance that was given on this matter by Senator Tate, the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, when this matter was debated in the other place. I reiterate that assurance and go just a little further than that in the sense that, if there are difficulties with this amendment, as indicated by my colleague in the Senate when the matter was debated there, we will monitor it very closely. Further, if there are difficulties, they can be dealt with the next time there is an opportunity for amendments to the Family Law Act which, as both honourable members will be more than well aware, arise somewhat frequently.

PARA.TAB: I want to go to a matter which concerns those opposite and which has become the magnificent obsession of the honourable member for Kooyong over the last few months or weeks. That is the question of the leave of the Solicitor-General and his right to private practice whilst on leave. Before moving to that, I should indicate that in committee I will be moving the amendment which has been circulated in my name. However, in the circumstances this evening I would prefer to touch on those matters now and, if they are raised again in committee, I will respond then.

I think, from memory, three Question Times have concentrated on this matter and we have had a censure motion in respect of it. The shadow Attorney has indicated some very strong views about it. Tonight he added a couple, saying that he does not know what is going on and that he needs more access to information. But then he indicated that he had no personal animosity towards the Solicitor-General—something which no doubt the Solicitor-General will be as delighted to hear as I was.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does he think I am chasing him?

—I should not respond to interjections, but the shadow Attorney wanted to know whether the Solicitor-General felt he was chasing him. I really do not know that I would waste a great deal of the time spent with the Solicitor-General in dealing with matters of importance to this Government by requesting him to indicate his views on what the shadow Attorney was doing.

PARA.TAB: A few points have to be made about this matter. Generally, as the shadow Attorney knows after almost an eternity in this place, Ministers have discretion as to what information they provide to Parliament, for example, in responding in Question Time. In exercising that discretion on what to provide to Parliament, Ministers can take into account various factors. In my view, all the relevant circumstances should be taken into account in determining whether and to what extent Ministers provide information on reasons for a decision. Although, of course, when Ministers are disclosing information, they are not required to act consistently with the provisions in the Privacy Act relating to the disclosure of personal information—for example, privacy principle 11—the existence of this discretion permits them to do so.

At present—and I think it is a point that has been overlooked for a long time—when an Attorney-General gives consent under section 10 of the Law Officers Act, there is a discretion not to disclose reasons for exercising that discretion. An Attorney-General may disclose reasons, but in choosing to do so, I suggest, any Attorney-General should weigh up a number of factors. Those factors are matters relating to the effect on the privacy of the individual concerned, taking into account the issue which the shadow Attorney has raised on many occasions, and balancing that with the public interest in making the disclosure. I accept that, and that is what I did. It is my view that, balancing those two things, the reasons should not be disclosed.

The new provision, which was inserted in the Senate, would remove that discretion from any Minister in this Parliament in the future. The privacy safeguards that I referred to would disappear. We would then move into the area of compulsion. In this instance, an Attorney-General would be compelled to disclose, regardless of the circumstances of a particular case, and the provision would prevent that balancing of the public interest and private interest before making a disclosure of information.

Such a lack of privacy protection is absolutely at variance with the policy of other legislation where the disclosure of personal information is in issue. For example, under the Freedom of Information Act, a document is exempt from disclosure—it is well known to those opposite—if disclosure would involve an unreasonable disclosure of the personal affairs of any person.

I cannot be persuaded that there is a difference in this case. I go back to where, in a sense, this whole argument started. The reasons for granting approval of the Solicitor-General's application to engage in private practice were simply these—and I have given them before. He wished to engage in private practice and it was possible, after discussions with the Solicitor-General, to agree to that request on the basis that there would be no conflict between Dr Griffith's private practice and his office of Solicitor-General. There was no other reason to refuse approval.

I come back to the question of intrusion on the affairs of a person—that is, the personal affairs, in this case, of the Solicitor-General. The Opposition's amendment has a retrospective operation in relation to Dr Gavan Griffith, QC. Senator Hill has said in the Senate that the retrospective application of the provision is not to elicit personal information which might be relevant to the approval being given to Dr Griffith to engage in private practice in 1992. To some extent, I can understand Senator Hill saying that. It was not his matter. It was my matter, on behalf of the Government, and the matter of the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong, on behalf of the Opposition.

But when we analyse Senator Hill's statement, it is quite an extraordinary statement. He says the purpose of the amendment was not to elicit personal information which might be relevant to the approval given to Dr Griffith. It is very difficult to see any other purpose in retrospective application of this provision. If the Opposition is moving to a stage of really gilding the lily, this is the classic case—getting up and saying, `It is not even in the future that we are going to change the terms and conditions of the employment of the Solicitor-General and require disclosure in this type of case; we are going to do it retrospectively. But that is not going to be used to elicit information which might be relevant to the approval given to Dr Griffith'.

That is what was said in the other place. We in this place all gave up believing in fairy stories a long while ago. If people can believe that, they can believe anything. I think it may well be that it was not fully understood when the matter was looked at in the Senate. I think that in touching on what was said in the Senate one has to come back to the exact wording. Senator Hill said:

SPEECH.PARA: We do not wish to intrude unduly upon the personal affairs of this particular officer or any other officers. . . There may well be ways in which he—
the Attorney-General—

can meet the obligation that we seek to apply without unduly intruding upon the personal affairs of the law officer concerned. That is not our wish; we do not seek that. What we do wish is that Ministers be properly accountable to the Parliament for expenditure of public moneys, particularly in most unusual circumstances. We regard this as a most unusual circumstance.
That was reported in Hansard on 26 November 1991 at page 3389. I repeat the words of Senator Hill:
We do not wish to intrude unduly upon the personal affairs of this particular officer or any other officers.

Yet we are told that this suggested amendment should be retrospective. It may be that from time to time we do become obsessed about odd things. It has happened to me on very rare occasions; it is happening more regularly to the shadow Attorney-General. I think that this one has got out of hand. If, as said by someone of the enormous significance of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, there is no wish to intrude unduly upon the personal affairs of this particular officer or any other officers, what are those opposite on about?

PARA.TAB: As to the retrospective nature of this legislation, we have all talked about the significance that has to be in a matter before we get into retrospectivity. This is not a fishing expedition for the Opposition or any of its members. In respect of the comments made this evening by the honourable member for Kooyong, the Solicitor-General's annual salary is just under $140,000, not $160,000 as was said earlier tonight. He will have just short of nine months paid leave—and I think this again is the interesting factor which is perpetually overlooked—that is, leave that he is entitled to and entitled to be paid for. Unpaid leave is from 2 September to 20 December. The value of the paid leave is of the order of $100,000. As I have said in this place before, if someone in those circumstances says that he is going to engage in practice during that period and I am satisfied, as I have been, that I could agree to that request on the basis that there would be no conflict between Dr Griffith's private practice and his office of Solicitor-General, I find it very difficult, and have found it so for a long time, to know why the honourable member for Kooyong wishes to pursue this matter with vigour—somewhat erratic vigour at times, but with an enormous amount of vigour. I will be accused of being unnecessarily provocative about that. He says that every time I come in here I attack him on this issue. I am not attacking him; I am just a bit worried about him at this stage.

The Solicitor-General—and I confirm it again—has an entitlement to paid leave. Nobody disputes that, not even the honourable member for Kooyong. The Solicitor-General has asked to take that leave and I have agreed to it. He is entitled to that payment for nine months, which is an accrued right that he has. He is entitled to it in 1992. Whether he went fishing or back to legal practice in that period, he is entitled to that leave. The question then became: should he be allowed to practise as a barrister at that time? And he asked for that. I have agreed, as I said, on the basis of no conflict being allowed to develop between his private practice and that of the office. It is not a matter for me or any Attorney-General, I would suggest, in the future, or anyone in this place, how often the Solicitor-General exercises that right of private practice. It is not a matter for me and it is certainly not a matter for the Opposition. He may exercise it a lot or he may not.

The shadow Attorney has an enormously exaggerated view of the capacity of people to go back to the bar for a short period—he may prove to be right; I hope he is—and earn enormous amounts of money. He is always talking about sums of $500,000 or more, depending on his mood from time to time, but it is a question that has to be addressed on the basis of the public interest being protected by the conditions that are granted for private practice to ensure that the office of the Solicitor-General is not subject to any conflict. In my view, that is probably the only relevant matter, despite all the rhetoric that from time to time the honourable member for Kooyong has gone on with and has then, of course, forced me into.

It is interesting to look at the debate in the Senate on this matter because it really did go to the essence of what is now suggested. Debates in the Senate, of course, go a lot longer, but in many ways the debate did get to the real essence of the matter. As was said in that House by Senator Tate, the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to enact this particular clause so that it becomes part of the Law Officers Act would be to retrospectively alter the statutory conditions under which the office of the Solicitor-General was conferred on a particular person.

I went to that earlier. By trying to draft the process of the ADJR Act into this situation, the Opposition has potentially created a grave invasion of the privacy of the holder of the office. That would not be permitted under the ADJR Act. Under that Act, of course, an aggrieved person cannot be given reasons where the giving of those reasons would impinge on the personal affairs of a third party; and, for reasons that totally escape me, that is what the Opposition is attempting to do here. The shadow Attorney has made an application knowing that the Act would not be applicable, because he is not an aggrieved person. That is a matter that I must not say a great deal about, because I understand that that and other matters, such as freedom of information, will be taken further by the shadow Attorney. That is of course his right—and the very best of luck to him. He will proceed with that—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will do very well, too.

—He may do very well with it, and if he does, he has gone through the legal processes which are available to him and should be used by him should he so desire. It will stop him coming in here and suggesting that I have done some particular peculiar deal to help, as he said on one occasion, a mate. I explained that that was anything but the case on any interpretation.

PARA.TAB: This is an ill-conceived attempt to write into a statute a means of overcoming an impasse which has developed between us in this place, where I am saying that when we analyse this matter there are some matters which are not the business of this Parliament, that is, the personal affairs which would have to be gone into of the Solicitor-General in this case or for that matter any other person.

On that basis I will be moving in committee the amendments which have been circulated. I hope I will not have to speak to them for very long, which will of course depend upon the current frame of mind of the shadow Attorney. In closing, I think the other substantive matters which were raised in respect of the other parts of this Act have been answered in a way which would satisfy the shadow Attorney and probably the honourable member for Ballarat. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I know a lot of interesting things have been happening in the House tonight, but it was my understanding that there were to be other speakers from the other side, and that is what threw me off balance. As honourable members know, I am very interested in these amendments, and anything to do with the Family Law Act, particularly as it affects families. The Attorney-General knows that prior to the Budget every year I express deep concern about family matters. Whilst we have amendments to the Family Law Act before us with regard to State child welfare organisations and their references to the Family Court, together with an amendment which refers to a Family Court judge not being disqualified from hearing a case where an offer of compromise, et cetera, has been made in a property dispute, I express on behalf of the majority of Australians, I believe, deep concern at the fact that we are always year after year putting the cart before the horse.

PARA.TAB: We are spending enormous, voluminous amounts of taxpayers' money propping up families because of marriage failure or family breakdown. In fact, in 1974—the Family Law Act was introduced in 1975—the cost to the taxpayer was a mere $40m. The Family Law Act has many good aspects and a number of very negative aspects, as it has turned out. By 1982 the cost to the taxpayer was $800m. I know the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), has heard me say this a number of times at the inquiry being undertaken into the Family Law Act and related services. In the 1991-92 Budget, the bill to the taxpayer, as a result of family breakdown, now amounts to just under $3,000m. I find that absolutely horrendous. It ought to concern this Parliament, but we seem to go on day after day totally unconcerned about the fact that the main areas of stability in any society, strong families and happy marriages, are receiving no attention.

For example, in 1985, the amount of money being allocated to marriage education in this country nationally was 25c per year per family; that is just unacceptable. We are paying out $500 and $600 per year per family to prop up families as a result of marriage breakdown. If that is not putting the cart before the horse, what is? The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) needs to pay a lot more attention to this, as does the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate). We have a situation in this country where—and it does not matter how good the new Prime Minister, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), will be or how good new economic packages are—if we do not have strong, stable families and a certain degree of moral fibre in our nation, we will go down the gurgler one day or another.

I want to express my very deep concern about the fact that we are continually putting the cart before the horse. Here we are spending just under $3,000m propping up families as a result of family breakdown, and a mere $16m on marriage counselling and a mere $500,000 on marriage education. Research and statistics show us that 75 per cent of marriages fail because of benign neglect, not because of malicious intent. They show that prior to marriage only 6 per cent of young people seek any kind of education with regard to making their marriages work.

While we are talking about the amendments to the Family Law Act, I place on record in the very strongest of terms that we need to pay a lot more attention to preserving marriages and making families stronger. If we do that, we will end up with a country that will be able to survive into the next decade and into the twenty-first century.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.
Amendments (by Mr Duffy)—by leave—proposed:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 2, lines 1 to 5, omit the clause.
(2) Schedule, page 5, proposed amendment of section 9 of the Law Officers Act 1964, omit the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, for the benefit more of those who are in attendance in the chamber at the moment and those who may be listening rather than those who avidly read the Hansard, let me point out what the Government is up to here. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has moved two simple amendments to omit two clauses that were put in the Bill when it went through the Senate. The Bill has come back here. The Opposition, with the support of the Australian Democrats, put in those amendments because the Attorney-General said to the Solicitor-General, `Here is $160,000 of taxpayers' money. You can take that money, go away and practice at the bar for the next year'. He later decided he would call that accrued leave and additional leave, allegedly without pay.

PARA.TAB: I have never in 26 years in this Parliament struck this as a precedent where a public servant can take his money, and go and work at something else like this, and I want an explanation for it. The Attorney has refused to give me an explanation saying, `It is private'. He says that, even though it is public money. He says, `It is personal and private and you are not going to be told why this money has been made available to the Solicitor-General. It is a very personal matter'.

The amendments that my colleagues in the Senate, with the support of the Democrats, brought about require the Attorney to give a statement to the Parliament in writing as to the reasons he gives this amount of money and leave in the circumstances. I think that is pretty reasonable. But now it has come down to the House, all we are asking for is a statement in writing that relates to the granting of the consent that he gave that refers to the evidence and other material. We are asking for the reasons to be given. We even said that we would compromise as to the nature of that statement, but that it would have to apply retrospectively. The Attorney thinks it is unfair for it to be retrospective. Unless we make it retrospective, we will not get an explanation with regard to the current Solicitor-General.

I do not like retrospective law normally, and those on this side of the chamber generally oppose retrospective laws where they impose a different duty on individuals and taxpayers. It would be ludicrous, for example, if we said that from last week any person who went through a green light would be committing an offence or if we retrospectively amended tax laws and the like. This proposal does not do that. This is a different form of retrospectivity. It is saying, in terms of months, this Attorney-General, as a Minister of the Crown, has an obligation to explain why these public moneys are being paid out. He ought to meet that obligation. We are prepared to put an amendment to ensure that he does.

We on this side of the chamber have a general policy against the enactment of retrospective legislation where it takes away a benefit or imposes obligations on private persons. That is one thing, but this amendment seeks to amend section 9 of the Law Officers Act. It does not fall foul of the general prohibition in that it imposes an obligation on a public figure, namely, a Minister of the Crown, the Attorney-General. In addition, the amendment does not take away any benefit. What is normally odious about retrospective legislation is that we can enact it and take away a benefit a person hitherto thought he had.

This confers a benefit on the taxpaying community by calling on a Minister of the Crown to account to the Parliament for the administration of a statutory office and the expenditure of public moneys. All we are saying, in essence, is that we want the Minister to fulfil his obligations and account to the Parliament by outlining the reasons for allowing the Solicitor-General to keep his title and practice at the bar, but not do any more work for the Commonwealth and still get all his money for the whole of 1992 while he earns an estimated $500,000 or $600,000 in private practice. I regard it as obnoxious that it has even been done. It is compounded by the fact that we are not even told why. That goes on and on in this place.

I have sent applications under the Freedom of Information Act and I will pursue them through to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if necessary. I simply want to know why, because I know that no-one in this place could get that sort of deal—nor should they. I do not want to know all the personal affairs of the Solicitor-General. I read in the paper that he has made some bad investments and he wants to make some more money. There are a lot of people out there who do not even have any money to make any investments, and there are a lot of people out there who cannot even get a job. But in this case not only is a man allowed to keep his job; he does not have to do any work in that job. It is not leave without pay, and it is an incredible sum of money. On top of that, the Attorney publicly wishes him well in earning in excess of half a million dollars. I do not know whether there is a different mentality in this world today, but I do not comprehend it. All I wanted was an explanation and all we have done in the Senate is seek that explanation.

The element of retrospectivity does not take away any benefit. It simply says, `This applies because some months ago you did this'. I know I will not get an answer from the Attorney in here and I will have to go further. It has been a difficult day for the Attorney; a day on which he honourably stood with his leader and lost in a battle a couple of hours ago. I will not dwell on that, but it has been a very difficult day for him because he has invested a great deal of time, emotion and loyalty in support of his Prime Minister. Nevertheless, I ask him whether at the conclusion of this debate he will please change his mind and at last account to the public why he is treating the Solicitor-General so favourably.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had an indication that we had better finish the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) fairly quickly. I want to touch again on a few of the matters raised by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), because every time he says something on this subject the obsession gets deeper and deeper. He is now telling us that the Solicitor-General does not have to work while he is on leave in order to receive payment. No, he does not have to work while he is on leave to receive payment for his leave because it is accrued leave that he is entitled to. I have said that over and over again. He is entitled to paid leave.

PARA.TAB: The shadow Attorney keeps saying that the Solicitor-General is being paid while he is not doing anything. That is a matter for the Solicitor-General. If we go on leave and we are entitled to leave and entitled to payment and we do not do anything, of course we are going to get paid. That is what the leave is all about. The difference here is that the Solicitor-General has made a decision that that was not what he wanted to do.

On the question of retrospectivity, the shadow Attorney referred again to the fact that he does not want to intrude on people's privacy. There is a terrible conflict here between what he says and what was said by his leader in the Senate: he does not wish to intrude unduly upon the personal affairs of this officer. I am afraid that if, for reasons which escape me, the shadow Attorney does want to find out personal information about someone which in my view he is not entitled to, and he proposes to pursue that through the legal processes available to him in this country, that is his right. I have told him before that it is none of his business. That was my position weeks ago and it is still my position. Should another decision be taken by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, good luck to the shadow Attorney-General. I have told him over and over again. His interest has become obsessive. I have to go through and say the same thing time and time again. I am not telling him or anyone on that side of the House. If he can get it through legal process, that is his right and he can go right ahead.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report—by leave—adopted.
Bill (on motion by Mr Duffy)—by leave—read a third time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the ninth, tenth, eleventh and twelfth reports of the Committee for 1991, which relate to stage 3 of the development of RAAF Base Tindal, Northern Territory; CSIRO redevelopment, Parkville, Victoria; relocation of Naval Support Command Headquarters, Pyrmont, New South Wales; and the Special Broadcasting Service, relocation of radio and television, Artarmon, New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The first report that I have presented relates to the third stage of the development of RAAF Base Tindal, Northern Territory. Stages 1 and 2 of the development were the subject of previous reports by the Committee in 1984 and 1987. The development of RAAF Base Tindal over the past seven years represents one of the largest and most expensive defence infrastructure developments in Australia's history. What in 1984 was a bare base located in a remote area with a harsh climate has been transformed into a modern air force base.

PARA.TAB: It was obvious to the Committee during the inspection of the base that the RAAF personnel are proud of what has been achieved. Stage 3 will involve the provision of air defence facilities, living-in accommodation, deployed squadron operational and technical facilities, aircraft pavements, aircraft shelters and associated engineering services. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $53.5m at April 1991 prices.

The Committee has recommended that the works comprising stage 3 should proceed. Facilities for the use of aircraft deployed to Tindal are required because existing operational and support facilities which were essentially provided for No. 75 Squadron are inadequate. Therefore, the Committee concluded that if it is intended to continue the deployment of fighter and strike aircraft at Tindal, adequate facilities must be provided for them. Similarly, additional aircraft pavements are required to realise the full potential of the master- planned coat-hanger runway and taxi configuration.

The Committee also concluded that now is a good time for the relocation of No. 2 control and reporting unit from Darwin to Tindal. Facilities in Darwin are inadequate to house replacement equipment which it has been proposed to acquire. There would be strategic and operational advantages as well as financial benefits if the unit were located at Tindal and for the relocation to coincide with the delivery of replacement equipment.

In conclusion, I would like to mention two matters which generated some local interest at the Committee's public hearing into the proposal. Firstly, a number of witnesses suggested that the scope of stage 3 development should be extended by the inclusion of a bicycle track from Katherine to Tindal. Some RAAF personnel cycle along the Stuart Highway, a practice which is potentially dangerous because of the heavy traffic. The Committee concluded that a bike track could be constructed linking east Katherine with Tindal, with the Northern Territory Government and Katherine Town Council meeting the cost.

The second matter concerns the need for an independent analysis of the drainage pattern of the Tindal-Katherine area. The Katherine Town Council submitted to the Committee that unusually heavy flooding of the eastern side of Katherine had occurred during the 1990-91 wet season. The Council believes that this flooding may be the result of the development of Tindal. The Committee has recommended that an independent analysis of the drainage pattern of the Tindal-Katherine area should be undertaken to identify factors contributing to flooding and to recommend realistic measures to minimise it. The analysis should be funded by the Commonwealth Government, the Territory Government and Katherine Town Council.

The second report I have tabled relates to the redevelopment of CSIRO facilities at Parkville, Victoria. CSIRO is proposing to redevelop its Parkville site as a major research complex and to provide the headquarters for the Division of Biomolecular Engineering. The redevelopment will provide facilities for 140 staff and work will be undertaken in three stages so that the site remains operational at all times. The Committee has recommended that the work proceed at a cost of $12.25m.

In February 1990, the mission of the Division of Biomolecular Engineering was changed to concentrate on assisting the development of the Australian pharmaceutical and health care industries. The change in direction away from wool technology and agricultural protein research will have a major impact on the nature of laboratory accommodation required by the Division. CSIRO advised the Committee that the existing laboratories require urgent upgrading to provide facilities suitable for sophisticated computer based instrumentation and micro-analytical techniques.

The continued operation by CSIRO of the site at 343 Royal Parade, Parkville, was strongly opposed by the Parkville Association. The Association fundamentally believes that the location in North Parkville of such a facility is inappropriate, because North Parkville is an area which the Association regards as being predominantly residential and having high environmental sensitivity. The view of the Parkville Association was supported by the Melbourne City Council.

While the Committee appreciates the wish of the Parkville Association and the Melbourne City Council to retain the predominantly residential nature of Parkville, the fact is that CSIRO has been established on the Parkville site in accordance with local planning regulations since 1952. The Committee accepts the view of CSIRO, which was supported by other research institutions, that the Parkville location of the Division of Biomolecular Engineering is vital to its research program.

In recommending that the works proceed, the Committee has recommended that CSIRO should provide it with a comprehensive report detailing the energy management systems and energy conservation measures to be incorporated in the Parkville development. Concern was expressed at the public hearing by the Commonwealth Fire Board and the Melbourne Metropolitan Fire Brigade regarding the effects of the immunity of the Crown from State building regulations, particularly in relation to fire safety. The Committee is still considering the wider implication of this issue and will report to the Parliament shortly. However, at this stage the Committee has recommended that consultation with local fire authorities should be undertaken prior to the referral of all projects to the Committee.

The third report relates to the relocation of Naval Support Command Headquarters from the Remington Centre in the Sydney CBD to two former naval warehouses at the Royal Edward Victualling Yard, Pyrmont. The proposal is to refurbish the historic warehouses to provide office accommodation. The Committee has recommended that the work should proceed at an estimated cost of $13.34m at April 1991 prices. The Committee concluded that accommodation occupied by the Support Command in the city is inadequate and very costly at an annual rental of $4.7m.

The proposed relocation and refurbishment appeared to the Committee to be the best option examined in terms of capital cost and recurrent expenditure. Indeed, the Committee concluded that the refurbishment offers the Commonwealth the opportunity to capitalise on an existing asset and, at the same time, provide the Support Command with accommodation in an area with a maritime flavour.

The two buildings to be refurbished are listed on the Register of the National Estate. The Committee concluded that, provided the recommendations of the conservation and management plan and of the Australian Heritage Commission are adhered to, the refurbished buildings will maintain an important part of Sydney's maritime heritage as well as providing modern office accommodation for the personnel of the Support Command Headquarters.

The Committee also concluded that the proposal represents an ideal opportunity for the inclusion of a state of the art building services system designed to exceed current energy targets, and for the provision of a building services monitoring system capable of sensing and rectifying air quality as well as temperatures. The proposal is the first occasion in which the Department of Defence has not used Australian Construction Services as its design and construction authority. Instead, Defence will call tenders for a number of contractors to design, execute and supervise construction. Given this change, the Committee has recommended that it be provided with six-monthly reports on the achievement of major milestones in the design and construction of the proposal and the level of expenditure.

The last of the four reports that I am tabling this evening relates to the relocation of SBS radio and television to premises in Artarmon, New South Wales. The SBS plans to relocate radio station 2EA at Bondi Junction and SBS television at Milsons Point to an existing building in Artarmon. The proposal that the SBS put to the Public Works Committee was for the renovation of an office-warehouse complex for the use of the SBS at a cost of $14.5m.

The Committee has concluded that there is a need for the SBS to have new premises. Its present premises are too small for its requirements, and its television service is constrained by the grossly inadequate studio space which is available to it. The SBS carried out an extensive search for new premises before choosing the Artarmon site. It found that a new, purpose-built building was beyond its means and opted to adapt an existing building to its requirements.
