The building in Artarmon will provide the SBS with the space that it needs and, most importantly, with the scope to adapt part of the warehouse in the complex as studios to industry standards. This will allow the SBS, for the first time since it was established in 1978, to extend its television current affairs coverage to panel discussions with more than three participants and with the possibility of having an audience. It will also provide the SBS with the means of making its own productions. With these facilities, the SBS will be better placed than it is at present to serve Australia's multicultural community.

Some concern was expressed to the Committee about the choice of Artarmon as the location for the SBS's new premises. On balance, however, the Committee believes that the location is a suitable one. It is a cheaper location than the central business district, it is near other television stations and associated services, public transport makes it readily accessible for staff and contributors, and it will prove to be an asset. Furthermore, the building is larger than the SBS needs. The SBS plans to lease out the excess space and use the revenue gained to help finance local productions.

The Public Works Committee is recommending that Commonwealth funds be spent on the refurbishment of the office-warehouse complex at 14 Herbert Street, Artarmon, to provide accommodation for the SBS radio, television and corporate services.

In making this recommendation, the Committee was concerned about the very tight time frame for the refurbishment and the use of fast-track methods of construction. We know that fast-track construction tends to be more expensive than normal methods. If a tight time-frame for the project slips, the SBS will encounter additional costs. Because of these concerns, the Committee has recommended that the SBS report to it every three months on how well the project is keeping to its program and budget.

Finally, I will mention that the Committee also made recommendations about energy conservation, parking and transport for shift workers and the provision of child-care. In addition, the Committee urges the SBS to undertake more comprehensive consultation with the unions than it has undertaken hitherto. I commend the reports to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I commend the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for its report and certainly support the relocation of SBS from its present substandard premises. However, the site SBS is moving to contains a five-storey car park. I believe that it is an outrageous use of taxpayers' money to fund such a car park, which is worth several million dollars, and convert the whole work force of SBS from public transport to private transport. It is not only outrageous but also an unfair use of public funds. It is totally contrary to all public policy, especially as it is in the centre of Australia's largest city.

PARA.TAB: We have heard the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) with his mantra about stopping urban sprawl. To convert a whole work force involving several hundred people to the use of private cars in an area that is already very much subject to traffic congestion and pollution will obviously exacerbate the sprawl and involve hundreds of millions of dollars of infrastructure spending. As the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) has said, this site is one of the best served in Australia by public transport facilities. There are buses and trains within a five-minute walk of the site. I do not believe that any argument can justify public expenditure on a five-storey car park for a staff of some hundreds. We are simply pandering to the selfishness of Commonwealth employees, particularly when it is so detrimental to the area. In those circumstances it should be recommended that SBS be directed to sell that car park by public tender. It could then be utilised by anyone who wants to use it and by the rest of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As all these references from the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works will be referred for construction by the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) as representing the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), I will be very brief and commend the Committee for the work it does. I think that the Committee puts a lot of time and effort into its references. I too want to make one brief comment about the SBS relocation. I commented on this matter a month or two ago in this chamber. I am concerned that SBS seems to be getting into the empire building operation. As was pointed out by the Chairman of the Public Works Committee, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), this complex is larger than current needs dictate, which does make one wonder about the future plans for SBS.

PARA.TAB: The question of fast-track construction also concerns me because I believe that SBS on its current site has a lease that will run until 1995. Therefore, I would have thought that there is no urgency to warrant getting into fast-track construction. Nonetheless, I also voice my concern as to whether the size of the current SBS operation is fully justified. Finally, I wonder whether we will ever see a time when the Public Works Committee knocks something back and says, `Hang on, is there an alternative?'. I am sure that the Committee does look at these things very thoroughly and I will take its guidance.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: Construction of Australian Archives Repository, Burwood, Victoria

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of a new permanent repository for Australian Archives at East Burwood, Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: To ensure the preservation of permanent value records the Australian Archives maintains purpose built repositories in all regions except Victoria. The Melbourne accommodation is located in two principal sites: Brighton for permanent records and Dandenong for the records of temporary value. The Brighton site is currently owned by the Commonwealth, while the Dandenong site is leased. The Brighton accommodation is extremely dilapidated, suffering from rising damp, salt and water penetration and floors which are breaking up. These poor conditions have led to one building having to cease being used for record storage. This, together with the general deterioration of paper records at Brighton, indicates that the higher than average temperatures within the repository are increasing the rate of decomposition. If the records continue to be exposed to the degrading influences of this environment, it will only serve to compound the problem for future generations.

PARA.TAB: The proposed facility will rectify these problems by providing up-to-date, climate controlled secure storage facilities for permanent value Commonwealth records. It will consist of three main elements, including record storage, office accommodation and conservation. The office accommodation and conservation areas will be located in a two-storey configuration fronting a three-level record storage area. The buildings and site planning will also allow for future expansion of facilities.

This building is estimated to cost $6.5m as at October 1991 prices. It will take approximately 12 months to construct. During this period it will provide employment for approximately 30 people, rising to 50 people during the peak construction period. I table supporting drawings and commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal that is to be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works concerns the construction of a new repository for the Australian Archives in Victoria. It might be argued that I face a conflict of interest between my role of Chairman of the Public Works Committee and my membership of the Advisory Council on Australia Archives. This matter was discussed by the Public Works Committee this morning and the Committee was unanimous in its opinion that there was no conflict of interest, for the following reasons: my membership of the Advisory Council is public knowledge; my role in relation to the Archives is only an advisory one; and I do not stand to make any financial gain from the proposal. I should add that the members of the Committee have in the past participated in inquiries dealing with matters of interest to them, for example, projects in their own electorates. I just wanted the relationship between my role as Chairman of the Public Works Committee and my membership of the Advisory Council on Australian Archives to be placed on the public record.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: Installation of Fire Sprinklers, International Terminal Building, Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Installation of fire sprinklers to the International Terminal Building, Sydney Airport, New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: The international terminal building was opened in 1970 and met all the then relevant codes. Since that time the building has been modified in a number of areas to ensure public safety is not compromised. Airport terminal buildings are not expressly covered by codes, but they need to have appropriate protection. A number of reports have recommended the installation of fire sprinklers to provide safety for the occupants of the building, to protect the property as well as other improvements to provide smoke isolation and an emergency evacuation system and additional fire exits.

PARA.TAB: The Federal Airports Corporation assumed control of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport on 1 January 1988. Since that time additional fire exits have been constructed as part of improvements to the international terminal which were completed in 1989 at a cost of $50m. Smoke isolation measures were also installed on existing stairwells and escalators. The Corporation later proceeded with further extensions to provide a new 70,000 square metre terminal and concourse at a cost of $272m. The design of fire protection measures for the new terminal expansion was based on the assumption that the existing terminal building would have fire sprinklers installed.

The works proposed at this time comprise the installation of fire sprinklers throughout the existing building, associated building works, the replacement of plasterboard ceilings and ceiling tiles in the customs hall and departure area and the treatment of asbestos within the ceiling voids associated with the sprinkler installation.

Subject to Government approval, the FAC Board has approved funding of $14.6m as an out-turn cost for the installation of fire sprinklers in the existing terminal building. It is proposed that these works will commence in June 1992, with completion within 2 1/2 years. I table selected drawings of the proposed installation of fire sprinklers at the international terminal building at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, New South Wales. I commend this motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly endorse this proposal. I must admit that when I saw the reference I thought for a minute it may be the third runway. I thought something was really going to happen after nine years, but it is only sprinklers. Maybe we will get a runway one day.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: RAAF Base, Tindal

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Stage 3 development of RAAF Base, Tindal, Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: This stage of the development will involve the provision of air defence facilities comprising the sector operations centre and No. 2 Control and Reporting Unit headquarters, accommodation associated with projected personnel increases stemming from the air defence facilities, deployed squadron operational and technical facilities, aircraft pavements, aircraft shelters and associated engineering services. The estimate for these works is $53.5m at April 1991 prices. It is planned that sections of the work will go to tender in March 1992, with overall completion by 1996.

PARA.TAB: In its report the Public Works Committee agreed to the stage 3 development of the RAAF base, Tindal, Northern Territory, subject to the implementation of the following recommendations: that Defence should liaise with the Defence Housing Authority to ensure that sufficient numbers of houses are available at Tindal or in Katherine for personnel when the planned population of the base is achieved; and that Defence maintains continuous liaison with the Defence Housing Authority to develop forecasts for changes to married quarter requirements. This process will include RAAF's perceived personnel increases from the stage 3 development as well as other influencing factors.

The Committee recommended that an energy audit of existing facilities at Tindal should be undertaken now. An energy audit of existing facilities at Tindal is currently scheduled for April 1992. The Committee also recommended that an analysis of the drainage pattern of the Tindal-Katherine area be funded by Defence, the Northern Territory Government and the Katherine Town Council to identify factors contributing to the flooding and to recommend realistic measures to minimise this. Defence intends to assist the Northern Territory Government and the Katherine Town Council to undertake an independent study of the drainage problems in the Tindal-Katherine area. I would like to thank the Committee for its support, and I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I have no doubt that this public work is needed, I do have a small concern. How can the Chairman of the Public Works Committee bring a report into this chamber, into the Parliament, and then, within a matter of minutes, the Government make a recommendation to proceed? I find it amazing that the Government can consider that report within a matter of minutes and say, `Yes, we are going ahead with it'.

PARA.TAB: I would like the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) to assure this chamber that he is not treating this Parliament with disdain or contempt by saying, `Well, whatever the Public Works Committee recommends, as soon as it has made its recommendation we will do what we were going to do anyway'. While I do not doubt the need for the works as designated, I do feel that the Minister and the Department involved ought to be able to demonstrate that they will consider the reports of the Public Works Committee with due regard.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: CSIRO Redevelopment, Parkville

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: CSIRO Redevelopment, Parkville, Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed work recommended by the Public Works Committee involves the redevelopment of the CSIRO Parkville site to provide a major research complex and new headquarters for the division of biomolecular engineering. The proposed facility will provide for 140 people and development works will be undertaken in three stages to satisfy client requirements that the site remain operational at all times.

PARA.TAB: The work will include: demolition of an old two-storey wing along the western boundary and construction of a new four-storey wing linked to the existing main laboratory; upgrading and refurbishing the existing main laboratory and administration building to house administration, amenities, research services and support units, including stores and workshops; and demolition of a portion of Mayfair, an old Victorian residence, and redevelopment of this area of the site as landscaped open space for increased staff recreation.

The proposal was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works in September 1991. The Committee tabled its report on 12 December 1991, recommending the redevelopment at a cost of $12.25m at August 1991 prices. These funds have been programmed into CSIRO's capital investment plan.

CSIRO and Australian Construction Services have noted all the Committee's recommendations, and CSIRO has undertaken to provide the Committee with copies of its reports on energy management systems, conservation measures and child-care need in respect of the Parkville redevelopment as soon as they are available. The PWC requested consultations on the critical technical advice on fire protection measures considered appropriate for a project of this nature. These will be augmented on future occasions on this and other projects as plans are prepared and throughout the construction phase. The PWC can be assured that all necessary consultations will be undertaken. I thank the Committee for its report and I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reiterate the point I made in regard to the last reference. I recognise there is still quite a lot of business on the Notice Paper so I will not repeat those comments, but I do think they are just as relevant to this reference as they were to the previous one.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In answer to the concerns raised by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), as I understand it, the reports were actually tabled in the Senate last week. That may indicate why the Government has been so speedy in its response.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: Naval Support Headquarters, Pyrmont

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Relocation of Naval Support Command Headquarters, Pyrmont, New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: The work will involve the internal and external refurbishment of two substantial buildings together with the removal of a vehicle garage, relocation of an electrical substation, and the construction of a special purpose workshop facility for use by the underwater systems division of the Defence, Science and Technology Organisation, DSTO. The work has been designed to keep within a cost budget of $13.4m at April 1991 prices.

PARA.TAB: In its report the Public Works Committee has determined that a need exists to refurbish buildings Nos 1 and 2 at the Royal Edward victualling yard at Pyrmont, but raised certain issues. The Committee recommended that the landscaping to be provided should include, if possible, some lawn and shade trees. Defence agrees with this recommendation and feels that a landscaped environment will add to the overall attractiveness of the site and increase the amenity of the area for staff.

The Committee recommended that the number of showers to be provided should be increased from three to six. Defence again agrees that an increased number of showers will be appreciated by the staff and that they, along with other staff amenities, including a gymnasium, lunch rooms, outdoor eatery, et cetera, will enhance the environment of the site.

It was recommended that the internal layout should recognise and reflect the potential changes in office requirements, particularly services such as power points and air-conditioning ducts and avoid rabbit-warren configurations evident in some other Defence office buildings. The internal configuration proposed for the two buildings will provide an open planned environment with functional work stations to take maximum advantage of the heritage character of the buildings and provide flexibility for growth and change.

The Committee recommended that consultation with local fire authorities should continue during the design development of this proposal. Defence agrees that consultation with fire authorities throughout the detailed design stage of the project will continue. Given that the proposed work is being undertaken by Defence in collaboration with a number of consultants, the Committee recommended that it should be provided with reports every six months on the achievement of major milestones in the level of expenditure.

Again, Defence agrees to the regular reporting of progress to the Committee and will liaise with the secretariat of the PWC on frequency, format and content. I would like to thank the Committee again for its report and commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the comments of the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) prior to this reference for approval, I take his point. I wish that the Government could be as speedy on responding to other reports. One week is not bad. Most committees of the House of Representatives find that if they can get a response within months, sometimes even six months, they are doing well. I am also impressed that the Committee is so concerned about those who are working there and to make sure that they are properly cared for.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: Special Broadcasting Service, Relocation of Radio and Television, Artarmon, NSW

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Special Broadcasting Service, relocation of radio and television, Artarmon, NSW.

The work will involve essential repairs and maintenance to the fabric of the buildings, the upgrading of existing fire protection and building services in accordance with the current regulations, and the fitting out of approximately half the existing building area to provide accommodation for SBS radio, television and corporate activities.

The total estimated cost of the project, including site acquisition, building adaptation and the fitting out of technical equipment, consultants' fees and making good to existing lease premises is $34.9m at June 1991 prices. The limit of cost for the refurbishment of the building is $14.5m.

In its report, the Public Works Committee recommended that refurbishment at Herbert Street, Artarmon, by the Special Broadcasting Service should proceed, but it raised the following issues. The Committee recommended and the Special Broadcasting Services agreed to report to the Committee every three months on its progress in meeting the programs set out for its relocation to Artarmon and the progress of the report against its projected cost. The Committee recommended that the Special Broadcasting Service provide transport for its shift workers between the buses and trains at St Leonard's and the Artarmon building. The SBS will provide such transport for its staff, including shift workers, subject to a joint union/management review of the extent of utilisation.

It was recommended that the Committee receive a copy of any results from the Special Broadcasting Service's studies of the building's potential for employing energy conservation measures. The SBS has agreed to provide the Committee with a copy of such results. The Committee recommended that the Special Broadcasting Service report to it on the number of car park spaces that will be allocated to the Special Broadcasting Service staff and other tenants of the building and the criteria that will be employed to allocate space among the Special Broadcasting Service's staff and visitors.

The SBS will report to the Committee in the terms required as soon as this issue is finalised. The Committee also recommended that the Special Broadcasting Service report to the Committee on the policy that it develops with dealing with the staff's need for child care. The SBS will report to the Committee as soon as that policy is finalised. The project is to be funded by SBS borrowings recently approved by the Loan Council, with repayments to be made from future rental and operational savings. It is planned that construction will commence in January 1992 with occupation of the facilities in February 1993. I would like to thank the Committee again for its report and commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not repeat myself, but I did make some comments on this reference as it came back from the Public Works Committee and I stand by those comments that I made a few minutes ago.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 12 and 13 (1991).

SPEECH.PARA: The tariff proposals which I have just tabled and which are now being circulated to honourable members relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Customs Tariff Proposal No. 12 (1991) will operate on and from 1 January 1992. Proposal No. 12 contains the following alterations: the implementation of the Government's decision to take economic measures against Yugoslavia; redefinition of the upper weight limit for light commercial vehicles; changes to item 36B in schedule four as a consequence of Customs Cooperation Council nomenclature changes and current phasing rates; and the introduction of a new item in schedule four to maintain current duty rates for orthopaedic appliances following changes to the harmonised nomenclature.

PARA.TAB: In response to the serious situation in Yugoslavia, the European Community, which has taken a leading role in trying to mediate between the parties, announced a series of economic measures against Yugoslavia, including the withdrawal of Yugoslavia's access to the European Community's generalised system of preferences. Australia and a number of other countries decided to take supportive measures. Accordingly, Yugoslavia will be taken off the list of countries which benefit from the Australian system of tariff preferences.

The European Community also decided that those of Yugoslavia's six republics which cooperate with the European Community's peace efforts would be exempted from the measures taken against Yugoslavia, and the Australian Government decided to adopt the same distinction. Accordingly, the republics of Bosnia, Croatia, Macedonia and Slovenia will be listed among those places which are eligible under the Australian system of tariff preferences. The business community has put on notice that these actions were to be taken in a press statement on 13 November 1991 by the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The date of effect of these changes will be 1 January 1992 so as not to disadvantage importers of goods on the water.

Under existing arrangements, light commercial vehicles have an upper limit of 2.72 tonnes gross vehicle weight. This limit is now being widely replaced by the European standard, which has an upper limit of 3.5 tonnes. The European standard is currently in use in Australian design rules for vehicles and is also used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The changes in this proposal arise from new automotive arrangements announced in the Government's March industry statement and bring the Customs tariff into line with current practice.

As a result of amendments to the harmonised nomenclature by the Customs Cooperation Council, two changes are being made to schedule four: the table to item 36B is being altered to reflect a change in schedule three and to remove references to classifications which become duty free on 1 January; and new item 40G is being introduced to maintain the current free rate of duty for orthopaedic goods of textile material which are currently classified in chapter 90.

Customs Tariff Proposal No. 13 will operate on and from 1 March 1992. This proposal inserts new tender quota and tender quota extension rates for textiles, clothing and footwear goods from 1 March 1992 to 28 February 1993, following the determination of rates under the 1992 tender quota scheme.

These changes have been made in the context of the post-1988 assistance arrangements for textiles, clothing and footwear industries based on the premium tender rates for the 1992 quota period. The out of quota rates also reflect the phasing down of duty rates announced in the 1991 industry statement. Summaries of the alterations that contain these proposals—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Sinclair

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. Television has just displayed the Prime Minister handing in his resignation. I would like to point out to you that under section 65 of the Australian Constitution:

INTERJECT.PARA: Until the Parliament otherwise provides, the Ministers of State shall. . . hold such offices as the Parliament prescribes, or, in the absence of provision, as the Governor-General directs.

The only provisions are under the Ministers of State Amendment Act 1988. There is no provision there other than that referred to in Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice. We are told that a Ministry's existence depends on the Prime Minister's continuance in office. The resignation or dismissal of the Prime Minister by convention causes the resignation of the full Ministry. A Prime Minister may resign—as the Prime Minister has—hence causing the resignation of all Ministers.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker, I point out to you that there is no Ministry. The Minister purporting to exercise the authority of office has no office. I put it to you that on that basis there is no reason for us to sit and listen to somebody who is not exercising that authority. In that circumstance, I would suggest that the House do now adjourn.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—I thank the right honourable gentleman for his contribution. It is the understanding of the Chair that it was the intention, if not by now an act, of the Governor-General to request the Prime Minister to continue as Prime Minister until such time as a successor will be sworn in. That being the case, it is the Chair's understanding that the current Prime Minister is still the honourable member for Wills until such time as a successor is sworn in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I accept your advice to the House. But could I point out to you that these are matters of very considerable constitutional significance. The appropriateness of laws that are passed by this Parliament depends entirely on the constitutional capacity of those who purport to be Ministers to have the authority which they assert. I would suggest that without some advice to this Parliament, when all of Australia knows of the Prime Minister's resignation and that the Prime Minister designate has not in fact been to Government House, it is quite inappropriate for us as a parliament to sit here in a travesty of the democratic process. This is supposed to be a parliament considering the laws applying to the people of Australia. How can we possibly deal with matters when we do not know whether the man who is on his feet has any authority?
—Order! I thank the right honourable member.
—I am wondering, Mr Deputy Speaker, whether this is a point of order.

—I take the Minister's point. In view of the circumstances, I was prepared to permit a certain degree of leeway. Nonetheless, I have explained to the right honourable member the situation as the Chair understands it, and that is that it was the intention of the Governor-General to request the Prime Minister to stay as Acting Prime Minister until such time as his successor has been appointed. That being the case and in the absence of any—

—How in the devil can you know the Governor-General's intent? This is one of the more fundamental parts of our democratic system. Mr Deputy Speaker, I would suggest to you that until we have had advice that there is a request to the Prime Minister to continue in office, these proceedings are totally irregular and their authority is left open to some probing by the High Court at a subsequent time. I suggest that this is something that even members of the Ministry would not want.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to speak to the point of order. I point out to the House that this difficulty arises because the Government has not seen fit to follow what I understand to be the correct procedure, when a change of Prime Minister occurs while Parliament is sitting, of the outgoing Prime Minister informing the Parliament of what has happened. I know from certain recollections that that was the case when Prime Minister Gorton was replaced by McMahon in 1971.

PARA.TAB: Can I simply say further to the point of order of the right honourable member for New England, that you have no way of knowing, the Leader of the House has no way of knowing and the Parliament has no way of knowing in the absence of a statement. What should have happened was that the honourable member for Wills, after the Caucus ballot, should first have come to this Parliament and informed the Parliament of the change of leadership in the Government party. He should have informed the Parliament of his intentions in relation to His Excellency.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel that I should say to the honourable member for Bennelong that I have extended considerable indulgence in terms of his speaking to the point of order. While, under the circumstances, I am prepared to be indulgent, I would ask him to bring his remarks to a close.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I support everything that the right honourable member for New England has said. I draw your attention to the fact that on earlier occasions when changes have occurred in the prime ministership while the Parliament has been sitting, the first act of the outgoing Prime Minister was to pay the Parliament this courtesy. I have to say that this is consistent with a long attitude of indifference to parliamentary procedure by the present Government. You do not know, he does not know and nobody formally knows what the outgoing Prime Minister told His Excellency.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, whatever may be the view of honourable gentlemen opposite on whether the Prime Minister should have spoken in this House or whatever as to his situation, the fact of the matter is that he is still the Prime Minister of the country. My understanding is that his successor will be sworn in tomorrow. The Prime Minister retains his commission. The Governor-General has received advice on that. There is absolutely no problem with the legality of these proceedings.

PARA.TAB: The argument about whether or not the Parliament should have been told as a matter of courtesy is not a problem in terms of the viability of the proceedings of this place. They can continue. Naturally, of course, at the point of time Mr Keating is sworn in as Prime Minister there will have to be other ministerial arrangements made.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may continue, summaries of the alterations contained in these proposals have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Mr Costello) adjourned.
Bill presented by Mr Free, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of aspects. The Bill will implement the changes initially announced in the March industry statement to taxation depreciation arrangements. Following consultations with business and professionals, further details of the changes to depreciation were announced on 26 September 1991.

PARA.TAB: The Bill also introduces amendments to prevent avoidance of tax under various provisions which authorise tax deductions for capital expenditure incurred in income producing activities.

Another amendment provides for a deferral—or `roll-over'—of balancing adjustments that may arise on the disposal of property to which the various capital allowance rules have applied; for example, plant depreciation or the various capital allowances for mining property.

The Bill will provide a company that is the beneficial owner of shares held by a trustee or partnership, with a rebate for its share of net income of the trust or partnership that relates to the dividends paid on those shares.

The Bill will also bolster the trading stock provisions of the law by ensuring that tax deductions under section 51 for buying trading stock are not allowed until the stock is on hand. This will remedy a weakness exposed in a recent Federal Court case.

This Bill will also amend the tax law to streamline the tax file number arrangements. The capital gains tax roll-over provisions for transfers of partnership assets to wholly-owned companies are also to be amended to correct a technical deficiency.

Other minor amendments to be given effect by this Bill relate to foreign source income measures; foreign exchange gains and losses, the rehabilitation of mining, quarrying and petroleum sites; the research and development provisions; substantiation; and the taxation of education entry payments.
Finally, the Bill contains a number of minor technical or procedural amendments of the tax laws.I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.

The Bill will implement a number of announced changes to depreciation arrangements. For the first time, a definition of effective life will be inserted into the income tax law. Broadly, effective life will be defined as the period during which an item of plant can reasonably be expected to be used for income producing purposes by any person.This definition will facilitate the matching of depreciation deductions to the income generated by the item of plant.

The new effective life definition will apply to assets acquired on or after 1 July 1991. However, following representations from business groups, assets acquired after 12 March 1991 will be eligible for the new effective life rules from 1 July 1991.

Consistent with self-assessment principles, taxpayers will be able to estimate the rate of depreciation at the time an item of plant is first used, or installed ready for use, for income producing purposes. This estimate will be based on an objective view of effective life having regard to the statutory definition.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioner of Taxation will continue to publish advisory depreciation rates that taxpayers not wishing to make independent estimates may adopt for convenience.

PARA.TAB: The Bill will also give effect to several simplification initiatives. The number of depreciation rates will be reduced from 18 to seven broad-banded rate classes, effective from the 1991-92 income year. All assets eligible for broadbanding, excluding motor vehicles, will receive loading at the rate of 20 per cent. For assets acquired on or after 1 July 1991, 100 per cent depreciation will be allowable where the value of the unit of plant does not exceed $300 or the estimated effective life of the item is less than three years. This will reduce the large accounting task associated with small items.

Also with effect from the 1991-92 income year, taxpayers will be able to pool items within a rate class for further administrative simplicity. The estimated cost of broadbanding and 100 per cent depreciation is $100m in 1992-93, with a declining cost in later years.

The Bill will correct a technical deficiency in certain provisions which provide tax deductions for capital expenditure incurred in income producing activities, for example, plant depreciation allowances and allowable capital expenditure in mining operations. The amendments will prevent avoidance of tax on recoupments of previously allowed capital deductions.

A common feature of the capital allowance provisions is that taxpayers are required to bring to account as income amounts received on the disposal of property that represent a recovery of deductions previously allowed. For example, under the plant depreciation rules, an assessable recoupment of deduction occurs when the disposal proceeds of an asset exceed its depreciated value.

In some instances, the existing law allows taxpayers to nominate as the selling price of an asset the lesser of its market value and its tax written down value. This rule can result in tax avoidance where an asset with a high market value and a low written down value is disposed of by a taxpayer to a related entity at the lower value. If the related entity then sells the property at its true market value, the proceeds cannot be treated as a recoupment of the previous owner's deductions.

To remedy the situation, the various capital allowance recoupment rules are being amended to treat disposals of relevant property under non-arm's length arrangements, or under arrangements that involve some continuity of ownership of the property, as occurring at market value.

The Bill gives effect to the then Treasurer's announcement of 8 December 1990 that wholly owned group companies could elect to defer capital allowance balancing adjustments that would otherwise apply to intra-company group asset transfers occurring after 6 December 1990 where capital gains tax roll-over relief applied.

A variant from the announcement is that, in respect of intra-group disposals occurring after today, capital allowance balancing adjustment roll-over relief will apply automatically whenever capital gains tax roll-over relief is obtained.
The Government has also decided to extend capital allowance balancing adjustment roll-over relief to the following kinds of asset disposals where capital gains tax roll-over relief is obtained:

SPEECH.PARA: .a disposal of an asset by an individual or trustee to a wholly owned company;
.a disposal of partnership property to a company which is wholly owned by the partners; and
.a transfer of an asset to a spouse as the result of a marriage breakdown.

An optional form of balancing adjustment roll-over relief will also be available for disposals of property which are taken to occur as the result of a part change in ownership of property, for example, as can occur when the membership of a partnership is varied. This will enable owners of property to avoid being unnecessarily taxed on amounts that relate to a share of property which they continue to own.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Dividend Rebates: Company Beneficiaries and Partners

PARA.TAB: The Bill will extend the scope of the inter- company dividend rebate to allow the rebate to companies that are not shareholders. The proposed amendment will overcome the effect of the High Court decision in the Patcorp case.

The effect of this decision was that only the registered shareholder was entitled to the inter-company dividend rebate. Even though a company was absolutely entitled to the shares as against the trustee and was taxed on the dividend as trust income, it was not entitled to the rebate.

The entitlement to the rebate of the beneficial owner or partner that is a company will be determined as if it was a shareholder and had received a dividend equal to its share of the income of the trust or partnership that relates to the dividend.

The amendment will apply to dividends paid after 17 August 1976—the day the High Court handed down the decision in Patcorp. But the assessment of any company that was not allowed the rebate in an assessment that issued before today will not be able to have that assessment amended to allow the rebate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Deferral of Deductions for Prepayments of Trading Stock

PARA.TAB: This Bill will affirm the principle of matching tax deductions for expenditure on trading stock against income from selling that stock in the appropriate tax year. This matching process is not just a principle of the tax law but is also a general accounting principle.

Under the present law, expenditure on trading stock is initially deductible under section 51 in the year in which it is incurred. To match deductions against appropriate income, section 28 then writes back as income the value of trading stock on hand at the end of the year. By this process, deductions are deferred until the stock is sold.

The Federal Court case of Federal Commissioner of Taxation versus Raymor exposed a weakness in the interaction of section 51 and section 28. In that case the taxpayer was able to achieve a tax timing advantage by prepaying the cost of certain trading stock that was not delivered, or even made, by the end of the relevant tax year. Because this particular stock was not on hand at year end, section 28 could not operate to defer the deduction allowable under section 51 for the expenditure incurred in that year.

The amendment proposed by this Bill will ensure that a deduction under section 51 for expenditure on stock is not available until the stock becomes trading stock on hand of the taxpayer. The amendment will apply to expenditure incurred after today.

The amendments to the tax file number provisions will deal with situations where a security, such as a share, is subject to a securities lending arrangement, or has been sold under certain `cum-dividend' or `cum-interest' contracts.

Also, investors in transferable investments such as shares or debentures will be required to quote their tax file number by the `books closing time' for the investment if they want to avoid having 48.25 per cent withheld from any income paid.
Securities dealers' `entrepot nominee companies', which are used solely to facilitate the buying and selling of securities, will be excluded from the tax file number arrangements.

The amendments will also correct a technical defect in the current law by making the person liable to pay income for the trust the `investment body' for the purposes of deducting tax file number amounts. The amendments will have no significant effect on the revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Capital Gains Tax Roll-over Relief for Partnerships

PARA.TAB: The Bill proposes to correct a technical deficiency in the capital gains tax roll-over provisions for transfers of partnership assets to companies wholly-owned by the partners.

Under the existing law, partners can obtain inappropriately high cost bases for shares received as consideration for transfers of partnership assets encumbered by attached partnership liabilities. This can result in increased capital losses or reduced capital gains when those shares are sold. These outcomes are unintended, and the law is to be amended to ensure that the cost bases of shares received in such circumstances reflect assumed partnership liabilities.

The amendments will prevent an unintended cost to the revenue, and will apply to disposals occurring after 6 December 1990, the application date for the capital gains tax partnership roll-over provisions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Taxation of Foreign Source Income

PARA.TAB: Amendment of the measures for taxing foreign source income in part X of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 will reduce the income of a controlled foreign company that is attributed to resident taxpayers by the amount of dividends paid by the company to unrelated parties on certain widely distributed finance shares.
This amendment, which will relieve taxpayers from an unintended liability to tax, is to apply from the time when the foreign source income measures took effect, generally the 1990-91 income year.

This Bill contains amendments which will ensure that the foreign exchange gains and losses provisions operate as intended. Any deductions for losses on a foreign exchange contract on capital account will be reduced by the amount of any offsetting gain on another contract if that gain is not included in assessable income.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Rehabilitation of Mining, Quarrying and Petroleum Sites

PARA.TAB: The Bill will make minor amendments to the rehabilitation provisions to clarify their operation.

It ensures that any rehabilitation which restores a site only part way to its pre-mining condition, or which restores only part of the site, will qualify for the deduction. It will also ensure that only depreciable expenses on plant or articles are excluded from the deduction.

These amendments, which will take effect from 1 July 1991, will alleviate concerns the mining and quarrying industries held on the operation of the rehabilitation provisions. They will not have any impact on the revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Research and Development Provisions in Relation to Core Technology and Expenditure on Plant

PARA.TAB: The Bill proposes three minor modifications to the research and development provisions of the law, which allow accelerated deductions in respect of expenditure on research and development.

Firstly, deductions in respect of `core technology' are to be limited to an arm's length amount. Secondly, amounts of expenditure incurred on core technology are to be excluded from the calculation of the reduced deduction that is available in the case of guaranteed returns.

The third amendment relates to deductions in relation to qualifying plant that is deductible in three equal instalments over three years. Where that plant is first eligible to be claimed as a deduction prior to 30 June 1993, it will continue to be deductible at a maximum of 150 per cent after that date rather than 125 per cent that is to apply to other types of expenditure deductible under the R&D provisions after that date.
The Bill will also amend the fringe benefits legislation to provide the Commissioner with a discretion to accept a lower level of substantiation than is currently allowable.

Under the present fringe benefits tax legislation, substantiation is required in order either to reduce the taxable value of certain fringe benefits or to ensure that certain other benefits are exempt from fringe benefits tax.

The proposed amendments will allow the Commissioner a discretion, similar to that contained in the income tax law when considering the substantiation requirements of the fringe benefits legislation. The amendment will have little impact on revenue.

An education entry payment for sole parent pensioners was announced in the 1991 Budget. The payment will be available to sole parent pensioners commencing or continuing full time or part time education courses which attract payment of Austudy.
The Bill ensures that, in common with other income payments, the education entry payment to be paid from 1 January 1992 will be taxed.
The impact of the proposal on revenue in each financial year is expected to be less than $100,000.

This Bill will make some technical and procedural amendments. One will clarify the operation of the provisions that deal with the carry forward of excess foreign tax credits. Another will make a technical correction to accurately reflect the text of the Australia-Fiji comprehensive taxation agreement. And another deals with the publication of indexation factors to be applied in calculating the motor vehicle depreciation limit and the capital gains cost base limit.
I present the explanatory memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Chaney) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the coalition, I would like to inform the House that the coalition totally agrees with the Government on this measure. The Public Service Amendment Bill makes commonsense changes to existing law. The aim of the Bill is to prevent officers employed by statutory authorities from accepting redundancy benefits and then returning to the Public Service.

PARA.TAB: The amendments would allow the employees either to accept the redundancy benefits or to rejoin the Public Service, but not both. It is my understanding that a like prohibition currently exists in relation to people who are employed at a departmental level, but it does not apply in relation to people who are employed by statutory authorities. The purpose of the Bill is to bring the practice in relation to statutory authorities into line with those of government departments.

I commend the Government for bringing the Bill in and offering it a speedy passage through the Parliament. Mr Deputy Speaker, I conclude my remarks by wishing you the compliments of the season and thanking you for your unfailing civility whenever you occupy the chair.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—The Chair is most grateful for those felicitous comments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Simmons) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 28 November, on motion by Mr Crean:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —While we on this closing day of the Parliament consider what is going to happen to the Primary Industry Councils Bill, I remind honourable members that the people most affected by this Bill—the primary producers of Australia—are in many cases, even this evening, going around in ever diminishing circles reaping the very crop that Australia needs in order to survive in export terms. This Bill is designed to set up the framework for the establishment of additional primary industry councils. It is specifically designed to cover the establishment of a council for the grains industry.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be aware, we have had Bills to establish appropriate primary industry councils covering the wool industry. This legislation is specifically deigned to provide a similar sort of council for the grain industry. It is proposed that the grains industry council comprise the president of the Grains Council of Australia with three members appointed on the nomination of the Grains Council; the chairman of the Australian Barley Marketing Federation; the president of the National Agricultural Commodities Marketing Association; the chairman of the Australian Bulk Grain Handling Authorities; the stockfeed manufacturers; the flour- millers; the president of the Australian Oil Seed Federation; the chairman of the grocery manufacturers of Australia; the malt producers will have a representative; the ACTU will have a representative; the Australian Agricultural Council will nominate someone; the chairman of the Australian Wheat Board; the chairman of the Grains Research and Development Corporation; and a government member will be appointed to the council.

A concern has been raised in my electorate by the representatives of the South Australian Co-op Bulk Handling Association about the establishment of these primary industry councils. This concern is expressed not only in South Australia but in Western Australia. Those of us in this House who represent the grain growing electorates of South Australia are aware that the chairman of the CBH in South Australia and, I am told, the chairman of the Bulk Handling Authority in Western Australia feel that there may be inadequate consultation between bulk handling authorities in dealing with this Bill. Given that the bulk handling authorities of both South Australia and Western Australia have reasonably secure financial outlooks, their concern has been that it may be appropriate for them as co-op bulk handling authorities to be represented on the council in addition to the bulk handling authorities which are already represented from other States and which do not enjoy the same sort of financial security as the Western Australian and South Australian industries. In fact, if we look at the bulk handling authorities of Western Australia and South Australia we find, to the credit of both their boards and their grower-owners, that without government funding both have capital assets of over $1 1/2 billion dollars and are in a financially sound position with bank balances in excess of $50m.

That is no mean achievement. It reflects on a rather different bulk handling situation in the States of South Australia and Western Australia. They have a valid point that they are currently being represented by the Bulk Handling Association of Australia, which represents bulk handling authorities that are not in as secure a financial position as their South Australian and Western Australian counterparts. Given the number of members of the Grains Industry Council, I think it would be inappropriate to expand it at this stage. But without seeking in any way to amend the legislation, we need to recognise that some of the cooperative bulk handling facilities have a viability that is not characteristic of their representation on the Council.

As I understand it, the Council is being established to provide a broader range of industry advice compared with the grower only groups that currently offer advice to the Minister. Because the Council will give this broader range of advice, the Opposition does not intend to oppose either the establishment of the Council or the Bill currently before the House. The functions of the Council will be to keep the strategic direction of the industry under review and to report to the Minister; to inquire into and report to the Minister on matters affecting the industry and which the Council considers require investigation or action; to inquire into matters which are referred to it by the Minister; to convene industry review conferences; and to consult with other bodies and persons as it thinks fit in the long term interests of the grain industries of Australia.

There is no doubt that the Council should be made up of members who have hands-on experience and who have been grain producers. Many people who ought to be on the Council find themselves currently too busy in production—which is primary industry—to make available the time necessary to do the Council justice. We need to recognise that farmers frequently find themselves represented by people who are, in many cases, professional board representatives. It is not a criticism I can make of the establishment of primary industry councils in general or the Grains Industry Council in particular.

While I am on my feet, I want to point out that currently the grains industry in Australia faces very much the insoluble problem of how to handle the subsidisation and the war of subsidy that is currently going on between the EC and the USA. When we consider that something like $55 billion a year goes into the subsidy of EC agricultural produce, we begin to see how impossibly difficult it is for Australian farmers to compete with such subsidies. Australian taxpayers, governments and oppositions cannot suppose that 17 million taxpayers in Australia can in any way match the subsidy being paid by the 270 million taxpayers in the EC and the USA.

It is essential that the Minister gets first-hand advice of the state of affairs in the grain industry in Australia. The Government and the Opposition have not pretended that we can enter into the grain subsidy war, but the success of grain growing in Australia will depend largely on the capacity we have to get the right sort of advice to the Minister. The Government has to represent farmers in such rounds as the GATT round. We cannot hope to win the economic battle; we can only hope to negotiate our way out of the present subsidy level that EC farmers are enjoying and that the European Community governments know they cannot continue to afford.

If that negotiation is to work, it is clearly important that the Minister be well briefed. It is clearly important that he be able to brief adequately the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett) as well. I would hope that the Grains Industry Council will see itself as having a key role in this briefing.

It needs also to be said that, if grain growers in Australia are to survive, the fundamental responsibility the Parliament has is to reduce their cost of production. The fundamental responsibility we have is effectively to encourage export income and, of course, the incentive in the Opposition's goods and services tax package is generated by an enthusiasm for increasing export income and reducing costs of production. In the interests of the grain growers and of all Australian primary producers and exporters, we have an obligation as a parliament to reduce costs of production. We have an obligation no less to encourage export income in order to meet the national debt that we have run up.

This Bill provides for the establishment of an effective Grains Industry Council. For that reason, the Opposition is happy to support the legislation. In fact, it does not take issue with the Bill currently before the House.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government in June introduced a series of wool Bills to prepare the way for the future arrangements for the wool industry. Amongst those Bills was a Primary Industry (Industry Councils) Bill, which was to be used as an umbrella Bill to establish initially a wool industry council, then a grains industry council and, presumably, other councils as well. We objected to that legislation because it was going to establish a series of primary industry advisory councils by regulation rather than by legislation. That is bad government at any time. We were successful in having that Bill withdrawn and replaced by a wool industry council Bill which was for the wool industry only and in which the membership and criteria relevant to that council were there by legislation rather than coming through at some other time by regulation.

PARA.TAB: This Bill, the Primary Industry Councils Bill, is another umbrella Bill, but it appears to be more appropriate in that any future council established will be by legislation rather than by regulation. The particular purpose of this Bill, as my colleague the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) has just mentioned, establishes a Grains Industry Council. This Grains Industry Council has 17 members; in other words, just about anybody—or organisation—who has any relationship to any aspect of the grain industry is included, as well as perhaps one or two who may not have too close a relationship.

The appointments to the Council are made by the Minister from those nominated by the various organisations. The Minister has the power to reject the nominations. The Council is established to provide a broader range of industry advice compared with the grower only groups, such as the Grains Council. It is interesting that the Grains Council supports this legislation because, in a way, it will reduce the significance of the Grains Council as a lobbying body with government.

We are not opposing the legislation, but I will be watching—I think my colleagues will also be watching—with interest to see, firstly, whether there are too many members on the Council. I have grave doubts as to the efficiency of a body with 17 members. The Council is subject to the Minister and the Government. At this stage, the Government is paying the bills and determining the membership. Just how important and independent will be the advice from that Council and how much note will be taken of it by the Government? It could be seen to be too much a creature of government rather than an independent industry body.

At present the grains industry is considering the best options for the future. It had the Grains 2000 conference. I note that one of the ways in which this Council and other councils can have an impact on forward thinking is to have similar types of seminars or conferences covering that industry. One point related to that which concerns me very much is that the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Miller, has been talking of his visions for agriculture, including the grains industry. This is causing considerable confusion and concern in rural Australia, because people are asking whether or not his comments are government policy.

If they are not government policy, the Minister for Primary Industries should say they are not. If they are, the Minister should confirm it. If they are not government policy, I believe the Minister for Primary Industries should ask the Secretary, Mr Miller, to confine himself to his official role as Secretary to the Department. If he wants to be part of the public debate on primary industry policy formulation, he can get out of what he is doing and robustly enter that debate. If he does not, I believe there is a conflict of interest in that he is making comments which I believe are inappropriate for a senior administrator of a department, though they would not be if made by a public policy debating official.

TALK.START.PARA: —Picking on the public servants again.
—That is an interesting point. It is a question of him playing his correct role.
—He can't defend himself and you come in here and pick on him. You ought to be ashamed of yourself.

—That is absolute rubbish. What about the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand)? Look what he has done as a Minister. Any time anybody said anything, look what he did to them. He is quite a hypocrite in this matter. What he is saying is quite out of hand. He is really being Left.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! the honourable member for Murray will continue his speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is two minutes wasted.
—That is more appropriate than what the honourable member has been doing tonight—talk about wasting time picking losers!
—Order! The Minister will restrain his enthusiasm.

—At least you are even-handed in this particular case, Mr Deputy Speaker. The other point I want to make is that the dairy industry is quite concerned that the Minister may have that industry as the next on his list for a council Bill of the same type. The dairy industry wants to make the point very clear to the Government that it has a Dairy Industry Council, which has been established for some time. The Council is made up of the different sectors of the industry—producers, processors and manufacturers—and is cooperating and working very well.

PARA.TAB: The dairy industry has the most value adding of any of the primary industries, with a range of value adding that takes place before export—in Australia rather than offshore. There is a different situation in most of the other primary industries. The industry is covering that situation very well at present. For all these reasons, the Government would do well to leave the industry alone rather than try to shape it into what the dairy industry considers to be not as effective or accountable an organisation. As I indicated earlier, the Opposition will not be opposing this legislation but will be watching its efficiency and value with some interest so that we can determine our position with regard to it and other councils when we become the government after the next election.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Beddall) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: TEXTILES, CLOTHING AND FOOTWEAR DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill amends the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Act 1988. The amendments to this Act arise from changes to assistance for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries announced by the Government in the March industry statement this year. Reductions in protection will be accelerated by phasing tariffs down to a maximum of 25 per cent by the year 2000, terminating quotas by March 1993 and abolishing bounties by June 1995.

PARA.TAB: The TCF industries will remain the most highly protected manufacturing sector but the March decision will bring them more into line with the rest of Australian industry. It will encourage the development of a more globally oriented TCF sector, while bringing benefits to the economy through the efficient use of resources and better products at cheaper prices for the consumer.

To help potentially competitive firms survive the pressure of protection cuts and to provide positive direction through this restructuring period, the Government decided to revise the TCF industries development strategy administered by the TCF Development Authority. The purpose of this Bill is to consolidate a number of the Authority's former programs into two stronger and more flexible programs, namely the incentives for international competitiveness program, which provides company specific assistance, and the broader infrastructure support program.

The new incentives for international competitiveness program will provide assistance aimed at improving the competitiveness of TCF firms by extending assistance for capital re-equipment and rationalisation projects, investment in manufacturing systems and raw materials processing projects.

The amendments to the Act will broaden the eligibility criteria in relation to export orientation and import replacement so that more firms will be able to take advantage of the program. Firms will still be required to demonstrate increases in international competitiveness with projects such as those aimed at export growth, import replacement, quality improvement and cost reductions.

An important element of this strengthened program is the integration of the former raw materials processing program. The Authority will continue to place high priority on assisting firms to efficiently process a greater percentage of TCF raw materials, such as wool, cotton, hides and skins. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House—

(1) at its rising at this sitting, adjourn until 2 January 1992 at 1.40 p.m, unless otherwise called together by the Speaker or, in the event of the Speaker being unavailable, by the Chairman of Committees, and

(2) at its rising on 2 January 1992 after an address by the President of the United States of America, adjourn until Tuesday, 25 February 1992, at 2 p.m., unless otherwise called together by the Speaker or, in the event of the Speaker being unavailable, by the Chairman of Committees.

SPEECH.PARA: At this time of the year it has become almost habitual to say that this has been an eventful year, but I do not think anyone would gainsay me if at this point I said that it has been an eventful year. Any parliamentary year that begins with a special sitting to debate Australia's involvement in a war would, for that reason alone, very seriously merit that description. This year has been much more than that, both internationally and here in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I suppose that uppermost in the minds of us all have been the further momentous changes in the Soviet Union and in eastern Europe. Whatever our political differences here, we are at one in a sense of joy that people so long oppressed and denied the opportunity of political liberty and the opportunity for full expression of their individuality, not only politically but economically, have now been given that chance.

Democracy is not something that just happens. It is something which has to be striven for. But, just as importantly as the striving for its achievement, very much we know that it has to be fought for to be maintained. We know, and I think we are proud of the fact, that in the striving to secure and to maintain democracy, the Parliament has a pivotal and foundational role. That is a privilege for us who are part of it. It is also an enormous responsibility.

Mr Speaker, the year has been full of so many changes and, if I may say so, so many achievements that I simply cannot take your time or hope to continue to receive your attention if I go to them all. I hope you will excuse me if I say, however, that I do have a sense of pride that this has been a year of considerable achievement domestically and internationally.

One achievement comes very particularly to my mind. Having had the opportunity last Saturday of seeing a great Australian produced film called Antarctica, I think the Government and this Parliament are entitled to have an enormous sense of continuing pride that this country, through the efforts of this Government and with the support of the Opposition, took a lead internationally in ensuring that that great and vast pristine continent should be preserved forever into the future as a safe place for the world.

The year 1991 has also seen the proceedings of this House televised for the first time as part of the steady effort to improve the operation of this place and to make it more accessible to the people whom we represent. It is a matter of regret to me that, for various reasons, we were unable to introduce further reforms to the procedures adopted in this place. But may I say as one who remains totally committed to this place that in time I hope those proposals will be adopted not only to the benefit of honourable members but also to the benefit of the people of this country.

As it is now very late, I have no intention of keeping honourable members here any longer than is necessary and so I extend to all honourable members, friends and foe alike, my best wishes for a happy and safe Christmas.

I also extend greetings to all those who work so tirelessly and so efficiently to keep this Parliament functioning smoothly and efficiently. The Clerk, the Deputy Clerk, the Clerk Assistants and the Serjeant-at-Arms have, as always, ensured that the business of this House is completed in the professional manner that we have come to expect, despite our own failings at times in the realms of parliamentary procedure.

The Joint House Department, the attendants, the transport office and all the others too numerous to name, of course, deserve not only our heartfelt thanks for a fine job well done but also the Christmas break upon which they will embark once we get out of their hair.

The same applies to the Parliamentary Liaison Officer, Clare Nairn, and her assistants, who once again have done a tremendous job. To you, very many thanks. It is, I am pleased to say, a tradition for me to single out the switchboard operators for very special mention. I do this because this select group of marvellously efficient, helpful and courteous ladies are for so many people the first contact point with Parliament House. I simply want to say to you, ladies, that your professionalism reflects well on us all. To Marlene and all her colleagues, my very sincere thanks. Mr Speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to thank my able and very well liked—indeed, loved—Leader of the House.
Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say I have no hesitation in declaring my love for him, and I thank him for his contribution throughout the year. Kim is a very special sort of bloke. He is the sort of colleague whom everyone wishes he had but very few of us are fortunate enough in fact to have. His advice is invariably sound; his good spirits and his enthusiasm for the parliamentary process are infectious; and, least but not last, he makes us all look well dressed.

PARA.TAB: In paying a sincere tribute to you, Kim, it would of course be totally remiss of me if I were not to mention your Opposition counterpart. It goes without saying that the quality and the integrity of the people who fill these positions are absolutely vital to the good running of this place. And Wal, you are a man of integrity. The relationship that you have with Kim is something which I know he respects, and we are all the beneficiaries of that relationship.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Bring the buggers to order, will you, Mr Speaker. I would also like to thank Kim's senior adviser on parliamentary matters, John O'Callaghan, who will be leaving us. Johnno will be leaving us for a more sane experience in January. Johnno, your contribution has been immense, if you are there.

PARA.TAB: Government members—He is in the gallery.

TALK.START.PARA: —Johnno, your contributions have been immense. Thank you for what you have done and the way you have done it. The best and most sincere thing I can say to you as a measure of your contribution is that you will be sorely missed by all of us and you go with our very best wishes.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish you and your deputies and committee chairmen a merry Christmas, a happy New Year, and we thank you for a difficult job well done.

PARA.TAB: I most sincerely extend to all honourable members my personal best wishes for a very happy, restful Christmas and New Year. Please, all of you go off with your dearly loved ones and have the rest that you deserve.

Mr Speaker, when I talk about members, obviously you will tend to think I am directing those remarks to my own side of the House. But in my time here as Prime Minister we have had some good jousts with you mob opposite, and I embrace you entirely in the remarks I make when I say I wish you the opportunity of having a good rest.

I would penultimately like to say to my own staff, whom I have not mentioned to this point, that I cannot adequately find the words to convey to you the sense of indebtedness that I feel, and I thank you very much indeed.

Finally, as this will be my last speech in this chamber as Prime Minister after nearly nine years, I would sincerely like to thank all my ministerial colleagues and those of my Party who have accorded me the privilege of leading this Party, this Government and this great country over the last nine years. It is impossible to tell you what pride I feel that you have given me that opportunity. I thank you most sincerely.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Whereupon honourable members stood and applauded.
