TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I might just take a few moments, as the hour is late, to express similar sentiments to those of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for the tremendous support that we in this House have enjoyed from those people who make our lives a lot easier than otherwise might be the case. Just reflecting on the year, I can only endorse what the Prime Minister said, that is, that it was a momentous year of change internationally. I think that what staggered most people was the pace of that change; how unexpectedly fast it was. Few of us just 12 months ago could have predicted the pace of that change, the break-up of the Soviet Union, the pressures in Yugoslavia—the staggering pace of change.

PARA.TAB: But for Australia, of course, it was a very hard year. It was a year when many Australians faced the reality of the deepest recession in 60 years. It is therefore going to be a pretty lousy Christmas for a lot of Australians. The challenge is there for all of us in this place to turn this place in the direction that it ought to go; that is, to ensure that there is good government, that the decisions that ought to be taken are taken and are taken quickly. The pain and hardship being experienced by average Australians today have not been experienced before by most of them in their lifetime, although some of them remember what their parents told them about the difficulties of the 1930s.

The year was also a very good year for the Opposition. It was a year of hard work. We produced a major plan for the rebuilding of the Australian economy—our Fightback package. As a party and as a coalition, it was a fightback for us too. We put the differences and the divisions behind us and got on and did the job. I am very pleased with the teamwork that was shown in the course of the year. A lot of people have contributed to that.

I must begin by thanking my colleague from the National Party of Australia, Tim Fischer, for the tremendous contribution that he has made to building a very effective coalition. I think it is the strength of that coalition which has been fundamental to our capacity to put together such an honest and substantive Fightback package as we have been able to achieve this year.

To my deputy, Peter Reith, I must say that he did a fantastic job—a phenomenal job in the amount of work that was done in putting that Fightback package together. Honourable members will notice that he is on my right-hand side these days. He has moved in that direction in the course of this year, and I am pleased to see that. But there was a tremendous amount of work done on that package. An enormous amount of detail went into that package. Never has there been a more detailed package brought down by an opposition and, dare I say, by many governments in the history of this country.

Robert Hill has run our Opposition in the Senate and has given the Government a good run in the Senate. I formally record our recognition of the tremendous contribution that he has made in the other place. To our Manager of Opposition Business, Wal Fife—I am not going to stand up here and say that I love Wal Fife. But Wal has made a phenomenal contribution to our side. What Bob Hawke said is true; Wal is a man of outstanding experience and integrity. That is evident every day. He is a very fine Australian who has a unique capacity, I think, to temper the enthusiasm of younger Turks around him. I think that is a very good thing, being one of those who have only recently come to this place.

Of course, I should also acknowledge the outstanding contribution of all the shadow Ministers on this side. They have worked very well as a team through a very detailed and laborious process of putting the Fightback package together. So I thank them all for their contribution. As well, I thank members of the back bench for the work they have done. To our Whips, Bob Halverson and Noel Hicks, Neil Andrew and Garry Nehl, I express my thanks for their tremendous contribution as well.

I would also like to thank the Clerks, particularly Lyn Barlin for the very quiet, professional and efficient manner in which he conducts this Parliament. Of course, I wish to thank the Serjeant-at-Arms, Phil Bergin, who has assumed that role in the course of this year and done an outstanding job. I wish to thank the parliamentary staff. There are many of them whose contribution we need to acknowledge. I refer to the PLO, Clare Nairn, the Hansard reporters, the attendants, the Bills and Papers Office. I wish to give special thanks, particularly given the amount of work we gave them this year, to the staff of the Parliamentary Library. I thank the catering staff, our drivers and so on. We have to formally acknowledge the tremendous contribution which they make to making our lives simpler and, of course, to making this place run as efficiently and as smoothly as it does.

I would like to pay a tribute to my own staff. They have made an outstanding contribution to the work that the Opposition has achieved this year. There are many stories that I can tell of the times that I have found them in the early hours of the morning asleep on their desks with the face of their watches imprinted on their foreheads. They have done a tremendous amount of work above and beyond the call of duty. I want to formally acknowledge not only the contribution of my own staff but that of the coalition staff generally.

To you, Mr Speaker—you have been, as you always are, a pillar of fairness and objectivity. We thank you for the contribution that you have made. We have had our differences at times. You have even warned some of us on occasions, but I think it is important that we acknowledge the contribution that you have made.

To the Leader of the House, Kim Beazley, congratulations on the way you have conducted the Parliament in the course of this year. Enough has been said about your dress sense and other features. My thanks extend even to the members of the press gallery. They are an essential part of what makes this place work. We must acknowledge the contribution that they have made.

Finally, I make just one comment on the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke). Of course, as political adversaries we have had our differences. Some of those have come to a head in the course of the last 12 months. But I would like to congratulate Bob Hawke on the very dignified way in which he has conducted himself in the course of what has been a very difficult year for him. Unlike the new Prime Minister, he has consistently refrained from dumping on his opponent in that leadership contest. I think that, even down to the final hours of today, Bob Hawke maintained the dignity which will be long remembered in this place.
Honourable members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I say that the difference between Bob Hawke and the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) I think explains why the electorate is so forgiving of Bob Hawke and why it will never be forgiving of the honourable member for Blaxland.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the `former' Prime Minister, the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in extending Christmas greetings to all. I would say at the outset to the honourable member for Wills that I wish him well in his life after direct politics—whenever that might be. I want also to make one other point. I had the privilege of going to the seventy-fifth anniversary celebrations at Gallipoli last year. It was a rare privilege to go with a group of members from both sides of the House—the Prime Minister, who was the host-in-chief, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) and the Leader of the Opposition —and more particularly with those veterans of World War I. It was a very moving occasion. Certainly, it was one which I was very honoured to attend on behalf of the parliamentary National Party.

PARA.TAB: I want also to say that I was a very new leader of the parliamentary National Party at that time. I had been elected just a few days earlier. In a situation in which the Prime Minister had a large number of official calls to make and had the whole cacophony of a bilateral visit as well as the Gallipoli visit, it was a matter of record that he extended every courtesy and additional courtesy on the occasion to both the Leader of the Opposition and me and made us feel very welcome and comfortable with the particular pilgrimage that we were making, including a very memorable day, the day after Anzac Day, when we crossed the Bosphorus on a boat—and survived—and attended a luncheon which I will also remember. I just want to place on record that it is perhaps, in these parting moments, a sign of the man that on that occasion he was a perfect host and catalyst to the occasion of the seventy-fifth anniversary of Gallipoli. I salute him for that.

Of course, I disagreed with the Prime Minister on the partisan political front. I know it is a matter of record, but anyone who has served as Australia's second longest serving Prime Minister must be acknowledged, and indeed the House did that in historic tones a short while ago.

Secondly, I wish to extend my thanks to my National Party colleagues, honourable members and senators, at the end of a long hard year; to my Deputy Leader, Mr Bruce Lloyd, and to the Whips involved. Certainly we have produced the goods through teamwork, and there is a lot of work to be done in the year ahead. I might also take this opportunity to express to my coalition colleagues and to the Leader of the Opposition, Dr John Hewson, my thanks for their liaison and cooperation throughout the year and, indeed, I pass on my thanks for all the arrangements associated with the progress which has been made this year.

I also express my appreciation to the Clerks, to the staff of the House and the Parliament, to the transport office, to Hansard, to the Parliamentary Library, to the catering service, to the national press gallery and, indeed, to my own staff for all the assistance which I have been afforded throughout this long, hard year.

I extend my best wishes to you, Mr Speaker, and to the President of the Senate. As we look forward to the Christmas-New Year break, short as that break may well be with the forthcoming visit of President Bush, I think we should all spare a thought for those in horrific economic circumstances this particular Christmas. We wish them well as we go about our own family reunions and the like.

I add two other things. It is my hope to spend this Christmas Day at home and not in Namibia or in the Gulf. I look forward to that because some of my nieces and nephews think I have been short-changing them on Christmas presents by coming up with these excuses to be away. But I did bring back some presents for them. So I do not disappoint the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley): I advise the House that it is my intention and my hope to visit Cambodia later on in January, as part of an annual pilgrimage to Asia, to see the Australian troops serving there at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not go on that train from Bangkok to Singapore, will you?

—No. And the trainline from Bangkok to Aranyaprathet to Phnom Penh has been bombed into oblivion in the key sections, so I will not be travelling on that either. Mr Speaker, in keeping with this time of the year, I wish everyone a very happy Christmas and, indeed, all the best for 1992.

—Mr Speaker, I must say this is a source of tremendous disappointment to us. We fought an enormous battle with a number of other nations that sought to do all sorts of things with that peacekeeping force in Cambodia so as to maintain the Australian position precisely to provide the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) with the opportunity to visit the troops in Cambodia for Christmas. But he has ducked it. I am stunned! He has obviously decided he will spend New Year with them, so I suppose that is some sort of substitute.

PARA.TAB: It is normal for me to make some remarks adding to those of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other speakers, and likewise for my counterpart from the Opposition at this time of the year. For me this is a day of great sadness on two counts, first because I sat to listen to the Prime Minister for the last time deliver the valedictories here. I think there is no member of the House who does not wish him well in his future. It is a measure of his contribution to the history of our Party that, as I had pointed out to me the other day by a friend of my father, although my father served something like three times as long as I have in this place, I have served three times as long as he did as a Minister.

For a member of the Labor Party to have had that privilege when we have had the rough end of the pineapple of Federal politics virtually since Federation is a mark of a sea change which will be of great historical record in times to come. The person who led us through that period, and who put us there in the first place, was the Prime Minister. His name and record are fixed forever in the history of this country and he needs no defence from me, or from any other member of this House.

The second reason for my sadness is what was referred to as the departure of Johnno. Johnno is a total political animal. It will be of interest to honourable members to know that he actually did not come from the branches or a background with the Labor Party with a long record of interest in party politics, as do many of our good staffers. He was in the Department of Defence and firstly came across to my office as a Defence official. He stayed on and grew to love this place and the members in it.

I am loath to say too much more about Johnno, and I will not for the sake of brevity and because fundamentally I think he is engaged in a hoax. I do not want to farewell him too fulsomely in case he takes it seriously. I know he is looking for something like double the normal four weeks annual leave and a few really decent Christmas gifts for a change, and then will return fully refreshed for the fray. Nevertheless, I express my very great thanks to him and anticipate a manifestation of yet another visitation by him at some point of time in the not too distant future.

A number of people have been thanked here in detail, and I will not mention them again. However, I do want to single out one or two people for special comment. The Clerk, Lyn Barlin, keeps this House ticking over in a most effective and non-partisan manner. Both sides of the House rely heavily on him and on his staff.

A number of people have not had the mention they usually have, but they do still deserve it. There is Liz who cuts our hair on occasions, and Aussie, and all those who run the small enterprises, official and unofficial, around the House. They all contribute to making the life of members in this place more comfortable. That goes for the medical staff as well, who have on occasion been called upon to render assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't forget Phil Bergin.
—I will not forget Phil Bergin. He is an honoured participant of the staff of this House and is deserving of a restful Christmas, as indeed are all the people who work for us.

PARA.TAB: I want to single out Clare, too, who has disappeared from the place now. She has done an excellent job as Parliamentary Liaison Officer. I thank the Whips, too, and there are several of them, basically because George skived off for a few months. The Whips are very important to the effective functioning of our side of the House, as I know the Opposition Whips are to that side. I wish them a very restful Christmas. In George's case he has had about three months rest, so I wish him a very active and reinvigorated period of activity back home over the next little while.

I thank you too, Mr Speaker, for the way in which you have conducted your office here in this place. We assigned you an enormously difficult task. In days gone by from time to time Speakers have been imprisoned, executed and in other ways harshly dealt with for the role they have played. Naturally a certain institutional toughness has been built into the operation and it seems like a mandate of heaven has descended upon you to ensure that you are protected in that position. I do wish you, Mr Speaker, all the best for Christmas and the New Year.

I endorse all the things that the Prime Minister said about my Opposition counterpart. The Prime Minister said it much better than I could. I agree with those comments, and I wish him and his family the very best for Christmas and the New Year. Of course, that goes for all Opposition members as well as those on our side of the House.

We have made a very substantial number of parliamentary changes over the last couple of years. By and large, they are working very effectively. I think that, too, the private members in this place have more authority and more opportunity to present their views than they have had in the past. There are still one or two problems associated with the treatment of private members' legislation, which we will have to deal with next year. I conclude, as other speakers have, by thanking the totality of my staff for the help that they have given me during the course of the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) have spoken more than adequately on behalf of the Opposition this evening. I do not wish to traverse all that they have said other than to associate myself with what they have said and the sentiments that they have expressed.

PARA.TAB: I thank you, Mr Speaker, for your cooperation with me in my official capacity during the year; I also thank the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley). On this special occasion, I also mention Mr John O'Callaghan, Clare Nairn and other members of the Leader's staff, who have always been very courteous to me and assisted me during the year in relation to the work of the Manager of Opposition Business. I thank honourable members on my side of the House, the Whips, my leader and all of the shadow Ministers for the depth and breadth of their support.

I would like, especially this evening, to associate myself with the sentiments that have been expressed to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). We have had our differences on political grounds over the years. Of course, for many years we have had a close association in a variety of ways—in various positions that I held in the State Government of New South Wales, when the Prime Minister was with the ACTU and when he was President of the Australian Labor Party. I would like to thank you, Prime Minister, for your many courtesies to me and to the members of my family.

I notice that there is another very special person here this evening in the gallery: Mrs Hawke. On behalf of members on both sides of the House, I would like to thank her for the way in which she has stood beside the Prime Minister in good times and in tough times. I thank her also for her contribution to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Often when the phrase `stable government' is mentioned, people think that we are talking about one side of politics or the other. But when one looks at the differences that exist in various countries around the world, one really understands what stable government is all about. When an election is held in this country, the party that wins is very happy; the party that loses is very disappointed. But the party that loses always respects the decision of the people. As I said in another debate earlier today, democracy is all about the opinions and decisions of the majority prevailing and the opinions and voices of the minority being heard. Whilst we take that for granted in this country, we need to reflect on the fact that many countries do not enjoy that kind of stable government. I believe that the outgoing Prime Minister has contributed to stable government in this country. I wish him and Mrs Hawke all the very best for the future.

—As somebody who sat opposite the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for some 3 1/2 years, I cannot let this historic occasion go by without saying something very briefly. It is a special, historic occasion. It is not often that a change of Prime Minister occurs during the lifetime of a government. It is even less often that it occurs while the Parliament is sitting. But I think we owe it to the importance of the institution and role that we all have as parliamentarians to not let occasions of this type go by without proper regard.

PARA.TAB: I hope that all of us on both sides of the House are objective enough to recognise performance and failure, and achievement and commitment, whatever our political beliefs may be. I do not think it is being cant, displaying humbug or being carried away by the emotion of the occasion to say that, in the sweep of certainly the history of the Labor Party and the history of both sides of politics in this country, the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) will be treated kindly by history. We will continue to disagree. The mere achievement of so many electoral victories has shown something of his skills as an Australian and as a political leader. There is no doubt that the particular contribution that he made to this place with his particular background has brought a dimension to the experience of the Labor Party that it had not previously had.

I have to say that the atmosphere in this place between both sides of politics, for what particular reason we might debate, is better now than it was some years ago. It was good when I first came here in 1974. As I have said on another occasion in relation to other issues, whatever the rights and wrongs are, the atmosphere of 1975 poisoned relations between both sides of politics. I think Australia was the poorer as a consequence of that.

Whatever the depth of division—and I think the Prime Minister is right—the next election will demonstrate a greater philosophical division between the two sides of politics than perhaps on other occasions in the recent past. But, in another sense, I think the place is a more civil, more understanding and, in a broader sense, a more Australian place now. There is a greater respect on both sides of the House for the other point of view; I think that is very important. I believe that the outgoing Prime Minister has made a significant contribution to that. I do not give him all of the credit, but I certainly give him a good measure of the credit for that. I have on other occasions—and one that I particularly remember—been moved to remark that, whatever differences there are between us politically, the things that unite us as Australians are more enduring than those that divide us.

I would like the outgoing Prime Minister to know from one of his continuing opponents in a political sense, but not in a personal sense, that I respect the contribution that he has made to, first of all, his country and also to his Party. He deserves to go from the proudest office that any Australian can hold with the personal good wishes for himself and his family for a very happy and healthy future life.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to be very brief. I have known the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for a long while and I, in a lesser form, have been through days like his, as has the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). I have also been here longer than anyone bar the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair).

PARA.TAB: I heard the former leader with whom I stood close in a leadership battle come into the House and announce his retirement as Prime Minister. As I recall it, he spoke using words to the effect of: `In the whole sweep of human history it matters little who stands at the dispatch box'. That might be true in the whole sweep of human history, but in the snapshot of contemporary times in which we serve, it matters a great deal.

I respect Bob Hawke. I have had a lot of battles with him and I have said things sometimes that I have regretted. But I have an enormous regard and respect for this man. I wish him well at the end of this adventure that awaits him and Hazel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, like my colleagues the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), I thought it appropriate that perhaps I say a few things too about my regard and respect for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as he steps down from his high office. First, I think it is important that we all understand that in the events that concluded the last century when the Australian Labor Party was established, when shearers were really not particularly well regarded by the fraternity of which I and a few of my colleagues are members—
—You still do not regard them well. You still treat them the same.
—On the contrary, we have had to become them. The Prime Minister reflects very much the trade union movement and he is perhaps the most distinguished graduate of that school.

PARA.TAB: I think it is important that we all respect and pay tribute to a man who has done so much for the working class antecedents of Australia. Certainly, he was a Rhodes Scholar. Some of us saw him as not necessarily a member of the trade union movement but as a man with a very considerable academic background and with considerable attributes outside the trade union movement.

But, Bob, you have been true to your cause and I regard you very highly for the fact that you have believed in it. Above all, I pay you great respect for the manner in which you have left your high office.

Like the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Fife), I would like to pay tribute to Hazel. It is a hell of a job, I think, being a spouse of a pollie. We are never home and our kids are brought up in spite of us. It does not matter whether the spouses are the wives or husbands of members—they do a great job. I think Hazel has been wonderful—God bless you and I wish you well.

Can I say that tonight has been one of those rare occasions in this place. I, too, happen to regard Paul Keating personally very highly. The only sadness in my heart is that I am very disappointed that the honourable member for Blaxland is not here for these tributes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before putting the motion, I would like to make just a few points. There are a lot of people who make this place work as a parliament. As others have said here tonight, although we are often reviled by the press and others, I do not think there is a higher calling that any of us can have than to be a parliamentarian. It is a honour that not many people in Australia get—the honour of representing in the national Parliament the people we have often grown up with and lived with. All of us have been given the high honour of doing this.

PARA.TAB: As other members have said, tonight is a very historical occasion. The Prime Minister has retired. As has been said, we all would be proud to have made half the contribution that Bob Hawke has made to Australia, both as a trade union official and as a Prime Minister of Australia.

I remember once going to an ACTU congress in the Dallas Brooks Hall in Melbourne and hearing the best speech I have ever heard in my life. That speech was made by Bob when he was the President of the ACTU. In that speech, without using notes, he gathered up the whole sweep of a couple of days of debate. That speech certainly carried the day.

I think, in a way, all of us have been very privileged to be here over the last few years. The remarks made by us are not adequate to say to you, Hazel and your family that you have done a job very well. All Australians are proud of you for the job that you have done. It is a job that you in your own heart know that you have done excellently.
No matter what our views on a whole lot of things are, tonight is a sad night. It is an important night and a different night. But essentially it is a sad night.

There is no-one in this House who does not wish you well in the future. There is no-one in this House who does not hope that you and your family will have a Christmas that you can enjoy and there is no-one in this House who does not hope that you will be able to serve Australia and do the things you want to do for the future of Australia, for the future of all of us. So, on behalf of all of us, could I just say thank you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, three cheers for Bob and Hazel Hawke. Hip, hip!

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hooray!

TALK.START.PARA: —Hip, hip!

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hooray!

TALK.START.PARA: —Hip, hip!

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hooray!

TALK.START.PARA: —Without any further ado, I will put the question that the motion be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) agreed to:
That leave of absence be given to every member of the House of Representatives:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1) from the determination of this sitting of the House to the date of its next sitting; and
(2) if the House sits on 2 January 1992, from the determination of that sitting to the date of its next sitting.

DEBATE.TITLE: TEXTILES, CLOTHING AND FOOTWEAR DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The infrastructure support program is designed to provide assistance in areas such as research and development, skills and training, marketing and management services where such assistance is currently not provided under other Government programs. The revised TCF Industries Development Strategy will now comprise four main programs:

SPEECH.PARA: .the incentives for international competitiveness program;
.the infrastructure support program;
.the capitalisation grants program; and
.the import credit scheme.

Other legislation covers the last two programs. In the March industry statement commitment was made to the continued provision of up to $120m through the IDS over the period until 30 June 1995. At the same time the decision was made to increase the annual allocation for the incentives for international competitiveness and infrastructure programs from $10m to $15m and to allow the Authority to roll over funds not spent in any one year to the following year.

PARA.TAB: These programs will assist TCF firms to respond positively to greater import competition. As protection falls, firms will need to review their competitive strategies to focus less on price and more on design, quality and service. Firms may find it necessary to invest in new technologies and processes to be able to provide superior products and services. As a result the industry will require a better trained and more highly skilled work force.

The revised industries development strategy will enable the Authority to help the TCF industries adapt to a new environment of relatively low protection. The challenge will be for firms to either succeed in export markets or to develop niche markets domestically. At the end of the decade, Australia can expect to have smaller but more dynamic TCF industries which will be viable with low levels of community support.

The amendments to the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Act 1988 have no financial implications beyond those already announced as part of the Government's 12 March 1991 statement. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. M.J.R. MacKellar)—Order! I understand that it is necessary for leave to be granted for the debate to be continued.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say just at the outset that, agree or disagree, it is a fine thing to see an eminent—

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. This is the third occasion tonight on which I have tried to point out to the House that this is an absolute farce. The Prime Minister has just announced that he has resigned. How can we possibly continue to sit to deliberate on significant and sensitive legislation in a climate where there is no Prime Minister. The House has just farewelled the Prime Minister. This legislation is not a matter which I would suggest we can pursue until the new Prime Minister has been accepted by the Governor-General.
—Order! The right honourable gentleman will resume his seat. The point of order was raised earlier in the day and it was ruled out of order, and I continue that ruling.
—It was not ruled out of order, you know.
—It may not have been, but it has been now.
—Prime Minister or no Prime Minister, it is a fine thing to see an eminent Australian leave that position of Prime Minister of Australia with great dignity and typical Australian courage.

PARA.TAB: This Bill proposes to consolidate a number of existing textiles, clothing and footwear restructuring assistance programs. We will not be opposing the Bill and, in the interests of members of this House, we will not be taking very long about speaking to it. Of course, the Bill is of minor importance in the greater scheme of things, but I must say just a few things about it.

Yesterday, the survey by the Australian Chamber of Manufactures predicted that unemployment would be at 11 per cent by Easter, and even that alarming prospect could be optimistic as thousands of school leavers flood onto the job market which has not many jobs to offer.

The textiles, clothing and footwear industry has not escaped this holocaust. Indeed, 20,000 TCF jobs have been lost in the last two years, with, of course, most jobs going in the footwear and clothing industries. In fact, the only manufacturing industry to fare worse is the transport industry.

In view of this scenario, a Bill which rearranges a few grants schemes worth a few million dollars is not a great substitute for a comprehensive taxation reform which, for example, takes $20 billion off business taxes, which reforms government, which reforms transport and makes for leaner government sectors and more responsible macro-economic policies. In short, it is a poor substitute for the Fightback package.

No-one disputes that the TCF industries have a massive restructuring process ahead of them. Their protection levels have come down somewhat, but they remain very high—far higher than the average for manufacturing industry. But, in our view, the necessarily limiting cash grants will not provide the basis for tackling this task, for a number of reasons that are known to many people in this chamber.

As I said, in the interests of time, I will be brief. This Bill proposes to consolidate the existing programs into two: the incentives for international competitiveness program, which will provide companies with specific assistance; and the broader infrastructure support program. These two programs will to some extent make slightly more efficient the arrangements, and the infrastructure support program is designed to provide assistance in areas such as research and development, skills and training and marketing and management services.

In our view, the consolidation of these programs should simplify the eligibility criteria, and to some extent simplify the whole process. As I said at the outset, the coalition will not oppose this Bill, but it cannot be emphasised enough that, unless the Government acts immediately to give leadership and a sense of direction and implements policies that provide a competitive climate where industry can match and beat international competition, the TCF industries—nor any other industry for that matter—will not have a future in this country. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Bill is indicative of the Government's failure to deliver a climate conducive to restructuring and long-term growth of the textile, clothing and footwear industries, in particular because it:

PARA.TAB: (1)fails to address the excessive tax burden on the industries;
(2)ignores the urgent need for industrial relations reform to promote genuine enterprise bargaining; and

(3)fails to deliver the generational changes in policies, attitudes and leadership which are needed to make Australian industry internationally competitive, as proposed in the Coalition's FIGHTBACK! program".
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Free) read a third time.
Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I take pleasure in introducing the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1991 to the House. The amendments provided for in this Bill are necessary to accommodate certain changes to the drug approval process which were recommended by Professor Peter Baume in his Report on the Future of Drug Evaluation in Australia and which were subsequently accepted by the Government for early introduction.

PARA.TAB: The principal thrust of these reforms is to give greater recognition to the need for early access by the Australian community to new drugs, provided of course that due attention is still paid to their safety, quality and efficacy. Thus one of the amendments is to the objects of the Therapeutic Goods Act to provide specific reference to the pursuit of timely availability.

Following the introduction of certain changes to both application requirements and to the evaluation process, it is intended to introduce certain target times for the processing of applications, with a financial penalty on Government in instances where those targets are not met. It is necessary to amend the Act to provide for the formal adoption of targets specifically recommended by Professor Baume.

Reducing the amount of information which is required in support of a marketing application means that greater responsibility rests with industry to report accurately and fairly on the various studies and trials which have been conducted and, where considered necessary, to provide ready access to supporting data. Professor Baume deemed it appropriate, and the Government has accepted, that companies should be penalised should they fail to honour this greater trust.

Another important aspect of the proposed reforms relates to access to unapproved drugs. In the case of patients who are seriously ill with a life-threatening disease it is proposed to leave the use of unapproved products to the patient and his or her practitioner to determine. In other cases, the limitations on access are to be reduced. It is also intended to more widely delegate the authority for approving the supply of unapproved drugs. A number of amendments have been necessary to accommodate these changes.

It is intended that companies should be able to make, without prior approval, certain changes to the information provided to doctors concerning a drug. These are safety related changes, where it is important that the company make the changes as quickly as possible. Amendment to the registration procedures is sought for this purpose.

Apart from the changes made to accommodate Professor Baume's recommendations, a further amendment has been included in this Bill. This relates to certain labelling requirements presently applying to registrable therapeutic goods that are intended for export only. The Bill removes the need for sponsors of such goods to comply with labelling requirements that have relevance only for the Australian market.
I commend this Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have been easier to address the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill if I had had a copy of the amendments or the changes to the amendments. My record in terms of the Therapeutic Goods Administration is well known. In Hansard on several occasions I have been very critical of the Therapeutic Goods Administration. We have been very supportive of the report by Professor Peter Baume, a former member of the Senate. His main aim was to improve access to drugs, pharmaceuticals, and yet maintain the provisions for protecting the public from inappropriate, ineffective or dangerous drugs.

PARA.TAB: In the past the emphasis from the bureaucracy has been very much on protecting Australians from new drugs that have not been thoroughly evaluated. That is something which we support, of course, except that the evaluations which have been required have been, I think it is fair to say, over the top. The documentation that has been required has been excessive. Only last week I found out about a drug for which the amount of documentation required by the TGA for the application was in the order of 86 volumes. Most of that documentation had been evaluated in at least five, if not six or seven, overseas countries. That product is available in almost every Western country.

What is happening is a duplication of a number of processes carried out overseas. We have said—and Professor Baume has also endorsed it—that the process is too slow, partly because of this approach. We should accept part of the evaluation processes done overseas. I was delighted to see in the report that the thrust of Peter Baume's comments was exactly this.

One of the problems has been that the Therapeutic Goods Administration has been very much a bureaucrat orientated monolith. It has not been very effective, it has been very slow, it has been cumbersome and it has been unable to respond to the needs of the Australian public. A number of products have just not been made available at the time when they should have been. The suffering which has occurred as a result of this has been very real indeed.

A number of drugs spring to mind. Recently erythropoietin has become available. It has taken an inordinate length of time to get erythropoietin available. The drug is not only effective in restoring the health of patients but is a cost-effective drug. The processes that have been used in drug evaluation have not saved the Government any money; indeed, they have probably cost money by keeping people in hospital or making it necessary for them to be re-admitted to hospital at times when that was unnecessary—for example, to have unnecessary blood transfusions, and being therefore kept out of the work force. The unavailability of erythropoietin has been a disaster for Australia—fortunately one that, in the last few months, has largely been corrected.

Somatonorm and other growth hormones took an inordinate length of time to come to Australia. A number of anti-cancer drugs which I was involved with in my previous career as an oncologist were not available in Australia at times when they were available overseas—and, indeed, were curing patients overseas. One particular drug, cis-platinum, was actually curing young men with multiple metastatic testicular cancer at a time when people in Australia were dying who might otherwise have been saved.

An anti-rejection drug, cyclosporin, was much slower to come to Australia than to most other overseas countries. We have the current problem with deprenyl and the recent nonsense with benemid, which is made in Australia and exported to New Zealand. There was a problem with a particular batch of benemid in Australia, so the TGA said that, contrary to requests from the company involved, we could not use the New Zealand batch; however, if people went to New Zealand and brought the New Zealand batch back into Australia, they were allowed to use it. That is real Sir Humphrey stuff.

There are still problems. This Bill has been considered by the Senate and three amendments were recommended. I have had no indication as to whether the Government will accept those. We will assess those in the committee stage. They related partly to the timeliness which Peter Baume, in his report, emphasised as being so important. We gave this equal weight and there was an amendment to make sure that timeliness was taken into consideration in the evaluation process.

We also wanted to ensure that the retrospectivity of some of the penalties and some of the other aspects of the legislation were restricted. It was obviously inappropriate to put retrospective conditions on drugs which were already going through the evaluation process. We wanted to ensure that the regulations were changed. Under the new special access scheme, where drugs were imported by an individual, it would have been possible, for example, for an individual to import a 12-month supply of a drug, use some himself and sell the rest. Clearly, that was not the intention of the legislation. I understand the Government has agreed to introduce in the regulations measures to prevent this from happening by ensuring that the control of the dispensing of the product remains with the doctor in question.

There are a number of problems. However, the amendments—which I trust the Government has not altered since the Senate considered them—will correct some of the problems. The legislation is long overdue. Whether it will actually work—whether the Therapeutic Goods Administration will actually work—will depend very largely upon its new chief, Professor Geoffrey Vaughan. I would like to take this opportunity of congratulating him on his recent appointment. I wish him well and I look forward to working with him in implementing an efficient administration to evaluate drugs not only in a protective way, to make sure that Australians are protected from irrelevant, inappropriate or dangerous drugs, but also, more importantly, so that useful, worthwhile drugs are allowed to come into Australia at an appropriate time and over an appropriate time scale. With those things in mind, I am happy to support the legislation as discussed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Humphreys) read a third time.
Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill proposes amendments to the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988, the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989, the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976, the Navigation Act 1912, the Pipeline Authority Act 1973 and the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991.

PARA.TAB: The provisions of the Bill are explained in detail in the accompanying explanatory memorandum. I will, therefore, confine my comments to the broad thrust of the amendments.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988

PARA.TAB: The amendments to the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988, known as the CERC Act, are contained in part 2 of the Bill.

The Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees, which operates as Comcare, was established under the CERC Act in December 1988 to effectively manage the Commonwealth public sector workers compensation function. The legislation introduced income-related benefits and emphasised the Commission's role in the prevention of workplace injury and disease through improved occupational health and safety practices and the rehabilitation of injured workers.

The amendments implement changes based on a recent review of the Comcare program. The review was conducted by Mr Ron Brown, a management consultant. He was commissioned in December 1990 to carry out a comprehensive review of the Comcare program, including the self administrators.

Comcare provides the full workers compensation insurance function to around 250 Commonwealth public sector agencies. Australia Post and Telecom, however, have been operating as `self administrators' on a two year trial. Under the self administration arrangements, these two organisations are responsible for all aspects of the administration of the CERC Act in relation to their own staff. The review was asked to consider the effectiveness of the Comcare scheme and any policy and legislative changes needed to better achieve the Government's objectives. The review acknowledged the success of improvements in workers compensation arrangements and policy achieved by the Commission since its establishment. Nevertheless, it targeted additional areas where effectiveness could be enhanced. In particular, the Commission is to be restructured to separate its regulatory and service functions.

Under the new provisions, the restructured Commission will be a tripartite body responsible for regulatory functions associated with the CERC Act, including determining and setting premiums, occupational health and safety and licensing of compensation self administrators. A new statutory body to be called Comcare is to be established, with responsibility for commercial and service functions under the Act.

The amendments create a new position of Chief Executive Officer of Comcare. The Chief Executive Officer is to be a member of the new Commission and to have responsibility for all functions under the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991 and the CERC Act, other than those performed by the Commission. The new Commission and the Chief Executive Officer of Comcare will be subject to ministerial direction and will be required to prepare annual reports.

The majority of the amendments made in this part of the Bill provide for the separation of the powers and functions of the current Commission between the new Commission and the new body to be known as Comcare. The Bill also provides for the transition from the current legislative scheme, to that which will result from the amendments, to ensure an orderly changeover. A number of other consequential changes are also made.

The amendments made to the CERC Act were the cause of some concern at the time the Bill was considered in the Senate. In order to clarify the position the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) tabled a statement further outlining the changes made to the Act by the Bill and indicating the Government's intention to introduce legislation in the autumn sitting 1992 to implement other recommendations of the Brown review, particularly in relation to licensing of self administrators. Some concerns were expressed during the debate in the Senate about the operations of the self administrators and the Minister's statement proposes an approach for dealing with these concerns in advance of that legislation.

The statement also expands on other areas of Comcare's activities which the Government intends to further consider, such as diversification of Comcare's market base outside the Commonwealth public sector, commercialisation of Comcare and a special redemptions arrangement for some beneficiaries.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989

PARA.TAB: The amendments to the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989 are contained in part 3 of the Bill and are designed to assist industry in the development and the use of chemicals and are therefore consistent with the Government's policy of enhancing industry development.The Act establishes the national industrial chemical notification and assessment scheme. The scheme requires that importers and manufacturers of new industrial chemicals submit a package of data on the chemical to Worksafe Australia in order that the chemical can be assessed before its introduction into Australia.

The Bill amends the Act to allow for a joint application to be made for an assessment certificate in relation to a new industrial chemical. Currently, the Act does not allow a joint application by two or more persons for an assessment certificate in relation to the importation and use of the same new industrial chemical. Where two or more persons wish to have the same chemical assessed, the Act currently requires separate applications to be submitted to the Director of Industrial Chemicals and the required information to be supplied by all applicants. This results in overlap in the information provided to the Director. It has also inhibited cooperation between applicants, usually companies, in the manufacture and use of industrial chemicals. The practice also leads to unnecessary duplication and inefficiency in the chemicals industry.

The major amendment, at clause 29 of the Bill, will allow two or more persons, manufacturing or importing the same new industrial chemical, to make a joint application for assessment of that chemical. The other clauses in part 3 of the Bill are consequential upon introducing a legislative scheme that allows for a joint application for assessment. For example, the amendments made by clause 31 of the Bill provides for each party to a joint assessment to be issued with an assessment certificate. Other amendments made in part 3 of the Bill are of a minor, consequential or technical nature.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976

PARA.TAB: The amendments to the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976, which makes provision for long service leave for Commonwealth employees, are contained in part 4 of the Bill.

The amendment in clause 36 of the Bill will enable regulations to be made under the Act to provide that certain categories of payments are excluded from `salary' for the purposes of calculating long service leave entitlements. In addition, the regulations shall be able to provide the extent and circumstances in which payments in those categories are excluded from `salary' for the purposes of the Act. Currently, regulations may only be made to prescribe those payments which are to be included as `salary' for long service leave purposes.

The proposed amendments to the Navigation Act, which are in part 5 of the Bill, arise out of the Government's initiative to increase the number of conventions of the International Labour Organisation ratified by Australia. As a general rule Australia does not ratify a convention until law and practice in all relevant jurisdictions complies with the requirements of the convention. The proposed amendments are intended to achieve compliance with two maritime conventions, thus enabling them to be ratified. The conventions are: the Accommodation of Crews Convention (Revised), 1949 (No. 92); and the Accommodation of Crews (Supplementary Provisions) Convention, 1970.

Each of the conventions is regarded as appropriate for ratification once compliance has been achieved. Although there is substantial compliance in practice, some States and the Northern Territory do not have legislation giving effect to the conventions. The two conventions apply to seagoing ships. Most seagoing ships in Australian waters are engaged in interstate or overseas voyages and therefore come within the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth and are, therefore, covered by the Navigation Act. A small number of seagoing ships, however, come within the jurisdiction of a State or the Northern Territory.

The proposed amendments, which have been developed in consultation with the States and the Northern Territory, will enable regulations and orders to be made under the Navigation Act to give effect to the conventions in respect of all seagoing ships in Australian waters. These orders and regulations will not, however, apply where any existing or future law of a State or of the Northern Territory gives effect to the conventions. This will ensure that the conventions are applied to all seagoing ships in Australian waters, while preserving the jurisdiction of the States and the Northern Territory in respect of the matters covered by the conventions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Pipeline Authority Act 1973

PARA.TAB: The amendments to the Pipeline Authority Act 1973 are contained in part 6 of the Bill. The Pipeline Authority Act establishes the Pipeline Authority which is the body charged with the function of constructing pipelines for the conveyance of petroleum to cities.

The proposed amendments to the Act are minor and correct an amendment made by the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Act 1991 Act No. 122 of 1991. An amendment made to the Pipeline Authority Act by that Act was not in accordance with the Government's intention that the Pipeline Authority be able to grant part time members leave to be absent from meetings of the Authority. The amendment proposed in clause 41 of the Bill gives effect to that intention. The Minister retains the discretion to grant a full time member of the Authority leave of absence.
I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few brief remarks regarding the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 which will be particularly cogent. I will not overly attempt to take the time of the House at this most difficult time considering the late hour that we are likely to be sitting. It must be pointed out to the Government that the most important amendments in this Bill are those relating to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988—the Comcare enabling Act. These amendments are based on Mr Ron Brown's review, commissioned last December, completed and handed to the Government in April, and published but not tabled in September. This is a quick Government, is it not? This rather inept, failed Labor Government is like most of the bureaucracy it is associated with—it is slow.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has proposed a second reading amendment. We are critical of the non-response of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) in his very offhanded second reading speech. After not tabling the report, he picked up only one recommendation, which was to split the Commission, and he ignored the other recommendations. He did not really address the content of the report. We believe that Comcare should be privatised. In that respect, despite the lateness of the hour, we should briefly examine the very major difference between the Government and the Opposition with respect to industrial relations.

It is my view—it may not be shared by all in the House—that the most major issue we address in this nation that is holding us back from real, progressive movement in terms of productivity, change, and providing new jobs and new opportunities is related to the industrial relations portfolio. Those changes are about to come. Those differences in the Government of Bob Hawke, the Government of Paul Keating and the Government to be of John Hewson are significant because in 1976 the Liberal and National parties finally made a decision, after decades of equivocation, to come down in favour of massive change in terms of our centralised, bureaucratic, inefficient, old-fashioned, irrelevant industrial relations system. The changes that the coalition proposed in 1976 are as relevant today as they were then, and they will be implemented in 1993 or before when there is an election and we have a Hewson government.

For those opposite who do not understand what we propose, those changes are that we will allow individuals—that is, employees and employers—to decide for themselves in the marketplace what sort of agreement they will come to, their wages, long service leave, how much holiday pay they will receive, and the wages applicable before dismissal. All the items that are appropriate to employer and employee negotiations will come before the employer and the employee. That means that the Industrial Relations Commission, the centralised system, the club, which includes major employer associations, the ACTU, and the major union players in Australia will be out of a job—done, finished. In fact, we will increase unemployment in Australia because we are going to get rid of a very major part of the industrial relations club that has for so long held this country back and has for so long caused us problems in many areas, including training, which is a major issue today!

The Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, of which I am the Deputy Chairman, released a report in the House today entitled Skills training for the twenty-first century: a report on skills training apprenticeships and traineeships. One of the things we said in that report is that the rigidities and demarcations that exist within the industrial relations system today in this country must cease in terms of employee training or we will not have any employees next year or the year after that. Why? Those opposite know, as I do, that no apprentices are being taken on by industry. Why not? The reason is that the economy is in recession. We have not encouraged industry to employ new trainees and we have not empowered TAFE to teach people a trade or a vocation without first having a contract of employment with their employer.

We still believe in the master-slave relationship of apprenticeship which was appropriate in the 1700s and maybe the 1800s, but certainly not in the 1900s or beyond the year 2000. We have very major differences with the Government, with the new Government and with the new Prime Minister in terms of industrial relations policy. That will ultimately prove to be the test between us and those opposite who claim to represent, firstly, the average worker and, secondly, the working class of Australia.

It is my contention that today we represent the workers in Australia. We offer workers in Australia not only hope but vision, improved financial reward and the opportunity to cooperate with their employer in a cooperative venture to manufacture profits from which they will benefit. It is important, despite the empty House, that we consider this major difference between the Labor Party and the coalition because it is not a goods and services tax or a taxation reform package that divides us so significantly. Government members wanted a GST. They would be delighted to get rid of employment taxes and would be happy if they could get rid of the blessed fuel excise and were able to rationalise taxes with respect to road transport. So they agree with us in that respect. There is no problem there. We disagree because those opposite are controlled and subsumed by the union movement and the ACTU, which control the agenda of those opposite.

A long time ago when the Labor Party thought about changing the taxation system, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), who is to be our new Prime Minister, thought it was a good idea. Bob Hawke thought it was a good idea and everybody on the other side of politics thought it was a good idea, except the ACTU. The ACTU said, `No, boys. Forget that one. Bye, bye'—and that was the end of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the girls.

—I forgot the girls. The ACTU said, `Boys and girls, no, no, no. We are not going to have anything to do with a goods and services tax'. So Bob Hawke rolled over, Paul Keating rolled over and they all rolled over. They lay down and that was the end of the ball game, because the ACTU and the union side of the labour movement control the agenda on the Government side of politics. Until we fix that problem in this country, until we allow individuals the right to negotiate their own conditions of employment, their own wages and their own circumstances, we have no hope of competing in the twentieth, much less the twenty-first, century.

PARA.TAB: Only minor amendments to this Bill from our side of the House and from the Democrats were accepted. One of the amendments was for withdrawal of the clause enabling compliance with an ILO maritime convention, which was opposed by the Northern Territory Government. We can live with that. There are many parts of the statement which were included at our request and which commit the Minister to certain assurances about this Bill in relation to later consideration of the Brown report.

I specifically note that the Minister, in his ministerial statement, on behalf of the Government, recognises the merits of commercialisation. That is important, because the Government has accepted that commercialism is critical. My side of politics thinks that Comcare should be commercialised. The Government is not quite there, but it is getting close. In this legislation, the Government introduced a series of changes to the operation of Comcare, the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees. Specifically, one of the most important aspects of that is that the Government proposes the separation of the chairperson from the CEO position. It proposes self-administration, and the Bill empowers the Commission to ensure that as far as practical there is no inconsistency in the administration practices and procedures used by Comcare and the self-administering procedures and authorities in the performance of their respective functions.

The Government itself is saying to us, `We ought to privatise Comcare. It ought to be in the hands of private providers. We ought to have a commercial operation with respect to this Government provision'. In terms of priority, the Minister said that he was going to ask the Commission to develop guidelines for, for instance, time limits for determinations and review—that is pretty significant—and procedures for review of disputed claims. We certainly should have those, or else we will wind up, as with any normal bureaucratic procedure, with no opportunity for those who feel disadvantaged to complain. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Because of some remaining confusion about the status of decisions and recommendations made by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal I will also ask the Commission to consider this issue as a matter of urgency.
The Commission has not, and we condemn the Government and the Commission in that respect. On the subject of redemptions, the Minister went on to talk about the Brown review. He said:

The Government recognises the need to consider the special circumstances of those claimants who have been most adversely affected by these arrangements, taking into account questions of equity. Therefore, we will consider, in the context of the 1992/93 Budget, a proposal for a special redemptions arrangement having regard to all factors including equity consideration.

We have yet to see those and we are unaware of the extent of the significance of those issues. When this issue was debated in the Senate yesterday a number of items were brought up which I think are significant and worth repeating in this House.

PARA.TAB: I believe the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) sought an adjournment of debate in order to engage in discussions and negotiations with the Liberal Party and the Democrats with respect to our concerns. Here we are at the twelfth hour. It is now 17 minutes past 12 o'clock on Thursday night and we are still debating an issue which the Minister should have completely sorted out before he brought it to the Senate, much less to this House, and we are rushing it through —even though we do not know whether a Prime Minister exists.

In the Senate last night Senator Chapman said that he welcomed the Minister's statement, which spelt out in much greater detail the intent of the Government with regard to the Brown report and to future legislation which the Minister has promised to introduce in the autumn session of Parliament. In the spirit of cooperation that our side of politics has tried to adopt with respect to the other side of politics in the last few days, and in discussions and negotiations with the Minister, Senator Chapman proposed in good faith that in the autumn session further legislation will be introduced and will proceed further down the track of implementing the Brown recommendations. I will hold the Minister at the table to that. From our side of the House this is an agreed statement. We accept the Minister's statement that he will further consult with us and that he will bring down further legislation which will be agreed between our side of politics and the Government.

The hour is late, but I cannot in all conscience conclude without saying that the most major difference between those opposite and our side of politics is industrial relations. It is an issue which will not go away; it is an issue which we will discuss time and time again in this place, because it is an issue which is at the heart of real reform of our economy, of real reform of operations in industry, of an opportunity to expand industrial operations in Australia and stop the regression which is occurring at present. We are not opposing this Bill, but with these few words I ask you, Madam Deputy Speaker, to ask the Government, with its new Prime Minister, to consider in all good faith the adoption of our recommendations for voluntary union membership, for the end of the closed shop and for true enterprise agreements in the Australian industrial context.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Tickner) read a third time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —In the early hours of 29 November, after reporting a message from the Senate returning the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4), the Deputy Speaker made a statement drawing to the attention of the House the question of whether the Senate was in fact able to amend the Bill in the way it proposed to do or whether the matter should have been dealt with by way of request.

PARA.TAB: I have now had an opportunity to study this matter in some detail. I have concluded that the concerns reported by the Deputy Speaker were indeed well founded. The third paragraph of section 53 of the Constitution states:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.

By amendment No. 8 to the Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 4), the Senate sought to extend eligibility for Job Search and Newstart allowances to certain farmers, subject to a number of conditions—which were set out in detail in the amendment. Payments for Job Search and Newstart allowances are funded from special appropriations and the effect of extending eligibility to another group of persons—although subject to conditions—is, in my view, to increase the charge or burden on the people.

PARA.TAB: The Hansard record suggests that those senators who spoke on this matter believed that they were considering an extension of monetary benefits to a group of persons not previously eligible for those benefits. The supplementary explanatory memorandum presented earlier in connection with the Government's proposed amendments supports this view; it contains an estimate that the financial impact of the amendments would be $11.7m in 1991-92 and $20m in 1992-93.

As is mentioned in House of Representatives Practice at page 445, difficult questions of interpretation can arise on the issue of the Senate's right to amend Bills. At one extreme almost every amendment could be seen as causing some degree of charge or burden on the people, whilst at the other extreme it could be argued that an amendment can be made by the Senate unless it can be proved as a matter of strict logic that it explicitly and necessarily causes an increased charge or burden.

Neither of these positions is appropriate. The better approach when such an issue arises is rather to ask what are the practical consequences of a proposed amendment. In terms of Senate amendment No. 8 to the Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 4), the answer to this question must surely be that there will be an increased charge or burden on the people. Had the amendment been initiated in this House, it seems certain that, if a Governor-General's message recommending appropriation had not been supplied, the requirement for it would have been recognised.

The First Parliamentary Counsel has advised that he agrees with the conclusion reached by the department in this matter. I add, however, that the Clerk of the Senate has contested the arguments of the First Parliamentary Counsel. It is naturally for the House itself to consider such matters, and not for me as Speaker. I believe my role is limited to bringing such issues to the notice of members—and it is an important issue. The Clerk will, however, ensure that messages from the Senate returning Bills with amendments are examined to ensure that the interests of the House are protected. For the information of honourable members, I present a copy of a note prepared in the Department of the House of Representatives on this issue. The Acting Deputy Clerk has a copy of the note.
Motion (by Mr Tickner)—by leave—proposed:
That the House endorses the statement of Mr Speaker concerning the Senate's action in respect of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, the Opposition supports the motion moved by the Government endorsing the content of your statement and the views that you have expressed. I was in the House in the early hours of 29 November when this Bill was being discussed and it occurred to me at the time that the Senate had possibly, in a technical sense, exceeded its powers. But I thought at the time that the decision to proceed was a commonsense decision and, therefore, I raised no objection.

PARA.TAB: As you, Mr Speaker, have pointed out, the third paragraph of section 53 of the Constitution states—and I quote again:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.

Because certain farmers were urgently in need of the assistance that was to be provided, I thought that the decision at the time to proceed was a commonsense decision—and I compliment you and the Clerks and others who might have been involved in preparing the information for the House for presenting it in the way that it has been presented this evening. It does clear the record and states categorically, with the support of both sides of Parliament, what the position is.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I take great pleasure in introducing to the House the National Road Transport Commission Bill 1991 at 27 past 12 on this rather momentous day of the parliamentary sittings. The Bill will establish a National Road Transport Commission and bring into effect the inter-governmental agreement, which was signed on 30 July 1991 by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the heads of government of all the States and the Australian Capital Territory.

PARA.TAB: The Bill provides for the Commission to be responsible for the development and recommendation of national road transport legislation and road use charges. This includes the preparation and provision of guidelines and principles of administration. The functions and powers of the Commission will be those that are set out in the inter-governmental agreement, which is included as a schedule to the Bill.

This Bill provides the administrative framework for the National Road Transport Commission. National road transport legislation will be developed by the Commission once it is established and will be introduced as separate legislation.

Under the terms of the inter-governmental agreement, national road transport legislation will be limited in its coverage to vehicles with a gross vehicle mass of more than 4.5 tonnes. Extension of the jurisdiction of the Commission to include light vehicles is currently under consideration through the Special Premiers Conference processes.

I would like to emphasise that this Bill does not in itself affect current road transport legislation or charges. It simply establishes an institutional framework for a national, co-operative approach to the development of future road transport legislation which is consistent across jurisdictions.

The Commission will be required to develop and recommend national road transport legislation and charges to a ministerial council. The ministerial council consists of Ministers representing each of the States, the Australian Capital Territory and the Commonwealth Government. Each Minister has equal representation on the council.

The Northern Territory does not have a member on the ministerial council, as it is not a signatory to the inter-governmental agreement. Although it decided not to sign the agreement, it does support the establishment of the Commission. The Northern Territory has stated that it will implement non-charging regulations which are agreed to by the ministerial council. In recognition of this commitment, the Northern Territory has been granted observer status at the ministerial council.

In discussing the contents of the Bill, I will outline the issues that will be considered by the Commission and the work that it will be undertaking. This Government is committed to a competitive and efficient transport system. Cheaper and more efficient transport means greater success in ensuring Australia's industries are more competitive.

More rational road use charges will provide the signal to improve the economic efficiency of the vehicle fleet and use and management of the road system. The road asset is one of the community's largest investments and increasing returns on this asset will provide significant, lasting benefits.

Transport has a strategic role to play in improving Australia's international trading performance. It employs around 400,000 people and contributes about 8 per cent of gross domestic product. Road transport alone accounts for about 4 per cent, or approximately half, of the transport component of national income.

More importantly, it is an intermediate service that is used by almost every industry and consumer. Virtually every product has at some point been carried by a road transport vehicle. Manufacturers rely increasingly on

SPEECH.PARA: just-in-time deliveries. The quality of the service directly affects the efficiency of the rest of the economy. Thus, any initiative that improves the performance of road transport will have a positive effect on the rest of the economy.

PARA.TAB: Transport has a pervasive influence over the efficiency of our economy and improvements in the system will have significant national benefits. The Industry Commission has estimated that a more efficient land transport system, including a more efficient rail system, alone could realise an additional $6 billion dollars in gross domestic product every year.

We have demonstrated our commitment to gaining an efficient rail sector through the establishment of the National Rail Corporation earlier this year. The National Road Transport Commission will also play a pivotal role in developing an efficient, national operating environment for road transport.

The Federal Government has been striving to improve the operating environment for the road transport industry since it came to office in 1983.
