It has achieved significant improvements in industry efficiency in recent years through the development of more uniform technical and operating standards for heavy vehicles, particularly the adoption of uniform mass and dimension limits. Most progress has been made on technical issues where the Commonwealth has the clear power to legislate.

The introduction of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 has ensured that uniform national design standards apply to all vehicles new to the Australian market. The Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 provided the Federal Government with the means to encourage the harmonisation of regulations affecting heavy vehicles. This legislation introduced the Federal interstate registration scheme for vehicles engaged solely in interstate trade. The scheme enabled the achievement of a uniform 42.5 tonne mass limit throughout Australia, which delivered major productivity gains to road transport and the Australian economy. Most recently, the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Act 1991 has allowed B-doubles to be registered under FIRS.

Previous attempts to introduce harmonisation across different regulatory and charging environments have relied on two factors: agreement being reached in the Australian Transport Advisory Council; and, on the implementation of these agreements, through policy directive and/or complementary legislative change. As ATAC is only an advisory and consultative body with no powers to require individual jurisdictions to implement agreed proposals, this process has had limited success in achieving a nationally consistent approach. Each State and Territory still has its own legislation covering the registration, regulation and charging of heavy vehicles.

What makes the Commission different from previous attempts at such a cooperative process is that it alone will develop charges and regulations for consideration by governments. The Ministerial Council will be a determinative body overseeing a streamlined legislative and regulatory process. A fundamental aim of the intergovernmental agreement is to ensure that a transparent road use charging system is developed which provides a clear link between road use and the contribution to the costs of road maintenance by the road transport industry.

Currently, there is little clear relationship between road use and damage caused by heavy vehicles and charges paid by road users. A road transport operator sees little or no direct connection between his or her use of the road and what is paid for this privilege. The intergovernmental agreement requires the introduction of a national charging structure comprising a nominal administration charge, a road use charge component of Commonwealth diesel excise and a registration or mass-distance charge for vehicles which do not meet their road costs through fuel payments alone.

The road use part of diesel excise is to be structured to avoid the imposition of mass-distance charges on most of the heavy vehicle fleet. The level of charges will be developed by the Commission based on the following principles: full recovery of all road costs while minimising over-recovery from any vehicle class;

SPEECH.PARA: a common methodology;
charges to be determined and collected in a way that achieves a reasonable balance between administrative simplicity, efficiency and equity in the charging structure;
improved pricing, leading to a better allocation of resources, with investment decisions being based on more relevant demand signals; and
minimising the incentive for operators to `shop around' for lower charges and undermining the integrity of the national charging system.

In recognition of the varying road costs in different parts of the country, two zones have been established for the purpose of charging. These zones generally reflect on the one hand the States with higher road costs, and those with lower road costs on the other.

PARA.TAB: The establishment of the National Road Transport Commission is the direct result of the resolve shown by all the States and the Commonwealth through the Special Premiers Conference to develop an efficient national structure for land transport. It will be the focal point of a more efficient and clearly defined process for gaining nationally consistent charges and regulations relating to heavy vehicles.

I now turn to the provisions of the Bill. The Bill provides for the Commission to have three part time members who will be chosen for their ability to bring an independent view and range of experience to the Commission. Each member will be appointed by the Governor-General, on the recommendation of the Ministerial Council, for a term of three years and may be reappointed only once. From the three members, one will be appointed as Chairperson of the Commission and another as Deputy Chair.

The objective of the Commission will be to facilitate improvements in road transport efficiency and road safety, and reductions in the costs of administration of road transport through a cooperative process between local government, the States, the Australian Capital Territory and the Commonwealth. The implementation of lasting reform is only possible with the cooperation of all levels of government and affected transport providers and user groups.

Part 3 of the Bill sets out the functions and powers which will enable the Commission to achieve its objectives. In particular, the Commission will have those functions and powers that are conferred upon it in the intergovernmental agreement. The Commission will exercise responsibility for the development of road transport legislation and for overseeing its administration by the States and the Australian Capital Territory.

The key aspect of the work of the National Road Transport Commission will be the development and recommendation of road use charges. The Commission will be required to report on or provide advice to the Ministerial Council on any matter relating to its powers and functions.

While there is clear emphasis on the accountability of the Commission to governments through the Ministerial Council, the Commission will be reflecting the broader interests of the community. To assist it in discharging its responsibilities in this regard, the Commission will consult widely with interested parties, including the road transport industry, industry in general, and the people and government organisations from rural and remote regions. It may also appoint committees to assist it in discharging its duties under the terms of this legislation. These committees will have such membership as the Commission considers appropriate.

I now turn to the administrative provisions of the Bill. This part of the Bill sets out the conditions relating to members of the Commission. It also establishes the basic meeting procedures for the Commission and provides for disclosure of interest by individual members.

The staffing provisions will enable the staff of the Commission to reflect the Commission's national character. The Commission will be able to employ staff, within the limits of its budget, from the public and private sectors. A chief executive officer will be appointed by the Commission to manage the operations of the NRTC according to the directions and policies determined by the Commission. Staff may also be employed through secondment arrangements with Commonwealth, State or Territory administrations.

Under the finance provisions of this Bill, the Commission will receive funding from the Commonwealth, the States and the Australian Capital Territory. The funding share of each Government will be determined by the Ministerial Council as set out in the intergovernmental agreement.

The establishment and running costs of the National Road Transport Commission will be jointly funded by the Commonwealth and the States and Territories party to the intergovernmental agreement. At the first Ministerial Council meeting it was agreed that the Commonwealth would contribute a 35 per cent fixed share of costs with the remainder being shared by the States and Territories based on heavy vehicle registrations. It is anticipated that the Commission's annual budget will total $3m to $4m. The Commonwealth has included a provision of $1m in this year's Budget as its contribution to the establishment and maintenance of the Commission in 1991-92.

I now turn to the final, miscellaneous provisions of the Bill. In regard to the powers and functions of the Ministerial Council, the Ministerial Council may delegate any or all of these to any one or more of its members. Such delegation must be made through a unanimous decision by the members of the Ministerial Council.

The legislation will cease to be in force after six years. At least six months prior to this, the Commission is required to make a recommendation to the Ministerial Council as to whether the legislation should be re-enacted. This follows the procedure established in the intergovernmental agreement. All members of the Ministerial Council and the Australian Local Government Association have considered the Bill and agree that it reflects the letter and spirit of the intergovernmental agreement.

The establishment of the Commission will reduce duplication of work between the States and the Commonwealth. It will also ensure that all governments will be working from a common perspective. No longer will we be in the situation where nine different bureaucracies are working to develop nine different sets of regulations affecting road transport. For the first time we will have nationally consistent regulations governing heavy vehicles. This is a significant achievement and is a clear demonstration of the maturity of Australia as a nation. It reflects great credit on the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), who is in the chamber tonight. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for entering into an agreement with the States which is flawed in that it fails to provide for:

PARA.TAB: (1)a thorough review of all inputs taxes and charges paid by the road transport industry; and
(2)an investigation of the current level of efficiency of road construction and maintenance practices;

SPEECH.PARA: and notes that the Senate may act to rectify these omissions by referring the issue to a Senate Standing Committee for inquiry and report".

I am appalled at the way the Government has handled the National Road Transport Commission Bill. Quite contrary to the words of the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), who introduced this Bill, the fact is that the Minister, who is now present and sitting at the table, has been totally disorganised. He could not even get it into this chamber in time for the matter to be debated here first, so it was rushed into the Senate and now we are trying to debate it in the dying hours of this final session of the Parliament for 1991.

PARA.TAB: Clearly the debate is being curtailed because of the late hour and because the Government is trying to rush through so much legislation at such short notice. I think it is an appalling abuse of the Parliament. It is an insult to the Parliament. It shows the level of interest the present Government and its Ministers have in true parliamentary democracy. It is an important piece of legislation, and I think it is appalling that so many members of this chamber who may have wished to make a contribution now feel, because of this very late hour, that they will be restrained from doing so.

When listening to the second reading speech I must admit I thought that this must have been another piece of legislation. Some of the comments in that speech really did not reflect the thrust of this legislation or the effect that this legislation will have on the road transport industry. In the brief time I will speak tonight, I will take up some of the key points I noticed in the Minister's second reading speech which really ought to be refuted.

The Minister spoke about getting cheaper and more efficient transport; yet he notes that this Bill is restricted to vehicles heavier than 4 1/2 tonnes. Anyone who has studied this matter knows that this Bill is about increasing the charges on heavy vehicles. The Government has failed to get any agreement from the States. Although in fact it made reference to the Special Premiers Conference, I think all honourable members would be aware that the last Special Premiers Conference failed dismally. In fact, it fell into a heap because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) no longer held the respect of the Premiers. Maybe the Government has taken some steps to change that situation today, but we will not deal with that now.

Talking about this Bill leading to cheaper and more efficient transport is a joke. It is all about increasing the cost to road transport operators. Certainly that will not lead to cheaper and more efficient transport. This matter has been drawn to the attention of this Government on many occasions—in the Senate, in the special inquiry that the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure held last Wednesday, and on numerous occasions in many public forums. The Minister is well aware of this. Yet he goes on and on talking about how he consults with industry. He seems to take no notice of the concerns that the industry raises.

Another matter referred to in the second reading speech was the establishment of the National Rail Corporation. It was spoken of as though that was done earlier this year. As the Minister is well aware, the legislation for the establishment of the National Rail Corporation has not passed through this Parliament and it is unlikely to pass through the Parliament this year. So much for the so-called improvements the Minister spoke about.

The Minister talked about the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 which is designed to encourage the harmonisation of regulations affecting heavy vehicles. If one talks with some of the operators who face the problems as they travel from State to State one finds there is not too much harmonisation.

The Minister talked about the Interstate Road Transport Act allowing B-doubles to be registered under the Federal interstate registration scheme. Whilst that is partly true, it is equally true that the Labor Government in Tasmania has not allowed B-doubles to be introduced into Tasmania.

The Minister said that a fundamental aim of the intergovernmental agreement is to ensure that a transparent road use charging system is developed which will create a clear link between road use and the contribution to the cost of road maintenance. A continuing objection the coalition has put to the Government, and one which road users have put to the Government, is that the Government continues to ignore the level of taxation on the road transport industry. Yet this Minister at the table, the Minister for Land Transport, had the gall, back in May, to say to the National Farmers Federation that he agreed that the road transport industry was taxed at 3 1/2 times the rate of other industries. The Minister sits there in front of some very significant road users in this community and tells them that, yes, the road transport industry is overtaxed. Yet when he introduced this Bill he had the gall to say it would lead to a cheaper and more efficient transport system in Australia.

All I can say to the Minister is that, if he wants to do that, he should have a look at what the coalition has put forward in the Fightback package, in which we talk about real reform and the real way of getting the cost of road transport down—that is, of course, by taking the excise off fuel. I think the Minister could do a lot better if he had a look at some of the things that we are offering.

He then tries to gloss over the fact that he could not get agreement amongst the States. It was not this Minister; I should say that the Prime Minister could not get agreement—this was taken out of the hands of this Minister—and, therefore, two zones were introduced. That matter is glossed over by the Minister with the use of the words `in recognition of the varying road costs in differing parts of the country'. That was not the point. When the Minister knows full well that the reason there are two zones is entirely that the Prime Minister could not get agreement from the Premiers of those less densely populated States, I do not know how he can come in here and make a second reading speech that tries to claim otherwise.

Before I come to some of the other details of the Bill, I would like to mention quickly a couple of other points from the Minister's second reading speech. He mentioned the fact that the legislation will cease to be in force after six years but, six months prior to that, the National Road Transport Commission will be required to make a recommendation to the Ministerial Council as to whether the legislation should be re-enacted. I would like the Minister to find an example of a government body which, having been asked to review itself, does not recommend that it continue in existence irrespective of its need.

Finally, in his second reading speech, the Minister made the claim that, for the first time, we will have nationally consistent regulations governing heavy vehicles. It would be great if we had that but, unfortunately, as the Minister full well knows, this Commission is not going to be able to make that sort of recommendation because of the difficulties that have been encountered with the States. To make such a claim in the second reading speech is highly misleading.

In speaking to this Bill, I would like to say that, as it was introduced in the Senate, my coalition colleagues there have gone to considerable lengths to, first of all, expose some of its weaknesses and to highlight some of the concerns that the road transport industry and road transport users have about the shortcomings of this Bill. I do not wish to canvass all of those. I would hope that people who are particularly interested will look to the Senate debates to see the detail. I pay special tribute to my coalition colleagues in the other place who have gone to considerable lengths to try to bring some commonsense back into the debate not only through their speeches in the other place but also through the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. They were prepared to spend many hours—in fact until two o'clock last Thursday morning—to ensure that people in the industry who were prepared to come all the way to Canberra at short notice were able to draw to the Government's attention some of the shortcomings of the Bill. While the Minister still seems keen to ramrod this legislation through, I believe that the onus is on him to take account of some of those concerns.

The point is that it is not the Bill itself that is objectionable; it is the schedule that is attached to it. Basically, as I pointed out, one of the major concerns that we have is that the National Road Transport Commission has not been given wide enough powers to consider the existing level of taxation that is already on the road transport industry. This point has been brought home to the Minister time and time again. If he wanted real reform, he would have the guts to stand up to the rest of his Party and say, `If we are going to get it, we have to take this into account'. Hence, the coalition has included in the inquiry that the Senate is going to undertake that this level of taxation on the road transport industry is, in fact, investigated.

Our concern, of course, is that the Government, having done a deal with the Democrats to set up an inquiry, has pulled the wool over the eyes of the Democrats to some extent. That inquiry of the Senate is not going to be reporting until September next year, and yet, at the same time, the NRTC is expected to make its recommendations by the end of March next year. According to what Senator Collins told the Standing Committee last Wednesday night, legislation on charging is going to be introduced in the autumn session next year. In other words, the Senate Committee is going to report after the charging legislation is to be introduced.

I have a couple of other concerns that I would like to raise. Not only do we have the problem of the zonal system—meaning that we do not get the uniformity that I think all of us would like to see—but we also have the problem that any State can make an application order, which means that the standards, the enforcement levels and the penalties may not be uniform. In addition, while the Government has made a big noise about the change to the Federal interstate registration scheme, as I said earlier, we do not see the B-doubles operating under a common system throughout this country.

As the hour is getting late, I do not want to canvass all of these areas other than to say that we have these two major concerns, which I have brought up in the second reading amendment. The coalition will be moving a further amendment in the committee stage. Again, I believe that, if the Government was serious about getting reform in this area, it would be prepared to look at the level of taxation right across the road transport industry. It would be prepared to take that into account because, as the Minister full well knows, road transport is not an end industry; it is an input to other industries. If we want to get those costs down and if we want to get that efficiency that the Minister is so keen to talk about and I think all of us would like to see, clearly the Government has to get the operating costs down and take the input taxes off. As the coalition has now given the Government a lead, it would be so easy to take up the coalition's proposals because the Government knows full well it would get support in the Parliament. If it could take that up, it would see some real efficiency gains; it would see the sorts of gains which the Industry Commission has been talking about and which the Government has been so keen to mention all around this country. The Government would then get the savings to people who want to conduct business that relies so heavily on freight. Of course, people in rural and regional Australia are those who are affected the most.

This Bill is not going to achieve that. We have repeatedly drawn attention to the fact that, if we are just to increase the registration charges for heavy vehicles, it could have a very serious impact on people living in country Australia. Despite the fact that the coalition has been calling for an inquiry into this for over 12 months, it seems that only belatedly is that to be done. It is unlikely that we are going to know the full impact until after the Commission has made its recommendations for charges.

There is, of course, another concern that there is a very real risk that this Commission will become highly bureaucratised. Already there are at least 21 committees to make recommendations to the Commission. Obviously, the workload that is going to be on industry in trying to keep up with all of those committees will be extremely onerous. Obviously, it will make it very difficult for a lot of industry groups to keep abreast of what is going on with that.

In conclusion, I come back to the point that, if the Government really wants the Commission to have support amongst the industry—support that would be forthcoming—and if the Government is prepared to take up those options, it has to look at the level of taxation on the road transport industry. It also has to take up the challenge of looking at the efficiency of road construction and maintenance and it has to be prepared to investigate what the likely impact on rural and regional Australia is going to be if, in fact, increased charges are to be recommended. I do not accept the argument that has been put by some members of the Government that an impact study cannot be done until the charges are known. That is just rubbish. Anyone who wanted to go through some likely scenarios that have been put to the National Road Transport Commission would know full well, by doing a series of figures, that one could get some indicative impacts over a range of charges. It would be dead easy to find out what the impact was going to be.

The hour is late. It is a great disappointment to the coalition that this Bill has not been given the full debate that it deserves in this place. As I have said, because the Government is not prepared to take on board all of the recommendations that the coalition has made in the other place and is making again here, we have moved an amendment. We are not prepared to accept the Bill in its present form.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Dubois)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

—The contribution by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), the shadow spokesman for the Opposition on land transport, reflects, I suppose, more than any other single contribution that he has ever made in this chamber the complete inadequacy of his understanding of road transport responsibilities. I have been extremely tolerant towards him, as he will know. I have also ensured that my office would be as cooperative with him as possible. We have made information available to him. I have made available officers of the Department. I repeat: I have been extremely tolerant.

PARA.TAB: I become a little intolerant, though, towards him when he adopts what has been a juvenile, arrogant and offensive attitude in relation to a—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have had a bad day.

—The honourable member should read what he has been saying. He should look at the sorts of things that he says around the country. He talks about my going around Australia and making some of these assertions. He should look at what he has been saying. He should read some of the reports in newspapers about his comments. He should not have such a quizzical look on his face. He knows exactly what I am talking about. I have become a little intolerant.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker, the shadow Minister has shown quite clearly his incapacity to understand the issues for which he has been given responsibility. As I have indicated from time to time, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has warned him off. There has not been one occasion during Question Time this session on which any question has been directed to me by the honourable member for Wannon.

Let us have a look at some of the strange assertions that he has made. First of all, he made a claim in relation to the last Premiers Conference in Adelaide. The reality is, of course, that the Prime Minister was not there. But to say that the Premiers Conference fell into a heap simply reflects a complete lack of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, the honourable member should have a look at the decisions it made. He does not even know the decisions that it made.
—Were you there?
—Look mate, one does not have to be there to read the decisions that it made or to go through the transcript of the discussion. Was the honourable member there?
—He is very toey, isn't he.

—Of course I am toey. I am a little toey in relation to some of the absurdities that I have seen from the honourable member for Wannon. If he is not embarrassed about the inadequacy of the way in which he has been responding to those responsibilities that he has been given, he should be.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member said that all of those reforms would not lead to any greater efficiency in transport. Well, he can dispute that with me. He can choose to dispute it with the Industry Commission. I would have expected some sort of bipartisan support. The Industry Commission indicated that the reforms that have been put into place in connection with road transport will bring about a net benefit to the Australian community every year in terms of GDP of something like $1.8 billion.

The honourable member says—because he does not understand—that it will not lead to any greater efficiency. He can dispute that with the Industry Commission at his leisure and to the extent that he wishes. But I will leave it to all of those people who understand something about this to make some assessment about the adequacy and the extent to which the honourable member is able to respond.

The honourable member even again repeated the absurd assertion that he has been hawking around Australia that, as a result of adjustments in the balance of the charges between different types of road users, there will be an increase in costs to the road using industry itself. He knows that the whole approach to that question and all of the reforms that have been involved have been—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is rubbish.

—Listen for a change. They have been premised on a requirement on our part that the whole exercise be revenue neutral. As far as the whole industry is concerned, there will not be, as far as it is possible for us to achieve it, one extra dollar raised out of those reforms. The honourable member knows it. If he does not know it, I will send some material around to him so that he can start having a look at it.

PARA.TAB: There is also the question of the level of taxation on road transport. The honourable member should go back to the original Inter-State Commission report which referred to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is really incredible. I said that I really have tried to be as tolerant with the honourable member as I can and I am getting to the end of my patience. The honourable member's colleagues know the inadequacy with which he has been facing the responsibilities that the Leader of the Opposition has given him. It is all right for the honourable member to become as juvenile and as arrogant as he wishes. But he does not like it when I start to respond. As I say, I have been very patient with the honourable member. He should go back to the original Inter-State Commission report which—

—The honourable member is just as stupid as he is then. This is the part time failed suburban lawyer who masquerades around this place as a Deputy Leader of the Opposition. What gall you have, you goat!

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker, the original Inter-State Commission report which dealt with some of these issues certainly referred to the fact that as far as road transport was concerned some of those taxation imposts themselves represented something like a 3 1/2 times increase. But if we took into account as well an appropriate level of charges for the use of the road system, the Inter-State Commission report itself said that the level of taxation on road transport was not significantly greater than it was for other industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said it was.
—I recognise the fact that it was referring to the base amount of taxation, as the honourable member knows. He should not try to misrepresent it. If he did not understand that, he should have.

PARA.TAB: A more recent analysis undertaken by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics indicated, as the honourable member should know—if he does not know, he should know—that the level of taxation, when we take all of those elements into consideration, on road transport represents something like 5.6 per cent of its total costs compared with about 5.5 per cent of the industry generally.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it is quite clear then that there is a significant lack of understanding on the part of those people on the Opposition side who are charged with a specific responsibility of leading for the Opposition on these questions. While some of the honourable member for Wannon's colleagues might not know, including the person who masquerades as a Deputy Leader of the Opposition, he knows that those people out in the industry know clearly what it is all about. When he makes these assertions, they are in an informed position to make some judgment about the adequacy with which he follows this. The honourable member has become a joke out in that industry and he knows it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what they say about you, Bob. You are an embarrassment.

—No, they have not. The honourable member has become a joke and they know it. The honourable member for Wannon referred to the impact that road user charges were likely to have in rural Australia. This is one of the other elements that he has been running with. He should know that the Inter-State Commission undertook initial analysis and made recommendations for possible road user charges in a report which it brought forward in May of last year. This is now December of this year. But in May last year the Commission was indicating that the impact of these charges would be somewhere between—

PARA.TAB: Mr Hawker interjecting—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Dubois) —Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I appreciate your protection. The Inter-State Commission was indicating that the impact of those charges would be somewhere between 50c and $1 a week. For each family, under the worst scenario in rural Australia, the maximum then would have been, say, $1 a week or $50 a year.

PARA.TAB: The person who ran most with that question that has been taken up by the honourable member of Wannon is Fred Finch, the Minister for Transport in the Northern Territory. It is interesting to examine just how Fred responded. After an analysis was undertaken by him or by people who were acting for him, he said that the total impact would be something like $700 a family. Did the honourable member for Wannon endorse that? I knew the figure could not possibly be that. When I looked through the analysis, I saw that Fred had put the decimal point in the wrong place. It was not $700, by the worst scenario; it was $70 a year. That is an example of the impact it will have. That was according to the original Inter-State Commission report.

More recently, as a result of the proposals at the July Premiers Conference—and this has been misrepresented as well—an indicative schedule of charges was simply tabled and received by the Premiers without endorsement and was referred to the working committee of officials. Those charges indicated that the impact per household under the worst scenario in the most remote part of Australia would be somewhere between 16c and 33c a week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who believes you?
—No-one believes you.

—It is not a question of believing me; it is a question of believing the competent authorities that have been given the responsibility of carrying out these analyses. The honourable member for Wannon has been saying the same sorts of things about whether he would accept any assertions I make. The honourable member for Wannon can, if he wishes, question my credibility, but will he question the integrity, the professionalism and the confidence of people in agencies such as the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics, the Industry Commission and all the other bodies that have been given responsibilities in these areas.

PARA.TAB: If the honourable member for Wannon wants to question my credibility, that is perfectly okay. I do not mind that at all. But if he wants to question the credibility of the organisations involved, he makes the position perfectly clear. When he hawks around Australia the claim about how the proposal will devastate families and households in rural Australia, it is a deliberate misrepresentation if he understands what the position is. If he does not understand what the position is, then it reflects even more adversely on the effectiveness with which he has been pursuing his responsibilities.

All of the issues concerned with national road transport reform have been premised on an obligation, an undertaking, which has been pursued with great vigour by the present Government to bring about reforms in this area. The honourable member for Wannon has made great play of the fact that I indicated that my personal target was to bring the National Rail Corporation into operation at least by incorporating the Corporation on 1 July.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has happened?

—If the honourable member listens, I will tell him. The State elections in New South Wales intervened. But not only that; the Premiers Conference, which was required to put the program into place, did not occur until July. That made it quite clearly impossible for the program to be put in place by 1 July. These are trivialities. What we have done, for the first time in over 100 years, is to put into place a national rail corporation which is going to make it possible for us—

PARA.TAB: Mr Hawker interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —God, you are hopeless.
—Order! The Minister should not respond to interjections.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, you know, as the House knows, that I am always extremely tolerant and patient. My tolerance and my patience have simply been wearing thin. I said before that I have directed most of my patience and most of my tolerance to the honourable member for Wannon and I have found it more and more difficult to maintain them.

PARA.TAB: We have had the national road transport reforms as well as the enormously important reforms connected with the National Rail Corporation, which have been estimated to have a value to the national economy of something like $1.3 billion every year. Yet the honourable member for Wannon has trivialised these major improvements, major reforms, major innovations, major benefits as far as land transport is concerned, just to score a few cheap points.

These reforms in national road transport will be of immeasurable value to the national economy for long into the future. All the people benefiting—people in the industry who have been seriously commercially disadvantaged in many different ways in the past as a result of lack of uniformity, inconsistency, duplication, ambiguity and confusion—are applauding the introduction of the reforms.

In relation to the second reading amendment which has been moved by the honourable member for Wannon, I want to indicate that the agreement on road transport that was entered into by the Government with the States and the Australian Capital Territory, as I have indicated, was really a major achievement in establishing the framework for a nationally uniform registration, regulation and charging regime. The lack of uniformity across jurisdictions has not only imposed an unnecessary cost burden on the road transport industry; it has affected all Australians, as nearly everything we export or buy has at some point been transported by road.

The National Road Transport Commission is to be responsible for advising governments on the proper relationship between their expenditures on roads and the charges levied on road transport. One of the clear objectives is to separate road use charges from general taxation in order to maximise the level of accountability by governments for their policies in each of those areas. General taxation on road transport, as on any other industry sector or on the community generally, is a matter for which governments are directly responsible and involves considerations beyond any single industry or sector. There are no taxes, as distinct from charges, which apply exclusively to road transport and taxation of road transport cannot be sensibly examined in isolation.

Asking the National Road Transport Commission to take account of the general level of taxation on road transport would make its task impossibly complicated. It would have to assess and address the general taxing policies of three levels of Government. Any recommendations it might make would be open to criticism not only in relation to the methodology for setting road use charges but also in relation to how well it had interpreted the social and fiscal objectives of the Government.

Giving the NRTC a role in broad taxation issues which are clearly beyond its purpose and expertise sits oddly with the Opposition's purported concern about delegation of powers to the National Road Transport Commission. In clearly establishing proper road use charges, the National Road Transport Commission will fulfil its role, leaving governments and the industry to address themselves to the taxation issues.

The Government has accepted a Democrat amendment moved in the second reading debate in the Senate calling on the Government to address concerns about the level of taxation on the road transport industry generally. The claims that have been made by the honourable member for Wannon fall apart in the light of that. Of course, the Government has been pursuing those inquiries previously.

The Government has also been actively encouraging improvements in the State road authorities and the road construction industry generally. The initiatives that have been implemented under Federal road funding legislation include public tendering of construction and all major rehabilitation works, the implementation of pavement management systems, the introduction of quality management procedures and the awarding of contracts on a quality assurance basis. The National Road Transport Commission already has a role in collecting and publishing information on road expenditure of governments and its relationships to charges.

At their meeting in Adelaide on 21 and 22 November the Premiers and Chief Ministers agreed to enhance this role by having the National Road Transport Commission publish comparative information on road safety, road charges, road costs and the efficiency and the effectiveness of roads expenditure. This proposal was made in the context of extending the NRTC coverage to regulation of light vehicles. This will require a further Commonwealth-State agreement which would be the basis for legislative amendments in the 1992 autumn sittings.

My time is just about exhausted. I could go on and deal at greater length with some of those absurd propositions which have been put forward by the honourable member for Wannon. In response to the motion that he has moved I simply announce, as the Government indicated in the Senate, where we were successful in defeating a similar motion, that we will not support it here.
Question resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am going to be very brief. The amendment that I will be moving to the National Road Transport Commission Bill has already been moved in the Senate but unfortunately was not accepted. I formally move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 8, page 4, line 12 at the end of subclause (2) add `and is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901'.

All this means is that we are going to require that any changes that are made to the agreement attached to this Bill will have to be approved by parliament. It basically means that changes cannot be made to the agreement unless they are also approved by parliament. We feel that in order to get proper accountability, rather than just allowing those powers to be conferred by the ministerial council, they should be referred back to the Parliament itself. For that reason we believe that the Bill is inadequate and that this amendment should be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) said he regretted that he did not have enough time to expand his remarks and say more things, because I want to take this opportunity while we are in committee to ask him to give a commitment on what he and the Government intend to do about increased funding for the Pacific Highway. It is only a matter of days since the Minister attended a function to the north of Coffs Harbour, when he was entertained to a free lunch. But of course there are no such things as free lunches, as we all know. He entertained the regional organisation of councils and re-announced a further $52m of expenditure which had already been announced 18 months before and re-announced another 27 kilometres—
—Did he do that?

—He does it all the time; he is an expert. This is the absolute, greatest re- announcer of all times. Perhaps the Minister did not personally see the letter I sent him on 14 September; but it is now 19 December, and I think that a reasonable amount of time has elapsed. I wrote to the Minister on my own behalf and on behalf of the people of the north coast, including the Northern Rivers Organisation of Councils, asking what his Government was planning to do about the Pacific Highway following the Premiers' working party on roads, which we understand is to recommend that there be Federal funding for the national highway system and for that system only, that all State roads be funded separately by the States, and that local government roads be funded by local government.

PARA.TAB: The Minister knows the state of the Pacific Highway because he has been there and he has been to the sites of all those deaths. He has told me in his genuine and honest way that he believes the Pacific Highway has a special case for priority funding. I note that he agrees with me now. He will recall the more than 50,000 signatures on petitions that I presented to this Parliament following the massive number of deaths on the Pacific Highway in the two bus smashes. The signatories were from all over Australia; people all over Australia recognise the national priority of the Pacific Highway, serving as it does not just the north coast but the two major centres of Sydney and Brisbane, and indeed the whole of Australia.

I ask the Minister again, as I have before, and undoubtedly I will continue to do so until he gives me an answer: what is he intending to do, what is his Government intending to do to guarantee special priority funding for the Pacific Highway, which is essential for the future of all Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly respond to the remarks by the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). I have publicly acknowledged, as he would agree, the extent to which he has indicated a genuine personal concern about the condition of the Pacific Highway. I have also publicly recognised that one of the reasons why governments have shown an interest, a concern and a higher level of commitment to that road is at least due in part to the way in which he has pursued the matter. The issue of those horrendous crashes was taken up by the Northern Rivers Regional Organisation of Councils, the North Coast Regional Organisation of Councils and councils all the way along the Pacific Highway. His colleagues and my colleagues as well—the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell), the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods), the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan)—are people who understand the inadequacies and the dangers of that highway. The honourable member knows that the New South Wales Government and the Federal Labor Government both responded. Bruce Baird and I both announced that $300m program over three years to bring about substantial improvements in the Pacific Highway. The honourable member for Cowper knows that we made an announcement. This is normal procedure; he knows this. I was a bit embarrassed by the way in which he responded, I thought quite ungraciously.
—Never ungraciously.

—He is not normally ungracious. Generally he is a very gracious gentleman. He was quite ungracious about that, because the normal procedure, as he knows, is that once we determine the general program, that is announced. People are entitled to know what it is. But when specific approvals are made, which mean the work is actually going to get under way, a clear legal commitment to fund the project is made. We went up there and we invited the honourable member along, and he graciously participated, as he generally does, in the opening. I took the opportunity, as the honourable member quite correctly said, to announce that there were additional specific funding approvals for additional work of $52m. I do not think that is small beer.

PARA.TAB: For a person who has applied himself and so much of his time and energy to getting additional attention for the Pacific Highway to then treat the matter in such a way really disappointed me, because it does not reflect his genuine approach. I was disappointed and he knows that I was. I would not have been making any reference to it but for the fact that the honourable member chose to make a public reference to it—it was in the papers up there, as he well knows—but he did not make it at the luncheon. I would have given him an opportunity if he had wanted to get up at the luncheon, but it might well have prejudiced his credibility in the eyes of his friends and acquaintances up there and others if he had adopted such an ungracious attitude at the luncheon.

We will continue to give the honourable member for Cowper whatever support we can on the Pacific Highway. The $300m provided for the current three years compares with $114m for the previous three years. It represents a flow of funds which would equal $1 billion over 10 years. That was precisely the level of funding that the road lobby, councils, other road interests and the honourable member for Cowper were considering appropriate. When we met that level of funding, for some reason—a political reason perhaps—it became inadequate. But I think it is an appropriate level of funding. The honourable member for Cowper drives along the road and he knows that the amount of work being undertaken there is enormous. There are tremendously important projects. So let us not diminish the importance of it. The people in the road transport movement who want freight efficiency are benefiting substantially by the improvements which have been carried out.

We reject the amendment which has been moved by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). Paragraphs 8(1)(e) and (f) referred to in this section are intended merely to facilitate the Commission in the performance of its functions, which are only advisory in nature. The functions and powers that may be conferred by executive action are limited to those that come within the executive power of government, such as powers to make inquiries, to form opinions about questions of policy, and to make reports or non-binding recommendations. It would be inappropriate, and time consuming, for such actions to be disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretations Act 1901, particularly as resultant decisions of the ministerial council—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 1.30 in the morning. You just go on and on.
—Why are you not in your dolls house, you twerp.

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN (Mr Hollis) —Order! The Minister will continue with his remarks. The honourable member for Mayo must not come into the House and start interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Chairman, I raise a point of order. It is 1.30 in the morning and the Minister keeps talking. He described me as a twerp. Not only is that unparliamentary, but from a man who cannot stop talking it might be appropriate if he used one of his millions of words to withdraw.
—I thought the honourable member might have been worried that I was referring to the dolls house. If he is worried about my calling him a `twerp', I withdraw. He is not a twerp.
—The Minister has withdrawn. The Minister should not be provocative.

—That would be a considerable elevation. The honourable member is not a twerp. It would be inappropriate and time consuming, as I have indicated, for such actions to be disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretations Act 1901, particularly as resultant decisions of the ministerial council will be subject to parliamentary scrutiny through the normal legislative processes. The amendment proposed is not in the spirit of the cooperative approach encompassed in the decision to establish the Commission. For those reasons, which were clearly indicated as well in the Senate, we will also not be supporting that amendment.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Mr Hawker's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Robert Brown)—by leave—read a third time.
The following Bills were returned from the Senate without amendment or requests:
Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1991
Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Bill 1991
Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Collection Bill 1991
Life Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1991
General Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1991
Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill 1991

Message received from the Senate acquainting the House that the Senate does not insist on its amendment disagreed to by the House of Representatives and has agreed to the amendment made by the House in place thereof.
Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The second reading speech for the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill is on the record in the Senate, where it was introduced by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), who is the Minister responsible for this legislation. At this late hour of 1.47 a.m., I do not propose to detain the House by reading the second reading speech. Therefore, I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fitting that the last Bill to be debated in 1991 is a Bill to amend the Bankruptcy Act. The year 1991 will be remembered as the year of the great recession, to compare with the years of the Great Depression of the 1930s. Later this morning a new Prime Minister will be sworn in. When he goes to have that commission granted to him, he will wear on his belt the scalps of nearly one million Australians—one million unemployed Australians will be hanging off the belt of the new Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: In 1981, when the metal unions had a wage campaign in the metal industry which was so disastrous for employment in this country, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), the then shadow Treasurer, was heard to remark subsequently that the metal union leaders had one hundred thousand scalps hanging from their belts, the one hundred thousand they had put out of work as a result of their wage campaign. The honourable member for Blaxland has one million unemployed people hanging from his belt. As he goes out to Yarralumla, he will carry on his back the highest number of bankruptcies ever in Australian history. Nearly 13,000 Australians were declared bankrupt in the year to June 1991. That was 50 per cent up on the previous record, which was June 1990, and 150 per cent up on the peak of the 1982-83 recession.

But clearly, there is worse to come. In the quarter to September 1991, there was a 72 per cent increase on the September 1990 quarter in that record 1990-91 year. At that quarterly rate, one in 1,000 Australians would be declared bankrupt in the 1991-92 year.

The previous Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), whom we have just farewelled—some of the Labor Caucus farewelled him earlier at 6.30 this evening—often liked to compare himself to John Curtin. I suggest he will be compared in history to Scullin—Scullin, the Prime Minister who fell during the Great Depression, and Hawke, the Prime Minister who fell during the great recession. The parallels might be interesting to journalists and historians. Prime Minister Scullin, of course, was done in by the New South Wales Labor Party under the influence of Jack Lang and the divisive and ruthless machine of which he was a part. Prime Minister Hawke was done in by that same ruthless machine, the Keating forces and the new Prime Minister, Paul Keating, who learnt his politics at the knee of Jack Lang. In the future, historians will draw parallels between the great recession and the Great Depression, parallels between Scullin and Hawke, and parallels between Lang and Keating.

So we end up this year debating amendments to the Bankruptcy Act as set out in this Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1991. It is going to be a sad and sorry journey out to Yarralumla later on this morning, it now being 1.50 a.m., as this new Prime Minister—the man who gave us the recession we `had to have', the one million unemployed and the record number of bankruptcies—journeys out for his reward: the prime-ministership of this country.

Bankruptcy is a difficult area. It is an area where we must balance competing goals of public policy. On the one hand, there are the rights of creditors, people who have advanced money or property or who have entered contracts and have not been paid. They are entitled to be paid. Where a bankrupt has income or assets, it is unfair that he or she gets to keep them if the creditors go barren. Indeed, the concept of cascading bankruptcy occurs where one person goes down and is unable to pay his or her creditors, and those creditors go down as a result. Bankruptcy, particularly in the small business community, can cascade as a result of failure. So we have that goal of public policy ensuring that creditors are given maximum entitlement to income or assets that are held by bankrupts.

On the other hand, the bankrupts themselves, people who have fallen on hard times or who have made bad decisions, have to be given the chance to clear the slate and start again. The goal of bankruptcy has always been to draw a line, as it were, to say that previous debts that cannot be paid shall be annulled or discharged, and that that person who cannot pay those debts shall be given the chance to start again, to resume a rightful place in the economic community.

We must be careful, however, when we approach the bankruptcy law that we adequately balance those two competing goals of public policy. We must protect the rights and freedoms of citizens, without allowing the protection of those rights to become a shield for the astute and dishonest to hide behind and to hide assets or income behind, to the detriment of creditors.

There is much in this Bill which is an improvement on the current state of the law. For that reason, the Opposition will not decline to give this Bill a second reading. However, a second reading amendment has been circulated in my name, and I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)deplores the fact that Australia's bankruptcy levels are the worst for 60 years; and
(2)condemns the Government for its proposal to single out business owners and operators for special punishment by disqualifying them from early discharge from bankruptcy".

I will come to that in due course. But on this side of the House we view one of the proposals in the original Bill as a proposal to single out for special disadvantage, by prohibiting access to early discharge, business bankrupts, as was originally proposed in section 149Y. I may just indicate that section 149Y was deleted in the Senate when the Senate considered this matter some hours ago.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, we make that stand part of our second reading amendment because it was the Government's original intention to single out business bankrupts and to subject them to special punishment by removing access for them to early discharge. Fortunately, the Australian Democrats in the Senate have agreed with us; the Bill comes into this House amended; and I need not move that amendment again—assuming that the Government does not try to reinsert it.But this amendment does indicate that the Government originally singled out, for special treatment and special disadvantage, people who had suffered bankruptcy by reason of business trading.

The reason why we do not believe they should be singled out for special punishment is that the overwhelming majority of those people have been put out of business by this Government. For the Government to put them out of business and then to say, `We will doubly punish you by removing your access to administrative early discharge' is to compound the felony which has been committed against them by an incompetent government.

The main features of this Bill are to introduce a compulsory income contribution regime; to substitute court ordered early discharge with an administrative system; to clarify the grounds on which a bankruptcy can be prolonged by self-executing objection; to impose a prohibition on overseas travel by bankrupts liable to make contributions from income without court approval; to introduce new administrative enforcement mechanisms to facilitate recovery of property into bankrupt estates; to expand the powers of official receivers to obtain information and to undertake inquiries in relation to financial affairs of bankrupts, including inquiries overseas; to clarify and codify the procedures of creditors meetings; and to enable the removal of a trustee of an estate by a majority in value rather than by a majority in number and at least three-fourths in value of creditors voting on a proposal for removal of trustee.

Let me come first to the proposal in relation to income contributions. The Act has always provided, by section 131, that a bankrupt is able to retain income for his or her benefit, subject to any order to the contrary. What this has meant in practice is that, if the bankrupt has income, an application must be made to the court and the court must make an order that that income become available for the benefit of creditors.

The court process can be costly to invoke and, on many occasions, the trustee in bankruptcy finds that he or she will not initiate the process because creditors are not willing to advance funds to enable the action to be taken. If the order is not complied with, the sanction is contempt. Indeed, there is court authority that says a bankrupt is entitled to live the standard of life to which he or she is accustomed. Courts have been reluctant on occasions to make that income available for the benefit of creditors.

It is of deep concern to many in the Australian community that they see bankrupts maintaining a high standard of life whilst creditors go barren. It is galling to Australians to see bankrupts who are living high on the hog, perhaps even living well overseas, whilst their creditors are not paid. The income that they are receiving or which is available for their benefit should be going first to paying debts, rather than maintaining a high style of life.

Under the amendments proposed in this Bill a trustee in bankruptcy will be able to make an assessment of the income likely to be derived by the bankrupt during an assessment period, which is an annual period beginning from the commencement of bankruptcy. Persons whose assessed income is below the proposed `actual income threshold amount' will not be liable to make compulsory contributions, but may do so voluntarily.

The Bill provides for a base income threshold amount equal to 3.5 times what at any time is the maximum basic rate of pension under item 3, column 3, table B, point 1064-B1, pension rate calculator A in the Social Security Act 1991. As of 1 July 1991, this refers to a gross annual income of $22,800, approximately, for a person with no dependants. The actual income threshold amount will increase by percentages based upon the child support percentages contained in the Child Support Assessment Act 1989, according to the number of dependants. Half of the assessed income above the actual income threshold amount will be payable by the bankrupt.

I have received some submissions about this which suggest that bankrupts will be forced to live in poverty and that their income will be, effectively, taken from them by reason of the amendments in this Bill. I do not believe that to be the case. As a result, we will support these particular measures because they do allow the base rate of around $22,800 of income to the bankrupt and it is only half the amount over that which will be taken off for the benefit of creditors.

There will be provision for the Official Receiver in Bankruptcy to authorise departure from the relevant contribution regime in cases of hardship for medical reasons, work related expenses or child-care. Decisions by trustees in relation to income assessment will be reviewable by the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy and by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Bill also provides that provisions be inserted enabling the Official Receiver to collect moneys owing by way of contribution from third persons through garnishment or a charge over property. The provisions enabling this to be done, sections 139ZK and 139ZL, are based on section 218 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and corresponding provisions in other legislation such as the Social Security Act 1991, the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986.

I come now to the proposals for administrative early discharge. The Bill before the House provides that people can be discharged earlier than after the normal three years by administrative mechanism. The trustee must evaluate whether the bankrupt is eligible for and not disqualified from discharge. The proposed criteria are that the bankrupt has no or insufficient divisible property to enable the dividend to be paid, that the bankrupt has not disposed of property in a transaction void against a trustee and that the bankrupt earns an income which is less than the actual income threshold amount applicable to him or her at the time the application is made.

Various disqualifying criteria are set out which would prohibit the bankrupt taking advantage of the administrative early discharge scheme. Those disqualifying criteria pick up breaches of the law. They also pick up a situation where the bankrupt has engaged in misleading conduct, as defined. Misleading conduct is defined in section 148. It does in fact pick up many of the restrictions which are contained in the current Act in section 269—conditions such as that which state that a bankrupt must disclose that he or she is a bankrupt when obtaining goods to the value of $500.

In this particular case, the misleading conduct which picks up those restrictions and prohibits administrative early discharge has a different quantum—the quantum of $3,000—but does in fact pick up most of those disqualifications. The disqualifying criteria that the Opposition finds objectionable are the disqualifying criteria as originally proposed in section 149Y, which states that a person would be disqualified from early discharge if that person became a bankrupt by reason of engaging in business.

We cannot see why people who engage in business should be subject to such disqualification. As I have said earlier, many business bankrupts are bankrupt because of the policies of this Government. We considered that to single them out for special disqualification, as the Government sought to do in its original Bill, was to give them a double penalty not warranted by the circumstances. I am glad that the Senate has taken it out.

Proposed new subsection 149J, which we also object to, provides that a person is disqualified from administrative early discharge where that person's unsecured liabilities exceeded 150 per cent of income in the year immediately before the date of bankruptcy. It has been put that this is defensible on the basis that a person has run up large debts which amount to more than 150 per cent of income and therefore should be penalised in a special way. I point out, however, that if a person's income collapsed in the year immediately preceding bankruptcy, it would not be very hard for that person's unsecured liabilities to amount to much more than 150 per cent. Suppose a person went into negative income in the year immediately preceding bankruptcy. It would not be very difficult at all for such a person's unsecured liabilities to amount to much more than 150 per cent of the income derived in that last year.

As I read the legislation, that is the way in which that proposed new subsection would operate. It would, in fact, pick up many business bankrupts whose income collapses leading up to bankruptcy. We consider that to be another backdoor way of penalising business bankrupts, a corollary to proposed new section 149Y—and we find that offensive as well. That is why we have moved in the Senate to delete it. We will move here to delete it as well.

By operation of law, a bankruptcy ends after three years, and there are various grounds on which objections can be lodged to automatic discharge. They are matters such as continuing to manage a corporation, contrary to the corporations law; failure to provide information about assets and liabilities where requested by the trustee to do so; departure from Australia; failure to attend a meeting of creditors; and like offences. We considered that, in these cases where the bankrupt does engage in conduct which is not cooperative, the period of bankruptcy ought to be extended. We support those provisions.

There are also restrictions on overseas travel. We support those as well. A bankrupt who is assessed as liable to make contributions from income will not be able to travel overseas except by permission of the court. Permission will be granted by the court for compassionate reasons related to death or serious illness. There are also provisions for the official receiver to recover property. The official receiver has powers to make inquiries, and these are based on the Income Tax Assessment Act.

We also have an amendment which enables a trustee to request that an official receiver make inquiries on his or her behalf. It is said by the Government that the Bill does in fact contemplate this being done, but it does so in the most indirect way. The Government relies in this respect on proposed new subsection 163A(2), which provides a power for the official receiver effectively to bill a trustee where he does something at the request of the trustee, but there is no actual clause in the Bill itself which gives the authorisation for the trustee actually to request that to be done. So there is a power to charge, but no actual enabling mechanism. We think that that ought to be clarified, and it will be clarified by amendment No. 2, which we will move in due course.

Clarification and codification of meeting procedures are welcome. There has been an amendment in the Senate already, which I will not dwell on. That is our amendment No. 1, which has been passed in the Senate. I need not amplify that at any length because that has already been accepted and I assume that the Government will continue with the Senate amendment in this House.

I come to one final matter which I feel I should raise before this legislation is completed. A new subdivision J is to be inserted with proposed new sections 139ZQ and those following. This provides that, where a transaction is void against the trustee, the trustee can give a written notice that the money, or an amount equal to the value of the property, be paid back.

It is an administrative scheme to recover moneys which have been alienated from the trustee in void transactions. The trustee can also take a charge over property which is void as against the trustee by administrative mechanism and a person, who could be a third party, failing to comply with a notice is guilty of an offence punishable.

We were concerned about this particular provision because, under the provisions of the Act, certain transactions are declared void and then a defence is inserted in the Act which says that, if the third party can prove that the transaction was bona fide for consideration, the transaction which would otherwise be void is not avoided. The way in which the provisions have been drawn, it says in subdivision J that, where a void transaction is entered, the notice can be given.

It might be said that, since certain transactions, for example, under section 120 or section 122 are prima facie void and the obligation is on the third party to establish as a defence that it was done in good faith and for valuable consideration, the notice could be given on the basis of the transaction being prima facie void without the necessity to establish, as a precondition to giving the notice, that the defences do not apply; namely, the defences that it was done in good faith and for valuable consideration.

This point was drawn to the attention of the Opposition by Mr Cholmondely Darvall, QC, a member of the New South Wales bar. I was sufficiently concerned about this to write to Senator Tate, and I received a reply from Senator Tate on 18 December 1991. I feel that I should read what Senator Tate said because second reading speeches can be taken into account by courts when interpreting the law. We have not had a lengthy second reading speech but, since this is a letter from Senator Tate, the responsible Minister, to me, it effectively takes the place of a second reading speech.

The letter does clarify that it is not the intention of the Government, by the provisions of subdivision J, to effectively deprive third parties who acquire goods in good faith and for valuable consideration of their full rights and title by reason of the provisions of subdivision J. Senator Tate said this to me in his letter:

SPEECH.PARA: You sought my assurance that the Bill does not contain provision having the intention or effect suggested by Mr Darvall that third parties who have acquired property from a bankrupt in good faith and for valuable consideration will be deprived of their title.

PARA.TAB: Nothing in the Bill has the effect which Mr Darvall suggests it has, nor was any such thing intended. The power of the Official Receiver to issue a notice to a person under proposed Subdivision J of Division 4B of Part VI can only be used where a transaction which under Division 3 of Part VI is void against a trustee has occurred. Where a person has received money or property from a bankrupt, but has acted in good faith and has provided adequate and valuable consideration, the transaction is not void, and the preconditions to the exercise of powers under Subdivision J simply would not arise. Any purported issue of a notice would be void ab initio.

A notice which is factually incorrect would not be valid. Apart from being subject to the general powers of the court to resolve all questions of fact or law arising in bankruptcy under section 30 of the Bankruptcy Act 1966, and to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to and resolve such questions, decisions by the Official Receiver to issue such a notice are also subject to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 requiring the rules of natural justice to be observed, the decision to be authorised by the enactment concerned, the decision being supported by evidence and the other matters provided for in that Act.
Mr Darvall's submission is incorrect, and I can assure you that it is not the Government's intention that persons should be affected in the manner he has suggested, nor does the Bill in fact do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I still have a legitimate concern about that, but I have read into the Hansard the reply of the Minister because we will accept the reply of the Minister. We want to put it into the Hansard to make it clear that this is not intended, so if the matter does arise in a court of law we hope that the court will have reference to that Hansard, understand why we did not move amendments, understand why the Government took the position that it did, and understand that it is not the intention of those particular proceedings to deprive third parties who receive goods or money or property in good faith and for valuable consideration of their rights. I give notice that I shall move two amendments in the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

—The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) indicated that the Opposition proposed a second reading amendment to the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill but would not decline to give the Bill a second reading. He spent a good deal of time addressing the matters that he wishes to be dealt with in the committee stage. However, at this time of the morning, I wish to indicate at this stage rather than in committee the Government's attitude to the amendments.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Higgins referred to a letter from the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), which was to the effect that nothing in this Bill will affect or is intended to affect matters raised by Mr Darvall. In response to the amendments which have been foreshadowed by the shadow Minister for consumer affairs, the honourable member for Higgins, I understand that the first relates to clause 12, page 10 and will seek to omit proposed subsection 64H and substitute a subsection. I would inform the House that that amendment was carried in the Senate and is part of the Bill. The second foreshadowed amendment was to clause 19, page 22, and sought to insert a subsection after proposed subsection 77AA. That amendment is not accepted by the Government.

The third amendment relates to clause 20, page 23, but I understand that it will not be pursued. Finally, amendment 4 relates to clause 27, page 63, and seeks to omit proposed sections 149Y and Z. The two proposed sections were split for purposes of argument. Indeed, the amendment in respect of 149Y was accepted in the Senate, but the second part of the amendment relating to 149Z was not accepted.

These matters have been traversed in great detail in the Senate, and indeed have been gone into in some detail by the honourable member for Higgins. Therefore, in view of the long debate on this matter and the time of the morning, I do not propose to add anything further at this stage.
Amendment negatived.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN (Mr Hollis) —Before I call the honourable member for Higgins to move his amendments, I understand that amendment No. 1 as circulated has been agreed to by the Senate—I realise that the honourable member mentioned that in his speech—as has part of amendment No. 4. I presume that the honourable member for Higgins will not be proceeding with those amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right, Mr Deputy Chairman. Can I indicate that I will proceed with amendment No. 2. I will also proceed with the balance of amendment No. 4 which has not been accepted by the Senate. Mr Deputy Chairman, I seek leave to move those amendments together.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Clause 19, page 22, after proposed subsection 77AA(1) insert the following subsection:

" `(1A) A trustee may by application in writing request the Official Receiver, or an officer authorised in writing by the Official Receiver, to enter premises on behalf of the trustee to seek information for any purposes of this Act and, if the Official Receiver, or an officer authorised in writing by the Official Receiver, acts on behalf of a trustee pursuant to such an application, the provisions of subsections (1), (2) and (3) of this section apply in respect of such actions provided that:
