PARA.TAB: (a)the application by a trustee shall contain reasonable details of the information or the type of information sought and the reasons the trustee requires the information; and

(b)if the Official Receiver acts on behalf of a trustee as provided by this subsection, on presentation by the Official Receiver of documentary evidence to support the claim, the trustee shall reimburse, out of the proceeds of the property of the bankrupt estate, the Official Receiver for costs and expenses incurred by the Official Receiver in so acting.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: (4)Clause 27, page 63, omit proposed section 149Z.

I will not detain the House by speaking to these amendments. Amendment No. 2 clarifies the power of the trustee to make application for an official receiver to make inquiries on his or her behalf. I have explained the rationale behind that. The balance of amendment No. 4 is to omit proposed section 149Z. I have explained the rational behind that.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendments; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Mr Duffy)—by leave—read a third time.
Motion (by Mr Duffy) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I put the question, I would like to wish all honourable members a happy Christmas and a refreshing break. I look forward next year to seeing your smiling faces.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.EMPHASIS: House adjourned at 2.24 a.m. (Friday) until 2 January 1992 at 1.40 p.m., in accordance with the resolution agreed to at this sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 14 May 1991:

PARA.TAB: Has the Government established an interdepartmental committee (IDC) to develop an Australian national plan of action for implementing Australia's commitments to the World Summit for Children; if so, (a) what are the IDC's terms of reference, (b) which departments are represented, (c) has the IDC met; if so, when, (d) will the IDC invite public submissions, (e) will the IDC present a report; if so, when and (f) is there a timetable for implementing Australia's national plan of action.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Following a preliminary meeting of departments on 31 October 1991, a formal interdepartmental committee (IDC), chaired by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, met on 14 November to develop the Australian response to the Declaration on the Survival, Protection, and Development of Children and its accompanying Plan of Action. The IDC will also consider Australia's participation in the International Year of the Family (IYF) in 1994.
In developing Australia's response, the IDC will examine what further steps the Government can take both in Australia and overseas to achieve the objectives enunciated in the Declaration.

Departments and agencies involved in the IDC include the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Department of Finance, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Department of Social Security, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, the Australian Institute of Family Studies and the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
State governments, which have a major responsibility for issues relating to children, and non-government organisations will also be consulted in this process.
The Government is working towards completion of a National Program of Action as soon as possible.
Prior to convening the IDC, the Government had taken a number of important decisions in response to its obligations under the Declaration and its accompanying Plan of Action.
Late last year Australia co-sponsored a resolution at the United Nations. This resolution asked countries to help developing countries reach the goals of the Declaration.

On 13 May this year, I officially signed the Declaration on Australia's behalf and added our nation to the list of nations committed to providing support for children as a priority both at home and overseas.

Furthermore, as Senator Evans pointed out in the Senate on 8 October 1991, the overseas aid budget for 1991-92 includes increases in specific sectors relating to our international obligations under the Declaration. These increases were made precisely with those obligations in mind. For example, UNICEF will receive $4.1 million, a 7.3 per cent real increase on last year. International children and related programs will receive $4.2 million, a 2.1 per cent real increase. Other significant contributions will be made to maternal and child health projects in bilateral programs.

Our contributions to UNICEF and to the World Health Organisation's Immunisation Program have also been important in helping those organisations achieve the United Nations goal of universal child immunisation. The United Nations recently announced it had surpassed its 1990 target of immunisation of 80 per cent of children against six preventable diseases.

The aid program also includes a $20 million four year health initiative, a significant part of which is directed to improving vaccines and their delivery. Funding for further proposals in the fields of immunisation, maternal and child health, education, water and sanitation will be considered in the 1992-93 budget.

At the recent meeting of Commonwealth Heads of Government in Harare, I joined with other leaders to welcome the Plan of Action and to commit ourselves to achieving its goals. We stressed that specific actions for children should be pursued as an essential part of wider national and international development activities including poverty alleviation, human development and environmental protection.

These actions are a clear indication of the Government's intention to contribute to the realisation of the objectives of the Declaration on the Survival, Protection and Development of Children both within Australia and overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 20 August 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that from 19 December 1989 migration decisions were taken in accordance with the Migration Act 1958 and were not the subject of ministerial discretion in the first instance; if so, why.
(2) How many illegal immigrants are present in Australia.
(3) What percentage of applications received by his Department from illegal immigrants are successful on compassionate grounds.
(4) Who decides what criteria must be met for acceptance of an applicant on compassionate grounds.
(5) Do all applicants who place an application of any type have a right of review if their applications are rejected.
(6) Has there recently been a dramatic increase in application fees; if so, why.
(7) Can an illegal immigrant be arrested, detained and deported while the person's application is pending.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Applications made on or after 19 December 1989 are decided in accordance with the Migration Act 1958 as amended, the Migration Regulations which came into effect on that date, and subsequent amendments to those regulations where applicable. Under s115 and s137 of the amended Act the Minister has the power to intervene after a rejected application has been formally reviewed where he believes it is in the public interest to do so. As Minister I have no broad discretionary power in respect of migration applications.

In announcing the introduction of the new Migration Regulations my predecessor Senator Robert Ray noted that the establishment of immigration rules and criteria within the legislation would `... ensure accountable and consistent decision-making, open and fair to all...The Regulations create entitlements and restrictions at law. These must be clear and precise in intent if decisions are to be made equitably and accountably. More importantly perhaps, they allow for consistency of decision-making without undue political influence being brought to bear...'.

Applications made prior to 19 December 1989 were, and continue to be, decided in accordance with the requirements applicable at the time of application, ie the Migration Act 1958, and relevant policy. This is provided for by subsection 6(4) of the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989. Ministerial discretion was exercised in accordance with the administrative law requirement that policy not be applied inflexibly. Delegated officers are also required to ensure policy is not applied inflexibly.

Policy still has a place in the decision making process for applications lodged on or after 19 December 1989. However, most of the matters previously covered by policy are now the subject of regulations and the role of policy is no longer as significant as it once was.
(2) The estimated number of overstayed illegal entrants in Australia on 30 April 1991 was 78,000. No estimate has been made since that date.
(3) Records for the period 1 July 1989 to 30 June 1991 show that the percentage of applications received by my Department from illegal entrants were successful on compassionate grounds as follows:
5% of applications made prior to 19 December 1989 (under section 6A(1)(e) of the Migration Act 1958)
0.6% of applications made on or after 19 December 1989 (under Migration Regulations 140 and 142C).

(4) Grant of permanent residence on compassionate grounds under section 6A(1)(e) of the Migration Act 1958 as applicable prior to 19 December 1989 was subject to policy guidelines issued by my Department.
The criteria under Migration Regulation 140 (Compassionate grounds permanent entry permit after entry) were approved by my predecessor at the time the Regulations were introduced in December 1989.

In respect of Regulation 131A (1)(d)(v) which provides for grant of an extended eligibility temporary entry permit (preliminary step to grant of permanent residence) on compassionate grounds to certain illegal entrant applicants, I have approved policy guidelines under s179 of the Migration Act 1958.
(5) People can apply for review only if the application is for a certain class of visa or entry permit which has a right of review.
The underlying principles determining the availability of review of migration decisions are:
there is an Australian person or organisation affected by the unfavourable primary decision; and
the applicant (if in Australia) was lawfully in Australia when he or she lodged the visa or entry permit application.

For people who apply for a visa overseas, generally an Australian person or organisation affected by the rejection of the application has the right to apply for review. For people who apply in Australia, generally both the applicant and the Australian person or organisation supporting the application have the right to apply for review.

Although non-residents legally in Australia have standing to seek review in some cases, the classes of visa and entry permit in respect of which non- residents have standing are generally those where there is a connection between the non-resident principal applicant and an Australian citizen, permanent resident or business. An Australian usually also has standing in such cases.
Entry permit applicants who were illegal when they lodged their applications are specifically excluded from the right to seek review. There are limited exceptions which are as follows:
(a) people who have been illegal entrants since 19 December 1989 and applied for entry permits before 1 November 1990 or who have applied for the December 1989 entry permit.
(b) certain people who became illegal entrants before the age of 18 and subsequently applied for entry permits.
(c) certain people who became illegal entrants on entry (ie not overstayers) and have not left Australia since that entry.

(6) On 15 April 1991 the fee for applications for permanent residence on spouse grounds was increased from $360 to $750. I announced the new fee in January 1991 at the same time as the stringent new arrangements intended to reduce abuse of the previous arrangements for people seeking to remain in Australia as the spouse of an Australian citizen or permanent resident. The new fee reflects the higher processing costs and additional workload involved in the new arrangements.

On 26 July 1991 the fee for applicants for permanent residence on skilled (excluding business) grounds was increased to $750. A media release of 30 April 1991 announced the increase as a further move to reflect the costs of processing applications.
On 1 October 1991 all fees for permanent residence were increased in line with the CPI index. Fees are increased in this way each year.
(7) An illegal entrant may be arrested and detained while an application to remain in Australia is pending but may not be deported until the application is resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 21 August 1991:

PARA.TAB: Further to the answers to questions Nos. 22 (Hansard, 13 September 1990, page 1924) and 516 (Hansard, 20 February 1991, page 1067), when does he expect to put forward a request to finalise accession to the Unesco 1961 "Rome" Convention for the Protection of Performers, Producers of Phonograms and Broadcasting Organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Once regulations are made and in force under the Copyright Act to protect broadcasts and performances of other Convention member countries, I will be in a position to ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to finalise arrangements for accession to the Rome Convention. These regulations have now been submitted to Executive Council approval and, if approved, will come into force on 1 and 2 January 1992. The regulations are a prerequisite to acceding to and thus accepting the obligations of the Convention.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 8 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the total cost, including salaries, training, administrative support and accommodation, of the military police of the three arms of the Australian Defence Force in (a) 1988-89, (b) 1989- 90 and (c) 1990-91.
(2) Has restructuring and rationalising military law enforcement and security been considered; if so, what is the status of that consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) At this time the Services do not keep detailed records of the costs involved in administering and accommodating a single Branch of personnel within their Service. The following qualified figures are indicative of the costs attributable to military police training in each of the three Services:
(a) NAVY

The RAN accounting system is not yet able to provide a total cost which includes salaries, training, administrative support and accommodation. The figures provided below are a direct cost for each rank which includes salary plus an administrative cost.
(b) ARMY

The costs detailed below are based on salary costs of Military Police borne in the ARA and ARes in the years shown. Detailed costs of training, administrative support and accommodation are not held by Army for a single Branch.
(c) AIR FORCE

All costs directly attributable to RAAF Police cannot be readily extracted from available expenditure records for the years specified. Based on current RAAF strengths by rank, salary and allowance costs are estimated to be approximately $9.00m p.a. (2) The concept of restructuring and rationalising the military police and security function in the Services has recently been considered. It was one of the issues reviewed by the Defence Regional Support Review (DRSR) which looked at integrating certain police functions on a regional basis. After considering submissions from the Services it was determined that there were limited prospects for integration. Collocation of certain police and security functions is being progressed as an integral part of the on-going DRSR Development Plan.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 10 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the total anticipated expenditure in 1991-92 in each State and Territory for the Ready Reserve recruiting drive initiated in October 1991.
(2) Are the figures referred to in part (1) expected to vary in (a) 1992-93 and (b) 1993-94.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The value of advertising placed with the press and television is as follows:
NSW (incl. ACT)—$576,802

In addition brochures, display kits, counselling films and posters have been produced for national distribution at a cost of $467,000. Further expenditure in 1991/92 is dependent on recruiting numbers cleared as "suitable for entry".
(2) Plans for recruiting for the Ready Reserve in 1992-93 and 1993-94 have not been completed but some reductions in advertising may be possible as initial set-up costs will not recur.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 15 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will he instruct the Wool Realisation Commission to publish the price at which wool is sold from the stockpile; if not, why not.
(2) Does the Government own the wool stockpile or do the growers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The Australian Wool Realisation Commission (AWRC) operates under the provisions of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991 and the related regulations and Guidelines. My powers of direction over the AWRC are outlined at Section 66 of the Act and allow me to give directions to the Commission on matters concerning the performance of its functions and the exercise of its powers. However I am only able to exercise that power of direction if I am satisfied that there are exceptional circumstances, and direction is necessary in order to ensure that the Commission's activities are consistent with major government policies. I consider that in view of the above criterion, I do not have the power to direct the AWRC in the matter you refer to.

The AWRC makes decisions on the terms and conditions of sale of wool from the stockpile and, in this regard, has publicly announced that it would be selling its stocks at a premium to the 27 June 1991 auction prices or the current market prices, whichever is the higher for the particular type of wool. This minimises the impact of stockpile sales on prices received for sales of the current production.

As you will be aware, wool sold by the AWRC does not reliably compare to a farm lot as the wool has generally been dumped and grouped, and may have been transported overseas or have been partly processed. Therefore, any price information would be misleading unless the additional factors were taken into account.

The AWRC currently publishes on a weekly basis details of wool sold from the stockpile, the total value of those sales, and the quantities of stocks remaining. The wool trade therefore is aware of the AWRC's activities and can assess how the Com-

ANSWER.PARA: mission is progressing against the requirement to reduce the debt each year by the amounts specified in the Guidelines.

PARA.TAB: (2) The AWRC owns the stockpile.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 16 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the total real level of Commonwealth payments to (a) each of the States and Territories and (b) all the States and Territories together in each year since 1980-81 in 1991-92 dollars.
(2) What was the annual change in total real Commonwealth payments to (a) each of the States and Territories and (b) all the States and Territories together in each year since 1980-81.
(3) What was the real change in total Commonwealth payments to all the States and Territories over the decade between 1981-82 and 1991-92.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Commonwealth payments to the State and Territories are defined as payments (including net advances) to self-governing States and Territories, and those made directly to Local Governments. As such, payments received by the ACT prior to 1988- 89 were classified as Commonwealth own purpose outlays. Therefore, prior to 1988-89 total payments do not include figures relating to the ACT.
With respect to your specific questions:
(1) Table 1 details the total real Commonwealth payments to the States and Territories for each year since 1980-81 in 1991-92 dollars.
(2) The annual percentage change in the total real Commonwealth payments to the States and Territories is tabulated in Table 2.

(3) The real change in total Commonwealth payments to all States and Territories over the decade between 1981-82 and 1991-92 is -0.17%. You should note, however, that payments to the ACT were not included in the 1981-82 calculations.

ANSWER.PARA: [THE TWO TABLES ARE OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE, SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 3917]

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 16 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: Is all furniture to be used in Government offices required to be certified "worksafe" with prescribed markings; if so, (a) must furniture be inspected prior to certification, (b) is the only agency in Australia able to certify the furniture located in Sydney, (c) must furniture manufactured elsewhere be sent to Sydney for inspection and certification, (d) does this limit the opportunities available to manufacturers in remote areas and (e) will the Minister act to enable inspection and certification to be performed elsewhere; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's questions:

PARA.TAB: Worksafe Australia is the Commonwealth Government's authority on occupational health and safety standards, including ergonomic standards for furniture.
DAS is concerned to ensure that the furniture available on common use contracts complies with appropriate ergonomic guidelines.
Therefore,

(a) if Worksafe Australia has been engaged to carry out ergonomic testing, the sample items of furniture submitted by suppliers are inspected by Worksafe against ergonomic criteria which that organisation has established. Spot checks are carried out on items under contract to ensure they continue to meet the criteria.

(b) Worksafe Australia is the Commonwealth Government authority for ergonomic standards and its office is located in Sydney. It is not the only agency available to carry out ergonomic testing, but may be requested to do so.
(c) If ergonomic testing by Worksafe Australia is a requirement of a tender, samples of items must be sent to Sydney for ergonomic testing.

(d) Manufacturers are given ample opportunity to submit samples when ergonomic testing is required. Manufacturers in remote areas are not considered to be disadvantaged by this procedure. The certification received for compliant furniture is valuable in marketing those items and is considered to far outweigh costs involved.

(e) While Worksafe Australia is the Government's authority on ergonomic standards for furniture, the Department is not obliged to use it exclusively for testing. For example, the Australian Furniture Research and Development Institute in Launceston Tasmania is established to carry out all types of testing related to furniture including testing against ergonomic standards.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 16 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the article in the Melbourne Herald-Sun of 13 October 1991 relating to the extension by the Federal Government of coverage for workers' compensation to Australian territories including the Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands which is uninhabited.
(2) Is there a need for the extension of coverage for workers' compensation to the Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands.
(3) Would journalists working within the Territory be covered for workers' compensation if coverage had not been extended.
(4) Does the North West Shelf gas field lie within the economic exclusion zone of the Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) Yes. As the honourable member is no doubt aware, whilst the Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands (the Territory) is uninhabited it is visited on a regular basis by persons who should be covered by workers' compensation. Those visitors are currently covered by the Northern Territory Work Health Act 1986, applying by virtue of the Ashmore and Cartier Islands Acceptance Amendment Act 1985 which extends to the Territory the laws of the Northern Territory as in force from time to time.

(3) No. However, prior to the current arrangements workers' compensation was provided by the application of Northern Territory Acts and Ordinances in force immediately before 1 July 1978, by virtue of the Ashmore and Cartier Islands Acceptance Act 1933.

(4) No. The North West Shelf gas field generally refers to the North Rankin field area which is within Australia's 200 nautical mile zone but some 500 nautical miles to the south west of the Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 17 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will she attend the 1992 Olympic Games; if so, will she be accompanied by any staff members or other persons; if so, (a) who and (b) for what official purposes.
(2) Will she perform any official duties at the 1992 Olympic Games; if so, what duties.

(3) If she attends the 1992 Olympic Games will she travel elsewhere on official business as part of her journey to or from the Games; if so, will she be accompanied by any staff members or other persons; if so, (a) who and (b) for what official purposes.
(4) If she attends the Games what is the estimated cost to the Government of her attendance and that of persons accompanying her (a) at the Games and (b) elsewhere during the same journey.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(a) The final make-up of the Ministerial group is yet to be decided. However, it is expected that I will be accompanied by a Ministerial Adviser (to be determined) and the Portfolio Secretary, Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.

In addition, the Australian Sports Commission Chairperson and Executive Director will be attending in their own right. The Portfolio Secretary and I may be accompanied by our spouses in accordance with normal Public Service and Ministerial entitlements.
(b) The official duties to be performed by the Ministerial Adviser and the Portfolio Secretary are yet to be finalised and will depend in part on circumstances as they develop in Barcelona.
(2) The official duties I am to undertake at the 1992 Olympic Games are yet to be finalised.
(3) It is expected that I will attend Australia's National Day at EXPO 92 in Seville on 18 July '92.
(a) It is expected that I will be accompanied by a Ministerial Adviser and the Portfolio Secretary at EXPO 92, although the final make-up of the group is yet to be decided.
(b) The official duties of the Ministerial Adviser and the Portfolio Secretary at EXPO 92 are yet to be finalised.
(4) The estimated cost of my attendance and that of a Ministerial Adviser and the Portfolio Secretary at the 1992 Olympic Games and EXPO 92 is currently unknown.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 17 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: Did he give any undertakings to the Northern Territory Government before the federal election in March 1990 with regard to the Victoria Highway between the Northern Territory and Western Australia; if so, (a) what were those undertakings and (b) did they include a project to upgrade the highway to dual lane by the end of 1994; if so, (i) was $24 million to be provided by the Commonwealth in 1991-92 for the project, (ii) what sum was to be provided in (A) 1992-93, (B) 1993-94 and (C) 1994-95 and (iii) has the term of the project been altered from five to ten years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) and (b) At the time the final sealed section of the National Highway system between Newman and Port Hedland in Western Australia was opened in December 1989, I indicated my commitment to the elimination of all single lane sections of the National Highway in outback areas of Australia by 1994 through a widening program.

The National Highway widening program is directed primarily at very narrow single lane seal (less than 4.5 metres wide) of which there is about 265kms in Western Australia; 34 kilometres in Queensland, and 380 kilometres in the Northern Territory. The cost of the program was estimated to be $200 million.

The Victoria Highway, as part of the National Highway system in the Northern Territory, is included in the widening program. It involves the widening of 320 kilometres of pavement to two lanes, at an estimated cost of $94 million (revised upwards at a later date to $100 million).

Following approval of the five year National Highway strategy for the Northern Territory and the Annual Program for 1989-90, I wrote to the Northern Territory Minister for Transport and Works, Mr Fred Finch, on 14 March 1990 indicating that $56 million would be made available over the next five years for the Victoria Highway.
The Federal Government's commitment to the full funding of $94 million for the Victoria Highway was reaffirmed at the opening of Limestone Creek Bridge in the Northern Territory in June 1990.
(i) No undertaking has been made to the Northern Territory to provide $24 million for the Victoria Highway in 1991-92.
(ii)(A)(B)(C) The table below shows a five year funding profile for Northern Territory National Highway and the Victoria Highway commencing 1990-91.

In addition the Prime Minister, as part of his November 1991 statement on the economy and employment, announced that the Federal Government will provide an additional $2 million to the Northern Territory in 1992 for acceleration of widening work on the Victoria Highway.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Northern Territory—Proposed National Highway Funding Profile

ANSWER.PARA: [THE TABLE IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE, SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 3920]

PARA.TAB: (a) National Highway in the Northern Territory comprises the Barkly, Stuart and Victoria Highways. It should be noted that about 35% of total National Highway funding for the NT is spent on maintenance.
(b) PCRH—Provincial Cities and Rural Highway Program.
(c) The injection of the additional $5 million PCRH funding in 1990-91 has lifted the initial $56 million strategy figure to the present $61 million.

(iii) No specific timeframe for completing the Victoria Highway widening program has been set. At the present average annual rate of expenditure it is expected that about 90% of the narrow seal on the Victoria Highway will have been widened to 7 metres and about half of the 31 bridges widened or replaced by 1994-95.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 17 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Wide Bay Military Training Area, including Camp Kerr at Tin Can Bay, Qld, been used as a firing range for heavy artillery, anti-tank weapons, grenades and mortars; if so, (a) for what period and (b) will the Army continue to use the area as a firing range.

(2) Did the Department of Defence stress the importance of the Wide Bay Training Area as a firing range to Mr Tony Fitzgerald during a visit to the region as part of the Commission of Inquiry into the Conservation, Management and Use of Fraser Island; if so, is the use of the facility still considered to be essential.
(3) Did the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories consult him before the Wide Bay Training Area was nominated for World heritage listing.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Wide Bay Training Area has been used for field artillery, anti-tank weapons, grenades and mortars since 1957. I am advised that heavy artillery has not been used at Wide Bay.
The Army will continue to use the Wide Bay Training Area as a firing range.

(2) I am advised that the importance of the Wide Bay Training Area was stressed to Mr Fitzgerald during his visit to the region. The use of Wide Bay Training Area is still considered essential by Army to fulfil its training requirements.

(3) The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) consulted with the Department of Defence prior to the nomination of Fraser Island and the Great Sandy Region (including Wide Bay Training Area) for inclusion in the World Heritage List. The Department of Defence informed DASETT that it was prepared to support the nomination, subject to management arrangements for the area having sufficient flexibility to accommodate Defence requirements. I am advised that arrangements of this nature are in place for Defence activities within the World Heritage listed Great Barrier Reef, and are being developed for the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Area.
I am also advised that the continued use of Wide Bay Training Area for Defence activities is specifically mentioned in the Fraser Island and Great Sandy Region World Heritage Nomination document.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 5 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the most authoritative estimate of the cost of constructing a third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.
(2) What percentage of the cost referred to in part (1) is for additional infrastructure.
(3) What is the most authoritative estimate of the cost of constructing an airport at Badgerys Creek with two parallel runways and modest terminals.
(4) What percentage of the cost referred to in part (3) is for additional infrastructure.
(5) What is the nature of the infrastructure referred to in parts (2) and (4), respectively.
(6) If the projects referred to in parts (1) and (3) were started on 1 January 1992, when would each be completed.

(7) With respect to the construction of a general aviation runway at Badgerys Creek, (a) how many air traffic movements could be diverted to Badgerys Creek, (b) how long would completion take and (c) how many additional slots for commercial aviation would be provided.
(8) How many additional commercial aviation movements would be provided by the construction of a third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.
(9) How much disruption of existing services would be caused by construction of the third runway.
(10) Would any areas of Sydney be subjected to higher noise levels following construction of the third runway.
(11) What is the future of curfew arrangements at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.
(12) Would a curfew be imposed at Badgerys Creek.
(13) What sum has been committed to the Badgerys Creek proposal to date.
(14) Would any of the infrastructure cost attributable to the Badgerys Creek project be incurred even if a part of the project was not proceeded with.
(15) What sum could be realised by the federal Government if (a) the land acquired for the Badgerys Creek project or (b) the 700 hectares at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport were sold or redeveloped.
(16) Would urban renewal be enhanced by redevelopment of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.
(17) Is the Badgerys Creek project inevitable.
(18) Would Badgerys Creek benefit Sydney's western suburbs.
(19) Would Badgerys Creek be a preferable destination for passengers going to industrial areas in the western suburbs.
(20) Would landing charges be cheaper at Badgerys Creek.
(21) What would construction of a general aviation runway at Badgerys Creek cost.
(22) Is there a need for a general aviation runway at Badgerys Creek to be separate from further development.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Supplement to the Draft Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) estimates the cost of constructing a third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport is $275.2 million in June 1990 dollar terms.

(2) The cost estimate referred to in question 1 includes all components required for construction and operation of the runway. It does not include "additional" infrastructure such as facilities for corporate aviation or off-airport improvements to the roads.

(3) The Supplement to the Draft EIS provides a comparison of cost estimates for a range of different concepts and scales of development for Badgerys Creek. A concept broadly equivalent to that described in the question is an airport with two runways capable of accommodating international services with a passenger throughput of approximately 13 million per annum. The estimated cost of such a development is $1960 million.

(4) The estimate referred to in Question 3 includes all infrastructure required for the total airport project within the site boundary. It does not include "additional" infrastructure such as off airport improvements to roads, transport links and fuel pipelines.
(5) "Additional" infrastructure would be new or upgraded roads, access links, fuel pipelines etc as explained in Questions 2 and 4 above.

(6) It is estimated that the construction of the third runway at Sydney Airport would be completed by March 1995 if commenced in January 1992. The concept referred to in Question 3 could be completed by approximately 2000/2001.

(7) (a) The Department of Transport and Communication's General Aviation Development concept in the Badgerys Creek Concept Design Report assumes that the initial Badgerys Creek development would need to cater for growth in general aviation activity and general aviation traffic which may elect to transfer from other airports in the region. A means of identifying a potential market for general aviation facilities at Badgerys Creek is to consider forecasts of general aviation activity and the capacity of existing airports to meet the forecast demand. However, the establishment of a new airport represents a significant immediate increase in the supply of airport capacity and it is difficult to confidently predict how the market will respond. Therefore, whilst it is possible to identify potential for general aviation traffic at a new airport at Badgerys Creek, it is not possible to predict levels of traffic that would choose to operate at the new facility.
(b) The general aviation facility proposed in the Conceptual Design Report would take around 27 months to construct.

(c) The Badgerys Creek Concept Design Report proposes an area of around 5ha be provided for general aviation support facilities which would comfortably accommodate 20,000 to 30,000 general aviation movements per annum.

(8) The Supplement to the Draft EIS estimates the practical capacity of Sydney Airport with a third runway is 353,000 annual aircraft movements. The practical capacity of the existing two runway configuration is 268,000 annual aircraft movements using the current enhanced simultaneous operations procedures. The increase in capacity provided by the third runway is therefore 85,000 annual aircraft movements.

(9) There will be little disruption to services as a result of construction activities. The majority of the work is outside the existing airport boundary. There will be two taxiway connections to the existing runway and taxiway systems which will be constructed during curfew hours using the standard procedures for works of this type. There could be minor disruptions to operations of the CAA's runway 34 glide path due to dredging activities and also lane closures during off peak periods on General Holmes Drive with work on the taxiways and road crossings.

(10) The EIS for the third runway fully details the noise impacts as a result of operations with third runway. In general there will be increased impacts to the north of the airport and reduced impacts east and west of the airport. Impacts to the south will be largely unchanged.
(11) The existing curfew arrangements at Sydney Airport will continue.
(12) The Badgerys Creek site was selected as the location of the second Sydney Airport by the Commonwealth Government in 1986 so as to allow the airport to operate curfew free.

(13) Expenditure to the end of November 1991 on the Badgerys Creek Airport site amounts to around $138 million; the principal items being site acquisition, local road upgrading, purchase of properties within the noise affected area defined by the 35 ANEF contour, and the Badgerys Creek Airport Conceptual Design Consultancy.

(14) Badgerys Creek is situated in an area identified for large scale future urban development by the State Government. Provision of infrastructure will therefore need to occur in response to this development irrespective of decisions regarding the airport.

(15) (a) Based on the current market value of the Badgerys Creek Airport site, it is estimated that between $77 million and $82 million could be realized through the sale of the site. Badgerys Creek has been designated as the site for the second Sydney airport since 1986 and its future development as an airport is reflected in the New South Wales Government's urban development plans for the South Creek Valley region. Consequently, it would be unrealistic to speculate what sum might be realized if the site were redeveloped.

(b) The Supplement to the Draft EIS on the third runway estimates that $900 million could be realised through sale of the Sydney Airport site. This estimate is based on current market prices and allows for the removal of existing infrastructure and provision of services necessary for redevelopment.

(16) The Supplement to the Draft EIS on the third runway addresses the impact of the provision of additional airport capacity at Sydney Airport on regional planning and urbanisation considerations. It reports that the expansion of Sydney Airport is consistent with the State Government's proposed metropolitan strategy for the Sydney region as it reinforces an existing employment centre and counteracts the current decline in employment in the airport subregion. This accords with the State Government's preference for urban consolidation so as to make better use of existing infrastructure in inner city areas.

(17) Aviation forecasts of passenger demand indicate that eventually a second airport will be needed in the Sydney region. The Government is therefore committed to the staged development of Badgerys Creek airport in response to anticipated growth in demand in the Sydney region.

(18) The Supplement to the Draft EIS states that the development of a second airport at Badgerys Creek is viewed by the State Government in their metropolitan strategy for the Sydney region (1988) as an "opportunity to create an industrial zone for intensive advanced technology development and to provide the basis for major employment in outer areas".

(19) Information presented in the Supplement to the Draft EIS on the origin and destination of passengers and of passenger's choice of airports, indicates that it is likely that a large proportion of passengers would choose to continue to use Sydney Airport. An analysis of overseas experience of multiple airport systems suggests that accessibility is not the only criterion of passenger choice of airports. In addition to proximity and accessibility other variables such as flight frequency and service differentiation (eg pricing) influence passenger's preference. The analysis suggests that the attractiveness of an airport to a passenger depends on the trade off between accessibility and flight frequency, and indicates that as a second airport at Badgerys Creek would be likely to suffer a flight frequency disadvantage relative to Sydney Airport there would continue to be a concentration of passenger movements at the primary airport.
(20) The level of landing charges would be a commercial decision for the airport operator.

(21) The general aviation facility in the Department of Transport and Communication's Conceptual Design Report is estimated to cost $53 Million in December 1990 dollars excluding land acquisition costs.

(22) The conceptual design for the initial general aviation facility has located the general aviation runway on the alignment of the master planned parallel taxiway to the major runway. This will ensure minimum disruption to airport operations when the main runway is eventually developed and will allow the redevelopment of the general aviation runway to a parallel runway.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 5 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: Further to comments made by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications concerning the proposed application of road user charges by the National Road Transport Commission under agreements made at the Special Premiers Conference in October 1990 (Hansard, 9 October 1991, page 1517), (a) will the Commission have the power under the Constitution to impose additional road user charges with respect to vehicles licensed in non-participating States or Territories if those vehicles meet all vehicle configuration and load regulations set by the Commission and (b) will participating States and Territories need to enact complementary legislation to authorise the agreements made at the Conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) The guidelines and principles under which the new charging system is to operate were agreed at the July 1991 special Premiers Conference and were based on legal advice on their constitutional status. Charges for heavy vehicles under the national arrangements agreed by Heads of Government will be set under a decision-making process involving recommendations from the National Road Transport Commission and a disallowance procedure for the Ministerial Council. The new system will be implemented under Commonwealth and complementary State legislation.

No decision has been taken on the mechanism for charging vehicles from jurisdictions not participating in the national scheme travelling out of state. The Commission will be responsible for underta- king this task as part of its consideration of zonal charging arrangements.
The principle the Commission will employ is that vehicles travelling within jurisdictions participating in the national scheme should operate on a similar financial basis.

Vehicles from non-participating jurisdictions operating out of state should not gain a competitive advantage. On this basis vehicles crossing into higher charge zones will be required to pay a fee that reflects full cost recovery and is administratively simple and enforceable.

The Northern Territory has agreed to "mirror" all national regulations to ensure national uniformity. On this basis, all vehicles will need to meet vehicle configuration and load regulations to operate legally in any State or Territory. This would apply equally to vehicles registering in the Northern Territory and operating outside the Territory.

(b) The participating States and Territories will need to enact complementary legislation to authorise the agreements made at the Conference. It is envisaged that each jurisdiction will enact legislation to adopt, by reference, legislation which will be enacted by the Commonwealth on behalf of the Australian Capital Territory. This form of complementary legislation will lead to consistency across the States and should any changes to the legislation be necessary, ensure consistency is maintained. It will avoid the necessity to amend and make consistent nine separate pieces of legislation whenever change is required.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 5 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the costs of an annual subscription to (a) House of Representatives and (b) Senate Hansard.
(2) Have the costs referred to in part (1) recently increased; if so, (a) for what reasons and (b) in each case (i) by what sum, (ii) from what date and (iii) what was the cost before the increase.
(3) Who sets the prices of Australian Government Publishing Service publications and on what basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) $10.00 for current subscription to Weekly Hansard
(b) $10.00 for current subscription to Weekly Hansard

(2) (a) AGPS has recently sent out subscription renewal forms informing customers of a price increase for 1992 subscriptions. The proposed price increase has been deferred at the request of the Minister for Administrative Services.

The proposed increase was designed to recover full costs involved in providing subscription services. Current subscription rates and Community Service Obligation funding do not cover costs associated with maintaining this service (postage and packing, distribution, warehousing, and subscription maintenance).
(b) (i), (ii) and (iii) Please see table below:

TAB.TAB: (ii) Date Of

PARA.TAB: (i) ProposedProposed(iii) Current

(3) In most cases AGPS sets the prices of AGPS publications in consultation with author departments. In the case of Parliamentary publications the Parliamentary Departments set the prices in consultation with AGPS. Unfortunately this did not occur in relation to the proposed increases. The Minister for Administrative Services requested that the increases be deferred subject to a review being undertaken by the Minister and the Presiding Officers. The basis for AGPS publication prices is recovery of full costs after any subsidies that may be provided as Community Service Obligation funding or by the author department.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Community Cultural, Recreation and Sporting Facilities Program

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 6 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which Victorian organisations have received grants during the first 9 months of 1991 under the Community Cultural, Recreation and Sporting Facilities Program.

(2) For each organisation referred to in part (1), (a) what was the sum of each grant, (b) on what date was each grant made, (c) what project did each grant cover, (d) what determining factor under the established selection criteria led to each grant being made and (e) did any other government or regional authority fund part of each project for which a grant was made; if so, (i) which authority and (ii) what sum did it provide.

(3) What sums were spent during the first quarter of 1991-92 on Departmental (a) salaries, (b) consultancy fees, (c) staff travel expenses and (d) other expenses in operating the program referred to in part (1).

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) None. The Community Cultural, Recreation and Sporting Facilities Program was announced as part of the 1991-92 Federal Budget. Applications for funding have been sought by 6 December 1991. Successful applicants are expected to be announced in early 1992.
(2) Not applicable.
(3) (a) Estimated to be $11,677 to 25 September 1991 (nearest complete salary period); (b) Nil; (c) $1,012.00; and (d) Nil.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 6 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the screw-worm fly facility at Laloki, Papua New Guinea, close in December 1991; if so, has the Department of Primary Industries and Energy developed a contingency plan to respond to any outbreak of screw-worm fly in Australia following the closure of the facility.
(2) If a contingency plan has been developed, does that plan rely on breeding sterile flies for release in Australia; if so, (a) where would they be bred and (b) in what quantities.
(3) Will a new screw-worm fly facility be built; if so, (a) in what country, (b) what will it cost, (c) how many sterile flies per week will it produce and (d) when will it be completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, the screw worm fly facility at Laloki, Papua New Guinea will close by 31 December 1991. A contingency plan to respond to an outbreak of screw-worm fly has been developed by a national working party as part of the Australian Veterinary Emergency Plan (AUSVETPLAN). A screw- worm fly business plan, prepared by a national working group representing State, Territory and Commonwealth governments, the National Farmer's Federation and the Australian Veterinary Association, is now being implemented to enable that contingency plan to be executed in the event of an outbreak of screw worm-fly in Australia.

(2) The contingency plan that has been developed relies on a number of control techniques including the breeding of large numbers of screw-worm flies for sterilisation and subsequent release in Australia although this technique is yet to be validated for the Old World screw-worm fly.
(a) No decision has been reached on the location of a screw worm-fly production facility to service an outbreak in Australia.

Based on scientific concerns over possible strain differences in the screw worm fly it will probably be necessary to breed these flies in Australia to ensure that flies from the field outbreak can be introduced into the facility to counter the outbreak strain without the constraints of a third country's quarantine requirements.
(b) It is estimated that a sterile screw-worm fly production capacity of some 250 million per week would be necessary to service the national screw- worm fly contingency plan.

(3) Negotiations are being conducted to establish a pilot screw-worm fly facility in South East Asia from which to validate the sterile insect release method for the Old World screw-worm fly and to develop essential detailed design plans and specifications for a major facility that would be necessary to service the requirements of the contingency plan under AUSVETPLAN.
(a) The pilot facility will be built in Malaysia subject to funding. A full scale facility would in all probability be built in Australia.
(b) The pilot facility is estimated to cost approximately $2m. A full scale facility is estimated to cost $14m to $24m.
(c) The pilot plant will be capable of producing ten million flies per week. A full scale facility will be capable of producing 250 million flies per week.

(d) Subject to the availability of funds the pilot facility will be completed by July 1993. A decision on if and when to build a full scale facility will be taken once an assessment of risk of introduction, establishment and impact of screw-worm fly has been completed and following essential research and development work at the pilot plant or, on the outbreak of screw-worm fly in Australia in the unlikely event of this occurring first.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 6 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Under which (a) treaties, (b) conventions, (c) covenants, (d) protocols and (e) agreements is Australia required to make periodic reports.
(2) To which committees or councils must Australia report in each instance referred to in part (1).
(3) By what date is the next of each of the reports referred to in part (1) due.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: Australia is a party to several hundred Treaties, Conventions, Covenants, Protocols and other types of agreements, both of a multilateral and bilateral nature. It would be a major task to scrutinise all of these agreements to determine which require Australia to make periodic reports. This is especially so, given that a number of different areas of Government have responsibility for administering these agreements. A complete record of Australia's treaty commitments is summarised in the Australian Treaty List published by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, which has been passed to the honourable member. The Treaties Support Unit of the Department would be able to provide information on particular treaties.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 6 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many participants at the recent World Wave Ski Titles held on the Gold Coast were (a) questioned or (b) apprehended by officials of his Department for competing in the event having entered on tourist visas rather than temporary entry sporting visas.
(2) Upon whose instructions were Departmental officials acting with respect to the matter referred to in part (1).
(3) How many (a) staff and (b) staff hours were involved.
(4) Are tourists visiting Australia normally not precluded from taking part in amateur sporting activities while in this country.
(5) How many tourists participating in amateur sporting events other than that referred to in part (1) have been questioned or apprehended by Departmental officials since November 1990.

(6) Were (a) the South African or (b) other participants at the event referred to in part (1) offered the opportunity to pay $100 to change their visa status; if the South Africans were not but others were, why.
(7) Were some participants detained in a dark room for several hours and subjected to harassment, degradation and interrogation; if so, does he condone the treatment.

(8) Was the approach by Departmental officials heavy-handed and the action taken by them a gross over-reaction which resulted in the cancellation of the event; if so, will he apologise on behalf of the Australian Government to the organisers and participants of the event.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (2) The action taken was routine action in response to a media report which suggested that there may have been a breach of the Migration Act.

(4) Persons entering Australia are precluded from activities which are incompatible with their tourist visas. Such activities include formal study, work either paid or unpaid, or where the primary purpose for entering Australia is to have medical treatment, to perform as an artist or entertainer whether paid or unpaid, or to participate in a sporting competition either as an amateur or as a professional.

(5) Records of this nature are not maintained by the Department. However a number of people have been located participating in amateur sports such as rugby union in contravention of the Migration Act.
(6) (a) Yes; (b) Yes.

(7) All the participants who had entered Australia as tourists were invited to attend the Southport Office to discuss their situation. As they had commitments during the day arrangements were made for them to come to the Southport Office late in the afternoon. As the number of people who took up this offer was larger than could be accommodated in the office waiting area, they were invited to wait in some adjacent unoccupied office space. There was no coercion, harassment, degradation or interrogation.

ANSWER.PARA: *figures refer to Queensland based staff only.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 7 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the (a) names, (b) qualifications, (c) former positions and (d) salary levels, including entitlements, of the members of the Board of the Grains Research and Development Corporation.
(2) What principles guided the balance of representation on the Board.

(3) In what specific ways does the Board provide for input from (a) the rural community and its industrial representatives and (b) the scientific research community over the course of its deliberations.
(4) To which specific published guidelines does the Grains Research and Development Corporation refer when it makes its decisions regarding the allocation of funds for research.

(5) Has the Corporation recently shifted the emphasis of its funding towards market development; if so, (a) through which research or other programs will the new emphasis be realised, (b) on what basis and with what expectations was the emphasis shifted and (c) what is the Corporation's assessment of the outcomes of past funding of market development programs.

(6) With respect to any shift in funding emphasis, (a) what previously funded programs have received diminished support and (b) in each case, why was the program assessed as warranting reduced funding support.
(7) What previously funded programs have received reduced support under the current research funding program, irrespective of the impact of increased emphasis on market development.
(8) In each of the cases referred to in part (7), why did the Corporation deem the program to warrant reduced funding.
(9) According to the Corporation, what role does support for plant breeding, especially of wheat and barley, play in the future viability of the grains sector.
(10) Have the levels of support for all types of plant breeding research changed since the institution of the Corporation.
(11) Are any changes to the level of support for all types of plant breeding research (a) planned or (b) at the stage of preliminary assessment.

(12) If changes to the level of support have occurred, are planned or are currently being deliberated upon, why does the Corporation deem that reduced support for plant breeding is or might be warranted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) and (b) The names and academic qualifications of the Board members are Mr D. Blesing (Chairman); Mr G.T.M. Bolton Dip of Business Administration; Mr R.A.H. Davies BSc (Hons), Grad Dip in Occupational Hygiene; Dr A.K. Gregson BSc (Hons), PhD; Mr T.J. Flugge; Professor J.V. Lovett BSc (Agric) Hons, PhD; Professor D.R. Marshall BScAgr (Hons I & University Medal), PhD; Dr G.W. Reeves BAgSci, Postgrad Dip. (Agricultural Economics), Master of Agricultural Economics, PhD; Dr B.J. White BEc, PhD.
(c) Former positions held by members are:
Mr D. Blesing: Chairman, CSIRO Soils Division Advisory Committee; Chairman, Wheat Research Council; Director and Chairman, Christmas Island Phosphate Mining Company; farmer; business adviser.

Mr G.T.M. Bolton: Managing Director, Goodman Fielder Mills Ltd; General Manager, Flour Milling Division Goodman Fielder Mills Ltd; NSW General Manager, Flour Milling Division, Goodman Fielder Mills Ltd; Assistant General Manager, Operations and Administration, Australian Wheat Board; NSW Manager, Australian Wheat Board; South Australian Manager, Australian Wheat Board; Executive Assistant to General Manager, South Australian Co-Operative Bulk Handling Ltd.

Mr R.A.H. Davies: Scientific Officer, Centre for Overseas Pest Research UK; secondment to CSIRO Division of Entomology; Entomologist, Senior Entomologist, Product Manager, ICI Australia; Research Business Manager, ICI Research Group; ICI international divisions (product development, marketing); former member, GIRD Biotechnology Committee; currently Co-chair CRC Life Sciences Panel.

Mr T.J. Flugge: farmer; numerous grain industry positions including President, Australian Wheat Growers' Federation, 1983-84; member, State Wheat Advisory Committee of WA; member and Chairman, WA State Wheat Industry Research Committee; Chairman, WA Soil Fertility Research Trust Fund; Board member, Australian Wheat Board; Deputy Chairman, Australian Wheat Board; Adviser, CSIRO.

Dr A.K. Gregson: farmer; member, Barley Research Council; member, Board of CSIRO; Visiting Professor, Chemistry Department, University of North Carolina; Lecturer - Associate Professor, Department of Chemistry, University of New England; Postdoctorate Fellowship, Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory, Oxford and UKAERE Harwell.

Professor J.V. Lovett: Professor of Agronomy and Head of Department of Soil Science, University of New England; Professor of Agricultural Science, University of Tasmania; Associate Professor, Department of Agronomy & Soil Science, University of New England; Senior Lecturer, University of New England; Lecturer, University of New England; Visiting Professor, University of Helsinki; member, Australian Oilseeds Research Committee; Chairperson, Oilseeds Research Council; President, Australian Agronomy Society.

Professor D.R. Marshall: Professor, Plant Breeding, University of Sydney; Waite Professor of Agronomy and Head of Department, University of Adelaide; Director, Wheat Research Centre, University of Sydney; Queen Elizabeth II Research Fellow, CSIRO; Post-doctoral Fellow, University of California Davis; Post-graduate Research Fellow, University of Sydney.

Dr G.W. Reeves: member, Cotton Research and Development Corporation; Assistant Secretary, Wheat Branch and Assistant Secretary, International Branch, Department of Primary Industries and Energy; Agricultural Counsellor, Australian High Commission, London; various positions in the Bureau of Agricultural Economics including Assistant Director, Livestock Marketing and Outlook, and Chief Commodity Analyst.

Dr B.J. White: Director, Consultancies and Business Development, Queensland Department of Primary Industries, current position is Director, Consultancies and Business Development Branch; Statutory Appointments: member, Wheat Research Council 1989-90, member, Barley Research Council 1986-89, Director, Queensland Barley Marketing Board 1987-88, Director, Queensland Butter Board 1986, Deputy Chairman, Rural Reconstruction Board 1983.

(1)(d) All positions except that of Executive Director are part-time. Fees for Board members, apart from the Executive Director and the government director, as determined by the Remuneration Tribunal are as follows: Chairman $24,381 per annum, members $13,075 per annum. Travelling allowance for all members is $300 per overnight stay for a capital city and $155 for other than a capital city. The government director is not paid a sitting fee but is entitled to travelling allowance at the same rate as other Board members. The Executive Director receives a remuneration package of $120,000.

(2) The fundamental principle guiding the selection of the Board of the GRDC was to meet the requirements of the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 (Section 131) that the persons selected must be suitably qualified for appointment because of expertise in one or more of the following fields: commodity production, commodity processing, commodity marketing, conservation of natural resources, management of natural resources, science, technology and technology transfer, environmental and ecological matters, economics, administration of research and development, finance, and business management. The Act also requires that the Corporation should collectively possess an appropriate balance of expertise in as many as possible of these fields with particular regard to grains.

(3)(a) Opportunities for input to the Corporation's deliberations from the rural community and its representatives are wide ranging. They include direct meetings of members with farmer groups, which have included all State grower bodies affiliated to the Grains Council of Australia (GCA), as well as other groups such as the Prime Wheat Association, the Pastoralists and Graziers Association, and the Triticale Grain Association of Australia; formal and informal meetings with the GCA executive; participation of all Board members in the GCA's annual conference, at which the Chairman and other Corporation representatives account to grain growers for completed and proposed activities.

(b) Most of the projects funded by the Corporation are submitted and carried out by members of the scientific research community. This provides for a continuous interchange. Reviews of those projects are conducted by GRDC Committees, which report to the Board. Board members attend many meetings with both individual research scientists and representative bodies, such as the Australian Society of Agronomy, institutes of agricultural science, farm management societies, crop soil and weed science societies, and cereal chemists.

(4) The GRDC Board is preparing a consolidated five year plan for the Corporation as a whole, to be issued in 1992. Pending approval of that plan, the GRDC refers to the five year plans of the former Barley, Grain Legumes, Oilseeds and Wheat Research Councils and the State Barley and Wheat Research Committees, which have Ministerial approval. In addition to objectives, strategies and priorities for grains research, those plans contain criteria for decisions on funding allocations.

(5) The Corporation is in the process of developing its five-year strategic plan. A consideration in this process is a possible shift in emphasis of its research program towards market development. The Corporation's four major objectives, include improving grain varieties through nationally-focused and market-oriented crop improvement programs, and improving industry returns from market- focused R&D. In integrating breeding programs and production systems better with changing market requirements, some shift in the R&D investment portfolio might be required in order to pursue a more efficient and co-ordinated program structure. Shifts in priorities could result in a reduced share of total funding to breeding aspects of crop improvement and protection but this may not necessarily result in any diminution of the effectiveness of the Corporation's expenditure in this area of research. As a first step, the Corporation has decided to conduct a review to examine what scope exists for elimination of any duplication and a more rational deployment of funds in Corporation-funded breeding programs which currently absorb about one-third of total research expenditure. Plant breeders will be closely consulted in the conduct of this review.

(6) The 1991-92 operational plan is the first annual program to be prepared by the Corporation. The program continues the trend developed in recent years by the Corporation's predecessor organisations for State Committees to put major emphasis on crop improvement, production and protection, whereas national Committees, while still maintaining solid programs in those areas, saw gaps needing to be filled in other R&D fields.

(7) In terms of levels proposed in forward budgeting by its predecessor organisations, programs across the board of the GRDC's portfolio have received relatively less support in the current year's operational plan. This was necessary because of an unforeseen reduction in planned levy income, particularly for wheat, due to the sharp fall in prices and consequently value of the 1990/91 crop from which this year's income is derived.

(8) In most cases, the Corporation did not deem the program per se to warrant reduced funding. Even after cutting into reserves, the Corporation judged that, because of the substantial reductions in planned levy income and matching Commonwealth contributions, it could not avoid the reduced research allocations without seriously endangering the basic reserve levels necessary to maintain future research.

(9) In the Corporation's view, support for plant breeding, including the major crops wheat and barley, will play an important, integral part in the future viability of a market-driven grains sector. Sustainable rotations in the sector require integration of grain legumes, oilseeds and pasture legumes with cereals.

(10) As a proportion of the total grains research program, support for plant breeding research has not changed appreciably since the institution of the Corporation, although planned or hoped for support could not always be maintained because of the factors referred to in (7) and (8) above.
(11) and (12) See (5) above.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Qantas Airways Ltd: Bookings by Members of Parliament

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 7 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: Further to his answer to question No. 1059 (Hansard, 6 November 1991, page 2518), will he provide a specific response to part (6) of the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: My previous answer clearly stated that the Minister for Administrative Services will continue to keep arrangements for parliamentary travel under review.
As I have already indicated, where senators and members choose to purchase their own tickets and seek reimbursement, they are not restricted to arranging travel exclusively through Qantas.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 7 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the Government provide supplementary funding to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) and other Government agencies involved in Aboriginal Services to meet the cost of the proposed mandatory 3 per cent superannuation benefit for all employees to avoid a real reduction in the level of funding to Aboriginal community services.

(2) If not, will (a) the existing distribution of funds between organisations be maintained or agencies reallocate funds based on their priorities and (b) communities be consulted in relation to the reordering of priorities.

(3) If funds are to be reallocated, will he provide advice on the priorities for reallocation between the programs and regions, including the movement of resources between capital and recurrent programs.

(4) Have Aboriginal communities been consulted in relation to the application of the superannuation legislation to Aboriginal communities in terms of their preference for a 3 per cent real reduction in funding directed at redressing current disadvantage compared to improved income in retirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) If an application for supplementary funding is submitted by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission because of additional costs incurred as a result of the proposed 3 per cent superannuation legislation, it will be considered by the Government. I understand that ATSIC is examining the issue of how to accommodate superannuation.
(3) Any decision on funds reallocation, if this should become necessary, will be made by the ATSIC Board of Commissioners taking into consideration advice from Regional Councils.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 7 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) pursuing the extension of union coverage to all Aboriginal community employees; if so, will the cost of the extension result in a reduction in the level of service to Aboriginal communities; if so, what are the details.

(2) If the extension of award coverage results in increased costs, will the consequent reduction in service be distributed across all programs or will ATSIC and other agencies reallocate their resources between programs to reflect their priorities.

(3) If funds are to be reallocated, will he provide advice on the priorities for reallocation between the programs and regions, including the movement of resources between capital and recurrent programs.
(4) Will the Government provide supplementary funding to meet the costs referred to in part (2); if so, what limits will there be to the supplementation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission that a number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations are seeking the extension or introduction of equitable award (as distinct from union) coverage for their employees. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and Department of Industrial Relations are supportive of that process and are seeking to ensure that those organisations, as independent employees in their own right, have professional advice from an employer perspective to assist in their negotiations with the Unions under the Industrial Relations Commission setting. It should be noted that the terms and conditions of ATSIC grants place the onus on individual organisations to ensure that their employees are subject to appropriate award coverage.

(2) If the extension of equitable award coverage results in increased costs which are not able to be met from available funds, the ATSIC Board of Commissioners and various Regional Councils will re-examine priorities. There can, however, be no guarantee that additional funds will be forthcoming.
(3) Priorities for reallocation of funds will be set by the ATSIC Board of Commissioners taking into consideration advice from Regional Councils.
(4) If an application for supplementary funding is submitted, the Government will consider it and any limitations that may be necessary, at that time.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Air Travel by Australian Government Personnel

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 11 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Who are the travel agents who arrange air travel for persons whose fares are paid by the Australian Government.
(2) Are the agents referred to in part (1) required to use services which provide the best return for the Commonwealth at the lowest appropriate cost.

(3) What volume of the travel referred to in part (1) was provided by (a) Australian Airlines, (b) Ansett Airlines of Australia and (c) Compass Airlines in each of the last three months for which statistics are available.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Contracts are held with the following travel agents for travel required by most Australian Government Departments:
Qantas Airways Ltd
Australian Airlines
Thomas Cook Travel
Westpac Travel
Coles Myer Ansett Travel.

These arrangements have been in place since 1988 and expire on 31 December 1991. The arrangements made in 1988 with the Departments of Social Security, Primary Industries and Energy, and Arts, Sports, Environment, Tourism and Territories expired in June 1991 and a contract with Ansett Australia was then established for those Departments.
(2) Agents are required to book services as requested by the person travelling.

(3) For the Department of Administrative Services, domestic travel for the period 1 January 1991 to 31 October 1991 (a) 58.6% was provided by Australian Airlines, (b) 39.8% was provided by Ansett Airlines and (c) 1.6% was provided by Compass Airlines, East-West Airlines and other smaller regional airlines. Details of other Department's travel would have to be sought from these Departments as the Department of Administrative Services does not keep records for them.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aerospace Technologies of Australia Aircraft Services

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 11 November 1991:
