PARA.TAB: What sums in (a) cash, (b) credit or guarantee, (c) equity, (d) loans and (e) promotion and marketing assistance has the Government provided to assist Aerospace Technologies of Australia Aircraft Services with the commercialisation of Commonwealth assets in the aircraft industry at Avalon, Vic.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: ASTA Aircraft Services Pty Ltd (ASTAAS), as distinct from Aerospace Technologies of Australia Pty Ltd (ASTA), has received no monetary or promotion and marketing assistance from the Commonwealth in developing its business at Avalon Airport.
However, some assistance has been provided in the following form:
The Department of Employment, Education and Training has provided assistance in the retraining of Geelong-based motor vehicle industry workers to acquire aircraft industry skills;
Loan Council approval was given for the sale and lease-back of assets on a commercial basis;
ASTAAS was permitted to retain the proceeds of the 29.1% sell-down to Hong Kong Aircraft Engineering Company.

Separately, ASTA, as distinct from ASTAAS, leased Avalon Airport for a period of 99 years at a valuation of $70m. This was funded by a contribution of $20m equity provided by Defence to ASTA as well as a $50m part loan and part equity contribution from the Commonwealth through the Asset Sales Task Force.

Apart from the capital provided to ASTA to implement the lease arrangements for Avalon Airport, no additional capital has been provided to ASTA other than that represented by the assets of the former Government Aircraft Factories.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Financial Information Service

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 12 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many officers of the Minister's Department's Financial Information Service (FIS) are members of the (a) Australian Society of Investment and Financial Advisers Ltd or (b) International Association of Financial Planners.
(2) With respect to each officer who is a member of either organisation, (a) in which office is the officer employed and (b) how many other FIS officers are employed at the same office.

(3) Have any Departmental offices maintained a list of investment or retirement planning advisers; if so, (a) which offices, (b) what form did the lists take at each office and (c) which individuals and organisations appeared on each list; if not, why not.

(4) Do FIS officers refer the Department's clients to licensed investment advisers, licensed security advisers or retirement associations; if so, (a) to which individuals or organisations are the clients referred and (b) on what basis is the decision to refer to a particular individual or organisation made.

(5) Has the Department considered making available through in-house databases a list of licensed investment advisers or licensed securities dealers to clients requiring information regarding investment; if so, will such a facility be introduced and when; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) As far as my Department is aware, membership of the two organisations mentioned would not involve a conflict of interest for FIS officers. My Department does not, as a matter of course, obtain information on the organisations of which its staff are members. Obtaining such information would be intrusive and unnecessary for the performance of their duties.

(3) It is not appropriate for a government service to be seen as promoting members of the financial planning/advisory industry or any investment products which they may wish to recommend to clients. FIS officers are instructed not to provide investment advice such as which investment or type of investment is suitable to a client's particular needs.

(4) See answer to Question 3. Where clients appear to be in need of specific investment advice FIS officers are able to advise that professional advice is available from private financial planning/advisory services and may supply a client with a leaflet from the National Centre on Retirement Investments which recommends steps to be taken when choosing a private advisor.
(5) See answer to Questions 3 and 4.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 12 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the USA imposed a countervailing duty of approximately $A20 per head on pigs imported from Canada; if so is this evidence that the USA considers that Canada is dumping pigs on the US market.
(2) Is Canadian pork imported by Australia (a) tariff free and (b) at the risk of introducing swine gastroenteritis; if so, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, from 7 October 1991 the US increased the countervailing duty on live pigs from Canada to $18.04 (US) per 220 pound market hog or about 22 cents (Australian) per kilogram. This amount equates to almost $A20 per Australian pig which is lighter than the Canadian pig.

The US countervailing duty on live pigs from Canada is payable retrospectively by Canadian exporters who exported live pigs to the US between 1 April 1989 and 31 March 1990. The duty is indicative that Canadian producers of live pigs were receiving Government subsidies during that period and that the imports were materially injuring the US industry.

In this context the honourable member may be interested to know that the US applied a countervailing duty in 1989 of about 9 cents (Australian) per kilogram against imports of Canadian pigmeat. Canada appealed against this duty and the US International Trade Commission upheld the appeal, noting that although certain Canadian rural assistance programs were countervailable, there was no evidence of injury caused to the US industry. The duty was removed and previous duties paid were refunded.

(2) Canadian pork is imported into Australia tariff free, while commercial imports of live pigs from Canada are not permitted because of quarantine restrictions. Import figures show that for the 1990/91 year 1009 tonnes of pigmeat product valued at $4.4 million were imported from Canada. With Australian production of pigmeat estimated at 310000 tonnes and valued at $660 million for 1990/91, Canadian imports represented 0.3% of domestic production and 0.7% of the value of this production. For the first quarter of 1991/92 imports have reached 778 tonnes, an amount less than 1% of the estimated Australian production during this period. However it is estimated that the share of the market held by Canadian imports for boneless legs and middle cuts is around 3%-4% at present.

While the matter of Canadian imports of pork and the possibility of mounting a countervailing case against such imports is being considered by the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council and some processors, no application for action has been lodged with the Australian Customs Service.

Uncooked pigmeat from Canada has been entering Australia since the Government took the decision to lift the import embargo on such product in July 1990. This decision followed the assessment of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service that the risk of introducing the disease transmissible gastroenteritis through the imports was extremely low. The assessment was objective and scientifically based and was made in the light of Australia, as a major exporter of primary products, maintaining its reputation of not using quarantine restrictions for economic protection purposes. If a quarantine prohibition cannot be based on sound scientific evidence, the prohibition becomes a non-tariff barrier to trade and thus contrary to Australia's international obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 12 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does a report by Booz Allen and Hamilton provide a detailed analysis of the current rail traffic between Melbourne and Ballarat; if so, has that analysis been combined with load factors and actual speeds to produce an actual traffic flow pattern involving all train movements including those currently scheduled via alternative routes.

(2) Does the report referred to in part (1) claim that present and projected traffic can be accommodated without major work including duplication; if so, is he able to say whether that claim is correct; if it is not correct, why not.
(3) Is he able to say what is the average speed between Bacchus Marsh, Vic., and Ballan.

(4) Is he able to say whether the load of trains currently routed via Geelong and Cressy will need to be reduced to obtain the average speed referred to in part (3); if so, by what amount; if not, how many locomotives will need to be added.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I understand that the draft report referred to presents results, not detailed information on its methodology of the type requested by the honourable member.

(2) I understand that the draft report indicates that, apart from significant investment associated with standardisation, the line via Ballarat would be able to handle projected traffic levels. I am not able to say whether this is correct or not; this is a matter to be determined by the National Rail Corporation, in the light of its operational procedures.
(3) and (4) No. Rail operations are a matter for the Public Transport Commission of Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 12 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has a consultant's report recommended that all rail freight between Melbourne and Adelaide be carried via Bacchus Marsh; if so, does the report (a) recommend the use of existing rail infrastructure with only a change of gauge from 5 feet 3 inches to 4 feet 8.5 inches and (b) suggest that with that modification existing infrastructure could cope with existing traffic and future growth.
(2) Is he able to say whether freight trains travelling from Melbourne to Adelaide are routed via Geelong and Cressy.

(3) Does the report referred to in part (1) suggest that the route referred to in part (2) is slower and less cost effective than that recommended by the report; if so, is he able to say why it is used.

(4) Is he able to say whether trains travelling in either direction between Melbourne and Adelaide are often routed through Lethbridge and Geelong to reduce congestion between Bacchus Marsh and Ballarat.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)I understand that a draft report by Booz- Allen and Hamilton Pty Ltd, a consultant to the National Rail Freight Initiative Task Force, the precursor to the National Rail Corporation (NRC), suggests that Melbourne-Adelaide interstate rail freight traffic should be routed via Ballarat. It also indicates that standardisation of the line would be commercially worthwhile if all rail freight traffic between the East Coast and South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory is concentrated on the route. Any decision on future investment on the Melbourne-Adelaide line is a matter for the commercial judgement of the NRC.
(2)No. Rail operation on these lines are currently the responsibility of the Public Transport Commission of Victoria.

(3)I understand that the draft report indicates that simulations of identical trains (with a power to mass ratio comparable to those likely to operate on the line when the NRC is established) would take less time on the Ballarat route. Rail operation on these lines are currently the responsibility of the Public Transport Commission of Victoria.
(4)No. Rail operation on these lines are currently the responsibility of the Public Transport Commission of Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 13 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Further to the final report of the Industry Commission on the Australian dairy industry, presented to the House on 11 November 1991, was the methodology used by the Commission a standard form of calculating the effective rate of assistance to the dairy industry.

(2) In calculating the effective rate of assistance, should both the primary producer and manufacturing components of the industry be treated as a single entity; if so, what is the effective rate of assistance to (a) the primary producer and (b) manufacturing components of the dairy industry.

(3) In measuring the output of the dairy industry, is it necessary to include ancillary but integral production activities such as the value of livestock sold from dairy farms; if so, what is the effective rate of assistance to those activities.
(4) If a revision of the effective rate of assistance is necessary, how are the Commission's recommendations on the dairy industry affected.
(5) In calculating rates of assistance to the dairy industry is it sufficient to consider a comparison between domestic and export prices.

(6) If the dairy industry was deregulated, (a) would consumers pay the (i) export or (ii) import parity price for milk products, (b) what would be the difference in impact on the consumer between the respective parity prices and (c) does that difference have any bearing on the Commission's use of the export parity price as the benchmark for determining assistance rates.
(7) Are import parity prices for manufactured milk products an accurate indicator of their production costs.
(8) How does the average import parity price for market milk compare with the costs of local production.
(9) In the light of its perishability, is market milk's import parity price a legitimate basis for calculating nominal assistance rates; if so, on what specific grounds.
(10) Is he able to state which countries are known to subsidise which manufactured milk products and, in each case (a) to what extent and (b) by what means.
(11) Does the interference in production and export costs of manufactured milk products in other countries have any bearing on evaluating assistance levels to the Australian dairy industry.
(12) What data were used to answer parts (7)-(11) and will he make then publicly available.
(13) Is the Australian dairy industry genuinely efficient within the operation of the domestic price support mechanism known as the Kerin Plan.

(14) Does the use of the New Zealand import parity price as a benchmark for determining domestic price support under the Kerin Plan allow sufficient direct incentive to the industry to restructure; if so, which past and prospective movements in the NZ import parity price have given and will give that incentive.
(15) What factors have influenced and will influence the NZ import parity price.
(16) Is the NZ import parity price influenced by any market intervention of any form in the country of production.

(17) In the absence of domestic price support, (a) what would be the dairy industry's capacity to operate efficiently at the international price across the range of dairy products, (b) if the dairy industry contracted would it be able nevertheless to exploit openings in international markets and (c) on what grounds are these assessments made.

(18) With respect to the range of manufactured milk products which could be imported into Australia, (a) how, on average, would the price of each product line differ from the current domestic price for the same product and (b) could Australian consumers obtain market milk at lower prices outside the existing regulatory framework than is obtainable now; if so, (i) how and (ii) what would be the saving per litre; if not, why not.
(19) If the answer to part (18) is difficult to determine, why.

(20) Will he provide a list of the specific factors, in ascending order of significance and including the defined level of assistance, he will take into account when framing his response to the Commission's recommendations; if not, will he provide an unordered list.

(21) What would be the impact (a) within the first four years of their being introduced and (b) in the longer term of the Commission's recommendations on farm gate prices for milk destined for manufacturing.

(22) Within the first four years of implementation of the recommendation, what would be the impact of the resulting price shift on (a) the number of dairy farmers in each State and (b) the structure of the dairy industry in general.
(23) In the event of the dairy industry being restructured through deregulation, would resources be diverted to the beef industry; if not, to which industries would resources be diverted.
(24) What is the employment multiplier for the dairy industry.
(25) How do the (a) value added activities and (b) employer multipliers of the industries referred to in part (23) compare with those of the dairy industry.
(26) What will be the average impact on the prices received by manufacturers of manufactured milk products of the Commission's recommendations within the first four years of their implementation.
(27) How will the outcome referred to in part (26) affect employment levels within milk product manufacturing.

(28) Who are the registered milk manufacturers in each State and with respect to each manufacturer, what is (a) its ownership structure, (b) the percentage of the market within the State held by it, (c) the volume it produces in percentage terms in each product area (i) within the State and (ii) nationally and (d) the number of persons it employs.

(29) With respect to the manufacturing component of the dairy industry, what will be the result on (a) employment patterns, (b) industry structure and (c) ownership structure of implementation of the Commission's recommendations.
(30) What will be the effect of implementation of the Commission's recommendations in the longer term on the prices for manufactured milk products received by manufacturers.

(31) Who are the major retail food purchasers of market milk and manufactured milk products and what percentage of the market for (a) market milk and (b) manufactured milk products (i) nationally and (ii) in the State of production does each buy.

(32) Is there a concentration of purchasing power for dairy products; if so, what powers does the Commonwealth possess to ensure competition exists in the sale of dairy products to the major retail food purchasers.

(33) What would be the impact on the price paid by the consumer for (a) manufactured milk products and (b) market milk (i) within the first four years of the implementation of the Commission's recommendations and (b) in the longer term.
(34) Is the Australian dairy industry a price taker on the international market or does it hold sufficient trading power to set its own prices.
(35) If the Australian dairy industry is a price taker, what are the characteristics of its market position in each product area which makes it vulnerable to price fluctuations.
(36) What is (a) the total volume traded and (b) Australia's share of international dairy production in each area identified in part (35).
(37) Does Australia have any prospects of gaining access to international markets for dairy products within the next five years; if so, what are they.
(38) What are the potential market gains for Australia if access is eased to overseas markets for manufactured milk products.

(39) If the chances of longer term access to overseas markets are greater than those in the medium term, is the export potential of the dairy industry better developed outside the existing regulatory framework or from within.
(40) Have export market developments occurring within the existing regulatory framework provided a genuinely competitive basis for exploiting new markets.

(41) If world trade in dairy products improves beyond the next five years, will the market development activities of the dairy industry be better served from outside the existing regulatory framework or within; if so, in which ways.

(42) Was the tariff quota on cheese imports introduced in 1983 in exchange for dropping the countervailing cash securities imposed on importers by the Australian Customs Service after successful industry action against subsidised imports.

(43) With respect to the introduction of the quota referred to in part (42), do subsequent changes warrant the quota's withdrawal; if so, what changes and (b) what arguments support retention of the quota.
(44) Is the Commission correct in claiming that the continuation of the underwriting scheme is necessary for the viability of the dairy industry.
(45) What are the arguments which (a) support and (b) oppose (i) full, (ii) 95 per cent, (iii) 85 per cent and (iv) 80 per cent underwriting.

(46) What analyses of the cost structures which bear on the operations of the dairy industry have been undertaken; if none have been undertaken or the information is not available, will action be taken to make it available.
(47) Is the information referred to in part (46) influential in determining policy direction for the dairy industry.
(48) What areas of micro-economic reform are most likely to benefit the dairy industry and what gains can be quantified for the various sectors of the industry from those reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Mr McGauran is to be congratulated on his extensive and detailed knowledge of the Australian dairy industry.

The IC dairy report was tabled in the Parliament on 7 November. It is a comprehensive and challenging document and one that will need careful consideration at the Commonwealth, State and industry levels.
I have written to my State counterparts and to the industry inviting their views on the IC proposals. The issues that need to be addressed are largely those identified by Mr McGauran in his question.
When these consultations are complete I will take a submission to the Government on a package of measures and at the appropriate time I will be reporting to the Parliament on the outcome.
Meanwhile, it would be both premature and quite inappropriate to attempt any detailed reply to the question.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 13 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which organisations have been funded in the first round of the National Aboriginal Health Strategy and what sum was each organisation allocated.
(2) What criteria were used in determining the allocations.
(3) What consultation with regional councils or communities occurred in the development of the priorities behind the criteria referred to in part (2).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been provided with the following information by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) in response to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The following organisations were funded in 1990-91 and 1991-92 under the National Aboriginal Health Strategy (NAHS).

ANSWER.PARA: [THE TABLE IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE, SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 3937]

PARA.TAB: (2) Funding allocations were based on the criterion of meeting urgent outstanding needs in Aboriginal Health Services (AHSs).

The criterion was based on the National Aboriginal Health Strategy Working Party Report and the resolutions passed by a combined meeting of Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers for Health and Aboriginal Affairs. This meeting, held in Brisbane on 10 June 1990, resolved to:

TAB.EMPHASIS: "Note that provision should be made for increasing resources to, and upgrading facilities of, existing fully Commonwealth funded community-controlled health services, where needs have been established..."; and

PARA.TAB: "Endorse the establishment of new community controlled Aboriginal community-controlled

ANSWER.PARA: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health services..." (refer Resolution 5)

PARA.TAB: (3) Bids for funding were canvassed from all AHSs and ATSIC Regional and State Offices. Consultation with Regional Councils in the development of priorities was minimal because the majority of Regional Councils were not in place when the Government agreed to fund the NAHS for 1990-91 on 13 December 1990.

In view of the fact that most Regional Councils would not meet until February 1991, ATSIC Commissioners, as representatives of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, decided that a Commissioner, in consultation with the Chairperson and other Commissioners as appropriate, be involved in prioritising bids.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General upon notice, on 14 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: Did any member of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) either formally or informally, personally or in writing contact the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) or any officer of the ATO concerning the taxation affairs of Mr G Verducci, a person involved in Operation Seville conducted by the NSW Police and the AFP; if so, (a) when, (b) for what purpose, (c) by which AFP officer was the contact authorised, (d) on what grounds was it authorised and (e) was the Attorney-General, or any of his successors, aware of the contact.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Any contact between the AFP and the ATO concerning the tax affairs of any person or corporate body is formal. Informal contact would be illegal under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. As Attorney-General it is not my practice to reveal details of current or past operations and therefore I will not comment on questions (a) to (e).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 14 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: Will he provide details of (a) the membership contributions and (b) functions of the International Bauxite Association and (c) the reasons for Australia's withdrawal from the Association.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) Australia's membership contribution to the International Bauxite Association is A$387,673 in calendar year 1991.

Membership contributions are determined by dividing 30% of the IBA budget equally amongst members and 70% based on bauxite production. As the largest bauxite producer in the world (36.8% of world production in 1990), Australia contributes some 36% of the IBA budget for 1991.
(b) The objectives, as defined in the Agreement Establishing the International Bauxite Association, 1974, are
"to promote the orderly and rational development of the bauxite industry"

"to secure for member countries fair and reasonable returns from the exploitation, processing and marketing of bauxite and its products for the economic and social development of their peoples, bearing in mind the recognised interests of consumers"
"generally safeguard the interests of member countries in relation to the bauxite industry."

Over the past 17 years, the Association has conducted detailed analyses on the international market and industry, exchanged information on member country industries, consulted with a wide range of companies and industry analysts and attempted to apply a minimum pricing policy for bauxite and alumina. With the exception of the last mentioned, Australia has participated actively in all these activities. Australian delegations to IBA meeting have consistently entered a reservation to decisions of the IBA relating to recommended minimum prices.

(c) Australia's decision to withdraw from the IBA, followed a detailed review of Australia's membership against criteria for Australian membership of International Commodity Arrangements. These criteria, agreed by relevant Ministers in December 1989, include relative costs and benefits of participation, the views of industry, whether the organisation involves both producers and consumers and foreign and trade relations considerations. The review concluded that Australia's membership of the International Bauxite Association could no longer be justified, essentially on cost/benefit grounds.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 27 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: Does either the (a) Department of Transport and Communications or (b) Federal Airports Corporation (i) raise revenue through a levy on the sale of avgas at airports it does not control, (ii) control the airport at Broome, WA, and (iii) receive any portion of excise levied on avgas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (i) Neither the Department of Transport and Communications nor the Federal Airports Corporation raises revenue through a levy on the sale of avgas at airports it does not control. The question is referring to excise and customs duty on avgas and the arrangements in respect of that duty are explained in the answer to part (iii) of the question.

(ii) Neither the Department of Transport and Communications nor the Federal Airports Corporation controls the airport at Broome. Broome airport was previously a Commonwealth airport but was sold to Airport Engineering Services Pty Ltd in April 1991.
(iii) Excise and customs duty on avgas is collected by the Australian Customs Service (ACS). The duty is payable on avgas at the time it is delivered from premises under ACS control.

Under an arrangement suggested by the aviation industry in 1987, the rate of duty was increased in preference to the introduction of landing charges for avgas aircraft. The arrangement was suggested for its administrative convenience and simplicity.

Consistent with the arrangement around 90% of the revenue from avgas duty is now paid to the Civil Aviation Authority and the remainder is attributed to the Department of Transport and Communications' aerodrome cost recovery program.
No payment is made to the Federal Airports Corporation as the arrangement in 1987 envisaged that the corporation would introduce its own charges for the use of its facilities, which it has done.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, Science and Personnel, Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was a military dog wing in operation at the School of Military Engineering at Casula, NSW, in 1978; if so, (a) was the wing under the command of Captain David Midford-Burgess, (b) were Corporal Keith Burley, Sapper Paul McKewan and Sapper Mark Owen the dog handlers in the wing, (c) was the function of the wing to detect explosives using specially trained German shepherd sniffer dogs and (d) was an operational team from the wing placed on standby for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting at the Hilton Hotel prior to the explosion at the Hilton.

(2) If an operational team was placed on standby (a) was it ordered to train specifically for the detection of bombs, (b) did the team engage in training for about two weeks, (c) was the team (i) highly effective in detecting explosives and (ii) capable of detecting a bomb in a garbage bin and (d) did the team receive an order to stand down on the Thursday preceding the Hilton bombing.

(3) If the team was ordered to stand down, (a) was any explanation given with the order, if so, what was the explanation, (b) who gave the order, (c) why was the order given, (d) did the order originate from within the Army command or from Victoria Barracks; if so, who originated the order and why and (e) in standing down the team did the Army act on instructions from the federal Government; if so, who gave the instructions and why.

(4) Was the team ordered to the site of the Hilton bombing after the explosion; if so, did the team conduct searches for further bombs in the vicinity of the Hilton in areas designated by security officers and did those security officers include ASIO personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a), (b) and (c) A military dog wing was in operation at the School of Military Engineering at Casula, NSW in 1978. The wing was under the command of Captain David Midford-Burgess. Corporal Keith Burley, Sapper Paul McKewan and Sapper Mark Owen were dog handlers in the wing which had an establishment of one officer and fourteen soldiers.

(d) Several weeks before CHOGM an inspector of the NSW Police telephoned the Commanding Officer of the School of Military Engineering to ask if an explosive detection dog team could be made available during CHOGM. The inspector explained that they could be used to detect letter bombs. As the task involved the pre-planned commitment of military assets, the Inspector was advised that the procedure to obtain approval was to place a request on the Headquarters of the 2nd Military District at Victoria Barracks, Sydney.

(2) (a) The Officer Commanding the Military Dog Wing probably ordered his soldiers to undertake some training related to the possible task. However, this would have been a minor variation on the specified training program. This covered detection of all types of military and commercial explosives in a variety of circumstances such as open areas and buildings, and by day and night. Such training provided a comprehensive basis for tasks such as that envisaged by the NSW Police.
(b) It is unlikely that there was dedicated training for the possible task for a full two weeks. It is more likely that it was integrated into the existing training program.

(c) The team was highly effective in detecting explosives and capable of detecting a bomb in a garbage bin. However the effectiveness of a handler and dog could be affected by movement and people in the area of operation, excessive heat, darkness, and the general ability of the dog.

(2) (d) and (3) (a),(b) and (c) The wing may have been given an order to stand down by the Officer Commanding the Wing. The commanding Officer of the School cannot recall giving such a direction. However, he does not rule out the possibility. It is not known if any explanation was given. Probably, any order given to stand down was because the Police had not followed up their original request.

(3) (d) and (e) Any order would have originated from within the School of Military Engineering. Neither the Commanding Officer of the School, nor his Senior Instructor responsible for the training and deployment of the Dog Wing, received any external Army communications on the possible task. Both of these officers would have been aware of a formal tasking or an order to stand down. There were no such instructions given to Army by the Federal Government.

(4) Yes. The team was deployed at 2am following the explosion. There was significant confusion when the team arrived. Contact was made with the NSW Police and searches for further bombs were conducted. It is not known if security officers directed areas of search in addition to those chosen by the team, or if the security officers included ASIO personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, upon notice on 19 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to concerns expressed by Lavery International Pty Ltd and Murray Goulburn Co-Operative Pty Ltd, the parties to an Australian dairy industry joint venture, that they stand to lose their share of the US market for Goya cheese if the US Government extends grants of General System of Preferences (GSP) status.
(2) Is he able to say whether Goya cheese is (a) not subject to US quota restrictions and (b) subject to a 25 per cent duty when imported into the USA from a non-GSP country such as Australia.

(3) Is he able to say whether Hungary applied to the USA in 1990 for GSP status in relation to the export of Goya cheese but was refused; if so, was the matter reopened by US authorities despite US import law preventing reapplication within three years.
(4) Is he able to say whether the exemption from a duty of 25 per cent for exporting countries with GSP status is excessive under GATT.
(5) Will preferential treatment through extension of GSP status by the USA lead to the joint venture partners referred to in part (1) losing their share of the market.

(6) Is Australia the only non-GSP supplier of Goya cheese to the US market; if so, has the Government informed the US Government that it is not acceptable to Australia for the US to discriminate against Australia as the only non-GSP supplier.
(7) Is he able to say whether there is any legal barrier to the US Government offering Australia a quota for Goya cheese to ensure that Australia's share of the US market is not eroded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) I am aware of the concerns of Lavery International Pty Ltd and Murray Goulburn Co- Operative Ltd about the implications for Australian exports of an extension of GSP status by the United States to Hungarian Goya cheese. Goya cheese enters the United States quota-free but is presently subject to a duty of 25 per cent.

(3) Hungary petitioned the US Administration in 1990 for duty-free status for its exports of Goya cheese, under the GSP. That petition was rejected in May of this year. On 12 July, however, in the spirit of supporting economic and political transformation in Eastern Europe, President Bush announced a Trade Enhancement Initiative for Central and Eastern European countries, such as Hungary, which included a review of previously rejected GSP status petitions. This is despite the fact that US regulations dictate a delay of three years before such petitions can be reviewed.

The office of the US Special Trade Representative (USTR) will hold public hearings on the granting of GSP status for the products of Central and Eastern European countries, including Hungarian Goya, from 6-8 January 1992, after which post- hearing briefs in favour of, and opposed to, the proposals will be considered. Any modifications to the GSP resulting from this review are expected to be announced on or about 30 April and take effect on or about 1 May 1992. If GSP status is granted, it could also be extended to other GSP suppliers of Goya cheese such as Argentina.

US producers of hard cheeses similar to Goya have been, and remain, strongly opposed to the granting of duty-free status for Hungarian Goya on the basis that it could displace their products. They have mounted an extensive lobbying campaign against the proposal with the Administration and the Congress.

(4) and (5) GSP status is legal under the GATT. While appreciating the sentiment behind the initiative to review the rejected petition, the Government would be concerned if our main competitors were to enjoy a margin of preference of 25 per cent over Australian Goya. Such a development would have a detrimental effect on Australia's exports of Goya to the US market.
(6) As far as I am aware, Australia is the only non-GSP supplier of Goya to the US market. Our concerns about the effect that granting GSP status

ANSWER.PARA: to Hungarian Goya is likely to have on Australian exports have been highlighted with the US Administration in 1990 and, more recently, at the Australia/US Agricultural Trade Consultations in August this year. The Government continues to monitor the situation and will reinforce representations already made as appropriate.

PARA.TAB: (7) The only way in which the United States could apply quotas to Goya cheese, consistent with US GATT obligations, would be through Article XIX safeguards or under Section 22 of the Agricultural Adjustment Act. Both of these would require the US Government to fulfill specified conditions demonstrating the injurious impact of imports.

A quota would not, in any case, address the problem of a difference in tariff levels between Australian and Hungarian Goya. Instead of maintaining Australia's market share, it would very likely set quantitative limits on imports from Australia and other suppliers at levels lower than the level of imports before the imposition of quotas.

Moreover, a successful outcome to the Uruguay Round will see the tarriffication by 1993 of border measures, other than normal customs duties, on agricultural products, and such a result will remove the US Government's option of imposing Section 22 quotas.
